DOC.HEAD: Smoking Bill Gets Preliminary House OK
DOC.TEXT: A bill to limit smoking in this tobacco state won preliminary approval in the House of Delegates on Monday, but it is a weaker set of regulations than contained in legislation supported by health groups. The bill would require establishment of no-smoking areas in state and local government buildings. It would allow local governments to impose stricter rules against smoking, but would limit local efforts to ban smoking in small businesses, in theaters and on public transportation. The bill, passed in a voice vote Monday and was due for a final House vote Tuesday, was approved over the objection of health lobbyists and legislators who backed a bill calling for stricter smoking regulation. Nevertheless, some in the House worried about reaction in a state whose economy was built on tobacco. ``Seldom in my career have I built my own political gallows and provided the rope,'' said Delegate Charles R. Hawkins, a Republican from tobacco-growing Pittsylvania County. ``If I vote for this, I might be doing that.'' If it's approved in the final House vote, the bill would have to be reconciled with a more stringent bill recently approved by the Senate. In addition to requiring no-smoking areas in government buildings, the bill's main impact would be to set standards for local no-smoking ordinances. Local governments would be allowed to demand no-smoking areas in restaurants and ban smoking in elevators, schools, indoor service lines and school buses. But local ordinances couldn't regulate smoking in businesses with less than 10,000 square feet of floor space _ so-called mom and pop stores. Nor could they regulate smoking in privately owned meeting rooms, in theaters or on public transportation. The bill also doesn't address smoking in private work areas. The rejected rival bill, similar to that already approved by the Senate, would have allowed workers to declare their areas smoke-free by a two-thirds vote.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says a Reunified Germany Belongs in NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf 6: ``National security,'' with Scowcroft reaction
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying ``nobody wants to threaten the Soviet Union,'' said Monday that a united Germany belongs inside NATO, but Western forces might not be deployed in what is now East Germany. Bush applauded what he called the bottom line spelled out by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on the future of Germany: ``NATO membership.'' Bush also expressed ``my appreciation of Chairman (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev's statesmanlike view that decisions regarding German unity should be left to the people of Germany.'' But the official East German news agency reported Monday that Gorbachev told East German leaders flatly that a united Germany cannot belong to NATO. The news agency ADN quoted Gorbachev as telling Hans Modrow, East Germany's communist premier, that he had ``clearly told'' Kohl that a ``united Germany staying within the structure of NATO cannot be accepted.'' National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said Monday night, ``That's not exactly what (Secretary of State James) Baker was told'' during his visit to Moscow last week. ``It was not really as positive as that,'' Scowcroft said after a state dinner for the president of the Congo. Kohl said earlier that he had gotten the ``green light'' for unification from Gorbachev during a weekend visit to Moscow. Keeping Germany inside NATO would afford the most stability for both East and West in Europe, Bush told a news conference. U.S. officials disclosed in Ottawa that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had been discussing a U.S. plan for the unification of Germany with the foreign ministers of Britain, France, West Germany and the Soviet Union before and during his European trip. The so-called ``two-plus-four'' plan would call for leaders of the East German government that emerges from March elections to meet West German leaders to make plans for the political, legal and economic structures of the new country. The two Germanies, operating as sovereign states, also would have the power to determine the size of the German army. Afterward, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ the ``Big Four'' victors over Germany in World War II _ would discuss such security issues as German membership in NATO. At the NATO foreign ministers meeting in Ottawa, which eastern bloc countries are attending as observers, Baker took up the matter with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, on Monday and scheduled further talks with him on Tuesday. Britain and France have endorsed the idea and ``the Soviets are quite interested,'' said a State Department official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. ``There might be some flexibility, obviously, on the deployment of NATO forces'' inside what is now East Germany, Bush said. ``I think Chancellor Kohl is absolutely correct and we ought to support him: NATO membership,'' said Bush, who will confer with Kohl at Camp David on Feb. 24-25. Bush said NATO membership for a new, united Germany ``is the most reassuring and stabilizing concept,'' both for the West and ``in terms of how the Eastern Europeans will eventually look at it, maybe not today.'' ``There's some flexibility on deployment of NATO forces into Eastern Europe. Nobody wants to threaten the Soviet Union,'' said Bush. Bush conferred this past weekend at Camp David with NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner, who said afterwards that a way will be found to keep Germany inside NATO while recognizing ``the legitimate security interests of the Soviet Union.'' One possibility, Woerner said, would be not to extend NATO's military reach over the region that is now East Germany. Asked if Germany would be less threatening in an alliance rather than neutral, Bush said: ``I think so.'' The Germans are ``good NATO partners now and they'll be good NATO partners then,'' he said. East Germany is part of the Warsaw Pact. Bush said ``many Europeans'' would be concerned by a neutral, non-aligned Germany. ``It's a concern that would be allayed by having ... a unified Germany inside of NATO,'' said Bush. In Ottawa, meanwhile, Shevardnadze told a group of British correspondents, ``I am not saying neutrality is the only way, but it is the best way.'' Shevardnadze also said the Big Four might have to take up the issue of German reunification. ``There is room for negotiation among the four powers,'' Shevardnadze said. Bush said he did not think a meeting of the four powers was needed ``at this juncture. ... At some point, clearly, the four powers will have to have some say.''

DOC.HEAD: Plastic Surgery in Your Future? Buyer, Beware!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report. D.Ann, 22nd graf, is cq with no space.
DOC.TEXT: Looking for a present for the valentine who has more than everything? How about an eyelid tuck, or liposuction? But at anywhere from $600 to $8,000, cosmetic surgery may be too pricey, so how does $85 a month sound for the woman, or man, of your dreams? Buyer, beware! ``It really is a medical procedure and all surgery has problems. It's not buying a fur coat,'' warns Dr. R. Barrett Noone, a director of the American Board of Plastic Surgeons, which certifies doctors in the speciality. ``Don't bother,'' Lee Goldsmith, a physician and practicing lawyer, says to those thinking of cosmetic surgery. ``It's an abused, unnecessary procedure.'' Goldsmith only sees the failures in his New York-area law practice, such as the a woman who came in after an implant with ``one breast going up and one going down and the surgeon was going to charge her to do it over.'' But successes outnumber horror stories in the multibillion-dollar industry _ an estimated 1 million to 3 million ``image enhancement'' procedures a year in the United States. Cher had her nose ``refined'' several years ago. ``It looked too big onscreen and bothered me. Hey, if I need cosmetic surgery, the moment I need it I'm getting it. OK?'' she told People magazine. Angela Lansbury went public last year: Periodic cosmetic surgery dating to 1966 has helped keep her a leading lady. The star of the TV series ``Murder, She Wrote,'' said she decided to talk about it because ``cosmetic surgery shouldn't be just the secret of actresses and socialites now that it's available to anyone who wants it and can afford it.'' Supporters call that accessibility democratic. Critics call it a problem. ``Medicine goes Madison Avenue ... with the kind of advertising previously reserved for the ABCs _ automobiles, beer and cigarettes,'' says the staff of a House subcommittee preparing a bill to set some standards on how doctors can advertise such procedures and where they can perform the operations. Cosmetic surgery is ``a dangerously under-regulated medical field,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., who chaired hearings last spring that prompted his panel of the Small Business Committee to draft the regulations. The panel found that cosmetic surgery is often performed by unqualified doctors in underequipped facilities. The staff report estimated that 3 million cosmetic operations are perfomed a year, 95 percent of them in doctors' offices where crucial emergency equipment is often lacking. Some say the 3 million figure is way too high, but there's no way to know for sure. Men accounted for nearly 30 percent of the 1988 patients for doctors in the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery, and 22 percent of facial surgery by those in the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons. Earpinnings, or croppings, are big with males, who had 53 percent of those procedures reported for 1988 by the Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons group; a further breakdown shows that 53 percent of the total ear procedures was done on children age 12 or younger. Men had 23 percent of the eyelid surgery, 12 percent of the facelifts and 13 percent of the liposuction _ fat removal. The consumer's dilemma _ and everyone seems to agree the consumer can get caught in the middle _ is that any licensed physician can do cosmetic surgery. Or brain surgery, for that matter, but the demand doesn't seem to be so high. ``Physicians have responded to the demand, not created it,'' says Dr. Richard Caleel, president of the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery. The demand, or the money, has induced doctors who are certified in gynecology, ear, nose and throat, or whatever to turn to the more lucrative work. A top plastic surgeon can do 16 operations a week at ``$3,000 to $4,000 a pop,'' Goldsmith says. Doctors can legally advertise, perform operations any place they choose and call themselves board certified without designating the speciality. This has set up a feud involving doctors trained in plastic and reconstructive surgery and those trained in some other specialty who turned to cosmetic work, those who square off for or against advertising, and those who, like Goldsmith, say the risks of such elective surgery are just too great. Pity the poor consumer! ``There are some very serious abuses going on out there,'' says D.Ann Murphy, a staff investigator for Wyden's committee. ``People being blinded, lost limbs, serious scarring.'' It goes ``well beyond a turf battle'' among the various medical groups, she says, and blames a big part of the problem on people ``lured'' into doctor's offices by ads suggesting they need something they didn't know they wanted. Goldsmith is ``upset by the ads, to put it mildly. There is a tremendous selling of plastic surgery going on and much of it is being done by individuals who don't have the necessary skills.'' Advertising lets people know that techniques have improved, that a hospital stay isn't necessary, that face fixes are affordable, that it's not just for the rich and famous and, quite frequently, that one can charge it. Profiles & Contours, with clinics in New York and Connecticut, runs full-page ads with the headline: ``Look like a million for a couple of thousand.'' It goes on to say you can get liposuction or breast enlargement for as little as $85 a month. The group's 18-page booklet, with the picture of a young model on the cover, says cosmetic surgery is not about vanity or self-indulgence, it's about feeling better about yourself. ``As plastic surgery grows in awareness and acceptance it will gradually become as common as eyeglasses, braces, and hearing aids and be just as useful,'' it says. The booklet has a section on choosing a plastic surgeon that includes tips supporters and critics can agree on: Interview surgeons, check out the hospitals they're affiliated with, make sure they have the proper credentials. Those on the center's mailing list got a letter recently offering ``an interest rate that's just 12 percent. ... We can also help you by deferring your first payment till after the holidays.'' Costs range from $600 to $8,000. ``I call that seduction. That's not the way medicine should be practiced,'' Noone says of ads that promise facelifts for a small monthly payment. People need to know what's available, says Caleel, who practices in Chicago and is a professor of surgery at the Chicago College of Osteopathic Medicine. ``If a child is born with protruberant ears, having those ears repositioned can be very beneficial. They can be a type of stigma in our society,'' he said. ``It's very rewarding to see a woman in her 50s get her first short haircut,'' because she finally had surgery to correct large ears she'd been ashamed of.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Networks Go Live With Mandala Release
With PM-South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
Eds: Following is a review of network Mandela coverage.
DOC.TEXT: When Nelson Mandela, dignified but fists clenched high in exultation, walked out of South Africa's Victor Verster Prison, the major U.S. networks and CNN _ and South African TV _ aired it live. The dramatic moment doubtless was taken for granted by younger viewers used to instant TV news-by satellite. In the slow old days, the moment would be shot on film and wouldn't reach the U.S. for hours, or maybe a day. Still, it's how you tell the story that counts, not how you show off your techno-smarts. And on that basis, ABC's coverage of the Mandela story this weekend was easily the best in all respects _ in reporting the story, in giving it perspective, and in showing, with a minimum of extraneous chatter, the drama of the moments before, during and after Mandela's release. Ted Koppel, who went to South Africa last Monday and on Wednesday anchored the first of three ``Nightline'' broadcasts there, smoothly and knowledgeably anchored ABC's Sunday coverage from Cape Town. NBC anchorman Tom Brokaw _ he and Koppel were the only U.S. network anchors at Saturday's news conference in which President F.W. de Klerk said Mandela would be freed _ also was in that city on Sunday. Neither was physically present at the deceptively pleasant-looking prison grounds for the release, however. They worked from other locations, while CBS anchorman Dan Rather worked out of Johannesburg, more than 800 miles away. Sunday's live pictures from the prison entrance and the crowd and security police around it were provided on a pooled basis by the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. Koppel and ABC wisely concentrated on scenes of the prison entrance and the crowds there, showing the long wait, the patience of those come to see a man imprisoned 27 years ago for choosing to fight apartheid. Brokaw and Rather, on the other hand, tended to fill the wait with interviews of various South African figures, going more for the analytical than the personal.All that was well and good, journalistically speaking. But given the drama of main event at hand, it came across as awfully dry stuff. ABC and NBC also broadcast portions of the low-key, straightforward running commentary of SABC announcer Clarence Keyter, which gave U.S. viewers a sense of what kind of coverage South Africans were getting on state-run TV. All the networks had crews in Soweto, televising the reactions of a crowd of joyous blacks in front of Mandela's home there. But ABC, in a literal case of one-upsmanship, also had a chartered helicopter flying over the area, showing the scene from the air, giving viewers an idea of the size of the crowd, which seemed to fill perhaps two blocks. This may be an era of the portable anchor, but the story proved a long-distance scramble for Rather, and, to a lesser extent, Brokaw. Brokaw, in New York when NBC was tipped that Mandela might be released this weekend, made a mad dash for the airport Thursday and flew to South Africa, a spokeswoman said. Rather's trip was just as hurried, but far longer. After more than a week of anchoring from Moscow, he had returned on Friday to New York, a spokeswoman said. But he roared right out again Saturday morning to Johannesburg. Only ABC anchorman Peter Jennings was able to rest at home here. But he had a few air miles logged, too. According to a spokesman, Jennings, after a week in Cambodia working on a special, flew to Moscow last week to anchor part of ``World News Tonight'' from Monday through Wednesday. Then he returned here. He wouldn't have found ABC News president Roone Arledge here, though. A spokesman said Arledge had flown to South Africa to help direct ABC's coverage.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Woman Who Was Nearly Embalmed Now Can Joke About It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Carrie Stringfellow can't remember what happened to her six months ago when she was nearly embalmed after being mistaken for dead. That doesn't stop her from joking about it. ``I said `When I die, I'm going to stay dead,''' she said, laughing during an interview last week at a nursing home. But her experience was no joke to state officials, who are tightening up the rules defining who is qualified to declare a person dead. Ms. Stringfellow, who is 88 years old and blind, appeared to lose consciousness on Aug. 5 at a Springfield boarding home where she was a resident. The owner, Robbie Caldwell, said Ms. Stringfellow had no pulse. When Dennis L. Porter, director of the Dennis L. Porter Funeral Home, arrived to pick up the body, Ms. Stringfellow was slumped over in a chair and appeared to be dead. Porter took Ms. Stringfellow to his funeral home and was preparing to move her to the embalming table when she uttered a sound. He said it was ``a very eerie feeling.'' ``I heard that the man had taken me to embalm me, was getting his tools ready, I started talking, and he broke and run,'' she said in the interview. ``I laughed about that.'' Ms. Stringfellow was hospitalized for about a week and then transferred to Odd Fellows Rebekah Home, a nursing center where she still resides. She said she was told about the incident by a doctor a few days later. ``He told me they had me dead,'' she said. ``I said, `What?' He said, `Yeah, they had you dead, sure enough.' I said, `I ain't dead.' I must have been off in a trance or something like that. I didn't believe it. I didn't pay him too much attention.'' But she believed a nephew who confirmed the incident the next day. In the wake of the incident, Ohio Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. asked a Clark County court to keep the boarding home from being operated as a nursing home. The action was dropped after Ms. Caldwell agreed to remove residents who required skilled nursing care. The case also led to a review of state medical rules requiring only that a ``competent observer'' personally examine a body before death is pronounced. ``We felt very strongly ... that competent observers should be more definitely defined as someone who has the proper medical training,'' said Kay Reitz, an aide to state Sen. David Hobson, who has led the reform effort. A rule was drafted for the State Medical Board defining ``competent observers'' as registered nurses, licensed practical nurses, emergency medical technicians, paramedics, interns and residents, clinical fellows, and licensed embalmers and funeral directors who complete courses in patient assessment. Board spokeswoman Lauren Lubow said the board is expected to vote on the proposed rule soon, possibly in March. Ms. Stringfellow said she isn't angry or upset about what happened to her. ``I couldn't blame them for thinking I was dead,'' she said. She said she isn't frightened by what happened but guesses that people probably have been embalmed alive before. ``If he ever started to work on me, I would have been dead,'' she said. ``Thank God, I wasn't dead that time.'' Ms. Stringfellow spends her time listening to television, talking with friends and visiting with family. Barbara Trimble, director of the nursing home, said Ms. Stringfellow has a good number of visitors. ``She's a riot,'' said Ms. Trimble. ``She's wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Weighs Child Abuse vs. Due Process
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A kindergarten teacher near retirement breaks up a fight among her pupils and ends up on Florida's computer list of ``confirmed'' child abusers. A father of seven, twice named his school's teacher of the year, brings in clothes for a needy student. Other teachers find the girl trying on a blouse in the cloakroom of a nearby classrooom, and he ends up on the list. Those were two ``horror stories'' a teachers union attorney told a task force formed to study how the state handles child abuse accusations against parents, teachers and other caretakers. Both teachers cleared their names, but not before they _ like other innocent teachers _ were hurt by the system, said Elizabeth DuFresne, an attorney for United Teachers of Dade. ``We have had in Dade County in the last two years, six teachers ... lose their homes while suspended without pay, three marriages break up, an entire emotional deterioration of one teacher who ultimately was justified on every single ground,'' Ms. DuFresne said. The last example was a kindergarten teacher planning her retirement after 37 years in the classroom. The woman, who broke up a kindergarten fight, ``literally couldn't handle being accused,'' Ms. DuFresne said. Last year in Dade County, 57 teachers faced abuse investigations after breaking up fights, she said. Ms. DuFresne was one of several education representatives at public hearings throughout Florida in recent months to urge the task force to recommend that lawmakers change the way the Florida Abuse Registry works. Access to the registry is limited to Health and Rehabilitative Services investigators, police and prosecutors, who use the computer list to keep confirmed abusers out of caretaker jobs such as work in day-care centers. Public schools do not use the list for screening _ the task force wants to change the system so they will _ but teachers, like any other caregiver including parents, can be put on the list. Educators say the registry violates the constitutional rights of the accused, listing them as confirmed abusers without a hearing, and even in some cases listing them for incidents of school-sanctioned paddling. Appeals cost thousands of dollars and take months, often while a teacher is suspended without pay. ``Confirmed'' abusers remain on file for 50 years, ``indicated'' abuse cases for seven years and ``unfounded reports'' for a year. Last week, the task force decided to recommend changing the ``confirmed'' classification to ``proposed confirmed'' while people accused of abuse go through an administrative appeals process lasting no longer than 140 days. The panel also decided to propose changing some ``indicated'' case classifications to ``indicated, undetermined perpetrator.'' Ms. DuFresne cited the case of the teacher who brought in the used clothes for a 12-year-old girl whose home was damaged by fire. After trying on a blouse in the teacher's absence, the girl, who was in a class for children with emotional and learning problems, was found getting back into her own clothes. The student said the teacher who gave her the clothes neither watched her try them on nor touched her, but after two hours of questioning she said she had been fondled, Ms. DuFresne said. The story changed again when Ms. DuFresne was taking a deposition for criminal charges that had been brought against the man. The girl got details mixed up and became upset, Ms. DuFresne told the task force. ``She started crying,'' the attorney said. ``She said `They all just wanted me to say something. I tried to say what they wanted me to say. That's all.''' By that time the teacher had been out of the classroom for eight months. The union had spent more than $30,000 in his defense, and he had spent $5,000. Although the panel considered several aspects of child abuse, it focused on the concerns of teachers and administrators, who make up only a small percentage of those reported to the state and confirmed as abusers. In fiscal year 1988-89, 132,805 abuse or neglect reports were made to the state's Abuse Registry, according to B.J. Cosson, director of Florida Protective Services System, which runs the registry. Only 796 of the reports involved public school employees, most of whom were teachers, and just 68 of those cases were ``confirmed'' cases of abuse. Linda Harris, an HRS attorney, defended the system as constitutional, arguing that classification as a confirmed abuser is not final until after the appeal process is concluded. ``Teachers aren't being singled out,'' she said. ``That was the special interest group that got heard from the most,'' said Michael B. DeMaria, a psychologist specializing in child abuse, said he sympathized with teachers but was concerned with the emphasis on adults' rights as opposed to protection of children. ``We don't want to throw out the baby with the bath water,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Increased Violations of Swedish Waters, Rand Says
DOC.TEXT: Soviet submarines have illegally entered Swedish waters in dramatically stepped-up operations since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, according to a study released Sunday. In one case, a Soviet minisubmarine got as far as Stockholm harbor, coming within a mile of the neutralo country's royal palace, said the Rand Corp. report ``Strager Than Fiction: Soviet Submarine Operations in Swedish Waters.'' ``Despite what appears to be real Soviet progress in domestic reform and arms control, this is still going on, and why the Swedes continue to permit it, I don't know,'' said Gordon H. McCormick, who wrote the report based on public documents and Swedish sources. The report was sponsored by the U.S. Air Force. The intrusions have harmed Gorbachev's attempt to change his country's image in the West, but he is unlikely to scale back operations unless he can demonstrate they are causing greater difficulties for the Soviet Union in the West than has been the case so far, McCormick said. Soviet submarines have penetrated Swedish waters since World War II. But before the 1980s there were never more than four probable intrusions a year, and those usually involved one submarine at a time in outer coastal waters, the report said. ``Since 1980, Swedish sources indicate that an average rate of between 17 and 36 foreign operations are being conducted per year, depending on the degree of probability that is assigned to each underwater contact,'' the report said. In addition, the new operations utilized multiple submarines, minisubs and combat swimmers, and penetrated much deeper into Sweden's coastal defense zones, including harbors of major naval bases, the report said. Some intrusions made international headlines. In the 1981 ``Whiskey on the Rocks'' incident, a Soviet Whiskey-class U-137 submarine ran aground near the Karlskrona naval complex. Moscow termed it an accident, and after a confrontation that lasted 10 days, the sub was released. In 1982, multiple submarines were identified deep within the inner waters of Harsfjarden near Sweden's largest naval base. Covert onshore activity also has targeted the Swedish defense establishment. The report cites a 1986 incident in which Soviet intelligence agents posing as Polish art dealers visited the homes of 120 Swedish pilots, apparently to determine their identities. According to Swedish authorities, it was part of a plan to decimate the Royal Air Force in the event of war by gunning down the pilots in their homes. The report said the greater frequency of submarine operations in Sweden can be linked to Soviet suspicion of its status as a neutral nation, and the increasing strategic value of the Scandinavian peninsula in Soviet contingency war plans. Those plans apparently would involve crossing Sweden to reach Norway, which is a NATO member, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Threatened Colombians Must Deal With Anxiety, Isolation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For Colombians battling the drug establishment, life is lived in a sealed, guarded box. Breaking out can mean death at the hands of terrorists waiting patiently outside. Jaime Pardo Leal, the leftist Union Patriotic Party leader, ventured out in 1987, only to be assassinated as he drove near his farm west of Bogota. So stifling had his box become that Pardo ``said that life was ending for him,'' said a friend, Bogota criminal court judge Consuelo Herrera. ``He couldn't go to public places. He felt his intimacy with his family was being destroyed by the presence of bodyguards and security measures. Finally he couldn't take it any more and broke out.'' A normal reaction, psychologists say, for the politicians, journalists, judges and others living under death threats from the cocaine cartels. Often, a deadly one. Herrera said Pardo had begun to drive with his family to their farm without first telling the national intelligence police, who had been providing bodyguards for him. ``He was killed because he did not have the necessary protection. He always said that he was not important enough for anyone to try to kill him,'' Herrera said in an interview. So alarmed is the nation over death threats _ and the threat of threats _ that executives have become accustomed to traveling with bodyguards carrying submachine guns. Private guards wearing bulletproof vests and dark glasses can often be seen standing outside chic restaurants while their charges dine. Although Herrera said she had not been threatened, other judges have. Thirty-six have been assassinated over the last 12 years. ``The first response by many people who have received a threat is to try to put it out of their mind,'' Bogota psychologist Leonidas Castro said in a recent interview. ``It is most important that people at risk take an active role in protecting themselves, that they avoid the image of themselves as helpless targets,'' said Castro, who specializes in treating the stress and anxiety of high-risk officials. ``That feeling of helplessness is the source for anxiety that can be as bad or worse than the threat itself.'' Many threatened Colombians, Herrera said, ``feel alone and won't talk about the problem, but I've seen their worry and fear affect their families like a poison.'' One journalist who had received several threats said that, at first, he felt the problem was not ``radical enough'' to cause him to change his lifestyle. Later, though, he relayed the threats to the intelligence police, who said they had evidence that a contract had been put out on his life. He left the country. Judges don't usually have that option. ``For judges, leaving the country or installing a home security system is rarely an option,'' said Herrera, ``We will often have to fight a major battle just to get an extra government bodyguard for a threatened judge.'' Indeed, even affording psychological help can be difficult for judges, who earn an average of $380 a month but who would have to pay $25 to $100 an hour, by Castro's estimate, to see a psychologist. Although judges handling drug cases should take threats seriously, Colombians not directly involved with the cartels need not live in fear, Castro said. ``A Colombian bank president who has not received any specific threat can lead a perfectly normal life,'' the psychologist said.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Trade Union Seeks New Roots in Poland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In this textile center, the Solidarity trade union collects used clothing for the poor, buys sugar wholesale to sell cheaply to workers and helps determine which managers the government should fire. ``We control everything in town and are trying to get involved in everything,'' said Zbigniew Ragan, a Solidarity leader at the state-owned Revolution of 1905 Textile Factory, which turns out linen fabric, tablecloths and napkins that are popular in Poland and abroad. But he concedes that his membership is only a fraction of what it was during Solidarity's heyday in 1981. And some workers may lose their jobs because of the policies of the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Preparing for its first nationwide congress in nine years, the East bloc's first independent trade union is striving to sink new roots among a work force hard-hit by Poland's rough transition from Communist economics. Ideally, Ragan and other leaders say, they should be concentrating their energies on defending workers' economic interests. But for now, they say, Poland's economic crisis is too dire and the victory over the old Communist order still too fragile for Solidarity to flex its muscles as an aggressive trade union. Instead the union is acting as a ``shield'' to protect its government from workers' complaints, says Jan Zak, chairman of the Solidarity chapter at the Zyrardow Technical Fabrics Factory, which makes synthetic fabrics for industrial uses. Solidarity in 1981 registered 14,000 members in Zyrardow _ a city of 41,000 people 30 miles southwest of Warsaw _ compared with 2,000 members today, Ragan said. The same trend holds true nationwide. In 1981, Solidarity was 10 million strong, more than half of Poland's adult work force. That was before the martial law that turned Solidarity into a banned organization for eight years. Membership is expected to be no more than 2.5 million by the time of the congress April 19-24, said Krzysztof Wyszkowski, political editor at the Solidarity weekly newspaper Tygodnik Solidarnosc. That is less than the 6-million-strong unions formed by the Communist Party while Solidarity was banned. Ragan and Zak said the lower membership has more to do with apathy and finances than disenchantment with their reborn union. Many people simply cannot spare Solidarity's annual dues of 1 percent of income, they contend, but in any decisive conflict workers support Solidarity. Meanwhile, with a Solidarity government in power and Communists in retreat, the union has greater influence than ever, Ragan said. Despite sharply rising prices and no wage increases, workers are not striking against the Solidarity-led government, Zak noted. But they do worry about job security. There are plans for layoffs, Ragan said. If it cannot prevent them, Solidarity hopes to find new jobs for those laid off. While muting criticism of the government, local Solidarity officials seek other ways to help members. At the Revolution of 1905 Factory, Solidarity last year realized it could save workers money on sugar by buying it for them directly from a sugar beet refinery, bypassing Poland's food-store monopoly. At the nearby Linen Industry Development Center, Solidarity Chairwoman Mieczyslawa Jednejewska says her 48-member local is involved in reorganizing the institute. But it also collects clothes for the needy and makes loans to pensioners that probably never will be repaid. ``People write us saying they don't have enough money to buy dinner,'' she explains. The upcoming Solidarity congress will be the first chance to gauge the rank-and-file's mood on a nationwide scale, and the depth of support for Chairman Lech Walesa and the National Executive Commission that has directed the union in recent years in the absence of an elected leadership since 1981. Walesa said recently he plans to step down as union leader. Solidarity's political struggle with the Communists _ which led to the selection of longtime union activist Mazowiecki as the East bloc's first non-Communist leader _ has pushed union organizing to the back burner. Now, many top union leaders and experts of 1980-81 are to be found not in the factories, but in the government, in Parliament, or in the Citizen's Committees, Solidarity's political wing. In the name of Poland's long-term national interests, they are enacting a stringent program to reform the economy that strikes hardest at the very industrial workers who created Solidarity. Walesa unites the trade union and the political currents in Solidarity, but it is becoming increasingly hard for him to hold the two together, Wyszkowski said. Although most Solidarity workers still support the government, leaders such as Warsaw Region Chairman Michal Boni say the union must be free to ``work out its own identity'' and they do not rule out ``a quarrel with the government.'' Walesa himself increasingly speaks of withdrawing Solidarity from politics and giving it a strictly trade union function, ``to protect the interests of the working people.'' What is not clear, Wyszkowski said, is whether Walesa wants to lead such a strict trade union or whether he would prefer embarking openly on a political career, by seeking to replace Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski as president. Walesa may ``move to Belvedere (the presidential palace), leaving the trade union to protect the workers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Front Line Hospital Keeps Going Despite Direct Hits, Shortages
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The little boy cringed in fear when a 155mm howitzer shell crashed near the battle-scarred Hotel Dieu Hospital, the largest in Christian east Beirut. His mother, sitting at his bedside, poured fruit juice from a thermos with a Batman logo and tried to calm him. ``Don't worry, Camille,'' she said. ``It's only thunder. They're the cannons of God. They don't hurt.'' ``But it's not raining mother,'' the boy muttered. The comforting lie no longer works in Lebanon, where the shells have been falling for nearly 15 years of civil war between Moslems and Christians. This time, Christian is killing Christian as troops of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun battle those of warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces for control of the Christian sector. Camille is one of 150 patients crowded into the fetid corridors of the French-financed Hotel Dieu. Alain Tessier, the hospital's French director, said 190 casualties had been brought in over the last 13 days, 21 of them dead on arrival. More than 450 people have been killed and 1,700 wounded since the bloodletting began Jan. 30. ``The hospital staff gave their blood to the wounded,'' said Dr. Pierre Farah, a surgeon. Some of the wounded died because ambulances could not get them to the hospital through the embattled streets, he said. ``Some had lost limbs, others were badly burned,'' he said wearily. ``They just got here too late.'' Those who make it to the hospital past the shellfire and snipers have to clamber up a rickety wooden ladder over the back wall because the main entrance is too exposed. Patients hooked to serum and plasma tubes lie on beds lining both sides of the corridors on the hospital's first floor and the undergound shelter. Among the wounded is a Lebanese Forces fighter, whose left leg was blown off Feb. 1 by an army shell in nearby Ein Rummaneh. The militiaman, who did not want to give his name, said: ``I was crying for help, but no one could get to me because of the shelling. Finally, my neighbors came out of their shelter and dragged me in until they could find a car to take me to hospital.'' The hospital has been hit by 15 shells. Doctors and nurses evacuated patients from the top two floors because they were so exposed. ``We couldn't count how many shells fell in the gardens because it's imposssible to climb on the roof and see. There are too many snipers,'' Tessier said. The hospital stands on the edge of the residential district of Ashrafiyeh, a Geagea stronghold ringed by Aoun's troops to the east, Beirut's dividing Green Line to the southeast and the Mediterranean to the north. The hospital is running low on just about everything, bread, oxygen, antibiotics and blood. However, Tessier said the Red Cross brought 2,200 gallons of water and some bread a couple of days ago during a lull. Hospital workers risked their lives to drive to the summer resort of Bikfaya in the mountains 12 miles northeast of Ashrafiyeh, to get eggs and meat. The morgue is overflowing with bodies because families of the slain have not been able to get through to retrieve them. The hospital's last well-equipped ambulance was blasted by a shell on Saturday. All roads leading into Ashrafiyeh are mined except for an overpass from Moslem west Beirut 50 yards from the hospital. Locals call it ``the ramp of death'' because anyone traversing it has to run a gauntlet of sniper fire. A doctor said at least three people a day are shot on that road trying to get to the hospital. The body of a man lies in fetal position beside a white Mercedes. Another is slumped over the wheel of his Plymouth. Other burned-out cars, including a Lebanese Red Cross van, litter the street. Nobody stops to count how many dead there are in them. Drivers step on the gas on this stretch. The International and Lebanese Red Cross have evacuated at least 50 wounded from Hotel Dieu. Sixteen were sent to France for treatment in a mission organized by Bernard Kouchner, France's minister for humanitarian aid. One was Micheleen Baruta, who lost an eye. Her mother, who worked at the hospital, was killed by gunfire as she drove the girl to Hotel Dieu.

DOC.HEAD: Exploring Last Frontier of Lincoln's Life in Fading Courthouse Files
LaserPhoto SD1
DOC.TEXT: The fading angular script spills across a brittle page of the leather-bound courthouse docket, seemingly a mundane entry in an obscure chapter of frontier justice. But it is signed ``Lincoln.'' The signature makes the 138-year-old notation a small piece in the historical mosaic being assembled by researchers tracing the law career of Abraham Lincoln, who was born 181 years ago today. ``Without exaggeration, it's fair to say that this is the last real gap in documenting the life of Lincoln,'' said Cullom Davis, director of the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency's Lincoln Legal Papers project. ``Historians are always uncovering new documents of Lincoln, but not very many. What's different about this project is that nothing has been systematically unearthed and published about his law practice. That's all there's left to do as far as documenting Lincoln.'' Lincoln practiced law from 1837, when the 28-year-old self-educated attorney arrived in the muddy frontier town of Springfield, until 1861. Then, he turned his law practice over to his partner of 16 years, William Herndon, and boarded a train for Washington, the White House and the Civil War. In 24 years as a lawyer, he handled disputes about stolen hogs and bad debts, complex appellate cases for railroads, and cases involving the corporate giants of the frontier. He took more than 260 cases before the Illinois Supreme Court, where his was among the dominant practices of the time, and gained a reputation as a writer of forceful, succinct briefs. Yet among the approximately 10,000 books on Lincoln, few have given thorough, accurate treatment to his legal career, Davis said. Popular accounts portray a humble horse-and-buggy lawyer dispensing homespun wisdom as he rode from courthouse to courthouse. A modern legal scholar, William Prosser, dismissed Lincoln's practice as ``rather petty and uninspiring.'' The Lincoln Legal Papers project, begun in 1985 and expected to take a decade or more, seeks to assemble a copy of every obtainable document from cases involving Lincoln, an estimated 70,000 papers. The complete record will be published on microfilm for sale to libraries. But assembling that record is a daunting task. Davis estimates that Lincoln handled up to 3,000 cases, but fewer than 400 have been documented. The paper chase is complicated by the brisk trade in Lincoln documents since his 1865 assassination. ``Lawyers have them hanging on their walls, they exist in obscure little libraries that somehow came to own them, manuscript dealers trade in these things all the time,'' Davis said. Persuading the owners of such documents to come forward is often difficult, Davis said, because many were originally stolen from court files or law firms. Even Lincoln's law partner systematically filched documents from Illinois courthouses after Lincoln's assassination, though his plunder is now in the Library of Congress. Much of the new information about Lincoln's legal career almost certainly will be assembled by combing the files of the Illinois county courthouses where he practiced. The tedious search began earlier this month in the Menard County courthouse at Petersburg, about 20 miles northwest of Springfield. Equipped with a portable photocopier and a computerized index of Lincoln's known cases, two researchers are scrutinizing virtually every court case from the Lincoln era. Menard County is expected to be a particularly rich source because it includes the site of New Salem, the village where Lincoln once lived. The area was home to many of his friends and acquaintances. ``When my boss asks me how long I'll be here, I just shrug,'' said Joanne Wallroth, a Yale-trained documentary editor who identified 20 previously unknown Lincoln cases in her first week at the courthouse. A typical case from the period finds Lincoln representing Mentor Graham, New Salem's schoolteacher, in a lawsuit seeking repayment of a debt of $15.83 from one Jacob Bale. The case dragged on for two years before Lincoln won a judgment for his client and a fee of $19.90 for himself. As Lincoln's practice grew more sophisticated, so did the legal system. Because of that parallel, Davis said, the research will give historians an insight on the development of the American legal system. The study also is expected to uncover the ways that Lincoln's parallel careers as lawyer and politician shaped one another. ``If Lincoln hadn't won the presidency in 1860 and had finished out his life as a practicing attorney ... he probably would have gone down as one of the great practitioners of the bar in the mid-19th century,'' Davis said. ``But that's nothing compared to what he in fact became.''

DOC.HEAD: Ship Pilots End Walkout That Crippled Port
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 7 grafs after 7th graf, `Only one ...,' to UPDATE with details on agreement; picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Harbor pilots at the Port of Los Angeles on Sunday ended a two-day walkout that had crippled the nation's second-busiest port, agreeing to a settlement that left open the possibility of more talks. The pact between the city Harbor Department and representatives of the 11-member pilots union contains no salary agreement, but scheduled a meeting Tuesday on wages, said port spokeswoman Julia Nagano. ``The pickets are being pulled and the pilots are returning to work,'' she said. She added that no retribution would be taken against the pilots. The pilots went on strike Saturday to protest what they called perilous working conditions that could cause a worse oil spill than the one off Huntington Beach on Wednesday that continued threatening the Southern California coast. They also had demanded a 50 percent pay increase, port officials said. Only one ship steered out of the port earlier Sunday as dockworkers honored pilots' picket lines, with management handling pilot duties. Another ship cancelled plans to do leave, while four others were moored inside or outside the port's breakwater, awaiting berthing. Under the agreement, the Harbor Department said it would allow pilots to refuse to perform a ship maneuver if they feel it is unsafe, said Wallace Knox, attorney for Local 68 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots. The pilots had argued that port authorities were using overworked, undertrained personnel. Pilots also had argued that they were making 50 percent less than their colleagues nationwide. They had sought to eliminate the difference over a period of years, Knox said. The city had offered a 4 percent, one-year raise. Officials from the Harbor Department were not available Sunday night to comment on the terms of the agreement. When both sides meet Tuesday, representatives of the dockworkers' union and the shipping industry's Pacific Maritime Association will be on hand as observers, Knox said. The pilots' walkout was the first strike at the port since the 1970s, when a dockworkers' walkout shut down the port for more than a week. The port occupies more than 7,500 acres, making it one of the world's largest manmade harbors. It handled more than 2 million cargo containers last year, making it the second-busiest port in the United States behind New York-New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Why Call Your Lover `Sugar Pie' When `Picklepuss' Will Do?
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: As Valentine's Day draws nigh, the treacle begins to flow. Can anybody explain why lovers call each other ``sweetheart'' or ``sugar pie'' or ``honeybun'' or other sweet nothings? Why not ``picklepuss'' or ``liverlips?'' Anthropologist Sidney Mintz of The Johns Hopkins University has some theories on why humans evoke the imagery of sweetness to express affection. Possibly, our fondness for sweet talk can be traced genetically to our primate ancestors, who discovered the delights of juicy jungle fruits as they swung from tree to tree, he says. Perhaps it is associated somehow with the infant's innate love for the sweetness of mother's milk, he says. In America, it might even be reinforced by the high sugar intake in our fast-food, candy-nibbling culture. While lecturing in Paris on the link between sweetness and sensuality, Mintz says, ``it struck me as curious that all the words we use to describe love and warmth and good feelings are derived from the sweetness end of the spectrum of taste, not the sour, bitter, salty or hot.'' ``Even the word `sweet' has its root in the ancient Indo-European word for `persuade,' so when we sweet-talk somebody, that's what it really is,'' he said. Sweetness is associated with the language of love in the Bible and the Kama Sutra. Chaucer wrote of ``my sweet cinnamon.'' The clown in Shakespeare's ``As You Like It'' declares that ``honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.'' And today, goodness is seen in the car engine that ``runs sweetly'' and or the triumphs of Walter ``Sweetness'' Payton, the great Chicago Bears running back. ``The candy associated with Valentine's Day brings together love and sweetness in a very striking way,'' says Mintz, who has written a book titled ``Sweetness and Power'' describing the role that sugar has played in modern history. Sweets have an erotic nature that's undeniable, he says. ``What tends to be forgotten about sugar is its intensity, an intensity that our bodies are immediately aware of,'' Mintz says. ``What do you experience with your first mouthful of a hot fudge sundae? It's not surprising that we carry it over to describe the intensity of love and sex.'' The scrapbooks that Mintz keeps in his office document the bizarre twists that sugar-fueled passion can take. There is a picture of Etienne Tholoniat, a master French baker, who created a lifelike female nude out of white chocolate with spun-sugar hair, lying on a bed of 600 sugar roses. A clipping tells the story of a 30-year-old woman in Santa Cruz, Calif., who covered her nude body with a chocolate glaze and, posing as a chocolate Easter bunny, went ``hippity hoppity'' across the front yard of a neighbor who had spurned her affections, according to police. The neighbor called the cops, who took her into custody after what was described as a ``sticky altercation.'' Mintz, 67, says he's been happily married for 25 years to ``a beautiful, brilliant woman'' named Jackie. They met on the campus of Yale University, where he was teaching and she was a young graduate student. He's called her ``sweetie pie'' ever since.

DOC.HEAD: New People Put Prague Back on World Map
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In eight short weeks, the new leadership in Czechoslovakia has done more to establish new ties abroad than its Communist predecessors did in decades. Under the guidance of former dissidents, President Vaclav Havel and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier, officials are working on Havel's declared goal of restoring Czechoslovakia's status as ``the spiritual crossroads of Europe.'' Like much of Czechoslovakia's revolution, the process appears almost effortless, as if planned years in advance. Dienstbier, dressed in an unaccustomed suit, shakes hands almost daily with another foreign minister. He apologetically told a Western reporter this week that March would be the best time for an interview. He'll be away in Paris, Ottawa, Washington, Moscow and Copenhagen until then. Rita Klimova _ known as the voice of the revolution for her translation at opposition press conferences in November _ is off to Washington as new ambassador. Despite being unable to travel for 20 years, these people maintained contact in the hard times with Eastern European dissidents or Western intellectuals, journalists and politicians. In this country abounding in ironies, the dissidents were better informed about thought abroad than other Czechoslovaks. When revolution propelled them to power, it was natural that their friends abroad would flock to show good will toward the new Czechoslovakia _ and perhaps invest in what many Western business executives see as a coming boom in central Europe. The business and celebrity visitors, ranging from British playwright Harold Pinter to American rock star Frank Zappa, are the eye-catching part of the serious diplomatic business of putting Czechoslovakia back on the world map. Havel made his first presidential visit not to Moscow, like his Communist predecessors, but to East Berlin and Munich, lending qualified support to German unification and trying to bury the ghost of 1938, the Munich agreement that paved the way for Hitler's invasion of Czechoslovakia. On his first weekend in office, Dienstbier joined Foreign Minister Alois Mock of Austria in cutting Iron Curtain barbed wire on their border, and repeated the same liberating act with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany days later. Last week, James A. Baker III became the first U.S. secretary of state to visit Prague since 1973. ``It gave us credibility, which we really need,'' said Karel Tucek, an adviser of the Civic Forum opposition that powered the revolution. Tucek especially liked Baker's stress on getting the economy out of state hands: ``After two months, we have so many businessmen and investors trying to find out what they can do. But we have to wait for Parliament to pass the laws.'' Baker left, and Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel arrived to re-establish the diplomatic relations Czechoslovakia severed in 1967, following Moscow's lead. ``There were never so many visits in the last years as in these weeks. Czechoslovakia is again an interesting country,'' Dienstbier told Arens, with the understated humor of many of today's Prague officials. Prague also swiftly followed Hungary in establishing ties with South Korea, and emulated Poland and Hungary in pursuing relations with the Vatican, inviting Pope John Paul II in April. In the reshaping of Eastern Europe into independent nations acting in their own interest, Prague has already surged ahead of its neighbors, benefiting perhaps from being later with its revolt against the old Stalinist ways. It was the strident demand from Prague for the withdrawal of Soviet troops this year that encouraged Hungary and Polish Solidarity leader Lech Walesa to demand the same. At last month's summit of the ailing Soviet-led trading bloc Comecon, it was Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus who gained attention with his threat, later modified, to quit the organization unless it changes radically. Havel journeyed to Poland and Hungary to propose that the three countries meet to coordinate their re-entry into Europe. In this effort to change relations with the East _ Havel travels to Moscow this month _ the Czechoslovak leaders can draw on old ties with friends in Poland and Hungary. All share the philosophy that powered their dissent, the creation of a society in which each individual takes responsibility for his or her actions. The effort, outlined in Havel's New Year address, ``to bring a new element into European and world politics'' by radiating love and understanding also has Czechoslovakia looking in less conventional directions than simply cultivating the West. Prague wants NATO and the Warsaw Pact to disappear. Havel has offered to mediate between the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Communists' Mideast friend, and Israel. Putting personal philosophy ahead of offending China, he meditated with the Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama. And he insisted on squeezing a visit to Iceland into his route to the White House this month. There also is a refreshing informality to the efforts to restore Czechoslovakia's standing and infuse new life into world diplomacy. Welcoming Arens, Dienstbier broke protocol and invited him to an art exhibit by a man who was his cellmate during a prison term. Why were you in prison, Arens politely inquired. ``Undermining of the Republic,'' answered Dienstbier, chuckling.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Companies Seek Less Restriction on Innovation
DOC.TEXT: It's Jan. 18, 2006. Sarah, a 77-year-old widow living with her son in Wheeling, W.Va., wakes up as a bedside video screen plays sequences of classical music. She uses her videophone to activate the kitchen coffee maker from her bed for her son, and then switches the music to his bedside screen and turns on a morning news show. When her son leaves for work she goes back to watching the news, which has been on hold since she left it. She dons a medical bracelet and plugs it into the videophone for a postoperative checkup from her heart surgery. Later, according to a futurist scenario envisioned by the Bell Atlantic telephone company, she leaves an audio-video message for a friend, listens to a ``talking'' book club and, when she goes to bed, programs an emergency pager that will, if need be, track down her son by phone. Bell Atlantic says the whiz-bang gadgets ``Sarah'' will take for granted are technically feasible now and could be in the average American's home by the end of the century. But first, Bell Atlantic and the other regional Bell companies say, they've got to get the government off their backs. Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., took a step in that direction Friday when he unveiled a bill to loosen the restrictions on information services and equipment manufacturing placed on the Bell companies in the 1984 consent decree that broke up the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. Previous efforts to free the Bells have gone nowhere in Congress. Opponents fear that unrestrained Bell companies could use their enormous resources to drive out competition by limiting phone access and by cross-subsidizing their new and riskier business ventures with their heavy local telephone earnings. But Markey, whose bill joins a similar measure introduced by Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., says it is time to defend U.S. telecommunications leadership against intense foreign competition. Markey's bill would give the Federal Communications Commission the oversight powers held by U.S. District Judge Harold Greene, who continues to enforce the 1984 consent decree. Greene in 1986 gave the Bells permission to transmit information services such as videotext, computer data bases, financial information and reservation and shopping services, but would not allow them to control the content of such services. Markey's bill would allow the Bell companies, among other things, to provide through non-joint venture subsidiaries: _Distribution of information services outside their calling territories. _Electronic ``yellow pages'' directories _ excluding classified advertising _ to be updated monthly for two years. _Emergency public safety services such as enhanced 911 calling. _Research, design and development of telecommunications equipment and, under certain conditions, equipment manufacturing. The bill contains mechanisms designed to prevent cross-subsidies and other anticompetitive practices, but allows the FCC to waive the separate subsidiary requirement after three years. The information service restrictions do not apply when a Bell company owns 5 percent or less of an information services company. Initial reaction from the Bell companies to the bill was cautiously optimistic. BellSouth described it as ``another significant step toward bringing America up to speed in telecommunications,'' while Bell Atlantic said it was ``another clear signal that Congress recognizes the need to address telecommunications policy for the nation.'' However, Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, was hesitant. ``This is a valiant effort to limit ratepayer risks, but it is not clear that the bill provides more concrete consumer benefits than current law. We're still skeptical of the need for this kind of legislation,'' Kimmelman said. MCI Communications Corp. said the bill was ``unneeded and will set back America's preeminence and global leadership in telecommunications.'' Although the consent decree didn't specifically mention cable television in the information services ban, court interpretations have included cable in that ban. Owning cable TV service is crucial to the Bells' plan to wire the nation with fiber-optic cable that could make a ``Sarah'' household a reality. But the cable industry is adamant about keeping the phone companies out of their business, and the Markey bill does not change the cable TV curbs.

DOC.HEAD: Difficult Road Ahead For Mandela and De Klerk
AP News Analysis
By DAVID CRARY
DOC.TEXT: Black hopes. White fears. These are the crucial factors that Nelson Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk must address as they set out on a precarious path in the direction of democracy and reconciliation. For South African blacks, Mandela's release Sunday was cause for unprecedented jubilation. Hundreds of thousands danced for joy in the streets of their cities and townships, convinced at least momentarily that their own political freedom was a big step closer. Many whites were far less happy. Liberal leaders lauded de Klerk for boldness but businessmen and homeowners worried about a possible upsurge of violence; police struck back hard at rowdy black revelers, and right-wing politicans accused the president of surrender. ``It's complete capitulation,'' said Koos van der Merwe, spokesman for the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, when he learned Mandela would go free. ``When the time comes, and they want to enforce black communist government on the whites, they will have to do it by force. We won't accept it passively.'' De Klerk, raised in a prominent Afrikaner family that believed whites were destined to rule, is not yet on the brink of capitulation. His proposals for power-sharing between blacks and whites stop well short of the one-person, one-vote system demanded by Mandela and the African National Congress. But the president's moves in the past 10 days have taken both his supporters and opponents by surprise. When the cautious, low-key politician took office in August, few South Africans would have predicted he would transform the political landscape by lifting a 30-year ban on the ANC, suspending executions, freeing prominent prisoners, telling militant exiles they can come back home. These moves have won an unusual degree of international goodwill for South Africa, but de Klerk's standing among his own white constituents may depend on whether the ANC is willing to meet him part way with concessions of its own. The president's brother, liberal political analyst Willem de Klerk, has met several times with ANC leaders and predicted in a recent article that the movement would make compromises. These might include official renunciation of violence and modifcations of the ANC's socialist economic policy, he said. But Mandela, in his first speech since his 1964 treason trial, told a huge crowd in Cape Town on Sunday that the time for compromise had not arrived. He reaffirmed his support for the ANC's guerrilla campaign and urged his followers to ``intensify the struggle on all fronts.'' He declared himself a ``loyal and disciplined member'' of the ANC and said nothing to substantiate South African press speculation that he might be at odds with some hard-line members of his movement's exiled leadership. The speech was not likely to reassure uneasy whites but was almost certain to be well-received in the townships, particularly among young militants _ hardened by years of street battles with police _ who might have been wondering if Mandela had mellowed. Mandela's only admonition to the youths was to be disciplined. ``I hope you will disperse with dignity,'' he said at the end of an evening marred by clashes between looters and police. ``Not a single one of you should do anything that which will make other people say we can't control our own people.'' Beyond the ranks of his own followers, Mandela faces the challenge of resolving ANC feuds with other black factions to its left and right. To many, he is the only South African capable of this task. At the same time, he could boost the ANC's long-term prospects by persuading a significant portion of the 5 million whites that their future in a black-ruled South Africa would be secure. He offered no specific inducements to whites on Sunday, but told them: ``The freedom movement is a political home for you, too.'' Mandela has stated in the past that he is aware of whites' fears of black domination. De Klerk has said repeatedly that he understands blacks' desire for full political rights. If they can find ways to convert this awareness into steps that make both blacks and whites feel more confident, then the ``new South Africa'' that each man envisioned in their weekend speeches might possibly materialize.
EDITOR'S NOTE: David Crary, the AP news editor in Johannesburg, has been reporting from South Africa since 1986.
