DOC.HEAD: Bush Declines Invitation to Address International AIDS Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Some organizers of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS said they weren't surprised when President Bush turned down an invitation to speak to the group. Bush, who declined to address the June conference either live or on videotape, was booed at the 1987 AIDS conference in Washington, D.C., when he was vice-president. The president's decision marks the first time in three years that the leader of the meeting's host nation has not addressed the assembly. White House Deputy Press Secretary Alixe Glen said Bush has addressed the AIDS issue and ``the need for compassion many times.'' ``We're disappointed,'' said Dr. John L. Ziegler, conference co-chairman and a professor of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco. ``We felt this was a real opportunity for the government to make a strong statement.'' But Stephen Morin, a member of the conference's community task force and an aide to Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., wasn't surprised. ``I think the president has good reason for not coming,'' he said. ``Neither the people of San Francisco nor the scientific community think much of his AIDS policies.'' Bush was discussing Reagan administration plans for mandatory AIDS testing of immigrants and prison inmates when he was jeered in 1987. U.S. policies restricting the freedom of foreigners infected with the AIDS virus to enter the country have been criticized. Although restrictions were eased last month, anyone infected still has to reveal their condition when applying for a visa and request a waiver of rules barring them from the United States. At least 16 groups, including the International League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, have said they will boycott the conference of 12,000 scientists and policy-makers unless the U.S. entrance restrictions are ended. Other national leaders who have spoken to the international AIDS convention include Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney last year, and Sweden's Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson in 1988. Although Bush declined to address the gathering, Glen said the president does plan to talk to the National Business Leadership Conference on AIDS next month in Arlington, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Taxes, Women, Scandal Dominate Japanese Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf ```Hideko Ito ...' to CORRECT that Hokkaido northernmost main island, sted main island. Pick up 5th, `With the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Socialist candidate Hideko Ito, in her bright red signature clothes, cuts a bold streak across the vast snowfields of northern Japan. Running for the powerful lower house of Parliament, Ms. Ito is blazing a new political trail with a mixture of fresh ideas and traditional values, hoping to attract votes away from the scandal-wracked, male-dominated Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan for 34 years. ``I want to change the many years of money politics created by Liberal Democratic control,'' she declares from atop her campaign van. ``They have not created a government that serves ordinary people like you and me.'' ``Hideko Ito _ mother and lawyer. She'll do her best,'' is the repetitive refrain blared from Ms. Ito's van as it barrels through the icy streets of Sapporo, a city of 1.6 million on Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island. With the ruling party at a turning point _ damaged by almost two years of scandals and unpopular tax and farm policies _ voters have a difficult choice: politics as usual or the uncertainty of a multiparty coalition led by the Socialists, the largest opposition group. Ousting the pro-business, conservative Liberal Democrats could signal more difficult trade relations with the United States. Political uncertainty has already bred instability in stock and currency markets in Japan and elsewhere in the world. The Socialist Party, seeking wider appeal, watered down its longstanding opposition to the Japan-U.S. security treaty, under which U.S. troops are based in Japan. But it is clear that a leftist-led coalition government would mean a reordering of Tokyo's relations with Washington. About 90 million people are eligible to vote in Sunday's election. Most analysts predict the Liberal Democrats will retain a simple majority of 257 seats in the 512-seat lower house. But a big drop from their current 295 seats could create a significant realignment of power. Polls show many voters are undecided, making the last week of campaigning even more crucial. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the leading economic daily, reported Friday that a telephone poll of 10,000 people showed 32.4 percent were undecided, while 34.1 percent said they would vote for the Liberal Democrats, 20.9 percent for the Socialists and the remainder for other parties. No margin of error was given. Now that the Recruit Co. influence-peddling scandal and the sex scandal that helped drive two prime ministers from office last year are out of the spotlight, public anger has subsided, political analysts say. But two Liberal Democrats who are on trial for bribery for their roles in the Recruit affair are seeking re-election, reviving memories of the scandal. The Liberal Democrats are attempting to cleanse the stain of scandal with pledges of honest politics, and to dilute the Socialists' popularity with declarations that a more leftist government would be bad for Japan. The Socialists' main theme is to abolish a 3 percent sales tax the Liberal Democrats rammed through Parliament. The Liberal Democrats also have been hurt by making trade concessions to the United States on agricultural imports. The Socialists promise a more protectionist farm trade policy. One of Ms. Ito's Liberal Democratic opponents, incumbent Shizuo Sato, 48, is just as active as she is, popping up at countless Lunar New Year festivities in Sapporo and visiting the city's Snow Festival, a weeklong show of ice sculptures that draws more than 1 million visitors from throughout the world. ``Now is the time for honest and courageous politics,'' Sato's campaign motto says. ``Many people are against the (sales) tax and many distrust my party,'' the Liberal Democrat tells about 40 workers at a small construction company. ``I understand their distrust, but if the party loses its majority it will be a disaster.'' Sato appears to be in danger of losing his seat, one of three held by the Liberal Democrats in the Sapporo constituency. Despite a well-cultivated image as an internationalist _ his campaign brochures feature pictures of him with Henry Kissinger and President Bush _ he is suffering from his party's image among the relatively progressive voters in Japan's fastest-growing city. Ms. Ito is expected to be a top vote-getter, though she is a first-time candidate with no experience in government. She is riding a wave of blossoming support for female candidates _ dubbed ``Madonnas'' because of the departure they represent from postwar politics, an all-male enclave of pork-barreling and backroom deals. In a profile of Ms. Ito on national television, the 46-year-old lawyer was heralded for studying for law exams while nursing one of her three children. She was dubbed the ``red Madonna of the snow-white cities of Hokkaido.'' ``I think women in politics is a good thing,'' says Keiko Sato, a woman working in a convenience store. ``It's important to have the views of women in politics.'' The Liberal Democrats will suffer if that view is widespread, since the conservative party has no women representatives in the lower house and is backing no female candidates. The Socialists, led by Takako Doi, the first female party head ever in Japan, are backing eight women. Nationwide, only 66 of the 953 candidates are women. Last July, women voters and candidates made a strong impact in the election for the less-powerful upper house of Parliament, costing the Liberal Democrats their majority in that chamber.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Settles With TWA
DOC.TEXT: A state Supreme Court Justice said he got a $12,500 settlement and a refresher course in the mechanics of lawsuits when he took Trans World Airlines to task over its manners. Justice Richard Neely, 48, filed the lawsuit in Kanawha County Circuit Court after a July flight from Seattle to New York during which TWA allegedly handled a luggage delay poorly. According to the lawsuit, Neely was shoved by a female employee while he was acting as an informal liaison for his approximately 150 fellow passengers who were waiting for their luggage. It was the first lawsuit filed by Neely since he was elected to the high court in 1973. ``It's good to get back in the courts as an attorney every now and then,'' said Neely, who had a private practice before the election. He said he wrote an article for the American Bar Association's magazine ``Litigation'' detailing the methods he used in his suit. He said the article would be published soon. Phone calls to Don Morrison, TWA's director of public relations in St. Louis, weren't answered Sunday night. Neely said he has no specific plans for the money. ``Am I going to go out and and spend it on fast horses, women and whiskey? At my age, no,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in early European trading today. Gold prices fell. Foreign currency dealers said trading was calm as investors tried to assess the impact of a possible monetary union between West and East Germany on the Deutsche mark. They said that with the Japanese markets closed for a national holiday, European traders started out with few clues and were waiting for U.S. markets to set the trend. The prospect of a Germany monetary union, which rocked the German bond market last week, has so far had little impact on the currency market. DOC.HEAD: Suspects in Weekend Massacre Still at Large
DOC.TEXT: Two ``coldblooded'' suspects in shootings that killed a man and three girls and wounded three other people during a bowling alley robbery have slipped past roadblocks, police said. Saturday's killings, along with an unrelated slaying the same day, brought the number of homicide victims in this city of 55,000 people to six this year _ triple the number for all of last year. ``It's not the city it was when I used to roam the streets,'' said police Capt. Fred Rubio. Police said Sunday they have had to rely on rough sketches, the survivors and tips from the public for leads into the bowling alley shootings. Police said two men walked into the Las Cruces Bowl early Saturday and herded seven people into an office in the front of the building, forced them to lie on the floor and shot them in the back of their heads. The men then set fire to the office in an effort to cover up the crime, police said. The shootings killed a 26-year-old man, his stepdaughter, his daughter and another young girl. Three others were critically wounded. Teams of officers were checking out about 100 pieces of information telephoned to Las Cruces police from other law enforcement agencies and the public. But no arrests had been made, police said. ``These people are just coldblooded people,'' Rubio said. He said police planned to give authorities in Mexico copies of composite drawings of the suspects. Las Cruces is 45 miles from the border. But police also are checking a report that the men are from the Las Cruces area, Rubio said. Killed were bowling alley employee Steve Teran, 26, daughter Valerie, 2, stepdaughter Paula Holguin, 6, and Amy Houser, 13. Police withheld the names of the wounded, but Rubio said they were two adults and a 12-year-old child. Two of the wounded were in serious condition and the third was in good condition, a spokesman at Memorial General Hospital said. ``They've got to be maniacs to do this,'' Audrey Teran said of the men who killed her husband and children. ``What can a 2-year-old do? What threat are they to them? ... My little girls, my babies. This whole thing is senseless.'' Police Lt. Jerry Fariss said he had spoken with two of the surviving victims. ``One of them was able to give a description that tends to match the one we've got,'' Fariss said. The bowling alley, which also has a restaurant and bar, is in a mixed commercial and residential area. Rubio said there were two homicides in Las Cruces in all of 1989 and six so far this year. The fifth homicide of the year, a stabbing, occurred Saturday afternoon. Police arrested James Hayes Lane, 30, of Abilene, Texas, who had recently been paroled from the Texas Department of Corrections after serving time for attempted murder and car theft.

DOC.HEAD: 58 Killed In Burmese Battles
DOC.TEXT: Burmese government forces overran the headquarters of an ethnic rebel group over the weekend in battles on the border that claimed the lives of at least 58 combatants, Thai and rebel officials said today. The officials said the fighting sent thousands of civilians fleeing into Thailand. A bomb blast killed 33 ethnic Karen guerrillas Saturday at their stronghold of Kaw Moo Ra on Thai territory, a spokesman for the group said. The spokesman said he believed the blast came from a booby trap in captured war munitions. Thai border police said they found the bodies of 19 Burmese and six Karen fighters Sunday at the Thai village of Ban Waeng Kaew. It is directly across opposite Kaw Moo Ra, about 250 miles north of Bangkok. About 200 Burmese troops crossed into Thailand on Friday to attack the base, one of the last held by the Karen on the frontier. Further south on Sunday, about 1,000 Burmese troops overran the headquarters of the New Mon State Army near the Burmese border village of Three Pagoda Pass, a Thai official said. They had seized and burned the town two days earlier. Kavee Minwong, district chief of the Thai town of Sangkha just opposite the battle zone, said Burmese troops began their attack about midnight Saturday and captured the base early the next day. Both sides appeared to have suffered heavy casualties, but neither was willing to reveal the extent of their losses, he said. About 4,000 ethnic Mon civilians fled into Thailand to escape the fighting and marauding Burmese troops, Kavee said. About 200 Thai civilians were evacuated to safety, he said. The official said the Mon refugees would be sent back across the border once the fighting died down. The Karen spokesman said the bomb blast at Kaw Moo Ra occurred while guerrillas were carrying captured weapons and munitions back to the camp. He said it was one of the worst Karen death tolls in years of fighting, and he suspected the munitions had been booby-trapped by the government troops. The Karen and the Mon are among the diverse ethnic groups that have fought for decades against central control by Rangoon. Both have relied on controlling smuggling routes between Thailand and Burma to finance their rebellions. However, the military government of Burma launched a sustained offensive in October 1988 that has badly hurt the Karen.

DOC.HEAD: Six Dead, Dozens Wounded in Salvador Air Raid During Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Government aircraft bombed and strafed suspected rebel positions during fighting around a northeastern village, killing at least six people and wounding 20, witnesses said. Also Sunday, a U.S. congressional delegation arrived in the country to investigate the November killing of six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter. The director of El Salvador's military college and eight other soldiers were charged last month with the murders. Sunday's raid came during fighting that broke out early Sunday between government and leftist rebel forces in the village of Corral de Piedra, 53 miles northeast of the capital, said a female church worker. She did not want to be identified for fear of reprisals. ``The planes and helicopters did their work for about two hours,'' she said. ``We were in chapel when we heard the shooting in the hills, and we heard about 10 bombs explode, shaking the chapel, and the dust then sifted in under the doors.'' There was no comment from the government about the attack. A resettlement camp for refugees in the decade-old civil war in Corral de Piedra appeared to be one of the targets, the witness said by telephone. ``When people finally dared to go out, we went into a house and we saw five children and one adult dead. The roof of the house was blown up by a bomb. At the same spot I saw about 20 wounded people,'' she added. The witness said she was able to get a car and evacuate five of the wounded. A nurse at the Chalatenango Regional Hospital said that the wounded were being evacuated there from Corral de Piedra. ``There are more than 10 wounded here. We have a lot of work. Another three (wounded) were taken to San Salvador, and it is known there are many dead there (in the village),'' the nurse said. She too spoke on condition of anonymity. About 300 refugees were living at the Corral de Piedra resettlement camp, which was set up when they arrived in October from the Mesa Grande refugee camp in neighboring Honduras. They had spent eight years in the Honduran camp. Senior military officers have been publicly saying in recent weeks that the people at the Corral de Piedra camp were secretly collaborating with the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, a coalition of five guerrilla organizations fighting to topple the rightist government. Human rights groups estimate more than 75,000 people have been killed since the rebel war began in October 1979, most of them civilians. The 14-member congressional delegation, led by Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., arrived at a military airport and did not talk with reporters. Its members were to begin meeting today with government, military, church, union and human rights officials as part of its investigation. The Jesuit massacre has provoked criticism of U.S. support for the Salvadoran government.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Offers to Negotiate Troop Withdrawal in Poland
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin says it is ready to negotiate the withdrawal of its troops from Poland as part of an overall cutback in the East bloc _ and is ready to begin the reductions without waiting for a superpower treaty. ``It is of importance not to miss the historic chance and to supplement political detente by a relaxing of tension in the military field in good time,'' the government said in a statement carried Sunday by the official Tass news agency. The statement declared the Cold War over and said it was time to begin ``the gradual dismantling of the outdated model of the European balance of forces.'' Superpower talks on cutting conventional armies in Europe have accelerated as Communist regimes have collapsed in East bloc countries and the governments that replaced them demanded that the Soviet troops go home. Soviet troops put down nationalist uprisings in Hungary in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush have agreed in principle on major troops cuts in Europe, and the Soviet Union has been negotiating with Czechoslovakia and Hungary on the withdrawal of troops. ``If the government of the Republic of Poland expresses an appropriate desire, we could discuss with its representatives the question of Soviet troops in that country,'' the Kremlin said. Of the 575,000 Soviet troops in Eastern Europe, about 40,000 are in Poland. Gorbachev has agreed with Bush's proposal to set a ceiling of 225,000 troops for each superpower in Europe, with 195,000 of them allowed in Central Europe. Following the visit of Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Moscow last week, Gorbachev suggested the limit of 195,000 be extended to Europe as a whole. The Kremlin statement Sunday said the Soviet Union was prepared to begin cutting troop strengths in the East bloc without waiting for an official treaty to be signed at the Vienna conference on conventional forces in Europe. ``There are misgivings that the results of the Vienna talks may lag behind the pace of reforms in Europe,'' the statement said. As a result, ``the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Treaty member states, without waiting for the conclusion of Vienna accords, are already taking steps toward unilateral cuts in their armed forces (and) making them structurally incapable of attack,'' the Kremlin said. The statement said withdrawal of Soviet troops in East Germany, host to about two-thirds of the Soviet soldiers in Eastern Europe, was a separate issue. ``The stay of foreign troops in both the GDR (East Germany) and the Federal Republic of Germany is a special issue connected with the Four Powers' obligations arising from the outcome of World War II, and it may be tackled only with due regard to the security interests of all the states concerned,'' the statement said. The ``Four Powers'' are the wartime Allies who defeated Nazi Germany _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. The troop issue was discussed Saturday during a one-day visit by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who enlisted the support of Gorbachev for German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Nelson Mandela Speech
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of Nelson Mandela's first public speech in nearly three decades, delivered Sunday outside Cape Town's City Hall.

Comrades and fellow South Africans, I greet you all in the name of peace, democracy and freedom for all. I stand here before you not as a prophet, but as a humble servant of you, the people. Your tireless and heroic sacrifices have made it possible for me to be here today. I therefore place the remaining years of my life in your hands. On this day of my release, I extend my sincere and warmest gratitude to the millions of my compatriots and those in every corner of the globe who have campaigned tirelessly for my release. I extend special greetings to the people of Cape Town, the city to which, which has been my home for three decades. Your mass marchesand other forms of struggle have served as a constant source of strength to all political prisoners. I salute the African National Congress. It has fulfilled our every expectation in its role as leader of the great march to freedom. I salute our president, Comrade Oliver Tambo for leading the ANC even under the most difficult circumstances. I salute the rank and file members of the ANC: You have sacrificed life and limb in the pursuit of the noble cause of our struggle. I salute combatants of Umkhonto We Sizwe (the ANC's military wing) ... who paid the ultimate price for the freedom of all South Africans. I salute the South African Communist Party for its sterling contribution to the struggle for democracy: You have survived 40 years of unrelenting persecution. The memory of great Communists like ... Bram Fisher and Moses Mabhida will be cherished for generations to come. I salute General-Secretary Joe Slovo, one of our finest patriots. We are heartened by the fact that the alliance between ourselves and the partyremains as strong as it always was. I salute the United Democratic Front, the National Education Crisis Committee, the South African Youth Congress, the Transvaal and NatalIndian Congresses, and COSATU, and the many other formations of the mass democratic movement. I also salute the Black Sash, and the National Union of South African Students. We note with pride that you have endured as the conscience of white South Africans, even during the darkest days of the history of our struggle: you held the flag of liberty high. The large-scale mass mobilization of the past few years is one of the key factors which led to the opening of the final chapter of our struggle. I extend my greetings to the working class of our country, your organized strength is the pride of our movement: You remain the most dependable force in the struggle to end exploitation and oppression. I pay tribute to the many religious communities who carried the campaign for justice forward when the organizations of our people were silenced. I greet the traditional leaders of our country: Many among you continue to walk in the footsteps of great heroes.... I pay tribute for the endless heroism of youth: You, the young lions, You, the young lions have energized our entire struggle. I pay tribute to the mothersand wives and sisters of our nation: you are the rock-hard foundation of our struggle. Apartheid has inflicted more pain on you than on anyone else. On this occasion, we thank the world, we thank the world community for their great contribution to the anti-apartheid struggle. Without your support, our struggle would not have reached this advanced stage. The sacrifice of the Front Line states will be remembered by South Africans forever. My celebrations will be incomplete without expressing my deep appreciation for the strength that's been given to me during my long and gloomy years in prison by my beloved wife and family. I am convinced that your pain and suffering was far greater than my own. Before I go any further, I wish to make the point that I intend making only a few preliminary comments at this stage. I will make a more complete statement only after I have had the opportunity to consult with my comrades. Today, the majority of South Africans, black and white, recognize that apartheid has no future. It has to be ended by our own decisive mass action in order to build peace and security. The mass campaigns of defiance and other actions of our organizations and people can only culminate in the establishment of democracy. The apartheid's destruction on our subcontinent is incalculable. The fabric of family life of millions of my people has been shattered. Millions are homeless and unemployed. Our economy lies in ruins and our people are embroiled in political strife.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CAPE TOWN, South Africa: political strife.
DOC.TEXT: Our resort to the armed struggle in 1960 with the formation of the military wing of the ANC (Umkhonto We Sizwe) was a purely defensive action against the violence of apartheid. The factors which necessitated the armed struggle still exist today. We have no option but to continue. We express the hope that a climate conducive to a negotiated settlement would be created soon, so that there may no longer be the need for the armed struggle. I am a loyal and disciplined member of the African National Congress. I am therefore in full agreement with all of its objectives, strategies, and tactics. The need to unite the people of our country is as important a task now as it always has been. No individual leader is able to take all this enormous task on his own. It is our task as leaders to place our views before our organization and to allow the democratic structures to decide on the way forward. On the question of democratic practice, I feel duty-bound to make the point that a leader of the movement is a person who has been democratically elected at a national congress. This is a principle which must be upheld without any exception. Today, I wish to report to you that my talks with the government have been aimed at normalizing the political situation in the country. We have not yet begun discussing the basic demands of the struggle. I wish to stress that I myself have at no time entered negotiations about the future of our country, except to insist on a meeting between the ANC and the government. Mr. de Klerk has gone further than any other nationalist president in taking real steps to normalize the situation. However, there are further steps as outlined in the Harare declaration that have to be met before negotiations on the basic demands of our people can begin. I reiterate our call for inter-alia, the immediate ending of the state of emergency, and the freeing of all _ and not only some _ political prisoners. Only such a normalized situation which allows for free political activity can allow us to consult our people in order to obtain a mandate. The people need to be consulted on who will negotiate and on the content of such negotiations. Negotiations cannot take place. Negotiations cannot take up their place above the heads or behind the backs of our people. It is our belief that the future of our country can only be determined by a body which is democratically elected on a non-racial basis. Negotiations on the dismantling of apartheid will have to address the overwhelming demands of our people for a democratic, non-racial, and unitary South Africa. There must be an end to white monopoly on political power, and a fundamental restructuring of our political and economic systems to ensure that the inequalities of apartheid are addressed, andour society thoroughly democratized. It must be addedthat Mr. de Klerk himself is a man of integrity who is acutely aware of the dangers of a public figure not honoring his undertaking. But as an organization we base our policy and our strategy on the harsh reality we are faced with, and this reality is that we are still suffering under the policies of the nationalist government. Our struggle has reached a decisive moment: We call on our people to seize this moment, so that the process towards democracy is rapid and uninterrupted. We have waited too long for our freedom. We can no longer wait. Now is the time to intensify the struggle on all fronts. To relax our efforts now would be a mistake which generations to come will not be able to forgive. The sight of freedom looming on the horizon should encourage us to redouble our efforts. It is only through disciplined mass action that our victory can be assured. We call on our white compatriots to join us in the shaping of a new South Africa. The freedom movement is a political home for you, too. We call on the international community to continue the campaign to isolate the apartheid regime. To lift sanctions now would run the risk of aborting the process towards the complete eradication of apartheid. Our march toward freedom is irreversible. We must not allow fear to stand in our way. Universal suffrage on a common voter's roll in a united, democratic, and non-racial South Africa is the only way to peace and racial harmony. In conclusion, I wish to go to my own words during my trial in 1964 _ they are as true today as they were then: ``I have fought against white domination, and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunity. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and to achieve. But, if need be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney, Aquino Strike Pre-Talk Postures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 10th pvs with PLO mtg; picks up, Her decision
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is sidestepping a striking snub from President Corazon Aquino and moving ahead with plans to meet top Philippine military officials on the future of U.S. forces in the unsettled country. Cheney, here on the opening leg of a two-week tour of Asian allied nations, did not respond to Mrs. Aquino's refusal to meet with him on his first visit to her country as defense secretary. ``He doesn't take it personally. We're still going to the Philippines and we expect productive meetings,'' Cheney's spokesman, Pete Williams, said Sunday. Cheney scheduled a full day of sessions with U.S. military chiefs from the Army, Navy and Air Force as well as touring a guided missile cruiser and lunching with the troops. While Cheney declined to offer a personal reaction to the latest rough spot in U.S.-Philippines relations, he did decide to slice a day off his scheduled Feb. 18-20 stop in the Philippines. The defense secretary also is slated to visit South Korea, Hong Kong and Japan over the next two weeks to assess the U.S. military posture in the Pacific in the wake of calls in Congress for sharp defense budget cuts and demands that nations hosting U.S. forces increase their contributions to the mutual defense. There are some 190,000 U.S. military personnel in the regions Cheney is to visit. U.S.-Philippine talks on renewing the lease on the strategically placed American bases, Clark Air Base and Subic Naval Base, are expected to begin next month. Mrs. Aquino, in a weekend speech, said she would not meet Cheney after expressing unhappiness over U.S. payments for the bases and negative U.S. media reports about her government's efficacy in light of a series of coup attempts. Even though a meeting with Mrs. Aquino had not formally been placed on Cheney's schedule, she has routinely met with such high-ranking officials. Mrs. Aquino met Sunday with representatives of the Palestinian Liberation Organization to sign an agreement to exchange diplomatic missions soon, Abdul Latif Abu Hajleh, director-general of the PLO's political department, said early today. Her decision not to meet with Cheney is noteworthy in light of President Bush's decision to send U.S. Air Force jets to her aid during the latest coup attempt Dec. 1. Williams said Cheney now plans to spend only a day and a half in the Philippines and will meet with his counterpart, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos. Williams said U.S. officials don't see Mrs. Aquino's announcement as a setback and noted that the defense secretary hadn't intended to negotiate about renewing the lease agreement on the U.S. military bases. Cheney, in comments to reporters, warned that the United States will have no choice but to leave its huge Philippines bases unless a new agreement is reached ``with terms we can accept.'' ``I'm not here to negotiate on the bases. ... Obviously, we are interested in renewing the base rights agreement,'' Cheney said. ``It's only going to happen if both parties can reach an acceptable understanding. It has to be on the basis that the Filipinos want us there and in accordance with terms that we can accept.'' ``The situation in the Philippines continues to be of concern,'' the secretary added, echoing expressions of concern by U.S. officials about dangers of renewed coup attempts and continued corruption in Mrs. Aquino's government. Bush ordered F-4 Phantom jets into the air over Manila to pin down rebel units during the December coup, a move that later gave rise to complaints from Mrs. Aquino's critics that she was beholden to the U.S. government. Ramos has been seen as a presidential contender in the country's 1992 elections, but his decision to seek U.S. assistance during the coup has reportedly diminished his popularity as well. In 1988, then-Secretary of State George Shultz agreed to pay $962 million for the use of Clark, Subic and four smaller bases during the final two years of the 1947 agreement. The Bush administration asked Congress to provide $200 million in military assistance and $160 million in economic support funds, but Congress cut the figure by $96 million and U.S. officials in Manila have said there is no chance the reductions will be restored.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavians at Rally Demand Political Independence
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Moldavians rallied in their capital to demand independence from the Kremlin, the official Tass news agency said today. At Sunday's four-hour rally in Kishinev, speakers from the Moldavian People's Front demanded social and economic independence from Moscow, a new constitution, laws on sovereignty, and the right to emigrate, Tass said. Authorities of the republic sanctioned the rally, which was organized by the People's Front. It was addressed by members of the front; representatives of informal groups; and Pyotr Luchinsky, first secretary of the republic's Communist Party, the news agency said. Speakers for the front urged the election of a new Moldavian legislature to ensure sovereignty in a revamped Soviet federation. Luchinsky urged the people not to get carried away by emotion and make unrealistic suggestions. People's fronts and various ethnic groups across the Soviet Union, and especially in the northwestern Baltic republics, are demanding independence from Moscow. Lithuania's Communist Party broke away from the national party in December. The Moldavian People's Front already has won its battle to establish Moldavian as the official language and a return to the Latin alphabet instead of the Cyrillic used by Russians. Moldavia is adjacent to Romania and shares the same spoken language. Moldavians go to the polls on Feb. 25 to elect republican and local officials. The front's candidates are expected to do well.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Swept By Fire; Luxury Savoy Hotel Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: A wind-whipped fire ravaged the 109-year-old Savoy Theater in London early today and forced an evacuation of the celebrated Savoy Hotel next door, police said. The theater was empty at the time, and no one was reported injured. The London fire brigade said in a statement that 60 percent of the theater in The Strand, central London, was ablaze when firemen arrived shortly after 1:30 a.m. Guests from the Savoy Hotel, including actor Richard Harris, were evacuated to the Strand Palace Hotel across the street as flames fanned by strong winds shot through the roof of the theater and lit up the night sky. Terry Robinson, a kitchen cleaner at the hotel, said, ``At first there was just dense smoke, and then all of a sudden it went up like a tinder box with the flames roaring away.'' Authorities said the Savoy Hotel suffered only minor damage. The Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, quoted an unidentified policeman as saying: ``The wind was so strong that it was blowing the firemen's jets away before the water could reach the fire.'' Wearing a white Savoy Hotel dressing gown and sipping tea as he watched firemen tackle the blaze, Harris told reporters he was in bed learning lines when he heard the hotel fire alarm. He said he walked downstairs because he had been told that people should not use elevators in a fire. Harris, 58, is due to appear in Luigi Pirandello's play ``Henry IV'' at The Haymarket theater in London later this year. The Savoy Theater, which can seat 1,123 people, was built in 1881. It was financed by Richard D'Oyly Carte for production of the hugely popular comic operas of the day by Sir William Gilbert and Sir Arthur Sullivan. The theater was the first public building in London to be lit by electricity. The current show there is ``It's Magic,'' starring magician Paul Daniels. The Savoy Hotel, which was built by D'Oyly Carte, opened in 1889 and swiftly gained a reputation as one of the world's grandest hotels frequented by the rich and famous. The best suites currently cost about $845 a night.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Of Velcro, Nature's Fastener, Is Dead
DOC.TEXT: Inventor George De Mestral, whose Velcro fastener stuck so well with the public it replaced millions of buttons and zippers, has died at his home, his wife said today. He was 82. De Mestral's wife, Helen, said he died Thursday from complications of bronchitis and other lung problems. He had been sick for about three weeks, she said by telephone from their home in this village near Lake Geneva. A Swiss mechanical engineer, De Mestral in 1941 conceived a fastener using two fabric strips _ one covered with tiny hooks, the other with a fuzzy web the hooks could grab. Patented after 10 years of refinement, Velcro entered production in several countries in the mid-1950s. The fastener, which can also be used to replace adhesive tape, soon became a worldwide success. It is especially known in the fashion industry. But it also was used in the U.S. spaceship that took astronauts to the moon in 1969. Despite its high-tech look, Velcro was inspired by nature. A passionate hunter, De Mestral came home once from a day in the fields and found burrs stuck to his pants. The idea of velcro was born when he examined the burrs under a microscope and found their surface to consist of little hooks. De Mestral's widow said she had no estimate of how much his invention earned.

DOC.HEAD: Tanks Attack Rival Christian Forces
DOC.TEXT: Tanks of a renegade Christian general pounded rival forces around mountain resorts today in a possible prelude to an offensive in the nearly 2-week-old battle, police said. In the rain-soaked streets of east Beirut, soldiers of Gen. Michel Aoun and the rival militia fighters clashed with automatic weapons and hand grenades, police reported. Aoun has been struggling to deliver a knockout blow by seizing strongholds of the Lebanese Forces militia, led by Samir Geagea. They are battling for control of the country's Christian enclave. There was no word on casualties in the latest clashes. The fighting has killed at least 457 people and wounded 1,701 since the fighting began Jan. 30. It has been the worst bloodletting by rival Christian forces in the nearly 15-year-old civil war that usually pits Christians against Moslems. Neither side has made significant gains since Aoun's troops captured a major militia base in the coastal town of Dbaye, north of the capital, nine days ago. Police said Aoun's army was concentrating on a new front in the mountain province of Kesrouan, 15 miles northeast of Beirut. His tanks pushed into a militia-held triangle formed by the resort towns of Daraya, Kleiat and Ajaltoun below the ski slopes in the Kesrouan mountains, police reported. A spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said the hit-and-run attacks appeared to be aimed at softening up Lebanese Forces defenses before a large-scale assault to encircle the main militia stronghold at Jounieh, a port 12 miles north of the capital. Relief groups and Christian religious leaders issued fresh appeals for a humanitarian cease-fire to allow civil defense teams to recover at least two dozen decomposing bodies from the streets. But there appeared to be no let-up in the fighting or sniper fire. Civilians trapped in underground shelters for most of the past two weeks took advantage of occasional lulls to dash across Beirut's Green Line into the Moslem sector. ``The snipers shot a woman running ahead of me,'' Therese Yakoub said after she sprinted 500 yards across the Green Line. ``Poor thing, she has five children, and she was planning to buy bread and powdered milk for them,'' Ms. Yakoub said. President Elias Hrawi appealed again to the superpowers, France and the Vatican to support possible intervention by his Syrian-backed troops to halt the fighting. Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are all Maronite Catholics, the sect that has dominated the government, army, and police since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi's government and considers himself the sole legitimate authority in Lebanon. He was appointed head of an interim military cabinet in 1988 by outgoing president Amin Gemayel until a successor could be elected. Hrawi was elected by Parliament in November with a mandate to carry out a peace plan brokered by the Arab League. It gives more power to the Moslems. Aoun rejects the plan because it does not provide for a complete withdrawal by Syria's 40,000 troops, who have been in Lebanon since 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Those forces control most of the country. Geagea has taken no public stand on the latest peace accord but recognizes Hrawi.

DOC.HEAD: Bloomie's Still Figuring Robbery Damage
DOC.TEXT: The armed and masked bandits who made off with a good chunk of a day's receipts from Bloomingdale's flagship store were still at large today and still had officials trying to count how much the robbers hauled off. The take for the Saturday night holdup was estimated at between $100,000 and $500,000. It probably will be the middle of the week before a precise amount is determined, police spokesman Sgt. Ed Burns said Sunday. Officer Janice Swinney said today that the bandits were still at large and the audit was not complete. Three security guards at the fashionable Manhattan department store, carrying the day's receipts in a locked cart, were leaving a freight elevator when they were confronted by robbers armed with a sawed-off rifle and a gun, police said. The thieves used bolt cutters on the lock. Police recovered a sawed-off rifle, two ski masks, a pair of gloves and a set of handcuffs. The New York-based Bloomingdale's chain is owned by heavily indebted Campeau Corp., a Canadian retail and real-estate company that owns strings of department store chains in the United States. Campeau recently filed for bankruptcy protection on behalf of its U.S. retail divisions, Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., both based in Cincinnati. Federated is Bloomingdale's parent.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ISLAMABAD
Pakistani Troops Said To Fire On Indian Security Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Indian claim that Pakistanis fired on Indian troops, details. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Pakistani troops fired on Indian security forces who stopped a mob of Pakistani protesters from storming across the border into disputed Kashmir, officials said today. At least three demonstrators were killed Sunday night, a Defense Ministry spokesman said in Islamabad. Pakistan's state-run TV said the Indian guards killed as many as six. The trouble started after Indian border guards opened fire on hundreds of Pakistanis who tried to cross a cease-fire line separating Pakistan-controlled Kashmir from the Indian-held region. A spokesman for the Indian Defense Ministry said Pakistani troops then fired about 200 rounds from light and medium weapons at Indian border posts in the Uri sector. Indian forces returned fire and the exchange continued for about half an hour, the spokesman said. No one was hurt. A Pakistani official in Islamabad denied the accusations. ``Pakistani military authorities and the Foreign Secretary are in touch with Indian authorities to remove the misunderstanding,'' said Additional Foreign Secretary Khalid Mahmood in Islamabad. Pakistan's top diplomat in New Delhi, Bashir Babar, was summoned to India's Foreign Ministry on Sunday and today and apprised of India's concern over the events, an Indian government spokesman said. A fluid 840-mile cease-fire line separates the Indian and Pakistani Kashmirs. Pakistan and Indian twice have gone to war over Kashmir, in 1948 and again in 1965. On Feb. 5, at least one person was killed and 12 wounded when Pakistani mobs tried to cross the cease-fire line near Jammu, 95 miles to the south. The two demonstrations at the cease-fire line were to express support for Moslem militants who are fighting for independence for the Moslem-dominated state from the predominantly Hindu India. On Sunday, the Pakistani mob retreated when soldiers of India's paramilitary border security force opened fire, said the Indian spokesman who refused to be identified. ``The mob returned a second time by which time it had become slightly dark,'' he said. ``That is when the Pakistani troops opened fire.'' A Pakistani spokesman, who also refused to be identified, said Pakistani army patrols repulsed a mob of some 1,200 demonstrators. Small groups broke away from the crowd and slipped into the Indian-held territory, he said. An official of the Indian border security force, which normally patrols the border, said the Indian army today took control of the cease-fire line. Some men in the intruding crowd were armed with guns which they fired occasionally, he said. ``It was becoming very difficult, our troops had to open fire,'' he said. Farouk Haider, vice-president of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front that is leading the uprising, said in Islamabad after the Indian firing that ``the situation is very confusing.'' Thirty-one people were wounded in the shooting, Haider said. Five were in critical condition in a hospital in Muzzafarabad, the capital of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, he said, adding he knew of only one death. The 40-year-old conflict over Kashmir flared Jan. 20 after a government crackdown and the arrest of 250 suspected militants. Most of them were subsequently released, but the arrests sparked widespread violence. At least 85 people have been killed since the crackdown began. Most of the victims have been curfew-breaking protesters shot by security forces in Srinagar. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, has been the center of the secessionist movement that has turned violent in recent years. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front had earlier campaigned for union with Islamic Pakistan but has in recent years demanded independence and the status of a neutral country. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, making it the only Moslem majority state in predominantly Hindu India's 25 states. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million population. Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Asks Bonn For Up To $9 Billion
DOC.TEXT: East Germany today asked the Bonn government for as much as $9 billion in financial aid in what it called a ``contribution of solidarity'' to help the state-run economy out of its growing crisis. As pressure toward German reunification continued to grow, a Cabinet minister in East Berlin accused West Germany of waging a ``psychological campaign'' against the government. Negotiators representing the Communists, their coalition partners and pro-democracy forces met this morning for their 12th session in East Berlin. The national discussions were broadcast live on East German television. They adopted a request to the West German government for a contribution of between $6 billion and $9 billion, a sum they said West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl promised at a December meeting in Dresden with Premier Hans Modrow. The negotiators rejected a Bonn proposal to join the two nations' currencies as a way to prop up the East German mark. The move bars Modrow from dealing with the issue during his trip to Bonn, which begins Tuesday. East German Cabinet Minister Wolfgang Ullmann, of the Democracy Now group, bitterly criticized the Bonn government at the start of today's session. ``Bonn is trying to discredit the government here at home and to put it under international pressure,'' Ullmann said. Citing an assertion from a high-ranking West German official that East Germany was near bankruptcy and considering moving up the election date, he said West Germans were waging a ``psychological campaign'' against Modrow's government. East Germany's first free elections are scheduled for March 18. A peaceful revolution last year swept the hard-line Communist leadership from power. Ullmann also said the Communist premier has had to learn about West Germany's positions regarding unification ``from reading the newspapers rather than from the usual diplomatic channels.'' The pace toward unification quickened over the weekend after Kohl brought back from Moscow what he called a ``green light'' from the Soviet leadership. He said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had not attached any conditions to approving the historic step of unification. On Sunday, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said he hoped a final unification plan could be worked out and presented to a full European summit in October or November, and unification completed this year. He emphasized that the World War II allies France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union also would be involved in drafting the plan with officials of the two German states.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Attends Services, Tells of Alcohol Dependency
DOC.TEXT: In his first public outing since checking into a treatment center last month, Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry went to church and admitted a dependence on alcohol, members of the church said. Barry surprised worshipers at New Macedonia Missionary Baptist Church with his Sunday morning appearance and a short speech, said the Rev. Thomas Masters, the church's pastor. ``Part of the recovery process is having a spiritual focus,'' Masters said. ``We were full of love, forgiveness and support for him.'' Masters said he did not know why Barry chose his church for the service, in which entertainer Ben Vereen also addressed the congregation of 500. The church is about a mile away from the Hanley-Hazelden Center in West Palm Beach. Barry began a 28-day treatment program at the center Jan. 22 after the FBI and Washington police arrested him and charged him with cocaine possession. Vereen, whose appearance was expected, is doing local perfomances, Masters said. Barry sat with the congregation during the three-hour service, clapping and nodding to the songs and speeches, members said. He gave an impromptu, five-minute talk near the end of the visit, they said. Barry said he was dependent on alcohol but did not mention cocaine, churchgoer Stephanie Strong said. ``He said he had a friend bigger than the U.S. attorney, and that friend is Jesus Christ,'' she added. ``He said he would go back to Washington and face his problems.'' Police in Washington have said they secretly taped the mayor smoking crack. But his staff said he checked into Hanley-Hazelden for alcoholism treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Kills Black Celebrant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with security forces killing black. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Twelve of...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A white security guard today shot and killed one of a group of club-carrying blacks who chased and cornered him during a celebration of Nelson Mandela's release, police said. The guard was harassed and chased along a central Johannesburg street by about 50 revelers, and fired after he was cornered by members of the group carrying bricks and clubs, Capt. Eugene Opperman said. Four bystanders were wounded by shotgun pellets. In Cape Town, a bomb blast early today caused extensive damage at the ticket office of a stadium where a boycott-breaking English cricket team is due to play this week, police said. It blew out windows of the office at Newlads stadium in Cape Town, and damaged the roof and wall, local cricket administrator Kevin Commins said. It was believed to have been caused by a limpet mine, a mine that can be attached to objects. Two other limpet-mine blasts were reported in the area late Sunday, causing slight damage at government office buildings in the towns of Paarl and Parow. Paarl is the location of Victor Verster prison farm, where African National Congress leader Mandela was held until his release Sunday. Police reported 16 additional deaths in political unrest across South Africa, raising to about 30 the number of blacks killed in the 24 hours ending at daybreak today. Twelve of the deaths were in Mpumalanga, a black township in Natal Province. More than 2,500 people have been killed in Natal in the past three years in a power-struggle between supporters of the ANC and Inkatha, a more conservative Zulu political organization. The English cricket team, led by former England captain Mike Gatting, has been the target of repeated black protests since arriving last month for a six-week tour that violates the international sports boycott of South Africa. Gatting's team was beaten decisively in a weekend match against the South African national team last week and begins a second match at Newlands on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Billionaire Trump Says He and His Wife Have Gone to Splitsville
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Donald Trump, who amassed a fortune with his name written all over it, wants to call it quits with his wife of 12 years, who has appeared to be a partner in the building of his empire. The owner of the Trump Shuttle airline, Trump Tower skyscraper and Trump casinos has a prenuptial contract giving his wife, Ivana, about $20 million of his reported $1.7 billion worth, according to a statement issued Sunday on behalf of the flamboyant tycoon. She'll also get their 45-room country home in Greenwich, Conn. Trump, 43, told his wife Tuesday before he left for Tokyo that the marriage ``just wasn't working out,'' said the statement. ``Ivana is a wonderful woman and a very good woman and I like her. We might even get back together. I can't say we won't. Who knows what could happen?'' the Daily News quoted Trump as saying. In his statement, Trump denied rumors that he has romanced other women. A comment attributed to the megamillionaire in the New York Post brought up the specter of quite another kind of woman. ``I like Ivana, but we've grown apart,'' the Post quoted him as saying, citing an unidentified ``intimate.'' ``Her level of arrogance has grown steadily worse in recent years,'' Trump said, according to the Post account. ``The bottom line is I don't want to create another Leona Helmsley.'' Ms. Helmsley is the self-styled hotel queen, convicted last year of income tax violations, who has long been accused of arrogance toward underlings. The Czechoslovakian-born Mrs. Trump, a former model and an alternate on her native country's 1972 Olympic ski team, used to manage the Trump Castle casino in Atlantic City, N.J., and has been in charge of renovations at the Plaza Hotel in New York City. When she got the Plaza job, her husband joked that she would be paid ``one dollar plus all the dresses she can buy.'' Trump moved out of the couple's 50-room triplex in Trump Tower following his return from his trip to watch the Mike Tyson-Buster Douglas boxing match, the Post said today. The Daily News reported Sunday that the 40-year-old Mrs. Trump was devastated because her husband was betraying her, but Trump denied that. ``And as for those other women I have been linked with, well, I want to say that we are all just friends and that's as far as it goes,'' he said. The statement did not address which parent would have custody of the couple's three children, Donald Jr., 12, Ivancka, 8, and Eric, 6. Forbes magazine says Trump is worth around $1.7 billion, ranking him 19th on its 1989 list of America's 400 richest people. He is the author of the best-selling ``The Art of the Deal'' and has even lent his name to a syndicated TV quiz show, ``Trump Card.''

DOC.HEAD: World Welcomes Mandela Release, But Cautious on Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with U.S., Soviet, European Community reactions, more Thatcher response. Pick up 9th pvs, `Foreign Minister...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People and their governments rejoiced worldwide at the release of Nelson Mandela, but Britain stood alone today in urging an immediate easing of sanctions to reward South Africa's white rulers. Most others said South African President F.W. de Klerk has a long way to go before apartheid is abolished. People celebrated the news Sunday night in the streets of Toronto and London. In Amsterdam, they draped buses and trams with the flags of his African National Congress. In the United States, which imposes some of the harshest sanctions of any of South Africa's major trading partners, President Bush telephoned Mandela Sunday to congratulate him on his release but said afterward, ``I am not prepared to express my view on sanctions at this time.'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said today that ``together with all countries and peoples we hail the release of Nelson Mandela.'' He said Mandela's release was a ``step that should have been taken long ago,'' and he expressed hope that ``an end would finally be put to the policy of apartheid.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has often argued that strict sanctions hurt South African blacks, stood alone in saying it is now time to use encouragement in South Africa, not sanctions. On Sunday, as Mandela walked free after 27 years in jail, Mrs. Thatcher wrote to fellow leaders of the 12-nation European Community urging a ``more positive'' approach. ``When people are doing the right thing boldly and courageously as President de Klerk is, it seems quite absurd to still use sticks to beat them with, however small those sticks may be,'' she said. But she abruptly canceled a news conference Sunday night at her 10 Downing Street residence after Mandela told a vast crowd in Cape Town that his African National Congress should continue the armed struggle and sanctions should remain in place. Britain intends to press the sanctions issue at a Feb. 20 meeting of group's foreign ministers in Dublin, Ireland. The main sanctions are bans on imports of steel, iron and Krugerrand gold coins. The Nigerian government said Mandela's release was ``positive proof'' that international sanctions are working. In Brussels, European Community leaders indicated today they feel it is still too early to lift the mild economic sanctions the community imposed on South Africa in 1986. EC Development Commissioner Manuel Marin ``believes there can be no question of a lifting of the sanctions now,'' said a community source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Foreign Minister Joe Clark of Canada said his country's sanctions will stay in force until apartheid laws of racial dicrimination are scrapped. In Toronto, crowds danced and cheered at a street party Sunday night to celebrate Mandela's freedom. In London, thousands of well-wishers held a street party Sunday outside the South African Embassy, where anti-apartheid demonstrators had manned a round-the-clock vigil since April 1986 to demand Mandela's release. In Amsterdam, buses and trams carried ANC flags. In the city center, thousands of people marched Sunday to the Leidseplein, renamed Nelson Mandela Square for the day. President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia called on the ANC to suspend guerrilla actions in South Africa but to maintain its military capability in case of violence by right-wing extremists. ``The time for talking has come,'' said Kaunda, whose country plays host to the ANC's exile headquarters and guerrilla bases. But the ANC said in a statement released in Harare that it was not prepared to open talks with the government of South Africa until it lifts a state of emergency, releases all political prisoners, and repeals all apartheid laws of racial segregation. In Harare, Zimbabwe, President Robert Mugabe today hailed Mandela's release but urged Britain and other Western nations not to reduce pressures on the South Africa to end apartheid. Mugabe criticized Mrs. Thatcher for ``too hasty an embrace'' of political changes in South Africa. The Organization of African Unity, based in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, hailed the freeing of Mandela and other political leaders as a ``significant step toward the elimination of apartheid and the establishment of a non-racial and democratic society.'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said Mandela's release was a ``clear turning point'' that would allow South Africa to move toward democracy. Japan is among countries that have imposed sanctions against South Africa. Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa called Mandela a man who devoted his life to realizing the ideal of equality. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Mandela's release and de Klerk's reforms ``mark a turning point in the process for the peaceful settlement of the political situation.'' In Beijing, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said China was ``very happy'' about the release of a man ``respected by all the justice-upholding people the world over,'' the official Xinhua news agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Stom Thurmond, Congress' Oldest Member, Announces for Re-election
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Strom Thurmond, who at 87 is the oldest member of Congress, returned to his hometown today to announce his intention to seek another six years in Congress. ``In all my years of public service, I have never felt a stronger obligation to continue my work for the future of our state and our nation,'' Thurmond told a small crowd of supporters gathered at the Aiken Municipal Airport. Thurmond, who was first elected to the Senate in 1954, briefly laid out his priorities for what would be his seventh term, touching on education, quality of life and the need to protect the environment against hazardous waste and pollution. The lawmaker, who became the oldest member of Congress when Florida Rep. Claude Pepper died last year at the age of 88, indicated his seniority in the Senate would help him better serve his constituents. ``I wouldn't elect a man just because of his seniority, but if he has all the other qualifications then it should be counted, and it is very helpful,'' he said. Thurmond is the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. He made known his plans to seek another term in a letter recently mailed to supporters. In it he said he has ``always looked upon public service as a sacred obligation and a public trust.'' Thurmond, who celebrated his 87th birthday in December, said at the time his secret for a long life is a good diet, exercise and an optimistic outlook. A new term would expire about the time he turns 94. He also said then that he owes it to the people of the state to seek re-election and, ``I might be letting them down if I leave now.'' A former governor, state senator and judge who ran unsuccessfully for president as a Dixiecrat in 1948, Thurmond switched from the Democratic to the Republican parties in 1964. He served as president pro tempore of the U.S. Senate from 1981 through 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Question Ethics of Using Unknowing Welfare Recipients in Study
DOC.TEXT: Experts in ethics are questioning a federal experiment that denies supplemental aid to some indigent people in Texas and four other states to determine how well they can live without it. Extra Medicaid and child-care benefits now go to about 8,000 people in Texas to encourage them to keep new jobs, while about 800 people _ selected at random by birth date _ are excluded as a control or comparison group. On April 1, those extra benefits will be available to more than 50,000 people statewide _ but not to the 800 unlucky Texans who face two more years without the extra help, The Dallas Morning News reported Sunday. The study aims to see how well the new expanded programs wean people off the welfare rolls. Similar experiments are being conducted in Ohio, Washington state, New York and Wisconsin, federal officials told the newspaper last week. Though federal officials say denying the additional benefits to small, so-called control groups is vital to determine whether the new programs work, critics disagree. ``People ought not to be treated like things, even if what you get is good information,'' said Philip Broyle, associate director for medical ethics of the Hastings Center, a New York think tank concerned with the ethics of experiments on people. Broyle said the study violates the kinds of federal standards medical experiments must meet. Those standards include informed consent _ that anyone in an experiment must be aware of it and of all its consequences. And they must have the option to refuse participation. Neither informed consent nor the right of refusal was offered to participants in the welfare study, officials said. The pilot program rewards welfare recipients who find jobs or job training. Traditionally, such recipients have received four months of free medical care, plus some child care, after they leave the welfare rolls. The experimental program extended the benefits to one year of Medicaid coverage and subsidized child care _ to all but the 800. The theory is that the extended benefits will encourage people to take and stay with entry-level jobs that are unlikely to offer medical insurance or child care immediately. And the tax money saved by getting those people off welfare will more than balance the cost of the new program. State officials said last week that they would try to break their contract with the federal government and provide the benefits to the 800. ``We're planning to argue with them,'' said Claudia Langguth, deputy commissioner for the client self-support division of the Texas Department of Human Services. In 1988, Congress decreed that people receiving benefits from Aid to Families with Dependent Children and Medicaid and who get a job or job training would be eligible for the extended benefits beginning April 1, 1990. Texas officials decided they wanted to try offering the new benefits a year early on a small scale. They got federal money for pilot programs in five urban areas but were required to exclude about 10 percent of those eligible _ the control or comparison group _ to see if they stay off welfare without the extra benefits. Federal officials say they were aware of the ethical question involved in the experiment. ``That issue was recognized and considered in the review of the Texas proposal,'' said Sidney Trieger, director of the federal division of health systems and special studies of the Health Care Financing Administration. He is in charge of evaluating the experimental results. ``It was worth proceeding,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Conference On Acid Rain Reviews Decade-Long Assessment
DOC.TEXT: Scientists who have spent the past decade assessing the impact of acid rain on the nation will share their results this week with their counterparts from around the globe. The National Acidic Rain Assessment Program, a consortium of 11 federal agencies, was established 10 years ago by Congress and has spent $500 million investigating the problem. It is holding a conference on Hilton Head Island to review data from the studies. One conclusion likely to provoke controversy at the conference is that acid rain generally isn't harming the nation's forests, said Joseph Barnard, a U.S. Forest Service researcher, who headed the work of forest scientists, The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer said in Saturday editions. The newspaper said it obtained a report expected to be presented at the conference, intended to summarize various scientific studies of acid rain. The report says that ozone does far more damage to trees than acid rain, although acid rain may be harming red spruces in the Appalachians northward to New England. The World Resources Institute, a Washington-based environmental group, disputes the findings, saying ``evidence is unambiguous'' that acid rain and ozone both contribute to the deaths of trees in the South, East and West. According to the newspaper, the report also says that a national survey found that only 4 percent of the nation's lakes and 6 percent of the streams were acidic. Researcher Lawrence Baker of the University of Minnesota said that eventually the soils will be unable to neutralize any more acid. ``The question is, 10, 50, 100 years,'' Baker said. ``There's quite a bit of debate on that.'' Acid rain is a combination of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide that mixes in the atmosphere and can be carried hundreds of miles before falling back to earth as rain, snow, fog and dust particles, affecting aquatic life, trees and humans. Much of the pollution comes from power plants which burn high sulphur coal although other industrial facilities also generate the pollutants. About 1,000 researchers have been at work during the past decade compiling 28 draft studies on the impact of acid rain. ``The whole purpose is to give outsiders a chance to critique the reports. It's a chance to get them out into the broader scientific community,'' said Chuck Herrick, a spokesman for the agency who said the review is probably the most comprehensive ever compiled. Later, information from the technical reports will be integrated into a final document. The computer models will be used to map various emission control strategies. Herrick said ``we will be running 30 scenarios for the future. The assumption then is the policy people will be looking at this and will be able to make their decisions.'' The agency itself is not mandated to make policy decisions, simply provide policy-makers with the best data possible, he added. President Bush unveiled his clean air bill last year _ a measure that would sharply reduce urban smog, toxic chemical air pollution and acid rain by the end of the decade. Bush has called for a 10 million ton reduction in sulfur dioxide _ one of the main ingredients in acid rain _ by the turn of the century. While the administration unveiled its legislation before the agency assessments were released, ``I don't know that the conclusion is that the administration bill is wholly lacking in scientific basis,'' Herrick said. ``Our people were extensively contacted. The argument could be made the bill does have a scientific basis,'' he added. He said 600 scientists from 35 nations are attending the conference, which opened Sunday and continues through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Independent's Foreign Editor Dies of Cancer at 47
DOC.TEXT: Nicholas Ashford, foreign editor of The Independent and a veteran South Africa and Washington correspondent, has died of cancer, the newspaper said today. He was 47. Ashford was appointed foreign editor last year, after serving as deputy foreign editor since the paper was launched in 1986. He became ill last August, when he gave up his weekly column on world affairs, and died Saturday. Ashford was a foreign and diplomatic correspondent for The Times of London before joining The Independent. In a front-page article in today's Independent, friends and colleagues praised him as a dedicated and talented writer and journalist. After a brief stint as a military officer, he began his career at The Middle East News Agency in 1966. He joined The Financial Times in 1967 and moved on to The Times in 1969. He covered southern Africa from 1975 to 1981, then became Washington correspondent until 1985. From 1985 to 1986, he was diplomatic correspondent based in London. Ashford is survived by a daughter from his first marriage, Dominique, and by his second wife, Giuliana.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Celebrate Release of Nelson Mandela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after the 5th to UPDATE with comment today from second Mandela daughter, picking up 6th graf pvs, `In Atlanta...'. SUBS last 2 grafs to delete now-redundant first reference to daughter.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AB1, BX2
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans danced in the streets and in church aisles to celebrate Nelson Mandela's release from a South African prison, but one of his daughters said much work remains before apartheid is abolished. ``This is only the first step, a little step, and we should not forget this,'' Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah said Sunday in Amherst, Mass., where she attends Boston University. ``The battle is not over. It's only starting at a renewed, higher level.'' Activists at events around the country rejoiced that the 71-year-old African National Congress founder was released after 27 years in prison. But many said U.S. sanctions against South Africa must continue until the nation's white-minority rulers grant non-whites basic rights. ``By freeing Nelson Mandela, South Africa has taken the first step toward freeing itself,'' said Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., a powerful black congressman who wrote legislation imposing sanctions. He urged keeping those sanctions in place. ``It's good news, it's welcome news,'' Gray said. ``But the fact is, South Africa remains a state that is not free.'' ``I think progress has to be quick. And I think my father will play a very specific role in bringing about peace in South Africa,'' said another daughter, Boston University student Zenani Mandela-Dlanini. ``He has to be there.'' ``He will work together with the movement,'' she said. ``I am positive about that.'' But she said she was worried about the psychological effect of his release after so long in prison, and about his safety. In Atlanta, Coretta Scott King, widow of slain U.S. civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., said she was overjoyed by the release of Mandela, ``who has shown us the tremendous power of unearned suffering for a just cause.'' ``I sincerely hope that the government and the anti-apartheid movement will continue to embrace the non-violent spirit in their negotiations as they seek a multi-racial democracy based on one person, one vote,'' Mrs. King said in a statement. In Texas, a delegate to the African National Congress compared Mandela's release to another event thought unthinkable just months ago. ``This is like the Berlin Wall,'' Rick Marshall-Greene of San Antonio told a rally at an Austin park attended by nearly 250 people. ``Nelson Mandela is that one brick, the first brick, that is coming out and that will help dismantle that wall'' of apartheid. But Mario Marcel Salas, another ANC delegate living in San Antonio, who like Marshall-Greene is barred from returning to his homeland, said, ``Nelson Mandela has been released, but Nelson Mandela is not free because Nelson Mandela cannot vote in the country where he was born.'' Whites joined blacks at a service at the New Hope Baptist Church in Evansville, Ind. ``It was a great celebration. People danced in the aisles, and we did our best to have a kindred spirit with the people of South Africa,'' the Rev. W.R. Brown Jr. said. Church services also were held in San Francisco and a musical celebration attracted 400 people to a park across the San Francisco Bay in Oakland, Calif. At Rider College in Lawrenceville, N.J., Army Gen. Colin Powell, the first black chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Mandela's release ``was the beginning of the end of apartheid.'' Seattle's first black mayor, Norm Rice, declared Feb. 11 Nelson Mandela Day. New York's first black mayor, David Dinkins, urged Pretoria to fulfill other promises it made earlier this month to replace ``current massive repression in South Africa with truly free political association.'' Hundreds of people danced and sang in the streets of New York City's Harlem section in a spontaneous celebration, while hundreds more crowded the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn for an exuberant service. They shouted and chanted as they watched Mandela begin his first televised address, and raised their arms in a salute as he did when he finished. On the side of the church's television, a sticker saying ``Free Mandela'' had been cut and refigured to say ``Mandela Free.'' In Cambridge, Mass., Patrick Lekota, a former political prisoner who was jailed with Mandela, said he had mixed feelings watching the release. ``In a way I was relieved. His release will bring stability to the movement and strengthen it,'' Lekota said. ``But as I watched him walk down the road, surrounded by police, I had a sudden fear that anything could happen.'' Ms. Mandela-Dlamini attended a church service Sunday night in Boston. She did not speak, but her husband, Thumbuzini Dlamini, told the congregation: ``Today is a very special day for us as members of the Mandela family. A victory has been won by our people.''

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Offers Resignation To Protest Gov't Policies
DOC.TEXT: Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, the chief opponent of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in the right-wing Likud bloc, today offered his resignation from the Cabinet to protest government policies he said endanger Israel. Sharon's surprise move came during a meeting at which he and other hard-line members of the party were expected to challenge Shamir's plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Sharon said he feared compromises would be made to end the Palestinian uprising that would jeopardize Israel's right to keep the occupied lands, which the Likud considers part of historic Israel. ``I know and am convinced that there are other ways to quell this terror,'' he said. ``We can make peace based on our historic right to the Land of Israel.'' ``I decided to resign from the government to continue my struggle for reaching our national objectives which are now endangered as a result of the government's policy,'' he said. As Sharon spoke, the more than 2,000 delegates to the Likud's Central Committee meeting rose from their chairs and several hundred began chanting ``Arik! Arik!'' Sharon's nickname. Shamir, who spoke after Sharon, received scattered boos as he began his speech by saying he would consider his offer to resign. It was not clear what the immediate effect of Sharon's announcement would be.
