Akiva Eldar, a political commentator for the daily Haaretz, said on Israel television that Sharon may have made the move merely to strengthen his position with the Central Committee. Sharon, who was defense minister during Israel's unpopular 1982 invasion of Lebanon, said he would resign only from the Cabinet, not from his party post as head of the Central Committee. Before the meeting, opinion surveys in Israeli newspapers showed Shamir was expected to easily overcome Sharon's challenge at the party meeting. The prime minister said he wanted a clear decision from the party's nearly 3,200 Central Committee members on his peace moves. ``I don't see any reason for a compromise,'' Shamir said on Israel radio. Shamir has threatened to resign unless he gets majority approval. His opponents, led by Sharon, want to vote on details of the election plan in order to block possible compromises urged by the United States as a way to start an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been pushing since December for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue to get the stalled peace process rolling again, but his efforts have been blocked by the Likud's squabbling over tactics. Shamir's plan, approved by the Cabinet last May amid international pressure on Israel to quiet the uprising, calls for electing Palestinians to negotiate a temporary peace with Israel. Later talks would decide the final status of the West Bank and Gaza. In the occupied Gaza Strip, meanwhile, a general strike was declared in Gaza City following the death of a 15-year-old Palestinian from wounds he suffered in a clash with Israeli soldiers Sunday night, Arab reporters said. The army confirmed the death but said it was still investigating. The death raised to 656 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 26-month uprising. Forty-three Israelis have died, and 181 Palestinians who were killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Says It Is Seeking Investor or Merger Partner
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said today it is in preliminary talks to find a major investor or merger partner after falling on hard times because of its criminal troubles and the slumping junk-bond market. In a statement, Drexel said senior members of the firm had concluded it should seek outside assistance. ``The unsettled markets, particularly in the high-yield area, have adversely affected the liquidity of our parent corporation, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group,'' Drexel said. The closely held Wall Street firm said the parent company had a condolidated net worth of more than $800 million. It said the securities business subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., ``continues to have good liquidity and has satisfactory excess regulatory capital.'' Drexel said it is ``taking appropriate action to maximize liquidity,'' but did not elaborate. Drexel reported a loss of about $40 million for last year, in which it pleaded guilty to six felonies and paid $650 million to the federal government to settle wide-ranging securities fraud charges and avoid a trial. The firm had been battered by the charges in the government's lengthy investigation of Wall Street securities fraud. The probe now focuses on the former head of Drexel's highly productive high-yield ``junk bond'' division, Michael Milken, who is under indictment. Back before Drexel's troubles mushroomed, Milken was reported to reported to have received $550 million in total compensation in one single year, 1987. Drexel also was hard hit by the collapse of the nation's $210 billion junk bond market last fall, following the collapse of a takeover deal for United Airlines' parent, UAL Corp. The market has yet to recover, and Drexel had to write down the value of its junk-bond portfolio. Drexel, which pioneered the use of the high-yield, low-grade securities, remains the leader of the junk-bond market and as such has been hit harder than other Wall Street firms by the market's slump. The firm has reduced its work force to about 5,300 employees from a peak of 10,700. It also sold its retail brokerage business last year. ``The past year has been an extraordinarily difficult one for us and our employees,'' Drexel said in announcing the 1989 loss. Drexel had long been rumored on Wall Street to be in serious financial difficulty and seeking an outside investor or partner. Such a move would conclude one of the most dramatic turnarounds in Wall Street history. Drexel was the emblem of the high-flying, takeover-driven 1980s and the firm made a profit of $522.5 million on revenue of $5.3 billion in 1986. The firm earned more than $400 million in 1987 and reported a loss of $166.7 million in 1988, which include a charge to cover the $650 million payment to the government.

DOC.HEAD: Three Suspected Robbers Killed in Police Shootout At Calif. McDonald's
DOC.TEXT: Four robbers leaving a McDonald's after tying up the manager were confronted by nine police officers early today, resulting in a gun battle in which three thieves were killed and one wounded, officials said. Elsewhere, a customer arriving at a McDonald's in Texas was killed when a robber shot him in the back. None of the officers involved in the northern Los Angeles shootout was injured. The gun battle occurred at about 1:30 a.m. in the neigborhood of Sunland, 15 miles north of downtown, said police Lt. William Hall. The robbers had been followed by undercover officers investigating a rash of McDonald's restaurant robberies, Hall said. Police said the restaurant was closed but the thieves broke in and confronted the manager. ``There was a female manager inside all alone,'' Hall said. ``The doors were locked. We don't know how they got in, but she didn't let them in. They tied her up and forced her to provide the combination to the safe.'' The unidentified manager wasn't hurt. The wounded bandit was taken to Holy Cross Hospital, where a nursing supervisor wouldn't give a condition report. In Texas, a Houston teen-ager was fatally wounded late Saturday when he and two friends interrupted a late-night robbery at a McDonald's, authorities said. Leshon Reagins, 15, died Sunday. Police said Reagins and two friends entered the McDonald's and one went to the restroom while Reagins and the other friend went to the counter to order. But they found no one behind the counter or in the customer seating areas. Police said that when Reagins' friend yelled for service, a man armed with a pistol and wearing a mask emerged and told the teen-agers to leave. While the two boys fled, the suspect fired one shot, hitting Reagins in the back, said homicide Lt. Dale Atchetee. Three armed robbers had rounded up about 10 people, most of them employees, and forced them to lie on the floor in the back of the restaurant, police said. The bandits took an undetermined amount of money and fled in a car driven by a fourth person, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Escape from Maximum-Security Joliet, Ill., Prison; One Recaptured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with search concentrating on Chicago area, picking up at the 7th graf pvs, `State police...'.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities today searched the Chicago area for five convicts, including three murderers, who apparently cut through two sets of bars and crossed a fence to escape from a maximum-security state prison. A sixth escapee from the overcrowded Joliet Correctional Center was recaptured in Chicago late Sunday, about 12 hours after the break, state prison spokesman Nic Howell said. The inmates apparently cut through bars on their cells, broke a window, cut through bars outside the window and crossed a fence to get away _ all without being detected, Howell said. ``We're questioning inmates and security guards to find out if this was a planned thing,'' he said. ``Obviously, this was a serious breach of security. It may be a while before all our questions are answered.'' Howell said Tommy Munoz of Chicago was captured around 5:30 p.m. by prison authorities who had staked out a cousin's house on the southwest side of the city, some 60 miles east of the prison. Munoz was returned to the prison, where he was serving a two-year sentence for narcotics violations and intimidation, Howell said. ``One down, five to go,'' Howell said. ``We've got a bunch of leads. We're checking out everything and anything that might be worth counting.'' The five others were believed to have headed to the Chicago area because they also have ties there, Howell said. Munoz provided few clues to the escape, Howell said in a telephone interview today. ``We've questioned him thoroughly and he hasn't been very helpful at all,'' the spokesman said. State police, local law enforcement agencies and 100 corrections officers specially trained to deal with escapes joined the search, he said. Searches of the prison area with airplanes, helicopters and dogs were called off late Sunday afternoon after officials determined the escapees had split up, state Trooper Thomas Miller said. Howell said the men were last accounted for at 4:55 a.m. Sunday and an inmate count did not come up short until 7 a.m. The men escaped from segregation cells, where they were kept because of disciplinary problems, he said. Four of the men were doubled up, two to a cell, and the other two each had his own cell. The prison houses 1,300 inmates, 500 more than it was built to hold. The escapees still at large, whom Howell described as ``extremely dangerous,'' were identified as: _Daniel Johnson, 24, of Buru, Tenn., imprisoned for murder. _James F. Allen, 40, of Chicago, imprisoned for three murders. _Dave Rodriguez, 21, of Chicago, imprisoned for murder. _Terry W. Colburn, 21, of Bloomington, Ill., imprisoned for burglary. _Ronald Roach, in his 20s, of Wyoming, Ill., imprisoned for burglary.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Fraud Trial Begins For Tennessee Congressman
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began today for the federal bank fraud trial of U.S. Rep. Harold Ford, one of Tennessee's most controversial and flamboyant politicians, and three co-defendants. Ford said he was optimistic when he arrived at the federal courthouse for the trial, beginning almost three years after he was indicted on 19 counts of conspiracy, bank and mail fraud. ``I feel like the day looks outside. It's beautiful,'' Ford said, refusing to comment further. The congressman and his co-defendants are charged with conspiring to funnel political payoffs to Ford through bogus loans from lending institutions once run by former Tennessee bankers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr., both serving prison terms on other charges. The government says Ford drew more than $1 million in loans from Butcher banks, though the amount of money the congressman allegedly received is unclear since some loans outlined in the indictment apparently were used to pay off others. Ford, a Democrat and Tennessee's first and only black member of Congress, is credited with running a political machine that can deliver the black vote in Memphis. He is accused of selling that influence to the Butchers for their political and business gain. He has faced little or no opposition for his 9th Congressional District seat since he was first elected to Congress in 1974. Ford, charged with conspiracy, bank and mail fraud, could be sent to prison for up to 95 years if convicted on all 19 counts against him The trial is expected to last as long as two months. The Butcher brothers once controlled a business empire that included some 40 banks and savings and loans but both are now serving 20-year prison sentences for bank fraud. C.H. Butcher Jr. has pleaded guilty to two counts in the Ford indictment. Jake Butcher, who ran unsuccessfully for governor of Tennessee in 1974 and 1978, was listed as an unindicted co-conspirator in the Ford indictment. Ford has argued since his indictment that racism and politics are behind his legal troubles, that he was indicted by a grand jury in Knoxville rather than Memphis because eastern Tennessee is heavily Republican and primarily white. Memphis, Ford's hometown, is 50 percent black. Ford failed to carry that argument in pre-trial motions and the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati refused to consider it before trial. The trial was moved to Memphis from Knoxville at Ford's request. Ford's co-defendants are accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz. They are all charged with bank fraud and mail fraud conspiracy. In addition, Schledwitz and Beaty face 15 counts of mail fraud and Crabtree is charged in four mail fraud counts.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Renews Talks on European Troop Cuts After Week of Busy Diplomacy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Baker's remarks today. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that U.S. differences with Moscow on troops and aircraft still stand in the way of completing an arms limitation treaty this year. Baker, opening an East-West ``Open Skies'' conference, said that after his talks last week with Soviet leaders, other key issues are closer to being resolved. But he criticized President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for rejecting a proposal by President Bush that would give the United States an edge of 30,000 troops over the Red Army in Europe. Gorbachev has proposed equal limits of 225,000 or 195,000 soldiers. Baker said that does not take into account the fact that the Soviets could quickly expand their forces in a crisis while American troops would be an ocean away. Baker also criticized the Soviets' resistance to imposing ceilings on aircraft that Moscow claims have a defense role. This was ``hardly a step toward arms reduction,'' Baker said. Raising the prospect of an impasse, Baker said ``disagreements over aircraft limits must not prevent us from signing a CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) sgreement this year.'' Baker's appearance at the conference capped a week of high-profile and apparently successful European diplomacy. He is here sounding out NATO allies on how to shape an accord with Moscow to withdraw a half-million U.S. and Soviet troops from the continent. The United States and Soviet Union now stand on the brink of treaties to slash their chemical weapons and long-range nuclear missiles. If the talks with allies and a session today with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze pan out, the differences between Bush and Gorbachev on troop cuts can be worked out. U.S. officials said Baker was ``neutral'' about Gorbachev's approach, which he lauded last week in Moscow, and the allies took no immediate stand. Other administration sources said the Bush administration had not decided on a position among the State Department, Pentagon and National Security Council. An agreement on a troop ceiling would set the stage for a treaty later this year between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact alliances to remove about 400,000 Soviet and 100,000 American soldiers from Europe. Bush proposed in his State of the Union speech on Jan. 31 a ceiling of 225,000 U.S. and Soviet soldiers each on foreign soil in Europe with no more than 195,000 in central Europe. Gorbachev countered at a Kremlin meeting with Baker that the 195,000 ceiling should apply from the Atlantic to the Ural Mountains inside the Soviet Union. That would mean the 30,000 troops Bush wants to keep in Belgium, Britain, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain or Turkey _ all NATO allies _ would be withdrawn, or U.S. forces would be reduced in central Europe to reach the lower figure. Otherwise, Gorbachev said he would accept the 225,000 ceiling but without restrictions in central Europe. That could benefit the Soviets. Since most of their troops _ about 385,000 in East Germany alone _ are in Central Europe, the Soviets would be able to keep 30,000 more soldiers in the central region than the Bush plan allows. Baker told Gorbachev he could not give him an answer until he consulted with the 15 NATO allies. The two-day Ottawa conference already was scheduled to consider unarmed aerial surveillance and other techniques for exchanging military data between NATO and Warsaw Pact countries. The U.S. reply is unlikely to be announced before Baker's departure for Washington on Tuesday night. The talks in Moscow paid off with an agreement that Bush and Gorbachev would sign in Washington in June providing for the destruction of all their chemical weapons in 10 years _ if all other nations capable of making poison gas sign a treaty. That represents a Soviet concession. Bush wants the right to retain 2 percent of the U.S. poison gas arsenal until all other producers approve the treaty. Also, Shevardnadze withdrew a demand to limit all foreign forces stationed in Europe to 300,000 or 350,000. That means the U.S. allies could keep their troops in other Western countries even after the United States met a treaty ceiling. On the strategic weapons front, meanwhile, Baker's trip cleared up questions about exchanging data from missile tests and how to identify which warplanes are carrying air-launched cruise missiles. An unexpected breakthrough was reached on sea-launched cruise missiles. The two sides agreed there is no reliable way to keep track of the weapon, which can be carried on submarines and aboard warships. Therefore, they decided to keep it out of the treaty and make separate statements about their arsenals. This removed a major roadblock to completing the treaty to reduce long-range missiles by 30 percent to 50 percent in time for Bush and Gorbachev to sign at their summit in Washington. Between his talks in Moscow and the East-West conference in Ottawa, Baker detoured over the weekend to Bulgaria and Romania, where he exhorted government leaders to hold free and fair elections.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Protestant Politician Dead at 50
DOC.TEXT: Harold McCusker, a schoolteacher who became prominent in Northern Ireland politics, died in a hospital Monday after a 16-year battle with cancer, his family announced. He was 50. McCusker was a member of the British Parliament for 16 years, representing the Official Unionists, the mainstream Protestant party in Northern Ireland. He was party deputy leader from 1982. The diminutive, bespectacled politician was an eloquent speaker and campaigner for tougher measures against the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to rid Northern Ireland of British rule. Like most Northern Ireland Protestants, McCusker fervently opposed the 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement that gave the Irish Republic a say in running the province. He served a four-day jail sentence in January 1987 for not paying the annual $75 car tax in protest of the accord. But he later became critical of older colleagues for failing to come up with an alternative to the Anglo-Irish pact, and co-authored ``An End to Drift,'' an influential analysis of ways out of the impasse. McCusker is survived by his wife, Jennifer, and sons, Moore, James and Colin.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Commission to Discuss Allegations About China
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people remain in prison eight months after China's army crushed the pro-democracy movement, and authorities continue to carry out arrests, torture and executions, a U.N. document alleged Monday. The allegations appear in reports included in the document given the Human Rights Commission by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The commission is to consider human rights in China during its current six-week session, which began Jan. 29. A letter from the Chinese government that is part of the 29-page document said authorities showed ``utmost tolerance and restraint in the face of illegal demonstrations'' and described China's actions as ``justified and legitimate.'' Ambassador Li Luye, who signed the letter, said nearly 300 people were killed in the attack June 3-4 on Tiananmen Square, including members of the armed forces, and ``besides ruffians, a small number of onlookers were shot accidentally, which is regrettable.' Some unofficial estimates put the number of unarmed civilians killed by soldiers in the thousands. In August, a U.N. panel of experts instructed Perez de Cuellar to ``transmit ... information provided by the government of China and by other reliable sources'' to the Human Rights Commission. One reports in the document is from Amnesty International, the human rights group based in London. Despite the lifting of martial law Jan. 10, it said, China has not announced pardons for thousands of people imprisoned for taking part in pro-democracy demonstrations. ``There have been further arbitrary arrests, and prisoners continue to be detained incommunicado without charge or trial, imprisoned or executed after unfair trials,'' Amnesty said. Tens of thousands of people have been arrested since June, up to 10,000 of them in Beijing alone, the organization declared. Official reports put the number of detainees throughout China at about 10,000. Amnesty estimated at least 1,000 people were killed and thousands injured when soldiers moved into Tiananmen Square. Another report, from the International Commission of Health Professionals for Health and Human Rights, gave graphic details of descriptions by witnesses of protestors being ``crushed by tanks into paste'' during the June 4 massacre. A third private group, the International League for Human Rights, accused China of the ``systematic terrorizing of much of Beijing's population'' and ``purging'' of those considered sympathetic to the pro-democracy movement. ``Chinese justifications of its actions are invalid,'' the league said. It argued that the suppression flouted international law, and thus was not the internal matter Beijing claimed. Luye, China's permanent representative to the United Nations, accused ``a small number of Western countries'' of violating the U.N. charter by interfering in domestic affairs. ``The so-called Tiananmen bloodbath is sheer fabrication,'' his letter said. ``The Chinese government's actions to put an end to the turmoil and quell the rebellion were justified and legitimate.'' China is the first permanent member of the Security Council referred to the Human Rights Commission for alleged abuses. Forty-three delegates from governments serve on the commission. Its annual sessions are attended representatives of most other U.N. member states and nearly 150 private human rights groups.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Dealer to Run for Congress
DOC.TEXT: Auto dealer Steve Tatone said Monday he will seek the Democratic nomination for the congressional seat held by Michael DeWine, who is running for lieutenant governor. Tatone, 34, will join Jack Schira, a retired Air Force officer from Springfield, as Democratic candidates for the 7th Congressional District seat. State Sen. David Hobson of Springfield is the only announced Republican candidate. DeWine, a Republican from Cedarville, is running for lieutenant governor on a ticket headed by former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich. Schira said the May 8 Democratic primary will be a ``doozy.'' ``I feel he's going to bring big money into it. It's not clear where he stands on the issues yet,'' Schira said. Tatone already has announced that he agreed to give up management of one of his two dealerships. Tatone, who has four children, said one challenge for his campaign will be to get voters to look at him as a political candidate instead of a businessman. Tatone said his campaign intends to address the federal budget deficit and the plight of the hungry and the homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers and Crew Survive Plane Crash in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: An airliner with 39 people aboard crashed after a failed takeoff attempt today and smashed into a car near the airstrip, killing a woman and her young son, authorities said. Most of the 36 passengers and three crew members suffered only minor injuries. The Fokker twin-engine turboprop, which belonged to TAM Regional Airlines, crashed at 9:40 a.m. as it tried to land in the southeastern city of Bauru, 220 miles from Sao Paulo, TAM spokesman Luiz Carlos Franco said. The plane failed to gain altitude as it tried to take off, said Maria Dalva, head of the news department of Bauru's Auri Verde radio station. ``As the plane came in for an emergency landing on an empty plot of land near the airport it smashed into a station wagon, killing a 29-year-old woman and her 4-year-old-son,'' said Dr. Cesar Carvalho, director of the Bauru Municipal Hospital. The plane also hit and damaged two unoccupied houses. Its wings and engines burst into flames but the fuselage remained intact, Ms. Dalva said. About 30 firemen and policemen quickly extinguished the flames. Most of the passengers and crew members walked away from the accident and only a few had to be carried on stretchers, she said. The pilot was in the hospital's intensive care unit with serious injuries and the co-pilot had a fractured spine, Carvalh said. Some passengers were released after being treated for minor scrapes and bruises.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, the Public Man, Tries to Rebuild a Private Life
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: If the roaring crowds and the journalists go away, Nelson Mandela finally may have some time with the wife and children who sustained him through 27 years in prison. Mandela, freed Sunday, appears to enjoy the spotlight and remains devoted to the African National Congress and its battle against white supremacy. He would rather talk about politics than his feelings, but said his family was his source of strength during the ``long and lonely years.'' ``I have lost a great deal over these 27 years,'' he told reporters Monday. ``It is not a nice feeling for a man to see his family struggling without security, without the dignity of the head of the family around.'' In a speech Sunday night, Mandela said of his family: ``I am convinced that your pain and suffering was far greater than my own.'' The black nationalist leader went to prison in 1962, four years after marrying Winnie, his second wife. They have two grown daughters _ Zenani, who studies at Boston University with her husband, Prince Thumbumuzi Dlamini of Swaziland; and Zindzi, 29, an unmarried mother of three who lives with Mrs. Mandela in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg. Mandela also has a son, Makgatho, and a daughter, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, by his 13-year first marriage, which ended in divorce in 1957. Makgatho is a businessman in the Transkei tribal homeland in the southeast, where his mother, Evelyn, lives in retirement from a nursing career. Mrs. Mandela-Amuah lives with her husband and children in the United States, where she studies at Amherst College in Massachussetts. His wife and other relatives were with Mandela at his first news conference, conducted on the lawn of Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu's home while some of the 12 Mandela grandchildren splashed in the swimming pool. The Mandelas stayed with Tutu on Sunday night, and after the news conference flew to Johannesburg, where they hope to live in the small house in Soweto they had shared for a few years. During the meeting with reporters, Mandela said he is not bitter about his imprisonment. He even had kind words for his jailers, one of whom was specifically assigned to look after him. ``They understand our point of view and tried to do everything to make you as happy as possible,'' Mandela said. ``That has wiped out any bitterness a man could have.'' When things are quieter, Mandela said, he wants to visit Qunu, the Transkei village where he was raised. ``I long to see the little stones on which I played as a child, the rivers where I swam,'' said Mandela, whose father was a member of the Tembu royal clan of the Xhosa tribe. He was unfazed by finding more than 100 journalists in Tutu's gardens or by their dozens of questions, which he handled with composure as Mrs. Mandela sat silently beside him, wearing a print turban and white, floor-length dress. Mandela expressed humility about the huge outpouring of support when he was freed. ``I am completely overwhelmed by the enthusiasm,'' he said. ``I am unable to describe my emotions,'' he said. Asked whether he had persuaded the government to make recent concessions to blacks, Mandela declared: ``It would be most presumptuous of me to think that I've had any influence on government policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Daughter's Plight Moves Lawmaker to Enter AIDS Debate
DOC.TEXT: Until three years ago, a state legislator from the Appalachian hills of eastern Kentucky says he never gave much thought to AIDS, assuming his family and friends were immune from a disease that he considered a big-city problem. State Rep. Paul Mason's sense of security ended abruptly when his daughter, Belinda Mason, contracted the AIDS virus through a blood transfusion in 1987. His daughter's plight spurred the used car salesman from Whitesburg to action, putting him on the front lines of a fight to promote AIDS education, prevent discrimination and curb the spread of the disease. ``It really wasn't a part of my world,'' Mason said. ``You're sitting in middle class America and AIDS is just not a part of your world. Now it's something I live with every waking moment.'' After learning of his daughter's affliction, Mason said, his apathy turned to anger. He was bitter at the blood donor and health care officials. ``You want to go after somebody with your bare hands,'' Mason said. ``I'm not sure I'll ever be able to look at my daughter ... and forgive him (blood donor). Nobody has a right to steal part of me.'' But Mason has learned to channel his emotions in another direction. The 1988 General Assembly enacted his bill to make it illegal to use blood for transfusions before the blood is tested for AIDS contamination. This year, Mason introduced sweeping AIDS legislation to foster a greater understanding of AIDS and to wipe out discrimination. ``When she contracted it there was a world of discrimination out there and a lot in the health care field because everyone was scared,'' he said. ``In the health care field, I have seen a world of change in attitude.'' Mason removed the proposal's two most controversial sections. One would have allowed a murder charge to be brought against a person who knowingly gives an uninformed sexual partner AIDS, resulting in the partner's death. The second would have allowed the state Cabinet for Human Resources to obtain court orders to detain people infected with sexually transmitted diseases in hospitals. The bill still would require extensive education programs for state and local agencies and mandatory AIDS training for health professionals. It also would give AIDS patients the same legal protections as handicapped people. Ms. Mason, 31, who was appointed by President Bush last year to the National Commission on AIDS, said her father's bill symbolizes the type of government action needed to assist AIDS patients. ``We have to stop relying on people's good manners and have some solid legal guidelines on how to treat people'' infected with the AIDS virus, she said. Mason said his bill stems from watching his daughter, who lives in Hartford, Ky., fight discrimination. Ms. Mason said much of her father's bill ``came two years too late for me,'' but is intended to protect other AIDS patients from encountering the same hostility and hardships. ``What my dad has attempted to do is to make the road for people who come after me easier,'' said Ms. Mason, who found out in October that her infection has developed into AIDS. ``He wasn't doing it just for his child,'' but for the countless others who have contracted the disease, she said. Ms. Mason said people suffering from the disease are engaged in the same fight as blacks, women and other minority groups in seeking to end discrimination. She is treated well when she visits home in Letcher County, in the heart of Appalachia, her father said. But other AIDS victims have encountered discrimination there, he said. One Letcher County man who is fighting AIDS has concealed his ailment from friends and neighbors, telling them he's suffering from another disease because he fears being ostracized, Mason said. ``That kind of points up the need for education and dissemination of information,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Trial Off Two Weeks, Reagan Deposition on as Planned
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today delayed the start of John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial by two weeks but said he will proceed with plans to take former President Reagan's videotaped deposition Friday in Los Angeles. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene said that ``hopefully'' Reagan's testimony can be taken in a courtroom of the federal courthouse in Los Angeles. The judge rejected a suggestion by the ex-president's lawyers that the deposition be taken in a building in Los Angeles where Reagan has offices. One of Poindexter's lawyers, Richard Beckler, had urged Greene to put off taking Reagan's testimony until the middle of the trial after Iran-Contra prosecutors have presented their case. ``I am not going to buy that; we are going to proceed,'' said Greene. Seven news organizations applied to the court for permission to attend the videotaped deposition. They are Cable News Network, Capital Cities-ABC Inc., CBS Inc., National Broadcasting Co., The New York Times Co., Times Mirror Co. of Los Angeles and The Washington Post. The judge said he will rule before Friday on their request, but he said he was ``doubtful that the press could be there'' in view of concerns over the possibility of disclosing classified information during the deposition. Such material would be edited out of the videotape before it is shown in court at Poindexter's trial. Greene said he is delaying the start of the trial until March 5 to resolve a number of issues, including disagreement concerning some 150 classified documents that Poindexter, a former national security adviser to Reagan, wants to use at his trial. Regarding the disputes over classified material, the judge will have to rule on whether the documents are necessary for the former national security adviser to get a fair trial. If Greene rules that they are necessary and if U.S. intelligence agencies refuse to allow their declassification, the Poindexter trial could be placed in jeopardy. As past Iran-Contra cases have shown it is not unusual to have unresolved last-minute disputes over the use of classified material. There were repeated disputes over the use of such material before and during the trial of former National Security Council staffer Oliver North.

DOC.HEAD: Milk From Papal Dairy Herd is Selling Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 8th pvs, `The farm...' to note that Castel Gandolfo is pope'e holiday residence; picks up 9th pvs, `The farm...' SUBS grafs 18-21, `The milk ...million surplus' with four grafs to restore dropped first reference, clarify surplus; picks up 22nd graf: But does ...
DOC.TEXT: It's not a magic elixir that builds strong souls and guarantees immunity from sin. But the milk produced by the pope's dairy herd must certainly taste like heaven. Each morning, a truck with Vatican license plates delivers 120 cartons of the milk to three local coffee bars. Within hours, they're sold out. ``We don't have enough to meet the demand,'' said the waitress at Mirko's Bar on Via Garibaldi who gives here name only as Manuela. ``It sells like hot cakes.'' Milk from holy cows? Actually, it comes from 30 black-and-white Holsteins on a small farm inside the walled compound of the 17th century papal palace. Until recently, this thriving dairy operation was the least-known of the public services offered by the Vatican, which also runs a postal service and pharmacy in Vatican City in the heart of Rome. The farm at Castel Gandolfo, the pope's hilltown holiday residence, covers about 60 acres on the palace grounds and is surrounded by pine, cypress and olive trees. In addition to milk, the farm produces eggs, olive oil and other products for distribution at the Vatican market, open only to Vatican employees and their families. The farm has been operating since 1933, but the sale of milk to the public began only six years ago. The cows produce 130 gallons of milk a day, most of which is transported to the Vatican market, and the remaining 31 gallons to the three cafes. Few people outside of Castel Gandolfo knew about the milk operation until the Rome newspaper Il Messaggero recently published an article entitled ``The Pope's Milk, How Tasty.'' Since then, people have been traveling 15 miles from Rome to sample the product at the two bars in Castel Gandolfo and one in nearby Albano. The milk comes in distinctive yellow and white cartons with the label ``Fattoria Ville Pontificie,'' meaning the Pontifical Villa Farm. ``Our regular customers are getting upset because there's not enough left for them any more,'' said Manuela, as she served up a capuccino with steamed Vatican milk. ``They're asking us to put aside cartons for them.'' One client, Rita Grecco, said she is taking no chances. ``I buy two or three liters every day,'' she said. ``I used to come in the afternoons, but now I have to come early every morning.'' The bar also receives 30 cartons of milk a day from another supplier but usually manages to sell only five of them, Manuela said. Price is not a factor. Both brands cost the same, about $1.10 dollars a liter. Even before its popularity reached outside the area, the locals put their faith in the Vatican milk when they were looking for products free of contamination following the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster. The milk was considered safe because the cows were kept inside their barns and fed hay and fodder that had been stored in protective silos, said Saviero Petrillo, director of the papal village. ``There was a much greater demand, especially from mothers with young children,'' he said. ``Today, in an era when there's a lot of emphasis on ecology and the environment, people are more conscious of products that are healthy and genuine.'' Vatican services seem to have a special allure for Italians and foreigners, who view the tiny city-state as a rock of efficiency in a land often associated with confusion and chaos. Many post their mail at the Vatican, knowing they can cut days, even weeks off the delivery time of a letter abroad. In 1988, the Vatican post office helped give the city-state a $13 million surplus. But does the Vatican's milk taste better than others? Some customers swear it does. ``It's creamier,'' said Mrs. Grecco. Vatican officials avoid comparisons, although they stress the cleanliness of the plant and the fact that the milk comes from a single herd. ``We have no secret formula,'' said Giuseppe Bellapadrona, who runs the farm. ``We just put the emphasis on quality.''

DOC.HEAD: Sanctions Law Set Out Rules for Ending Them
With AM-US-South Africa Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. sanctions against South Africa were imposed in 1986 when Congress enacted them, along with specific criteria for ending them, over then-President Reagan's veto. The sanctions would be lifted automatically if President Bush reported to Congress that the South African government had: _ Freed African National Congress chief Nelson Mandela and all other political prisoners. _ Repealed its declared state of emergency and freed all those detained under it. _ Legalized democratic political parties and political activity for all. _ Repealed the Group Areas Act and the Population Registration Act, which restrict where non-whites can live and work. _ Agreed to enter into good-faith negotiations with representative black leaders without preconditions. In addition, the president was empowered to suspend or modify any of the sanctions 30 days after reporting to Congress that Mandela and other prisoners had been freed, that three of the other four conditions had been met and that the government had made ``substantial progress'' toward dismantling apartheid and setting up a non-racial democracy. If Congress disagreed with the president's certification, it could head off any change in the sanctions by passing a joint resolution, which would then be subject to a presidential veto and override fight if both sides chose a confrontation over the issue. The law set immediate goals of encouraging South Africa to lift its declared state of emergency, free political prisoners, permit free political activity and establish a timetable for ending apartheid. It also called for establishment of democratic rule in the long term but did not lay out criteria for judging how that goal was being met. Among specific sanctions imposed were: _ A ban on the importation from South Africa of agricultural products, textiles, uranium and uranium ore, iron, steel and coal. _ Prohibition of South African airlines from operating in the United States, and barring of any U.S. airliner from taking off and landing in South Africa. _ A ban on importation of articles made by South African government-controlled organizations, with the exception of certain strategic minerals. _ An end to new U.S. loans to South African businesses or to the government, and an end to new U.S. private investments in South Africa. _ The shutdown of U.S. oil exports to South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: New Surge Of Oil On California Shore Threatens Wildlife Refuge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with large amoung of oil warshing ashore, new threat to state beach, wildlife refuge. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `The accident...'.
DOC.TEXT: A massive 2-inch-thick blanket of crude oil spilled by the tanker American Trader moved ashore today, invading a 2-mile stretch of beach near an environmentally sensitive wildlife refuge. A 200-member cleanup crew was dispatched to the fouled beach before dawn in an effort to mop up the black goo in what authorities called the most serious beach pollution since the 400,000-gallon spill last Wednesday. ``We got hit with more oil overnight than we have in this whole process. We got the biggest hit at Bolsa Chica State Beach,'' said Tony Kozlowski, spokesman for the cleanup coordinators British Petroleum, which chartered the tanker. The wildlife refuge, a wetlands area used by thousands of migratory birds and by fish, lies behind the state beach. There are not many migrating birds there this time of year, but officials fear an invasion of oily water could foul the area for months. In addition to the 30-foot-wide, 2-inch-thick slick on Bolsa Chica, the Coast Guard said smaller ribbons of oil 4-feet-wide were reported near the Huntington Beach Pier. Cleanup activities at Bolsa Chica were suspended briefly when workers began complaining of headaches and nausea from the oily fumes. The workers were back on the beach by dawn. Meanwhile, there was still no decision on when the 811-foot American Trader would be moved from its offshore mooring two miles offshore to Long Beach Harbor for cargo unloading and repairs. Scuba divers applied temporary patches to two holes in the punctured hull Sunday and authorities said the vessel passed ``watertight integrity'' tests, said Coast Guard Petty Officer 3rd Class Kristine Johnson. However, the vessel cannot be moved until it passes inspection for cleanliness and other pollution standards, she said. She estimated that the vessel could be moved no earlier than Tuesday, but other officials said an attempt to dock it could be made later today. Plans called for moving the vessel into an Arco dock to deliver the remainder of the cargo and to make permanent repairs, Coast Guard Capt. Jim Card said Sunday. Cleanup crews reported that the oil slick that coated 14 miles of shore with gooey muck was shrinking. One-third of the Alaskan crude still menaced the coast, staining sand as far north as Long Beach. Before today's oily onslaught, Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt described the cleanup as ``impressive,'' but cautioned, ``It's too soon to declare a victory _ there's 131,000 gallons of oil in the water.'' The American Trader's fouled No. 1 tank was to be cleaned before the Coast Guard gave clearance for the ship to dock for cargo delivery and permanent repairs. ``The tanks must be clean. You don't want it to be like a snail, leaving a trail of oil,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer 2nd Class Dennis Hall. On Sunday morning, divers temporarily repaired the hull of the tanker using prefabricated steel, plywood and water-resistant foam, Kozlowski said. The oil leaked from the vessel Wednesday after it apparently punctured itself twice on its own anchor while mooring in shallow water at an offshore oil pipeline. The accident remained under investigation. The Coast Guard said drug and alcohol tests on the ship's officers, including Capt. Robert Laware, were negative. National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration data showed 23 percent of the spilled crude had been skimmed or picked up at sea as an oil-water mixture while 43 percent had evaporated or naturally dissipated. The unrecovered 34 percent had spread out on the water as a thin sheen and was nearly impossible to retrieve, Meidt said. ``We've reached the point where skimming is of limited value,'' Meidt said, though skimming will continue for several more days in areas where the slick appears most concentrated. On the beaches, 415 cleanup workers were assembled by British Petroleum. Kozlowski couldn't say how long they'd be there. The state Department of Fish and Game reported 48 birds have been killed; British Petroleum officials put the number at 44 and said 126 birds were under care after cleaning. Two dead, oil-soaked seals and one sea lion also were recovered, but it wasn't known if their deaths were linked to the oil spill, Fish and Game officials said. Calm seas and light breezes continue to help the cleanup effort. ``We've been blessed with good weather in this whole process, but rain or high wind or choppy water could cause problems,'' Kozlowski said. ``We've had 3-foot ribbons of oil on some beaches. A huge wind could bring a considerable amount on shore.''

DOC.HEAD: Blacks End One of Two Sit-Ins In Selma, Ala., Public Buildings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with most protesters leaving City Hall, meeting with mayor, CORRECT Melika to Malika, raise first reference to judge and tighten.
DOC.TEXT: About 150 black students ended a five-day sit-in today at Selma High School today, then briefly joined a demonstration at City Hall, all part of a racial protest that shut down all schools in this landmark city of the civil rights movement. The protesters paraded about a mile, carrying a banner that said ``Keep The Dream Alive,'' to the City Hall where they packed the corridors. A few adults took part along with the students. Before their arrival, all City Hall offices were open, with only a handful of protesters in sight. When the students jammed inside, however, all offices closed, except for Mayor Joe Smitherman's. He remained, with several police guarding his door. By noon, all but about 25 adult and student protesters were gone from City Hall, and offices reopened. Smitherman, the same man who was mayor during the historic 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery civil rights march, met for less than an hour with six student leaders and two attorneys, state Sen. Hank Sanders and Yusef Salaam, both of Selma. The meeting ended without any sign of progress. ``He's not satisfied us. There was double-talking going on,'' said one of the students, Malika Sanders, a daughter of the state senator. The 150 sit-in protesters had left the high school after meeting with Sanders, a protest leader, and School Superintendent Norward Roussell. The students chanted ``Do the right thing'' as they marched. The departure of the protesters from the high school came as city leaders awaited a federal judge's decision today on whether to order an end to the protests. Smitherman had asked U.S. District Judge Charles Butler of Mobile for a court order and city attorney Henry Pitts had said he expected the request to be granted. The request was filed before the school building was vacated. Miss Sanders said the protests would continue. ``If we can sit in at Selma High School five days, we can sit here just as long,'' she said upon arriving at City Hall. She and another black student at Selma High School, Latima Salaam, said they ended the school sit-in not because of the threat of a federal court order but because they feared Roussell would be fired immediately. ``He's our leader. He felt it was in our best interest to leave. Plus, the school board would fire him if we didn't leave,'' said Ms. Salaam. The turmoil began when six white members of the city school board voted Feb. 2 to dismiss Roussell, the city's first black superintendent. The vote sparked protests leading to the closing of two schools Tuesday and all 11 of Selma's public schools Wednesday. Roussell was reinstated after initial protests. But students and other protesters want the school board to extend his contract, which expires June 30. Ms. Salaam said Roussell assured them that they would not be expelled for their occupation of the high school, but he did not rule out lesser disciplinary action. She also said he agreed to meet two student demands _ to allow them to wear African medallions to class and to offer Afro-American history classes. Roussell said no decision had been made on whether schools will reopen Tuesday. Black protesters, most of them students, took over the school's cafeteria Wednesday as rising racial tensions forced the closing of all 11 public schools in Selma's 6,000-student, 70 percent black system. Smitherman said the only alternative to the court order was turning the schools over to state control until the dispute can be resolved. ``Both black and white students are suffering at this point,'' he said. ``They are trying to force us to make mass arrests.'' Protest leaders at a Sunday night meeting warned of possible economic boycotts, and instructed the students holding the sit-in at the high school not to resist if police attempted to remove them by force. Sanders told the crowd of 400 people gathered at the mostly black First Baptist Church that boycotts of businesses were a possible response to a court order. ``I heard a rumor that once an injunction was issued there was going to be an economic boycott that was going to shut Selma down,'' said Sanders, who declined to elaborate following the meeting. Roussell told the crowd that he had refused a second time to sign an affidavit that was to be used to obtain the injunction. Roussell said he could be fired again for refusing to sign, but ``I'm not going to leave.'' On Saturday, protest leaders and the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, met with Smitherman and U.S. Justice Department representatives.

DOC.HEAD: It's Only Puppy Love
DOC.TEXT: Every dog has its day, and a Tokyo retailer is hoping that day is Valentine's Day. The Tokyu Department Store is going all out this year to make sure its pet-owning customers have a vast array chocolates, cookies, fish sausages and other drool-inducing delicacies to choose from. ``I'm buying chocolates for my boyfriend, so why not for my dog?'' said Ayako Endo, a 22-year-old office worker. Miss Endo said buying a $3.50 gift set of goodies was the least she could do for her 12-year-old English setter. ``They're good,'' she said. ``I eat them too.'' As in the United States, Japanese celebrate Valentine's Day by giving sweets to a loved one. Tokyu is hoping to expand the concept a bit to include animals. ``We've been selling the chocolates for about three years, but this is the first year we have gone all out,'' said Tokyu pet shop clerk Yoshiko Kashiwazaki, pointing to a large table covered with heart-shaped gift sets wrapped in red-and-yellow ribbons. A poster showed two furry creatures cuddled up over the slogan: ``For Lovers, Sweet Valentine.'' ``I love you only,'' said one. ``Me too,'' replied the other. Shoppers are eating up the idea. ``I just love cats and dogs,'' said 12-year-old Yuki Kuwahara, who bought a chocolate and chew-bone gift for a Maltese dog she's rather fond of. ``We don't have a pet of our own.'' Most of the customers who purchase sweets for their dogs are women in their 30s or 40s, Kashiwazaki said. The chocolates come in both the regular brown and milky white colors, ``contain 13 different vitamins and are made with only the purest milk,'' according to Morinyu Pet Foods, the company that makes them. Morinyu, a subsidiary of the huge Morinaga Milk Industry Co., Ltd., began producing the chocolates six years ago, intending them to be used as rewards given to show dogs during training. But Tokyu, which sells a variety of gourmet pet foods, decided to open the pet Valentine corner because sales of the chocolates had increased each year in mid-February, Kashiwazaki said. ``As far as I know we're the only department store doing this,'' said Masataka Tajima of Tokyu's Sales Promotions Department. Hundreds of thousands of chocolates are sold for Valentine's Day in Japan each year. The chocolates are given by women to men, who often return the favor on March 14, which is known as ``White Chocolate Day.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Monitors Face Interrogation As Hazelwood Tries to Shift Blame
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard monitor on duty the night of the Exxon Valdez disaster testified today he could not have ordered the ship to change course even if he had seen it was headed for a rocky reef. Gordon Taylor said it would have taken the authority of a higher Coast Guard officer to order Joseph Hazelwood to make a course change. However, Taylor said the matter never became an issue because the Exxon Valdez vanished from his radar screen shortly before the accident. Taylor said he struggled to adjust the radar but could not bring the ship back into his viewing range. ``So when you left, it was off the screen, and you didn't see it anymore?'' asked Hazelwood attorney Dick Madson. ``That's correct,'' said Taylor, who went off duty at 11:45 p.m. on March 23. He said he notified the monitor who took over for him that the vessel was outbound but had disappeared from the radar. Madson has maintained that Taylor and Bruce Blandford, the monitor who replaced Taylor at the Coast Guard's Vessel Traffic System on the night of the Exxon Valdez disaster, were not watching the radar screen. Madson says if they had alerted Hazelwood that his ship was moving perilously close to jagged Bligh Reef, the accident never would have happened. Scoring a key legal point, Madson won permission to raise the Coast Guard responsiblity issue after Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone initially vetoed the tactic. Johnstone reversed himself after considering case law on the issue. But the lawyer was barred from exploring another matter _ whether Taylor and Blandford were using drugs or alcohol on March 24 when the accident happened. Blood and urine tests administered between 15 hours and three days after the grounding showed that Blandford had a blood-alcohol level more than twice the legal limit for driving and Taylor showed a small quantity of marijuana in his system. Johnstone called the marijuana issue ``a red herring'' but said he would reconsider admitting the alcohol test if Madson can show its relevance. Blandford's alcohol reading of .203 was recorded 15 hours after the Exxon Valdez went aground in scenic Prince William Sound. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is being tried on a felony charge of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Prosecution witnesses have said Hazelwood spent much of the day before the accident drinking vodka at a bar in the port town of Valdez. But his shipmates said Hazelwood didn't appear drunk and appeared in command of his ship. The 987-foot tanker, which ripped open on the rocky reef, spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil, killing thousands of birds and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky coast. Exxon says the cleanup has cost $2 billion so far.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Scouts for `Lessons That Last s Lifetime'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush praised the Boy Scouts on Monday for teaching ``lessons that last a lifetime'' at a White House ceremony honoring scouting's 80th anniversary. Bush was presented the National Boy Scouts Organization's highest award, the Silver Buffalo medallion _ a miniature buffalo on a red, white and blue ribbon _ and wore it around his neck during his brief remarks. The president said he was observing a tradition ``that dates all the way back to 1910, when President Taft received the first Boy Scout delegation right here in the White House.'' ``Scouting is more than learning how to build a campfire or tie a knot,'' Bush told a group of scouts and their leaders. ``Scouting teaches a love of outdoors and appreciation of our environment; it teaches the spirit of serving others and self respect. And let me make it pure and simple: It teaches lessons that last a lifetime.'' Bush was given the Silver Buffalo medallion as well as the first copy of the new edition of the Boy Scout Handbook, which scout leaders said is second only to the Bible in terms of copies printed. The president, in turn, used the ceremony to announce that he was bestowing his daily ``point of light'' citation on the Montana Council of the Boy Scouts for an environmental clean-up project called ``Good Turn.'' ``In the past five years, Project Good Turn has collected over 5,000 tons of trash from all across Montana and involved more than 30,000 young people in the cleanup effort,'' Bush said. Bush announces the award each day to an organization or individual that illustrates his ``thousand points of light'' theme of volunteerism and community service. Recipients get a letter from the president. Monday's was his 65th Point of Light award.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Will Examine Wide Range of Issues in East River Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 7th graf, The plane, with pilots' union comment.
DOC.TEXT: Issues ranging from rudder control designs to the effects of airline mergers on safety are expected to come up in a hearing opening Tuesday into last fall's crash in New York of USAir Flight 5050. National Transportation Safety Board Chairman James L. Kolstad, who will conduct the four-day hearing in New York, said crewmembers, airline officials, Federal Aviation Administration experts and representatives of the Boeing Co. are expected to testify. Two people were killed and 61 others were saved in a massive rescue operation after the Boeing 737 airliner skidded off the end of a LaGuardia Airport runway and into the East River, breaking into pieces in an aborted takeoff. The crash has raised several safety issues and drawn attention to more than a dozen reports of problems with rudder controls on Boeing 737s. Kolstad said in a recent interview that the engineering and mechancial design of the rudder trim on Boeing 737s will be among issues taken up at the hearing. Investigators found that Flight 5050's rudder was improperly trimmed to full left although cockpit recorders indicated pilots had properly checked the rudder's position for takeoff. Pilot Michael Martin reported the plane was drifting to the left before he aborted the takeoff, which was being handled by co-pilot Constantine Kleissas. The plane was scheduled to fly to Charlotte, N.C. ``We feel the rudder trim system is what actually precipitated the USAir accident,'' Air Line Pilots Association representative Tom Kraemer said Monday. The pilots' union and other interested groups will participate in the hearing. Other matters to be explored during the hearing include cockpit crew training and crew coordination by USAir, its flight operations and the recent merger of USAir with Piedmont and its ``impact on flight operations,'' Kolstad said. The plane's co-pilot came to USAir in the merger. Kleissas was controlling takeoff of a 737 for the first time since training for the airliner. The safety board chairman said the hearing also will cover FAA surveillance of USAir operations and runway design, including whether it is advisable to install arresting gear at the ends of runways along with ramps for crash and fire rescue equipment. Finally, the hearing will cover FAA drug and alcohol rules, he said. The FAA suspended the flying certificates of the plane's pilot and co-pilot two days after the crash, citing their failure to appear immediately for drug and alcohol tests after the crash. Drug tests taken 44 hours after the crash showed no trace of illegal substances in either man. The safety board examines all aviation crashes, determines their probable cause and makes recommendations to airlines, manufacturers, Congress and the FAA for improving safety. The board has no regulatory power.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Attacks, Rioting and Looting Reported in Tadzhikistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with reports of deaths, injuries, Armenians focus of riots, details, quotes; No pickup; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: The capital of the Soviet Asian republic of Tadzhikistan erupted in rioting today, with mobs angry over rumors that Armenian refugees were getting preferential treatment, official sources said. There were deaths and dozens of injuries reported. The government imposed a state of emergency and a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in the city of Dushanbe to quell ``mass disorders and pogroms, and acts of arson and looting,'' the official Tass news agency said. Armored vehicles were brought into the city center, which was calm late today, said Musafar Madzhidov, correspondent for official radio and TV in Dushanbe. He said an unknown number of people had been killed and more than 70 injured. Rioting erupted after two rallies in a 24-hour period over rumors that Armenian refugees from bloody ethnic strife in the Caucasus region were being given preference for new housing, Madzhidov said in a telephone interview. Members of the crowd shouted, ``Down with the Armenians!'' he said. Armenians, a predominantly Christian people, have been involved for the past two years in a bloody dispute with predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan. More than 200 people have been killed in Armenian and Azerbaijan since Jan. 13, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was forced to send thousands of soldiers into the southern region to impose control. But until today there had been no reports that the trouble had spread to the predominantly Moslem republics of Soviet Central Asia like Tadzhikistan. The Tadzhikistan Communist Party leader, Kakhar Makhkamov, appeared before a crowd that gathered Sunday outside party headquarters in Dushanbe and asked for 24 hours to investigate the rumors, Madzhidov said. Another crowd gathered today, but ignored his report that all but one Armenian refugee already had left Dushanbe, he said. They pelted the party headquarters with stones, breaking all the windows, and then went on a rampage through shops located nearby, he said. Police fired in the air to disperse the crowd, but the rioting continued until armored vehicles brought soldiers at about 10 p.m., when the curfew was imposed, Madzhidov said. He did not know exactly how the casualties occurred. There were no reports that the violence had spread from the city of a half-million people to other parts of the republic, he said. Residents of Dushanbe reached by phone corroborated Madzhidov's report, but said there had been rioting in suburbs of the capital as well. Tass said Tadzhikistan Interior Minister M. Navzhuvanov had been appointed military commandant of the city. It did not give any other details of the unrest. Families in Tadzhikistan, a small mountainous republic bordering China and Afghanistan, traditionally are large, and there is a critical shortage of housing.

DOC.HEAD: Tribe Continues Casino Gambling, Despite Ruling That It's Illegal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `It also...' to CORRECT tribe membership to 2,276. Subs 12th graf, `The Lac...', to UPDATE with another district attorney declining comment on prosecution plans.
DOC.TEXT: Operators of an Indian casino say they will continue to offer Las Vegas-style gambling, despite a warning from the state's attorney general that such games are illegal. Leaders of the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa tribe say the opinion by Attorney General Donald Hanaway does not make sense in a state where a lottery and pari-mutuel betting at dog tracks are legal. It also threatens the economic revival of the 2,276-member reservation, which recently invested $134,000 to remodel a grocery store into the Lake of the Torches Casino in northern Wisconsin. Vilas County District Attorney David Penn said he will use Hanaway's opinion to raid the year-old facility this week and shut it down. ``I think the tribe realizes it is the law and it will be enforced in Vilas County,'' Penn said. But tribal officials said the casino, which provides 18 jobs and grossed $43,000 last month, would not close voluntarily. ``I will tell you right now, it will hurt us economically. It will hurt us quite a bit,'' said Tribal Chairman Michael Allen last week. Hanaway ruled Feb. 5 that the state's gambling laws, enacted in 1987, only allow bingo, lottery and pari-mutuel betting. Casino games such as blackjack, poker, craps, roulette and video gambling machines are illegal, he said. His opinion leaves enforcement to district attorneys in the state's 72 counties. Any attempt to enforce his opinion is likely to lead to a court challenge, observers said. In the last year, three Indian tribes in Wisconsin have opened casinos: the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa, the Lac Court Oreilles Chippewa and the Menominee. State officials can regulate gambling on the two Chippewa reservations but have no enforcement authority on the Menominee reservation, which falls under federal regulation, officials said. The Lac Court Oreilles Chippewa tribe, about 100 miles to the west, also plans to keep its casino open. Tom Van Roy, district attorney for Sawyer County, declined comment Monday when asked whether he planned to try to shut down the casino in his county. The Lac du Flambeau's casino, open Wednesday through Sunday, offers seven blackjack tables with $50 betting limits and some 40 video gambling machines, including blackjack, poker, horse races, a lottery, and an electronic slot machine. There is also a bingo parlor. Tribal Gaming Manager Jerry Maulson said the tribe invested $134,000 to remodel the building and buy the equipment. ``We know we aren't Las Vegas, but we wanted to make it look like that atmosphere,'' he said. The casino grossed $43,000 in January, about enough to pay the expenses, Maulson said, adding the venture can't survive without non-Indian players. Maulson said he fears non-Indians living near the reservation are staying away because of opposition to the tribe's spearfishing, hunting and timber cutting rights guaranteed by 19th century treaties. But players who showed up at the casino last Wednesday night were enthusiastic and unfazed by Hanaway's ruling. ``We go to Las Vegas twice a year. This is almost like Vegas but you don't have the glitter and the show. It is good entertainment,'' said Bob Hansen, of nearby Minocqua. Patrons Bob and Carol Peglow said they used to drive to a reservation in Watersmeet, Mich., before the Lake of the Torches Casino opened. Hanaway's ruling did not make sense to them, they said. ``You got a lottery, dog races. To me gambling is gambling,'' Chuck Peglow said, as he shuffled $1 chips back and forth a blackjack table.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Submarine Launches Trident 2s; Ends Test Program
DOC.TEXT: The nuclear submarine Tennessee successfully launched two Trident 2 missiles just 20 seconds apart Monday, ending the Navy's three-year test program for the weapons. The two 44-foot missiles were launched as the Tennessee cruised submerged in the Atlantic 200 miles off the Florida coast. The Navy reported both firings were successful, running the missile's string of successes to seven straight. The first shot officially ended the test program; the second qualified the Tennessee to become the first submarine to go on operational patrol with 24 of the nuclear-tipped missiles. The Navy says the Trident 2, priced at $26.5 million each, is much more accurate than its undersea predecessors, Polaris, Poseidon and Trident 1. Published reports said the weapon's warheads can strike within 400 feet of their targets, compared with about 1,500 feet for the Trident 1. The first launch Monday marked the final test flight for the Trident 2, completing a program which began in January 1987 with a series of 19 launches from land, 15 of them successful. Nine submarine tests followed, all from the Tennessee and seven of them successful. The second launch was called a ``demonstration and shakedown operation,'' or DASO which mainly tested the sub crew's ability to safely handle and launch the missile. Navy spokeswoman Pat Hicks said after each DASO is completed, a submarine is certified for deployment. The Tennessee is scheduled to go on operational patrol in March with 24 Trident 2s, each capable of delivering up to 12 nuclear warheads to targets more than 4,600 miles away. Current Navy plans are to deploy a total of 24 Trident 2 subs. The Pennsylvania is scheduled to arrive soon for its DASO test.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Soviet Decides to Convene Congress of Peoples Deputies
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet leadership today called for an extraordinary session of the national Congress to strengthen Mikhail S. Gorbachev's powers as president. The official Tass news agency said the presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the nation's highest executive body, ``unanimously favored the establishment of democratic presidential power in our country.'' Such a move, coming on the heels of a key Communist Party Central Committee meeting at which party leaders agreed to surrender their monopoly on power, would further strengthen the government while weakening the power of the party apparatus. Tass said the presidium, headed by Gorbachev, would ask the Supreme Soviet parliament to call its parent body, the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, into session in the near future, but did not give a date. The Supreme Soviet goes into session Wednesday. All constitutional questions, such as powers of the presidency, must be decided by the Congress, which meets briefly twice a year. The presidium said it made its decision because of the debate going on in Soviet society about the role of the Communist Party and political reforms. Government leaders want the Congress also to discuss issues concerning the Soviet political system, property and strengthening the Soviet government, Tass said, without giving further details of those issues.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Officials Working to Ease Trade Barriers by Spring
DOC.TEXT: Top U.S. and Soviet trade officials began negotiations Monday aimed at wiping away nearly a half-century of trade frictions between the two superpowers by the time of the Bush-Gorbachev summit in June. Both sides expressed optimism that a new trade treaty could be completed by then even though the complexity of the talks was highlighted by the size of the delegations and the length of the negotiating agenda. The U.S. team, led by Trade Representative Carla Hills and her deputy, Julius L. Katz, included 19 officials from six agencies including the departments of State, Treasury, Commerce and Labor. The first round of negotiations, which were scheduled to last through Tuesday, were to be followed by two more sessions in late February and early March. The Monday session included morning and afternoon meetings separated by a working lunch. U.S. officials said they hoped that all of the negotiations would be completed by the end of April to provide time to draft the final trade agreement so that it can be signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev at their June meeting in Washington. As the talks got under way, Hills told reporters that she was confident that the differences separating the two sides could be ironed out. Noting her Soviet counterparts, she said, ``We are a very efficient team.'' Yuriy N. Chumakov, deputy minister of foreign economic affairs and the leader of the Soviet delegation, urged reporters to hold their questions about the chances for success until negotiators had finished the initial round of talks. Hills listed as goals ``normalizing trade relations with the Soviet Union and facilitating trade between the two countries.'' The administration hopes that normalized trade will give a boost to the Soviet economy and provide economic support to the political reforms being undertaken by Gorbachev. The trade treaty would be used to grant the Soviet Union ``most favored nation status,'' qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to any other country. The Soviets are anxious to obtain this benefit since their imports to the United States must currently bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other nations. The higher tariffs are a result of a 1974 law known as the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which was passed by Congress in retaliation for the refusal of the Soviet government to allow Soviet Jews and other dissidents to leave the country. Bush has said he will ask Congress to waive the Jackson-Vanik restrictions once the Soviet legislature passes a law spelling out its new liberalized emigration policies. The new trade treaty would be needed to put the lower tariffs into effect. Hungary recently obtained a waiver from the high Jackson-Vanik tariffs. In addition to the Soviet Union, the administration is also considering granting waivers for Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and East Germany. The curbs against Poland were lifted in 1987. One of the issues in the Soviet negotiations will be how the waiver from the high tariffs will be accomplished. The administration would like to negotiate a three-year trade agreement with annual presidential review and waiver of the high tariffs. The Soviets would like to see the tariffs removed permanently as a way of building confidence among business leaders that trade relations will remain stable in coming years. But Congress, which is following the present negotiations with keen interest, is unlikely to go along with more than a one-year waiver. Other issues on the opening agenda were U.S. demands for protection of American-patented products from piracy, an arbitration method to settle business disputes and provisions to allow either country to impose temporary trade restrictions if a domestic industry suffers injury because of an unexpected surge of imports. The administration is predicting that two-way trade between the two countries could double or even triple over the next three years with a new trade agreement, although private economists doubt that assessment, given the numerous troubles plaguing the Soviet economy. Through November, the United States had sold $3.82 billion worth of exports to the Soviets, primarily farm products, while importing a relatively small $658 million worth of Soviet products, primarily oil, platinum and consumer goods such as vodka and furs. Trade relations between the United States and the Soviet Union began deteriorating with the onset of Cold War tensions following World War II. In 1947, President Truman placed restrictions on U.S. exports to the Soviet Union in an effort to keep military-useful technologies from falling into communist hands.

DOC.HEAD: Cellist Asks Government to Apologize to Solzhenitsyn
DOC.TEXT: Cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich, in his homeland for the first time in 16 years, said Monday the government should drop treason charges against Alexander Solzhenitsyn and apologize to the exiled author. ``It is ridiculous that a charge like this continues to loom over him,'' Rostropovich told a news conference the day after returning to the Soviet Union for concerts in Moscow and Leningrad. Rostropovich and his wife, singer Galina Vishnevskaya, were stripped of citizenship in 1978, four years after they were hounded into leaving the Soviet Union for giving refuge to Solzhenitsyn. Ms. Vishnevskaya had spent 30 years with the Bolshoi Theater opera company and her husband gained international renown as a cello soloist and conductor with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra. He has conducted the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C. for 13 years. In January, the Supreme Soviet legislalature restored their citizenship and nullified an edict stripping them of all honors and medals. When asked about the possible return of Solzhenitsyn to the Soviet Union, Rostropovich said the writer hoped to do so, but not until censorship of his work was completely lifted. ``I think that Alexander Solzhenitsyn will come back, but the Soviet Union must apologize for the absurd charge of high treason,'' he said. Failure to repeal the charge, which carries the death penalty, runs counter to the liberalization occurring Soviet Union, Rostropovich told reporters. Citizenship has been restored to several prominent cultural figures who lost it under previous regimes, and they have returned during the cultural thaw that prevails under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Solzhenitsyn, who depicted the horrors of Josef Stalin's prison camps in ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' was formally charged with high treason in 1974, stripped of citizenship and expelled. Rostropovich and his wife followed their friend a few months later. Soviet officials have said Solzhenitsyn's citizenship could be restored, but only if he formally asks for it. They say no request has been received from the author, who lives in Vermont. Rostropovich, 62, said he and Ms. Vishnevskaya had found their return a bittersweet and emotional experience. ``It is a strange feeling to be back in my own country,'' she said. ``Our reception was warm and affectionate, but many friends have passed away. It was very emotional.'' ``We left here insulted,'' Rostropovich said. Then, sarcastically, he said the order depriving them of citizenship was ``signed by Brezhnev,'' referring to the late President Leonid I. Brezhnev, ``who did not do any damage to the Soviet Union, of course.'' Brezhnev now is villified as a leader who brought economic and political stagnation during 18 years in power. Mrs. Vishnevskaya said she and her husband thought they never would return. ``We were thrown out of our own house,'' she said, but now ``the government has recognized its barbaric act as unworthy, and we had an opportunity to return.'' ``When we were leaving,'' Rostropovich said, the Soviet Union ``was an island of lies. Now is cleansing itself of these lies.'' The cellist, who will give concerts Tuesday and Wednesday at the Moscow Conservatory, presented Soviet health officials with 1 million single-use syringes Monday to help in the campaign against AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Conductor To Give Concerts in Romania
DOC.TEXT: Munich Philharmonic conductor Sergiu Celibidache will give several concerts in Bucharest next week after years of refusing to perform in his native country, the state Rompres news agency said Monday. Celibidache, who has been conducting in Munich since 1979, will perform works by Giuseppe Verdi, Richard Strauss, Johannes Brahms and others at Bucharest's famed Atheneum Concert Hall pieces. Some of the concerts will be broadcast live on Eurovision TV network to Western Europe, Rompress said. Celibidache left Romania shortly after the post-war Communist takeover and returned for a number of performances in the late 1970s.
