But he refused to return later because of differences with the cultural council under the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator who was overthrown and executed in December. One issue of contention was the refusal of the former council to allow young Romanian conductors to receive stipends from Celibidache for musical training abroad. The council was replaced last month by a minister of culture led by Andrei Plesu, a leading ex-dissident and art critic who had been banished by Ceausescu to a small village in northeastern Romania to work as a curator at a local museum.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Foundation Offers Grants to Foster Race Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The Ford Foundation invited 200 colleges and universities on Monday to compete for $1.6 million in grants aimed at improving race relations and exploring other cultures. ``We are looking for projects that will help weave diversity into the fabric of an institution's academic life and sense of purpose,'' Ford Foundation President Franklin A. Thomas said in a news release. The grants are being made because, Thomas said in a letter sent to education leaders, ``On many college campuses, reports of racial and religious intolerance and sexual harassment are rising.'' ``Diversity makes an essential contribution to the education of students,'' Thomas wrote, but added that ``some students find diversity confusing or threatening. ``For these students, college is often the first journey out of a homogeneous neighborhood into a more diverse world. Those who are not ready or willing to relate to people of a different race, religion or sexual orientation, or to relate to people with profoundly different political and ethical convictions, will be troubled and may express this through disruptive and hostile behavior.'' The grants may be used for course development or revision, study groups, colloquia, cultural affairs, visiting speakers and for acquiring or preserving materials used in undergraduate courses. The foundation plans to award 10 grants of up to $100,000 each for new programs and smaller grants of up to $25,000 to expand or enhance existing programs. Those asked to participate are schools that are largely or wholly residential. They include small schools like Berea College in Kentucky and Lincoln University in Pennsylvania and larger universities and colleges like Yale in Connecticut and the University of California. The Ford Foundation, established in 1936, is a private, nonprofit institution whose goal is to preserve peace and advance human welfare. The foundation, headquartered in New York, has granted $7 billion to more than 9,000 institutions and 100,000 individuals worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says It's Too Early to Discuss Lifting Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files and trims throughout to shorten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today praised the release of Nelson Mandela as a ``dramatic sign'' that South Africa is moving toward a more racially equitable society, but he said it was too early to talk about lifting U.S. sanctions. By law, Bush told a news conference, the economic sanctions enacted in 1986 ``remain on until the South Africans have taken certain steps'' beyond just the release of the imprisoned black nationalist leader. The president said he continues to find some of the sanctions counterproductive _ as had the Reagan administration before him. ``I think American jobs there make sense,'' he said. At the same time, Bush said his invitation South African President F.W. de Klerk to visit him at the White House bore no conditions. Bush extended separate invitations to both Mandela and de Klerk. ``I think his coming here evidences that we see in him a new brand of leadership,'' the president said of de Klerk. He praised the South African leader for taking steps that ``move South Africa down the road toward racial equality.'' Asked if he was uncomfortable by links between the Communist Party in South Africa and Mandela, Bush said: ``Too hypothetical. What's good is he's out of there.'' ``I'm not embracing every position of the ANC (Mandela's African National Congress),'' Bush said. ``What I'm embracing is the concept that he's out of jail.'' In any event, he said, ``I think these Communist parties are for the most part sliding down hill. What's coming uphill is democracy and freedom and I would hope steps Mr. de Klerk is taking would enhance that view that democracy and freedom are on the move.'' Earlier today, in a speech welcoming Denis Sassou-Nguesso, the president of the Congo, to the White House, Bush also promised that the United States will not overlook Africa in its concern with the events unfolding in Europe. ``Africa's our friend, and friends don't forget one another,'' he said. Bush said the release of Mandela after 27 years in prison ``is another important sign that South Africa may soon begin negotiating a democratic non-racial society and at last be on the way to ending apartheid once and for all.'' ``Some have suggested that events in the rest of the world including central Europe mean that the United States will no longer pay attention to Africa. I can assure and everyone in Africa that this is not the case,'' said Bush. He noted he visited Africa three times as vice president ``and hope to be able to do so again.'' Bush praised the Congolese president's role in bringing peace to southwest Africa. Sassou-Nguesso called Bush a ``great figure'' and heir to the legacy of two centuries of freedom. He also hailed Mandela as ``a great symbol of dignity for African men,'' and said his release ``ushers in great prospects for the negotiation of the future of South African society.'' Bush telephoned the newly liberated black leader on Sunday and invited him to visit the White House. Afterwards, Bush had only words of praise for both Mandela and de Klerk. Meanwhile, in television interviews this morning, the State Department's top policymaker on Africa said it may be time to ``make some gesture'' toward Pretoria to encourage further progress in race relations. The assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Herman Cohen, said on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show this morning that while ``sanctions played a positive role in changing the thinking of the white government, ... the main reason for changing policy down there is what happened internally _ the pressure from the black majority, economic realities, demographic realities. We just helped nudge them along.'' ``I think we should (make some kind of gesture) because when progress takes place, we should try to encourage more progress,'' Cohen said. ``The legislation we're working under provides for relaxation of sanctions when there is progress. I think we're rapidly reaching that point, but we're not going to make any decisions until we've consulted very closely with the Congress because it's a major political decision,'' the State Department official said. Speaking on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' Cohen said ``what we really care about is encouraging further progress. If that means relaxation of sanctions, fine.'' Two lawmakers, also appearing on ``Today,'' indicated that Congress would move cautiously in lifting the sanctions. ``I think the talk is premature and I suspect that it will continue for a while, but people ought to consider the fact that the talk (recently in Congress) was that more sanctions ought to be imposed,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. ``One factor perhaps in the timing of all this was to avoid debate in the U.S. Congress.'' Rep. William Gray III, D-Pa., the House majority whip, said: ``The law is very specific in terms of its requirement before the president can be making a recommendation. I'm not sure that there has been a compliance with all of those (requirements).'' Bush said he told Mandela ``that all Americans were delighted after these many years in jail that he was released, that we were rejoicing at his release.'' Bush said he told Mandela the United States wants ``to see a peaceful evolution towards a totally racially free South Africa, a society without prejudice, a society of total freedom.'' They did not discuss the future of sanctions. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said South Africa has not yet met the conditions for lifting sanctions. ``We need to adopt the same standard as we adopted to approaching Poland and the Soviet Union and other countries in Eastern Europe. We respond positively, but we do not reduce the pressure,'' said Wolpe. South Africa's minority white population of 5 million has maintained control through its apartheid laws and denial of political rights to the 26 million black residents. The Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986 _ passed over the veto of then-President Reagan _ stipulated that before sanctions could be lifted, South Africa had to free all political prisoners and meet at least three of four other criteria. De Klerk already has met one of the conditions by legalizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. The other conditions include an agreement by the government to engage in good faith negotiations on South Africa's political future, the lifting of the state of emergency, and substantial progress toward dismantling apartheid.

DOC.HEAD: Concerns Voiced Over Soviet Nuclear Stockpiles at Time of Unrest
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, concerned over whose finger stays on the button of the Soviet Union's 30,000 nuclear weapons in a time of internal tumult, is proposing that the Kremlin mount a ``fail-safe'' review of controls on its nuclear arsenals. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., also wants the United States to conduct such an independent review of its own safeguards against the unauthorized or accidental launch of nuclear weapons and says his committee will do the job if the Pentagon fails to act. With ethnic and political tensions straining Soviet unity, many American military experts and key congressional figures are fretting about the possibility that a nuclear missile could be unleashed on the world without the knowledge or approval of the Kremlin. ``My worst-case fear for the last several months is that we would wake up one morning and discover that an ethnic liberation front had obtained control of 100 nuclear weapons,'' said a military expert on the staff of the House Armed Services Committee. ``Nuclear weapons are in every Soviet republic that is potentially rebellious,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's a legitimate problem to worry about,'' he said. ``I'm not having nightmares about it. Stealing a nuclear weapon is not a simple thing to do. We know you can't just walk into a Soviet missile silo and fire them.'' But he added the equation might change if an ethnic faction seized control of an entire province. Bruce G. Blair of the Brookings Institution notes that the Soviets may have 100 or so nuclear weapons stored near Baku, in Soviet Azerbaijan, site of recent violent clashes between Moslem Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians. Until Soviet troops entered Baku to restore order, widespread reports had gunmen seizing conventional arms and ammunition from Soviet depots. ``It's a concern people are paying attention to, trying to monitor,'' Blair said. ``I think the Soviets themselves are so concerned about this problem that they're handling it just fine.'' Ethic violence flared again Monday, this time in the predominantly Moslem Asian republic of Tadzhikistan. Soviet authorities reported rioting in the capital city of Dushanbe, with mobs angry over rumors that Armenian refugees were getting preferential treatment. There were deaths and dozens of injuries and reports of looting before authorities declared a state of emergency and imposed a curfew. The issue of control over nuclear weapons may soon be explored in extraordinary public fashion, at a time the superpowers apparently are nearing agreement on several arms control accords. Yevgeni Velikhov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet's defense subcommittee, proposes an unprecedented joint hearing with the House Armed Services Committee to explore ways of reducing the danger of unauthorized or accidental launches of nuclear weapons. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House panel, says he is open to the idea of a joint meeting, leaving the topic of such a session to be settled later. Nunn said in an interview: ``I think you have to worry about thousands of nuclear weapons in a nation that has a lot of turmoil.'' Nunn wants the Kremlin to review the effectiveness of ``fail-safe'' procedures to insulate their nuclear weapons from the country's political troubles. ``I hope we can persuade them to do it,'' he said. The two superpowers should cooperate more closely on the issue because ``this is one area of technology that it would pay both sides to share,'' he said. ``In the event of instability, people have to be worried about who would be in charge,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Like others, Lugar noted that a probable silver lining to their worries is the continued cohesiveness of the Soviet military. ``There seems to be no instability whatsoever in the Soviet armed forces,'' Lugar said. ``They appear to be in full control of nuclear weapons, short- or long-range.'' The Soviets have an extensive security system to protect their nuclear weapons, placing missile sites in remote locations, surrounding their perimeters with heavily armed guards, separating weapons from launchers and triggers, and installing multiple launch controls.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Inundate Ailing Entertainer with Good Wishes
DOC.TEXT: Fans have offered an outpouring of affection to song-and-dance star Sammy Davis Jr., who remains hospitalized with throat cancer, Davis' spokeswoman said Monday. ``He's in touch with friends and family and is receiving bagfuls of messages from throughout the world,'' Susan Reynolds said. She declined to reveal Davis' condition, however, saying only, ``He remains hospitalized at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center of Los Angeles undergoing appropriate treatment for a recurrence of carcinoma of the throat.'' A hospital spokesman referred inquiries to Ms. Reynolds. Davis, 64, was diagnosed with throat cancer in September. The versatile singer-dancer, whose career has stretched from poverty to the Las Vegas stage and motion pictures, most recently appeared in the 1989 movie ``Tap,'' playing an old-time tap dancer named Little Mo. During a tribute earlier this month, the thinning Davis appeared weak and was in obvious declining health.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf to fix date. Grafs 8-9 new with South Africa comments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that the United States and the Soviet Union made ``solid progress'' last week toward arms control agreements, but cautioned against hope that three treaties might be ready by the time of his June summit with Mikhail Gorbachev. The president said he hoped he and Gorbachev could sign a troop reduction agreement this year and that treaties should be ``substantially completed'' on reducing long range nuclear weapons and chemical weapons by the time of the summit. He rejected Gorbachev's counterproposal to his own initiative to cut European troops. At a White House news conference that focused almost exclusively on fast-moving subjects of foreign affairs, Bush said the issue of German reunification was up to the German people. He ruled out a neutral nation and said whatever emerges would have to remain a member of NATO. He also offered to play a mediating role in resolving South Africa's racial conflict if it seemed appropriate. Fielding questions in the White House briefing room, Bush was asked about Nelson Mandela's declaration that armed struggle against the white minority in South Africa should continue. He said he would discourage violence, and said the South African leader _ freed Sunday after 27 years in prison _ had said such actions should be ``defensive.'' ``We've always advocated nonviolence and I think the United States ought not to move away from that,'' he said. Bush ruled out a partial lifting of sanctions against South Africa, saying he was barred from taking that step despite Mandela's release. Asked about Mandela's alliance with communists, Bush said he saw communism ``sliding downhill'' throughout the world, with democracy on the ascent. Bush said he believed both Mandela and South African President F.W. deKlerk had accepted his invitations to visit the White House ``in principle'' but that no date was set for either to visit. Asked whether he expected to play a major role in the discussions between Mandela and the South African government, Bush said: ``If such a role would be productive, I certainly would. But I have the feeling ... they feel that can talk to each other without the U.S. catalytic role. But sure if we could be helpful in a way of that nature then sure.'' In an opening statement, Bush tossed a bouquet at Gorbachev and his communist colleagues in Moscow, embracing their movement ``toward pluralism'' last week when the Communist party endorsed a plan to give up its monopoly on power in the Soviet Union. Bush, who had called for deep force cuts in Europe, nonetheless rejected Gorbachev's counterproposal that would have left both sides with 195,000 troops in Europe. To attain this level, Gorbachev wanted the United States to recall 30,000 troops in countries _ Great Britain, Italy, Greece and Turkey _ not covered under the original negotiations. The president said the disagreement didn't amount to an impasse in the negotiations, saying, ``This is the way it works.'' Bush hailed Gorbachev's declaration that Germans should decide their own fate, and said the time was not yet right for a meeting of the four nations who hold occupation rights as a result of World War II _ the Soviet Union, the United States, France and England. The president also said that if East Germany was to join West Germany in a unified nation, the new Germany should be a member of NATO. He said there was flexibility on where Western troops could be positioned within the new country. Bush opened his news conference by saying he wanted to ``commend'' the developments in the Soviet Union last week in which the Communist party was stripped of its automatic leading role in governing the country. He noted ``solid progress'' by Secretary of State James Baker III in his talks in Moscow. He said the talks had covered conventional arms control, long range nuclear weapons, nuclear testing and chemical weapons, as well as issues such as Central America and Afghanistan. He said the talks had accomplished ``much`` of what he and Gorbachev had hoped for when they set up the negotiations at their Malta summit last December. ``I am confident that if we continue this kind of momentum ... the June summit will be a major success,'' he said. At the same time, Bush said ``I'm not sure there will be three treaties to be signed by the time we have this summit. But I think there's going to be progress toward all three.'' He said the goal was to get the agreement signed on reduction of conventional forces in Europe. On other issues Bush: _ Said he would decide shortly whether to permit the sale of leases for offshore drilling on the California Coast. He said that despite last week's tanker spill, ``I'll be damned if I think we ought to shut down offshore drilling everywhere.'' _ Said he would tell the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia at a drug summit this week that the United States was making major efforts to cut down the on the demand for cocaine in this country. _ Said a long list of proposed military base closings was drawn up ``without political favoritism,'' and urged Congress to drop the ``age old adage, `cut here, cut there but don't cut in my district.''

DOC.HEAD: Hasidim Mourn Leader Slain By Thief
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Haskel Werzberger, who survived the Auschwitz death camp as a child 45 years ago, died Monday of a bullet wound from a thief who accosted him last week on his way to morning prayers. He was 58. Werzberger, a leader of the 25,000 Jews of the Satmar Hasidic sect in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, died early Monday, four days after the shooting. About 200 family and sect members had kept a vigil at Bellevue Hospital, where Werzberger underwent surgery and was kept on a respirator. His funeral was held later in the day at Congregation Yetev Lev and drew a police-estimated 8,000 mourners, including Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes. Moses Teitelbaum, the grand rabbi of the ultra-Orthodox sect, delivered one of five eulogies. ``The death of this man of peace has diminished the lives of all New Yorkers,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said in a statement. Werzberger was shot early Thursday as he sat warming up a car, preparing to drive from his apartment to the synagogue for morning prayers. The gunman dragged him from the car and drove off, leaving Werzberger bleeding in the street. The car was found Friday in another Brooklyn neighborhood, the driver's seat and dashboard spattered with paint. A $10,000 reward for information that leads to the killer has been offered, but no arrests had been made Monday. Werzberger was born in Hungary and emigrated with others of the Satmar sect after World War II. He leaves his wife, Rifka; two sons and four daughters; a brother and numerous grandchildren, said Satmar spokesman Isaac Abraham.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats Monitoring Council Reports to Romer, Skaggs
DOC.TEXT: A special state environmental panel on Monday called for increased public disclosure about operations at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant. ``In order to be a responsible neighbor to millions of people living nearby, the Rocky Flats plant must be open and honest about its operations and their impact and be willing to listen and respond to the community's concerns,'' said state Rep. Sam Williams, chairman of the Rocky Flats Environmental Monitoring Council. Gov. Roy Romer and U.S. Rep. David Skaggs appointed the 11-member council in January 1988 to promote communication between the plant and concerned public agencies and the public; and to monitor environmental, safety and public health concerns. The plant 16 miles northwest of Denver manufactures highly radioactive plutonium detonators for nuclear weapons. It has been under investigation by a federal grand jury since shortly after a raid on June 6, 1989, by scores of FBI and Environmental Protection Agency agents investigating allegations of illegal radioactive waste storage and disposal. Plutonium operations at the plant were suspended in November by Energy Secretary James Watkins until health and safety concerns are met. No startup date has been announced but sources have said plutonium processing could resume in late spring or summer. The DOE also transferred management of the plant to EG&G, a major defense contractor, from Rockwell International on Jan. 1. The council noted in its report ``that improved communication is critically needed. DOE and its contractors have historically demonstrated a reluctance to share information about the general operation of Rocky Flats, about incidents and problems that have occurred and about anticipated future problems. This lack of openness has aggravated public mistrust of the plant and its possible impacts upon the environment and public health safety.'' Melinda Kassen, a senior attorney for the Environmental Defense Fund, said the report contains ``nothing new or revolutionary.'' The report serves as ``an exclamation point at the end of what's already been said,'' Kassen added. Kassen said the Bush administration did not include funding in its budget proposal for the plant's five-year plan for environmental restoration, new initiatives for waste management and corrective activities for complying with existing legal requirements. Among the report's recommendations: _Full funding of health studies to assess the effect of plant discharges on the community and reactivation and expansion of a study of effects on Rocky Flats workers. _Minimum level plutonium processing until a previously initiated safety review is completed and all suggested corrective actions are implemented. _Strict air emission monitoring. _Issuance of publicinformation papers by the Rocky Flats plant openly discussing tough issues facing the plant. _Placement of various oversight responsibilities for nuclear weapons plants outside the Department of Energy. _Formal agreement not to permanently dispose of any wastes at Rocky Flats and to put a premium on eliminating offsite discharges of hazardous materials.

Here is a transcript of President Bush's news conference Monday at the White House: Bush: Good afternoon. Well, this has been an extraordinary and positive week in East-West relations. And in the Soviet Union progress was made at the Central Committee Plenum on moving the Soviet political system toward pluralism and genuine respect for the views of the Soviet electorate. I commend this development which demonstrates once again why our administration has supported Chairman Gorbachev's efforts to extend glasnost and perestroika through the Soviet Union. Secretary Baker's visit to Moscow made solid progress in pushing the US-Soviet agenda forward in preparation for the June summit here. We made important headway on conventional arms control, START, nuclear testing and chemical weapons and continued to explore ways to reduce our differences on regional issues, especially concerning Central America and Afghanistan. All in all, Secretary Baker's talks in Moscow accomplished much of what Chairman Gorbachev and I intended when we set the goals for this meeting during our discussions at Malta. I am confident that if we continue this kind of momentum in our bilateral relationship with the Soviet Union, the June summit will be a major success. And, finally, I want to congratulate Chancellor Kohl for his successful visit to Moscow. His visit reflects the accelerating pace of German self-determination. And the statements on German unity on the Soviet side _ by the Soviet side were most welcome. And we support Chancellor Kohl's position that a unified Germany should remain a member of NATO. Let me also express my appreciation of Chairman Gorbachev's statesmanlike view that decisions regarding German unity should be left to the people of Germany. I made a statement this morning on the wonderful news of the release of Mr. Mandela, so I will leave that to the question period. But, Terry, I understand you have the first question. Q: Yes, Mr. President, what is your reaction to Mr. Gorbachev's counterproposal for troop cuts in Europe? And in the wake of Secretary Baker's visit to Moscow, what do you think the likelihood is that there'll be three treaties to be signed this year _ chemical, strategic and conventional? Bush: Well, I, let me take the last one first. I'm not sure that there will be three treaties to be signed by the time we have this summit, but I think there's going to be progress towards all three. And it's still our goal to get that agreement signed. On the troops, where Gorbachev wanted to have either 195,000 or 225,000, we're going to stay with our proposal because we don't see this linkage to that degree. We're talking about the forward deployment there in Europe, the 195,000, and that's what we're challenging him to reduce. And we've got a big ocean between us and Western Europe. And so, the argument that we should always have a linked reduction is one that I want to get away from now. We've _ I think we've made some real progress on this, and I was very pleased with his reaction to our proposal. But I don't think we need to have exact linkage from this point on. Q: Well, if you're rejecting his counterproposal, is there an impasse now? Bush: I wouldn't call it an ``impasse.'' You know, this is the way it works when you're discussing these arms control things. No, I don't think we've got an impasse. Q: With the breakup of the Soviet empire and you want Germany to remain in NATO, who's the enemy? Bush: What was that? Q: Who's the enemy? Who are they supposed to be fighting against? Bush: Who? Q: The NATO troops, U.S. troops in Germany. Bush: The US troops are there as a stabilizing factor. Nobody can predict, Helen, with total certainty what tomorrow is going to look like. I've been wrong, you've been wrong, he's been wrong, she's been wrong on how it's going. And we don't know. Q: But hasn't the Soviet Union _ Bush: And our _ may I finish, please? Q: OK. Bush: Our European allies want us there. I have a feeling that some of the Eastern Europeans want us there, because they know that the United States is there as a stabilizing factor, and we will be there for a long time to come, hopefully at significantly reduced numbers. Q: May I just add, Mr. President, that there's a wide perception that your whole military budget is out of sync, that you're tone deaf into what's been happening, and that there is a possibility of this money going for distressing domestic need. Bush: I don't think that perception is widespread with the American people. I think the American people want a cautious approach to this. I don't think any of us think we can see with clairvoyance as to what's going to happen the day after tomorrow. And we are reducing our defense expenditures. We've sent a budget proposal up there that makes good sense. You're right, some of the Democrats are jumping all over us. But that's all right, that just goes with the system. The main thing is the Europeans, our staunchest allies, want us there, because they see the U.S. as a stabilizing presence, and so we're going to remain there. Now, as I say, I hope negotiations go so well that we can have substantially reduced numbers over the years.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Hunger Striker Near Death While Awaiting State's Appeal
DOC.TEXT: An inmate whose drug convictions were overturned last month is near death after an 11-month hunger strike and will be force-fed while prosecutors appeal his case, his attorney said Monday. Rene Acuna, 37, of Detroit has dropped to just over 100 pounds and a prison doctor says his weakened heart may fail, said Paul Denenfeld, legal director for the Michigan chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Acuna is still imprisoned because he is unable to meet a $100,000 bond. ``I think at this point what we are seeing is an example of how the justice system can break down,'' Denenfeld said. ``We have three appeals court judges saying the man should never have been in jail in the first place. We think it is outrageous that he is still in jail. He should already be out.'' Department of Corrections spokeswoman Gail Light said doctors began force-feeding Acuna at 11 a.m. Monday after receiving permission from his court-appointed guardian, Anna Sossa. ``I can generally say the doctors believe this is a life-threatening situation and they need to get some nutrition down him again,'' she said. Acuna weighed 180 pounds when he began his hunger strike March 3, shortly after he was convicted. The convictions carried mandatory terms of life in prison without parole. He refused to resume eating after the Michigan Court of Appeals threw out his convictions for lack of evidence in a ruling released Jan. 23. The Cuban immigrant said he will not eat until he can return home to Sossa, his longtime companion, and his two daughters. He is at the Duane L. Waters Hospital next to the State Prison of Southern Michigan in Jackson, unable to post a $100,000 bond while the Macomb County Prosecuting Attorney's office appeals to the Michigan Supreme Court. Carole Murray, chief of the drug unit in the prosecutor's office, said the appeal was filed Friday. Sossa said she agreed to permit the force-feeding because prison doctors threatened to go to court to have her removed as guardian and because she fears for Acuna's life. ``He's really in bad shape. If he dies now after he has won his appeal, what are we going to get? Nothing,'' she said. ``I don't want to give (Macomb County Prosecutor Carl) Marlinga the pleasure that he dies.'' After the appeal bond was set Feb. 1, Acuna refused his regular diet of water and coffee with sugar and refused to be weighed, Denenfeld said. Acuna weighed 107 pounds before the appeal bond hearing and may be just over 100 pounds by now, he said. Prosecutors accused Acuna of serving as a lookout for a 1988 drug buy, during which undercover agents bought cocaine. Acuna has denied any involvement. The appeals court reversed Acuna's convictions of delivery and conspiracy to deliver more than two pounds of cocaine and refused to order a new trial. Acuna was force-fed last fall after his weight plunged below 107 pounds and gained about 20 pounds, but resumed his hunger strike after the nasal feeding tube was removed.

DOC.HEAD: Buffalo's Blacks Hardest Hit By Industrial Decline
DOC.TEXT: Blacks could hold the key to a resurgent Buffalo, says the author of a study released Monday that is billed as the most comprehensive ever done of a single black community. Blacks began migrating to Buffalo in large numbers around 1940, just about the time when the city's industries began a slump from which they never really recovered, said the study conducted by the State University of New York at Buffalo. ``At that point when thousands of new residents were pouring into Buffalo, the city's economy was beginning to change,'' researcher Henry Louis Taylor Jr. told a news conference. ``The jobs that lured black people to Buffalo were disappearing almost as fast as they could get them.'' ``The Buffalo labor force is old,'' he said. ``There is no population younger than the African-American community. If you train them ... you solve one of Buffalo's major problems.'' The unemployment rate among blacks in Buffalo was 26 percent in 1940, 16 percent in 1960 and 21 percent in 1980, a consistent 8 percent higher than the city's overall unemployment rate for those years, said Taylor, director of SUNY-Buffalo's Center for Applied Public Affairs Studies. The study addresses housing, education, crime and the quest for community among the city's 94,262 blacks. University officials said it was the most comprehensive study ever of a single black community. The Buffalo Urban League and the Common Council, which commissioned the study, plan to use it for a range of policy issues. The report suggests that the East Side, where 84 percent of Buffalo's black residents live, should become one of the city's top priorities for economic and social reform before it becomes a disaster area like the slums of Chicago or Detroit. Taylor said city leaders should officially designate the East Side as a Development Zone, the target of a coordinated effort to transform it into a wholesome community, or in Taylor's words, ``a Renaissance City.'' Leroy Coles, the Urban League's president, said it will be hard to persuade city leaders that the East Side's rebirth should be a priority. ``City Hall, it seems to me, has to become more concerned about the growing population suffering from a number of things this report speaks to,'' Coles said. ``The report is a good way for white folks to begin to understand that this is not only about our problems, but about theirs as well.'' The report says that while many Buffalo blacks own their own homes, the homes are likely to be shabby and the owners are unlikely to have enough money to fix them up properly. Blacks are more likely to be arrested than whites of the same age for all crimes except, surprisingly, drug offenses, the report said. At the same time, there are encouraging signs, such as the fact that the East Side contains a broad cross-section of middle-class and working-class blacks and a large array of community organizations, Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Moderates Urge Closer Ties with Pretoria, Hard-liners Urge Sanctions
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Conservative African leaders responded to Nelson Mandela's release by calling Monday for closer ties with Pretoria, which is wooing black Africa with cheap goods and promises of aid. Hard-line states such as Nigeria and Zimbabwe issued predictable statements endorsing sanctions and urging no leniency toward the Pretoria government. But Gabon's President Omar Bongo, basking in the euphoria surrounding Mandela's release Sunday after more than 27 years in prison, declared it ``a triumph for dialogue over cannons and guns.'' ``We need to review our relations with South Africa, to re-establish diplomatic ties, even if we do not send ambassadors,'' Bongo said in a radio broadcast. His declaration indicated a growing chasm in black Africa's often hypocritical stand on South Africa. Most African countries trade with Pretoria, but few openly acknowledge the economic links made more attractive recently by the weakened South African currency and some states' over-valued currencies, particularly those French-speaking Africa. The Ivory Coast, reported to be considering diplomatic relations with Pretoria, urged a new approach to President F.W. de Klerk's government. ``The time has come for Africa to end its current opposition (to the South African goverment) and to encourage and support the efforts of President de Klerk,'' said Foreign Minister Simeon Ake. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny sent a telegram to Mandela appealing to him to negotiate with de Klerk and implicitly chiding the newly released leader for his endorsement of violence against apartheid. ``The whole world and all Africa is counting on you to work through dialogue toward a triumph for the noble cause of peace, equality and brotherhood,'' Boigny said. He also praised de Klerk, who visited the Ivory Coast in December. ``History will ... pay you homage for the personal part you have played in the changes that give great hopes to all South African people for the building of a great and democratic nation,'' Houphouet-Boigny said. Other African countries welcomed Mandela's release, but joined his African National Congress in warning that much work lies ahead. Nigeria's military government said Mandela's release is ``positive proof that concerted pressure on the apartheid regime, including mandatory sanctions, continue to have the desired effect.'' Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe urged the world not to be deceived into believing de Klerk has yet ``tackled the substantive issues of apartheid.'' Mugabe, like the leaders of Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Liberia, said Mandela's release must be followed by freedom for all political prisoners, the lifting of emergency regulations and the repeal of all racist laws. A Liberian government statement said Pretoria's action accentuated the need for continued international pressure on South Africa. But it welcomed Mandela's release from an imprisonment it called ``a violation of his fundamental human rights.'' Liberia itself is drawing increasing international criticism for human rights abuses that culminated in January with the alleged killings of at least 500 civilians by troops fighting to put down an ethnic rebellion. The killings have caused some 144,000 refugees to flee the country. As the world celebrated Mandela's release Sunday, the West African state of Senegal, which boasts it is a democracy, quickly detained opposition leader Abdoulaye Wade as he returned home from a six-month exile. Wade claims his Senegalese Democratic Party won February 1988 elections in which President Abdou Diouf claimed victory for his Socialist Party. Some Western countries accuse African governments of similar hypocrisy in their calls for sanctions against South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: the years.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, does the release of Nelson Mandela and the other steps announced by President De Klerk in South Africa alter in any way your views toward United States' economic sanctions, which, of course, the Reagan administration and you as a part of it were never very enthusiastic about? Bush: What do you mean, in the sense of altering my views as to what we ought to do in the future? Q: Well, as to whether they work or not. Bush: Well, I don't know that one can attribute all the change in South Africa to sanctions. Now, we've got some sanctions on there, and by law, they remain on until the South Africans have taken certain steps. And I think that, you know, somebody asked me about this yesterday, I said, ``Well, I can't judge.'' Frankly, I think some are counterproductive. I happen to think American jobs there make good sense, and I don't think they perpetuate the status quo. But I think what's really changed is the mindset of the South African leadership, and I think that we ought to give Mr. De Klerk certain credit for being able to look much more realistically about political change, and hopefully, more favorably about a society that eventually eliminates this racism that is equated with apartheid. Q: Well, would you be willing to push for the lifting of any of the sanctions before all of the conditions set forth in the law have been met? Bush: We can't do that. I'm bound by the law. And what I do want to do is discuss these provisions with Mr. Mandela and with Mr. De Klerk. And I've invited both of them to come here, and I also want to see them continue to talk with each other. And then out of that, I think we'll have a much more realistic picture of what the United States might do in the future. Q: Nelson Mandela continues to call for armed struggle to overturn apartheid. When he comes to the White House, would you urge him to adopt the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King? Bush: Yes, I would. But what I _ and I hope I didn't misread it. I read his statement to be more on the defensive side when I looked at it this morning. But I _ yes, we've always advocated nonviolence, and I think the United States ought not to move away from that. Q: If I can follow-up on the question of the sanctions. Are there things that you can do for the South African government apart from lifting sanctions? You realize that by law, you can't lift sanctions unilaterally. Are there other things you can do, other than just asking De Klerk to come to Washington? Bush: Well, I would say out of the meeting with Mr. De Klerk, I would have a clear perception of what other things might be. I think having him here is a major step. I think it's a very important step. And so I would simply have to defer on that question until I have a chance to talk to him. Q: Mr. President, there are those who say keeping on with sanctions _ that now is more of a time than ever to keep all the pressure on, and if not keeping the pressure on, even go one step further. I wonder if you intended your invitation to Mr. De Klerk as a reward for what he's done, given that no South African President has ever been here before? And secondly, do you think it's time, regardless of what you think of sanctions, to reward them in some other way? Bush: Reward? Q: Reward South Africa. Bush: Well, I don't know about rewards. I think his coming here evidences the fact that we see in him a new brand of leadership, a man who is making dramatic changes in South Africa. The freeing of Mandela clearly is a very positive sign. And so I think there's much more to be done, but there are things that he has done that I think deserve our support and, I'd say, appreciation because I think these steps he's taking move South Africa down the road towards racial equity. Q: Mr. President, on Germany. Would you be willing to consider a situation where a united Germany was not necessarily a full member of NATO? Bush: No, I think that Chancellor Kohl is absolutely correct and we ought to support him: NATO membership. And I think it's stabilizing, I think it's good. There might be some flexibility, obviously on deployment of NATO forces, but in terms of membership, I think that is the most reassuring and stabilizing concept. I happen to believe that is the most reassuring and stabilizing in terms of how the Eastern Europeans will eventually look at it, maybe not today _ Q: But you mean the same kind of membership that West Germany now has. Bush: Sure, yeah. But as I _ there's some flexibility on deployment of NATO forces into Eastern Europe. Nobody wants to threaten the Soviet Union. As I was trying to say to Helen, the U.S. presence is a stabilizing presence. Q: Mr. President, on the De Klerk visit that now seems to be almost a fait accompli, are there any conditions on that? Does he have to lift the state of emergency, and in your conversation with him, did he tell you when he would do that?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Sex Offenders Would Get Choice: Castration or Longer Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Senate on Monday narrowly passed a measure allowing sex offenders to choose castration in exchange for reducing their sentences by as much as 75 percent. The bill was approved 25-23 and sent to the House where Speaker Joe King said the measure probably won't come up before next year. ``We just don't know if we're ready to experiment on the public yet,'' King said. The measure, and other legislation aimed at repeat sex offenders, is the Legislature's reaction to recent crimes, including the sexual mutilation of a 7-year-old Tacoma boy. Senate critics accused backers of the bill of showing ``blood lust'' and said such a law would dump unrepentant sex criminals back on the streets years earlier than if they were to serve full prison terms. They predicted the courts would throw out such a law. But sponsors said studies have shown castration to cut repeat crime by 75 percent or more. ``Mutilation is too good for these people,'' said Sen. Brad Owen. ``It should be mandatory for these creeps.'' ``No one mentions cruel and unusual punishment of the citizens,'' agreed Sen. Bob McCaslin. Both houses have approved tough sex-crimes legislation suggested by a citizens task force appointed by Gov. Booth Gardner. Informal negotiations are under way to iron out the differences. That legislation includes stiffer sentences, a procedure for civil commitment of incorrigible sex offenders and more services for victims. Sen. Ellen Craswell, sponsor of the castration bill, and her Senate allies contend those efforts aren't enough. Surgical castration ``does affect violent behavior. The lowering of testosterone level affects violence,'' said Craswell, referring to a male sex hormon. She said she prefers life sentences for sex criminals. Foes of the castration bill said it won't survive constitutional scrutiny on 8th Amendment grounds of cruel and unusual punishment. They noted the South Carolina Supreme Court so ruled in the case of three rapists offered the option in exchange for suspended sentences. Craswell's measure includes provisions for court hearings before to castration to ensure the offender understands the legal, medical, emotional and psychological consequences of surgical castration. The bill would allow a 75 percent reduction from what the sentence normally would be under the standard sentencing range used by judges across the state. Gardner all but promised a veto if the measure should make it to his desk. Studies don't prove castration is an effective deterrent, and early releases for sex criminals could make the assault rate even worse, he said. In the mutilation case, Earl Kenneth Shiner, who had a history of violence to young people, was convicted last week of attempted murder, rape and assault and could be sentenced to 99 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: do that?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: There are no conditions on my invitation, if that's the question; absolutely not. Q: Well, would he come if the state of emergency has not been lifted? He hasn't done that _ Bush: I don't know, I don't know whether he would or not. Q: You didn't discuss that? Bush: No. I didn't discuss any conditions. I said I want him to come. ``You have freed Nelson Mandela, you have taken certain steps that are positive and we want to see more, we want to see you go further, but you're welcome.'' And that's the way _ Q: Mr. President, do you have any second thoughts about the trip last week? I'm especially thinking of the war games with the Soviet tanks, particularly when your views on the defense budget are well known and the Central Committee was meeting at the same time? Bush: No, I think it was a good trip and I've read some tick-tock inside here, but it doesn't bother me a bit. I think that those people that were there understood that that training has applications elsewhere. We've seen recent areas where military force was used because it was well trained. And so I stand by that was a very good trip. You see, I support our defense budget. I think it makes sense, and the fact that we've got some critics up there that don't like it, that's too bad. I think the American people want to see us stay strong. Q: What signal does that send to Mr. Gorbachev, however, you just praised a few minutes ago? Bush: Well, it sent a pretty good one, I guess, because we came out of that meeting with some forward motion and I salute him. I can't say the trip to the state of California's desert had a heck of a lot to do with it, but if you'd listen to some of the critique from Capitol Hill you'd have thought it had been a disaster. And yet, I've told you, we've just completed one of the most successful ministerial summits that we've had with the Soviets. So, you can't _ the critics up there on the Hill can't have it both ways. Q: I just wanted to follow up on the East Germany question. You said you thought that the Eastern Europeans would ultimately come to see this alliance with NATO as a positive thing too. Are you suggesting, sir, that there is something less threatening about a Germany that is in alliance _ in the alliance rather than a neutral Germany? Bush: I think so because I think that a Germany inside the NATO alliance _ they're good NATO partners now and they'll be good NATO partners then. And they're very closely linked to the United States and I think that's a very good thing. Q: Can I just turn that around? Do you think that a neutral Germany does pose a threat and potentially could be dangerous? Bush: Well, I know that's the concern of many Europeans, but it's not the concern that _ it's a concern that would be allayed by having West Germany _ having Germany a unified Germany inside of NATO. Q: Mr. President, you indicated you don't think the conventional talks are at an impasse. Would you be willing to consider an arrangement, an agreement in which the U.S. was able to keep extra troops in Europe, but at a number somewhat less than the 30,000? Bush: Well, we've made our proposal. Our allies _ I don't make these proposals without consulting the allies _ and there's agreement that these are the proper levels. It's a level that has been scrubbed by our military and I think there's a happiness in our own military about this. For this time in history, I think it's the right level. And, so, we're not out there trying to trade that away. Q: Mr. President, you said _ you talk often about the importance of free markets to democracy, but Nelson Mandela supports the ANC view about nationalizing the South African industries, including banks and mines. How do you feel about that? And does that pose a problem for real democracy in South Africa? Bush: We are not for nationalizing, we are for privatization across the _ we're for free markets. And, so, if we have a difference there, that's fine. We'll discuss it with him. But I'm not about to embrace the idea that what we want to do is go down to more socialism when socialism is folding, folding its hand and going over to the other side all across the world. I mean, you see this. So, this is _ this is, you know, a difference that we _ if that's his view, why, certainly we're not going to embrace that. Q: Is that a severe obstacle, though, to having a successful democracy there? Bush: Privatization of all the _ I mean, nationalization of all the _ I don't necessarily associate nationalization, socialization of industry, the goods and services produced belonging to the state, I don't see that as particularly helpful towards democracy, if that's what you mean. But what I think and what I do agree with Mandela is, is to try to get a society that is _ that is not a racist society, doesn't support a concept of apartheid. Q: On South Africa, the question is how far _ how willing are you to become personally involved, your administration become personally involved in facilitating negotiations between Mr. Mandela and President De Klerk? Are you ready to play a role like President Carter did in the Camp David Accords on the Middle East?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Program Will Boost Farm Income
DOC.TEXT: The massive land-idling Conservation Reserve Program will boost farm income and improve environmental quality through the end of the century, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. But consumers will pay somewhat higher food prices as farmers take up to 45 million acres of highly erodible cropland from production under 10-year contracts, the report said. The CRP was authorized by the 1985 farm law and signups so far have resulted in about 34 million acres, an area almost the size of Michigan. ``Consumer food costs will climb by $12.7 billion to $25.2 billion over the life of the CRP, peaking around 1995,'' the report said. ``Food cost increases will be less than 1 percent in any given year.'' Under the plan, farmers agree to take fragile, highly erodible land from crop production and plant it to protective grass and trees. In return, the government helps pay the cost of the initial plantings and then pays the farmer annual rent during the 10 years of the contract. The payments average about $50 per acre annually. The report, prepared by the department's Economic Research Service, was based on an assumption that the maximum of 45 million acres would be enrolled in the long-term program. However, Congress set a minimum of 40 million acres to go with the maximum of 45 million acres, and administration officials have indicated the minimum will be the target. Robert J. Gray, a private conservation specialist and consultant, said 45 million acres had been thought a reasonable goal for the CRP. He said 5 million acres probably could be added to the minimum 40 million through tree plantings in shelterbelts, windbreaks and other projects. ``I would prefer 45 million acres, no question about it,'' Gray said in a telephone interview. He said he had not seen the new USDA report. The report said that 45 million acres in the CRP for 10 years ``increases commodity prices and reduces environmental problems linked with soil erosion.'' Further, it added, the price increases and production cuts ``cause ripple effects in the farm sector, agricultural industries and other segments of the economy'' related to U.S. agriculture. ``Farm income (based on present values) will rise by $9.2 billion to $20.3 billion between 1986 and 1999 from higher commodity prices and lower production costs,'' the report said. ``Landowners who plant trees as the cover crop on approximately 3.5 million CRP acres will gain $4.1 billion to $5.4 billion in wealth.'' Environmental benefits were estimated at $6 billion to $13.6 billion, mostly in off-farm areas being affected by agricultural soil erosion. The value of improvements in surface water quality from the CRP ranges from $1.9 billion to $5.3 billion. Wildlife habitat improvement was valued from $3 billion to $4.7 billion, and wind erosion abatement was projected at $400 million to $1.1 billion. ``A 45-million-acre CRP will cost the federal government $21.5 billion to $22.8 billion in rents, bonuses, cost-sharing and technical assistance,'' the report said. ``Most of these costs are offset by savings in price and income support payments to farmers.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspended `60 Minutes' Humorist Says Off-Camera Endorsements Are Better
DOC.TEXT: Andy Rooney said Monday he appreciates what ``60 Minutes'' anchorman Mike Wallace said on the show about his suspension from CBS but added that it was nothing like the off-camera endorsement he got. ``I got great support from Mike on Friday,'' Rooney said in a telephone interview. ``It was just wonderful. I wish the statement on `60 Minutes' had been as good as he was in person.'' Rooney said the statement by Wallace, made during the regular Sunday ``60 Minutes'' broadcast, was written by ``60 Minutes'' producer Don Hewitt. The noncommittal statement acknowledged Rooney's suspension and said his colleagues looked forward to his return. Rooney at first declined to say what he thought of the statement but then added: ``I thought it would have been nice if it would have been stronger in my support.'' Rooney was suspended last week for three months by CBS News President David Burke after a gay magazine, The Advocate, quoted him as saying blacks have watered down their genes because ``the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children.'' The 69-year-old humorist denies having said it. The telephone interview with Advocate reporter Chris Bull was not tape-recorded. Rooney says the support he's received from colleagues and strangers alike has been ``incredible.'' A CBS spokesman said the network's audience services unit has received about 2,600 phone calls backing Rooney and 45 supporting his suspension. ``It's like being at your own funeral. People I didn't even know liked me have come to my support,'' Rooney said. ``People are beginning to see that it was a statement made by people with a cause who were out to get me _ and got me,'' he said. Rooney had angered the gay community when he said on a Dec. 28 broadcast that ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced.'' He then cited ``too much alcohol, too much food, homosexual unions, cigarettes.'' Rooney, a CBS employee for 40 years and ``60 Minutes'' humorist since 1978, said he accepted the suspension because he had no choice. ``I have my money, but I like my work. ... I did not want to lose it, if that was weak of me. Of the alternatives, this was the lesser.'' Asked what his professional relationship with higher-ups would be when he returned, Rooney said, ``They were awfully nice to me. I don't know, it would be difficult in relationship to Mr. Burke, if he's still there. It would be hard.'' Rooney said he went to CBS Saturday to pick up some reference books and paperwork but has not been in the office otherwise. ``I don't know that I couldn't but I haven't. It just seems like bad taste.'' He said ``It's not easy for me to go out these days'' and added that he was being hounded by supermarket tabloids and ``tacky TV shows.'' Rooney said he would use the suspension to work on a new book about his experiences as an Army reporter during World War II, write his twice-weekly syndicated newspaper column and concentrate on ``losing weight.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: Middle East?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: If such a role would be productive, I certainly would. But I have the feeling from the talks with both men _ just the short phone conversations with both Mr. De Klerk and Mr. Mandela _ that they feel they can talk to each other without the U.S. catalytic role. But sure, if we could be helpful in a way of that nature, we certainly would. Q: Mr. President, there are some people who are questioning the need for a conventional forces treaty at all at this point, the argument being that we're at a situation in which the East European countries are going to invite all the Soviet troops to go home anyway, and all that we'd be doing is codifying the Soviet presence that isn't even wanted in Eastern Europe. What's your response to that argument? Bush: I'd say it's very interesting and it may well be that the pressure on the Soviets will have them withdraw to lower levels. I don't think there's great sentiment in the Warsaw Pact countries for a continued Soviet presence and that _ I'm not sure that it would negate the need to have an agreement, I think the Soviets would like to get our commitment, too. But you see, those troops are not wanted in Eastern Europe anymore. Our troops are wanted by the free world, and I suspect _ can't prove it _ that some countries in the Warsaw Pact countries today would see us not as a threatening presence, but as a stabilizing presence. Q: But is it possible the Soviets might use the treaty as an excuse to keep troops where they're not even wanted? Bush: I don't think they can do that. I think they've got a problem with a treaty _ a CFE treaty with us and others, but they also have the problem of opinion inside these countries, and they have enormous budgetary problems that make things very difficult. Q: Mr. President, what was your reaction to the rather effusive embrace of the South African Communist Party and the presence of the communist party flag on the balcony when Mr. Mandela made his speech yesterday? Bush: I didn't notice that, but you see, I think these communist parties, for the most part, are sliding downhill. And I think what's coming uphill, and triumphantly so, is democracy and freedom. And I would hope that the steps that Mr. De Klerk is taking and has suggested be taken would enhance the view that democracy and freedom are on the move. Q: To follow up, sir. If Mr. Mandela persists in allying himself with the Communist Party, would that change your view of his _ Bush: Too hypothetical. I mean, what's good is that he's out there _ been in jail a long time _ and an interesting question back here, but I'm not embracing every position of the ANC or of some of the positions that are represented here today as Mr. Mandela's positions. What I am doing is embracing the concept that it's good that he's out of jail, and that it's good that the South Africans seem to be moving towards a more equitable society. Q: Do you think it's time for a conference of the Four Powers on Germany? Bush: No, not at this juncture. I know that idea has some credibility right now, but I think it's moving along pretty well, and we have always favored the self determination and _ but the Germans have to sort this out at some point. Clearly, the Four Powers will have to have some say, there's no question about that. Whether it's two plus four or what the formulation is, we are not locked on that at all. Q: If Gorbachev continues to insist on German neutrality, Mr. President, do you think that could create a dangerous impasse that would spawn a neutrality movement in West Germany? Bush: Not necessarily, but I think that we've seen the Soviet Union's position change on the whole concept or the whole acceptability of German reunification. It wasn't so long ago that Mr. Gorbachev and the Soviet system were positioned very skeptically about any reunification. And that's what was so symbolic about the Kohl-Gorbachev meeting, and so important about it. And I might say that it's a very emotional day for people in Germany, GDR and FRG, highly emotional; brother separated from brother, cousin from cousin and all of this, now with the chance to have a peaceful reunification.
