DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.BYLINE: Leadership Calls for Establishment of Strong Presidential Rule ^By MARK J. PORUBCANSKY
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leaders called Monday for a special session of Congress to strengthen the office of president, a move that would solidify Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hold on power. The development, coming on the heels of a landmark Communist Party meeting at which the party agreed to give up its constitutional monopoly on power, would strengthen the government and further erode the party apparatus that has ruled the country for 72 years. Gorbachev now holds the offices of party general-secretary and of president. The new powers being proposed for the president would make it more of a Western-style office. Tass said the presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the country's highest executive body, ``unanimously favored the establishment of democratic presidential power in our country.'' The statement did not say whether the president should be directly elected by voters, but one of Gorbachev's key allies on the Communist Party Politburo said last week that a nationwide popular election might be possible. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, speaking at the three-day meeting last week of the party's policy-making Central Committee, said a new draft of the Soviet Constitution now being written could include ``direct and general elections for president of the country.'' Gorbachev ducked the question of whether he would run for president if the office were up for national balloting. ``Let's wait and see,'' he told reporters on hand for his meeting Friday with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The party's Central Committee approved the idea of a strong presidency at its meeting last week. But in the text of its new platform, released Monday night in Moscow, the party leadership left open the question of how the new, stronger president should be selected. It said a strong presidency is necesary to ensure stability, make reforms irreversible, make all government institutions democratic, ensure law and order, and represent the Soviet Union abroad. Another key Gorbachev ally on the Politburo, Alexander N. Yakovlev, said Gorbachev was seeking election of a president to a fixed term and would empower the president to choose the Cabinet. Gorbachev is now serving a five-year term as chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, informally referred to as president, but his real power base remains the party, which he leads as general secretary. But the party post has no certain term, and in recent weeks party reformers have expressed concern that he could be ousted by hard-liners opposed to his dramatic reforms. The party platform called for consolidation of the ``positions and prerogatives of the Council of Ministers,'' or Cabinet, but it was not clear what would happen to the post of premier. That job now is held by Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. The party Central Committee decision last week cleared the way for eventual establishment of opposition political parties. The party leadership will call on legislators to remove the Soviet Constitution's Article 6, which establishes the Communist Party as the ``leading and guiding force'' in Soviet society. Tass said the presidium, headed by Gorbachev, would ask the Supreme Soviet, or legislature, to call its 2,250-member parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies, into session in the near future. No date was proposed. The Supreme Soviet reconvenes on Wednesday and is likely to follow the recommendation of its presidium. All constitutional questions, such as powers of the presidency, must be decided by the Congress, which is supposed to meet briefly twice a year. Under reforms pushed through by Gorbachev in December 1988, the president is chosen by the Congress. The presidium said it called for the convening of Congress because of the debate going on in Soviet society about the role of the Communist Party and political reforms. Government leaders want the Congress to consider a variety of other issues concerning the Soviet political system, the ownership of property and strengthening the Soviet government, the Tass report said.

DOC.HEAD: Rocker Billy Idol Faces More Surgery to Repair Motorcycle Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Spiked-haired rocker Billy Idol, who has twice undergone surgery to repair a leg mangled in a motorcycle crash, faces at least one more operation, a hospital spokesman said Monday. Idol was in fair condition at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center after surgery Sunday, the second operation on his right leg since his accident a week ago. ``There is a least one more surgery scheduled that I know of,'' said spokesman Ron Wise. ``It will probably be done within a week.'' It wasn't immediately clear what impact the operation would have on Idol's plans to appear in a film by Oliver Stone on the life of the Doors' lead singer, Jim Morrison. Filming is to begin next month, and Idol was to play the late rock star's best friend. Idol's publicist, Ellen Golden, said it would likely be several days before Idol knows if he'll be able to go ahead with the movie and a concert tour this summer. She said Idol remains in good spirits and spent much of the weekend listening to the album he completed just before the accident. She said actor Jack Nicholson, rocker Eric Clapton and comedian Don Rickles have sent Idol gifts or get-well wishes. Sunday's operation was to repair muscle damage. Skin graft surgery was also to be performed, but because of the complexity of the muscle repair work, doctors decided to postpone that part of the work, Wise said. ``This is not like tripping over a pair of roller skates and fracturing your ankle on the back stairs, which can be bad enough. This is a very serious break he sustained,'' Wise said. Wise declined to speculate on how much longer the British star would be hospitalized or how much rehabilitation he would require. On Idol's side, he said, is good health and upbeat attitude. ``He's young, he's strong. He has been an excellent patient,'' Wise said. ``Everyone who has worked with him has been enormously impressed by his character and how cooperative he is. He's generally won a lot friends around the medical center.'' Idol, 34, underwent his first operation immediately after Tuesday's crash. Police said he ran a stop sign and sideswiped a car while driving home from a studio where he had just completed work on the album ``Charmed Life,'' which is to be released April 17.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Sinking Nine Ships, Capturing 46 Tanks
DOC.TEXT: Eritrean rebels said Monday they sank nine Navy vessels and captured 46 tanks in three assaults on the Red Sea port of Massawa in northern Ethiopia. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said 21 crew and a large but unspecified number of army personnel also were taken prisoner during the siege. The rebels said ``fierce'' fighting was continuing in a separate attack they launched Sunday east of Karan, 55 miles west of Massawa. It was not possible to independently confirm the rebel claims made in a statement issued in Khartoum, Sudan, where the Eritrean Front maintains an office. In Addis Ababa, the government issued no more information on the fighting after saying Sunday its troops and the rebels were battling for control of Massawa. However, the government did not directly deny a Saturday night claim by the rebels that they had captured Massawa, one of the country's only two ports. The rebel statement Monday said government troops were withdrawing from the city but made no mention of whether they were being evacuated by sea or were fleeing into the arid countryside. In their Saturday broadcast, the rebels claimed to have seized control of the 40-mile road that connects Massawa and Eritrea's capital, Asmara. If the rebel claim is true, Asmara would be virtually cut off from Addis Ababa except by air. Another rebel group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, cut the southern road to Addis Ababa more than a year ago. The Eritrean Front did not specify the types of nine vessels sunk or tanks captured, but the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies says Ethiopia has two frigates and 21 patrol craft, some carrying missiles and torpedoes. The rebels are known to have speedboats with cannons and machine guns. The Eritrean Front offensive began Thursday after a lull lasting nearly a year. Late last year, the rebels held peace talks in Atlanta and Nairobi, with former President Carter mediating. Both parties agreed to meet again and seek an end to the 28-year-old war, Africa's longest, but set no dates. The renewed fighting around Massawa effectively halted relief operations by the United Nations, which hoped to ship most of 700,000 tons of food through the port in the next few months to northern drought victims, mainly in Eritrea and its southern neighbor, Tigre. The Eritrean offensive came as the government appeared to be regaining ground the Tigrean rebels captured when they swept out of their strongholds in Tigre in late August and moved south and west into Wollo, Showa and Gonder provinces. The Tigre and Eritrean Fronts have different goals, but have coordinated their attacks in the past. The Eritreans want independence for their province while the Tigreans seek President Mengistu Haile Mariam's ouster and the establishment of a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe. Most of Ethiopia's soldiers are poorly paid conscripts who are often shipped to front lines with little training. The army suffered a leadership crisis last May with the arrest of virtually all top commanders following an abortive coup against Mengistu.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Concerned About Reports of Chinese Restrictions on Students
With AM-Bush Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed concern Monday about reports of new restrictions China is imposing on students who want to study abroad. ``I thought that was counterproductive, very much so,'' Bush said at a news conference that dealt with a wide-ranging array of topics. China is requiring students to spend five years working in China or to pay large sums of money to the government as a deposit before they go abroad. The Chinese State Education Commission, in promulgating the rules recently, said it was acting to ensure that students return home rather than staying abroad once their education is complete. Bush said he was disturbed by reports of the move. ``I feel that student exchanges are very good things to have between our countries,'' Bush said. ``I know that some visas have recently been given to students, so I'd want to check the statement against the reality.'' Bush last month won a veto battle with Congress over legislation that would have guaranteed visa rights for Chinese students now in this country who are afraid to return home. Bush said no Chinese student who fears recriminations at home will be deported, but he said passage of the legislation would have antagonized Chinese leaders and could possibly have erson, the longest-held Western hostage, ``we are at a loss to understand'' why he is being held. ``As all governments have made clear that they are not prepared to barter his release, we urge all those who have any influence with his captors to join in urging his release,'' the commission, a private organization, said in a statement. The call by the Geneva-based commission coincided with a trip to Geneva by Peggy Say, Anderson's sister, who has long campaigned on his behalf. Her meetings with international organizations launched a three-week tour of Europe and the Middle East for talks with global leaders in a new effort to win his release. The jurists' commission, winner of several international human rights awards, appealed ``on humanitarian grounds to those who are holding him to set him free.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, was kidnapped on a Beirut street March 16, 1985. Like most of the 17 other Western hostages in Lebanon, he is believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremists. The International Commission of Jurists appeal also urged freedom for all other hostages in Lebanon. It specifically mentioned the latest two, Emanuel Christen and Elio Enrique, health professionals working for the all-Swiss International Committee of the Red Cross, who were kidnapped last October. ``My heart goes out to the families of the Swiss hostages,'' said Say, of Cadiz, Ky. ``I know they share our sense of outrage and frustration.'' Say held talks Monday with International Commission of Jurists and Red Cross officials. She also met Morris Abram, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N. Human Rights Commission and other international bodies in Geneva. She next meets Pope John Paul II in the Vatican on Wednesday, continuing what she calls a ``journey of peace, reconciliation and hope.'' Say also will also be visiting the archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, in London; the European Parliament's Committee on Human Rights in Strasbourg, France; and U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization director Federico Mayor in Paris. She said she also hopes to see Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Iranian leaders. Iranian officials have not responded to efforts to arrange a meeting. Sheikh Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, the spiritual head of Hezbollah, believed to be an umbrella group for Shiite Moslem kidnappers, refused to meet outside Lebanon. Say, who has traveled widely to seek her brother's release, is being accompanied by her husband and AP executives.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: peaceful reunification.
DOC.TEXT: And so, I don't want to buy into any real hypothesis on what might happen, but I think we ought to applaud the fact that the Soviets demonstrated a real flexibility on this question, that we didn't think they had a few months ago. Q: Can I just follow? Do you now think, then, that German reunification is unstoppable and that Gorbachev will back-off his demand? Bush: Well, I think again I'd just refer it to the will of the people there, and it seems to be moving very fast in that direction. Q: So what is your visceral reaction to the resignation of Ariel Sharon and its effect on the peace process? And is this part of a pattern of the hardliners losing out around the world? Bush: You know, I just heard about this, and I have to understand more about what went on there. But Mr. Shamir was a proponent of these talks, and if this clears the way for the talks to go forward, that would be in keeping with U.S. policy. Q: When you talked with Mr. De Klerk and Mr. Mandela, did you talk about democracy and freedom, did you make the point that in our understanding of democracy the majority rules? Bush: We didn't go in _ yeah _ Q: I especially was wondering about De Klerk. Or will you talk with him about that when he comes? Bush: I am sure we will, and with Mr. Mandela _ but that did not come up in these conversations; none o the detail here on the various sanctions or anything of that nature came up. Q: Is that what you would tell him? It's De Klerk I'm speaking of. Bush: Well, let's wait and see what happens when he gets here. Q: Sir, we have a big problem in this country with the bases that we have being closed and the tens of thousands of personnel we have to let go out of the military and out of the civilian roles, too. I wonder if you would be for taking these military bases and turning them into prisons rather than building new prisons and if you'd be for using the extra housing for the homeless? Bush: Well, Sarah, let me say this, that when military bases close, various communities, historically, seem to prosper. And I think of one in Waco, Texas where a base was closed, it was, oh, years ago _ all kinds of speculation that this would be the end of the world, and then gradually found out that it doesn't work that way. And so, I think there will be socially redeeming uses for these benefits that municipalities and county governments and others may _ these bases that these entities may want to use them for. And so, I would say that it's a good question because we can say to others, this is not the end of the world. But let me say on base closings, I _ these suggested closings were made without political favor and I would hope that we could get the Congress convinced that the age-old adage, ``Cut here, cut there, but don't cut in my district'' could be laid aside now. And I hope that that's what will prevail. I said out there in San Francisco that instant doves become feathery instant hawks on base closings if only it's in their district. And I want to see that change, and I've got to convince these folks that we are not doing this in some vindictive political way. We're doing it to try to accommodate to what will be a new kind of defense force in this country. Q: Mr. President, I wonder if you could clarify your position on your hopes for the June summit. Is it your view that it may be possible there, if not necessarily to sign formal treaties, but to substantially complete the CFE and the START and even maybe the chemical _ Bush: Chemical. I'd hope we'd be substantially completed is a good way to phrase it. Q: You _ your assistant secretary for Africa seems to suggest that some sort of gestures were now needed toward South Africa. Has there been any discussion of that, or have you pretty much ruled it out, any concrete move, until the state of emergency is lifted? Bush: Well, we have certain provisions in the law that have to be met. But I would hope people would see the invitation to Mr. De Klerk as a _ certainly as a gesture _ but one that will have, after the discussions with him, I think considerable more substance, too. Q: Can you support a situation back to Germany where there is membership, let's say political membership in NATO, but not a military relationship that exists now, with the possibility of no foreign troops on German soil and a unified Germany? Bush: I don't think we're contemplating a neutralized Germany, and I have stated my position in terms of the Alliance. And that's the way we view it, and I'm sure that's the way our allies look at it. Q: Could I ask how, since you had mentioned that unification is a matter to be left to the German people, if there were some referendum where they wanted a configuration without foreign troops on German soil, how would you deal with it? Bush: I would cross that bridge when I came to it, but I would point out that Helmut Kohl, to his credit, is not considering that. Q: Mr. President, in a different hemisphere. Over the past couple of months when asked why you're going to Cartagena this week, you've said want to show support for the government down there. Now as you're just a couple of days away, do you expect to do anything more than that _ than show the flag? Do you expect anything concrete to come out of it; perhaps increased use of military down there?

DOC.HEAD: Manhunt for Five Escapees Focuses on Chicago
DOC.TEXT: A manhunt for five men, including three convicted murderers, who escaped from a maximum-security state prison focused on the Chicago area Monday. A sixth escapee was captured late Sunday near his cousin's home in Chicago, and the five still at large _ described as extremely dangerous _ were believed to have also headed for the city, said corrections spokesman Nic Howell. The inmates, who escaped Sunday from the Joliet Correctional Facility, may have ties to Chicago or may simply hope to lose themselves in the large metropolitan area, he said. ``We have no reason to think that these guys are out of state or are not in the general vicinity of Chicago,'' Howell said. But authorities have no specific leads, he said, noting the recaptured inmate had provided little information. ``Nothing has panned out yet,'' Howell said. Early Sunday morning, the inmates apparently cut through bars on their cells, broke a window and cut through bars outside it, then climbed a low fence and fled the northern Illinois prison undetected, Howell said. About 100 corrections officers and officials were involved in the case _ either helping with the search or the internal investigation and security review at the prison. The prison houses 1,300 inmates, 500 more than it was intended to hold, but Howell said he didn't know if the crowded conditions contributed to the escape. The six prisoners were last accounted for at 4:55 a.m. Sunday. The escape was discovered when a headcount came up short at 7 a.m., Howell said. The men escaped from segregation cells, where they were being kept because of disciplinary problems, he said. Four of the men were doubled up, two to a cell, and the other two were alone in their cells. Tommy Munoz of Chicago was captured just after 5:30 p.m. Sunday by prison authorities who had staked out his cousin's house on the city's Southwest Side, about 40 miles east of the prison, Howell said. Munoz was returned to the Joliet, where he was serving a two-year sentence for narcotics violations and intimidation, the spokesman said. Still at large were: _Daniel Johnson, 24, of Burns, Tenn., imprisoned for murder. _James F. Allen, 40, of Chicago, imprisoned for three murders. _Dave Rodriguez, 21, of Chicago, imprisoned for murder. _Terry W. Colburn, 21, of Bloomington, imprisoned for burglary. _Ronald Roach, in his 20s, of Wyoming, Ill., imprisoned for burglary.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Former Celtics Owner Gets $5 Million Malpractice Verdict
DOC.TEXT: The family of Robert Schmertz, a former owner of the Boston Celtics basketball team, has been awarded more than $5 million because of Schmertz's death due to negligence following brain surgery. Almost 13 years after the malpractice lawsuit was filed, a jury in Manhattan's State Supreme Court awarded $4 million to Schmertz's widow, Phyllis, who lives in Florida. The jury also awarded $500,000 to each of his two mentally handicapped children, Ronald and Jane, who live at the Woods School in Langhorne, Pa., and it gave $50,000 to his third child, Nancy, who lives in Manhattan. The children are Schmertz's from a previous marriage. The award will be paid by Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, where Schmertz, 48, had surgery July 15, 1975, for cranial bleeding due to a congenital condition, said Steve Mangione, spokesman for Schmertz's lawyer, Thomas Moore. The hospital's lawyer, Luke Pittoni, could not be reached for comment Monday, but Mangione said hospital lawyers said they would appeal the verdict. Schmertz's operation was a success, but the jury found that the anesthesiologist, Dr. Richard Matteo, and others were negligent because they failed to monitor Schmertz's heart and breathing properly in the recovery room, Mangione said. Shortly after entering the recovery room, Mangione said, Schmertz vomited and aspirated the vomit into his lungs, further compromising his breathing. He lapsed into a coma and died July 23, eight days later, Mangione said. The hospital said it was unable to produce records and X-rays that documented what happened to Schmertz, Mangione said. He said Moore felt it was ``more than a coincidence that the two crucial X-rays and the documentation were missing.'' However, on the eve of the trial, Columbia-Presbyterian brought in a videotape of the Schmertz operation, which the hospital said would show that the surgeon, James MacMurtrey, caused Schmertz's death, Mangione said. But Moore observed that the hospital had been using that video for 13 years to instruct surgical residents in how to perform correctly the procedure done on Schmertz. MacMurtrey was eventually removed from the case as a defendant. The jury ruled Friday following a three-week trial and two days of deliberations. Schmertz owned the Celtics from 1972 to 1975, Mangione said. He was also a part owner of the Hartford Whalers and a co-founder of the now-defunct USFL.

DOC.HEAD: Honey Production Drops 21 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Honey production dropped 21 percent last year to 169 million pounds, the Agriculture Department said Monday. About 3.3 million colonies produced honey in 1989, a 3 percent increase from 1988, according to the annual report. But the average yield per colony was only 51.1 pounds, down from 66.3 pounds in 1988. ``Adverse conditions were encountered in most states and included wet weather, restrictions on movement early in the year, dry weather, disease and mite infestations throughout the year,'' the report said. Price for the 1989 crop averaged 48.4 cents per pound, down 1.6 cents from 1988, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Group Says Bush Plan Could Be Hard on Farmers
DOC.TEXT: A national dairy organization said Monday the Bush administration's farm bill proposals would mean hardships for milk producers and consumers. The Bush proposal announced last week would continue the Agriculture Department's current basic milk price support formula but also seeks more flexibility in adjusting supports in line with market conditions. ``This plan would only create more instability in the dairy industry, with wilder swings in consumer prices and the loss of dairy farmers throughout the country,'' said Tom Camerlo, president of the National Milk Producers Federation. Camerlo said in the federation's newsletter that the plan amounts to ``even more and deeper price cuts'' for dairy farmers than allowed by the current law.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: down there?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: Well, I do think that we want to support Mr. Barco, a courageous leader. And I think going there will certainly indicate how strongly I feel about that. But I think there will be more than that come out of it. I hope we can get agreement in terms of support for the anti-narcotics efforts in these three countries: Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. What was the last part? Q: Anything in particular, like the increased use of the military, the plan that seemed to have been scuttled earlier to use U.S. warships off the coast of Colombia? Bush: Well, what happened on that plan was some mischievous stories that suggested blockade. So, one of the things I'll try to do _ because there was never any intention of a blockade. Absolutely absurd. And yet that threw a panic amongst many of the Colombians who said, ``We don't want a blockade off our coast.'' And that wasn't what ever had been intended. But in terms of interdiction, what I'd like to convince them is that we can be extraordinarily helpful, particularly to Colombia, in their courageous fight against narco-traffickers by a sophisticated interdiction effort. Q: Mr. President, on the same subject. Some observers and some headlines recently have talked about we're winning the war on drugs, and I believe your last statement, you said, ``We're just starting on the war on drugs.'' Bush: Starting to win. Q: We're starting to win. Bush: Combine the two statements. We'll meld them. Q: What, as you head for the drug summit, what will you tell the other leaders about the status of the war on drugs in this country? Bush: I'll tell _ one of the points I'll emphasize at the beginning is: Look, I know you three leaders think that this is all the fault _ not entirely _ but a lot of the fault because of the demand in the United States. And let me assure you we're not just talking about interdiction. We're not just talking about anti-crime aspects of this in the United States. We're talking about major efforts on the demand side, a major initiative. And a lot of it _ most of it is out in the private sector, in the schools, to educate people against the use of narcotics. Because they think that it's all _ that the United States is causing all this problem. It's changed a little bit, because some of them are beginning to see user problems inside their own countries or neighboring countries or countries that have crossed the ocean even. So, I think we've got to convince them that we are going out on all fronts, and I think I can do that. Q: As a follow-up, sir. They're, from what we've have heard, going to ask you for more money for crop substitution, to substitute other goods for the coca crop down there. Will the U.S. put its money where it's mouth is on that? Bush: Well, we'll listen to what they have to say on it, but they should _ ought not to be condoning the growth of crops that are illegal in some areas, and certainly crops that are clearly used in the cocaine trade. And so that's a moral question. I'd try to put it on that kind of emphasis, and then see what we can do over here in terms of trying to help financially. Q: You said that Eastern European countries want the Soviet troops to leave, and you've also pointed to the progress in talks about conventional force reductions, but the fact of the matter is virtually all those Soviet troops are still there now in Eastern Europe. Bush: Yes. Q: Can you point to any real progress on the ground in terms of any changes in Soviet troop deployments in Eastern Europe? And to what extent do you see the continued threat for reversals, politically, inside the East Bloc that could cause those troops to continue to be deployed? Bush: To be wanted? I can't see a political change inside the Eastern European countries that would have an invitation go out to please remain. I don't see any politics, or any political changes that would make me think that that is a likely _ a likely scenario right now. But _ and I do think that you put your finger on something, they have not I don't know, I was looking for Brent to see if any have been pulled back at all. Gen. Brent Scowcroft: Yes, they have. Bush: And he says some have, so we'll have to get you the information on exactly what withdrawals have taken place. Q:Mr. President, do you have a date for the summit with Mr. Gorbachev yet? Bush: I don't think we've set the exact date. Q: Mr. President, when you won the China veto vote, you said there were signs things were easing up in Beijing. Now they say they want, before students can leave the country to study abroad, they'll have to spend five years at work. Isn't this backsliding? Or is there some evidence that you have that things are easing up in China? Bush: Well, I'm disturbed by that statement, I don't like that statement, because I feel that student exchanges are very good things to have between our countries. I know that some visas have recently been given to students, so I'd want to check the statement against the reality. I know that some students over there have been issued visas to come to the United States. But I saw the statement, and if you just want me to comment on the statement, I thought that was counterproductive _ very much so. Q: Mr. President, has the current oil spill in Southern California in any way changed your thinking about the wisdom of further development of offshore oil lease sales? And what is your timetable for when you're going to make the decision on those lease sales?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Farm Employment Down 2 Percent in Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of workers employed by farmers declined seasonally in January and was down about 2 percent from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said Monday. A quarterly report said the hired work force on farms was estimated at 690,000 during the week of Jan. 7-13, down from 983,000 in October. A year ago in January, the work force was 701,000. Those did not include 143,000 ``agricultural service'' workers provided by crew chiefs and labor contractors. In October, those totaled 308,000 workers, and in January 1989 they were estimated at 152,000. Mostly dry weather and above-normal temperatures prevailed across the nation during the Jan. 7-13 survey week, the report said. The report said the national figures for hired workers had a sampling error of 3.7 percent. Average pay for all workers hired directly by farmers was reported at $5.70 per hour, up from $5.42 in October and $5.51 a year ago, the report said. For workers hired by contractors, there was no national wage rate available. However, workers in California were reported at $6.20 per hour, compared with $6.41 in October and $6.42 a year ago. Florida workers averaged $6.23 per hour, compared with $5.15 in October and $5.79 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Boxers Return Home After Disputed Match
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for COLUMBUS, Ohio, datelined story on AM-News Advisory. Stories on the boxers' return also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Boxer Buster Douglas returned home to a hero's welcome Monday, greeted by hundreds of fans who wanted to see the man who surprised heavyweight champion Mike Tyson in Tokyo, while Tyson's homecoming was more subdued. When Douglas left Columbus, Ohio, and headed for Tokyo to fight Tyson, he left in obscurity. Hardly anyone noticed or cared. But he was met by a cheering crowd when his plane landed Monday. His grandmother, Sarah Jones, stepped to a microphone, held the World Boxing Council belt high in the air and said: ``We did it, Columbus, we got it. And now we're going to keep it.'' The crowd cheered. Douglas was introduced by his manager, John Johnson, and the crowd cheered again. Douglas, 29, shocked the boxing world Sunday with his 10th-round knockout of Tyson, who went down to his first defeat in 38 fights. But two of boxing's three governing bodies suspended Douglas' victory, pending review of film to determine if Douglas received a long count when Tyson knocked him down in the eighth round. The International Boxing Federation said it recognized Douglas as the champion, but the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association suspended the result pending their investigation. They could order a rematch. In New York, fans called out ``you're still the champ, Mike,'' when Tyson and promoter Don King arrived at JFK Airport. ``I had a pretty bad performance but I'm not going to make excuses,'' Tyson said. ``I'm just going to go on and make better results.'' ``I've lost before,'' he said, referring to fights during his amateur career. ``It's no big deal. I've always come back from a loss. I feel great. I have a slight swelling in my eye and as soon as it goes down, I'm ready to go back to training.'' Douglas said he wants to take on undefeated Evander Holyfield. ``Evander Holyfield's the No. 1 contender, and he would be the next opponent,'' he told reporters. Tyson's loss torpedoed plans for a big money, pay-per-view title defense against Holyfield in June. Tyson stood to make at least $25 million by fighting Holyfield, and Holyfield at least $12 million. Douglas got $1.3 million for Sunday's fight. Lou Duva, Holyfield's manager, was in the crowd that met Tyson at the airport. ``When Tyson walked into the ring, I could see something was wrong,'' Duva said. ``He had no life. He didn't have that drive. He's not the fighter he was with Kevin Rooney.'' Tyson dismissed Rooney as his trainer a year ago. The Douglas bout on Sunday was his third title defense without Rooney in his corner. Johnson said he discussed with Mayor Dana Rinehart the possibility of having Johnson-Holyfield fight at Ohio Stadium, home of the Ohio State football team in Columbus. After the airport, Douglas was greeted by about 500 pupils of the Windsor Alternative School, where his son, Lamar, is a fifth-grader. A parade was scheduled for Wednesday morning in Columbus.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Undecided on New Off-Shore Oil Wells
With AM-Bush Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that he hasn't decided whether to open new tracts off California and Florida to oil drilling, but he defended offshore-well safety and said the country needs oil. ``I have said that we're not going to have drilling in highly environmentally sensitive places. But I'll be darned if I think we ought to shut down all offshore drilling everywhere,'' Bush said at a news conference. He questioned the logic of drilling opponents in California who believe their case was bolstered by last week's oil spill off Huntington Beach when a tanker's anchor gashed a hole in its side. ``A freighter or tanker has a hole punched in it and I see a whole bunch of guys jumping up and down saying this proves you can't have any offshore drilling,'' said Bush, a former oilman. ``I'm not sure I understand the connection. ``I don't see that a spill from a tanker really has much to do with whether you can drill an offshore well safely, because it's going on all the time. ``This country depends on it. We depend on offshore oil ... domestically for our own energy requirements,'' he said. ``It reinforces my view that we've got to be very careful about leasing in sensitive areas, even though there's no connection between a tanker spill and a drilling of a well.'' Bush said he had read the recommendations of an administration task force on whether to lift the moratorium on drilling in sensitive tracts off the coast of California and Florida and that his decision would come ``fairly soon.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: lease sales?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: You know, I saw somebody _ a freighter or tanker has a hole punched in it, and I see a bunch of guys jumping up and down saying, ``This proves you can't have any offshore drilling.'' I'm saying to myself, I'm not sure I understand the connection between tankers _ do they want to cut off all tankers? Or do we just want to do our level best to make tankering safer? I have said that we're not going to have drilling in highly environmentally sensitive places, but I'll be darned if I think we ought to shut down all offshore drilling everywhere. And I don't see that that _ that a spill from a tanker really has much to do with whether you can drill an offshore well safely, because it's going on all the time. And this country depends on it _ we depend a lot on offshore oil in _ domestically, for our own _ for our own energy requirements. But, I tell you what it does do, it reinforces my view that we've got to be very careful about leasing in sensitive areas, even though there's no connection between a tanker spill and a drilling of a well. Q: But when do you plan to make your decision on those lease sales? Bush: Fairly soon. I've read the recommendations and the report. It should be fairly soon. Q: Mr. President, did Mr. Mandela and Mr. De Klerk accept your invitations? And if so, when are they coming? Bush: I felt _ I have to go back and look at my notes _ but I felt they accepted in principle, both of them. I think Mr. Mandela said he wanted to talk _ I thought he said to his Executive Council or something. But anyway, he had to _ he wanted to talk to some others; that came first, you know, right out of the first few hours. I must say, he seemed very pleased at that, and I think Mr. De Klerk the same way. But there isn't _ there wasn't any time set on either of those invitations. Q: Mr. President, is this the time to re-examine the flexible response doctrine of NATO, and particularly the wisdom of continuing work on the Lance missile? Bush: Well, that decision will not be taken until 1992; that was an agreement between all the NATO partners. And I see nothing to change that at this point. Q: But could I just follow up? How can you, under current circumstances, justify deployment of the Lance which would hit with nuclear warheads East Germany, perhaps Poland and Czechoslovakia? Bush: If you have these dramatic changes get effected, then you take a look at all these considerations. That's what I'd say. Q: You spoke a lot about troop cuts, but nobody is explaining how these soldiers would physically _ how tens of thousands of soldiers would physically be removed from the armed services. What are your suggestions? Bush: I was talking to Marlin when I should have been listening, excuse me. What was your question? The first part of it. Q: A lot of people are talking about troop cuts, but you have not proposed a way to get several thousand _ lots _ many thousands of soldiers out of the armed services. How do you propose getting people out of uniform, force a lot of them into retirement? Bush: Well, I tell you, in our defense budget, we did propose reductions. They'll come up over the years, not necessarily all at once _ 81,000 troops, two active army divisions, and then some _ two battleships, 14 B-52s, all of which have personnel with them, M-1 tanks, Maverick missiles, sea launch system, Apache helicopter. Several different systems that will eventually result in lower personnel. Maybe I'm missing the question. Q: You're only talking about reducing forces by attrition? Bush: Oh, I would hope a lot of it could be done by attrition, because of the highly trained, dedicated men and women in the air _ in the armed forces. I would hope a lot could. You have high _ you know, relatively high attrition rates, in spite of pretty good retention, but there's still attrition. And I would like to think that a kid that went in to make a career out of this would not be unceremoniously dumped from the armed services. No, that's a good point, but I'd _ and I'd hope _ I would hope that attrition can take care of the cuts that inevitably will be coming. I'm told by Marlin that this has got to be the last one. Q: Mr. President, what role did anti-apartheid demonstrations in this country play in the release of Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners? Bush: I don't know, because you had anti-apartheid demonstrations in many countries. So I think _ I think if people get the feeling in South Africa that apartheid itself is abhorrent to the United States, through whatever way they get that feeling _ whether it's a statement by the President, whether it's some legislative action, or whether it's some demonstration _ that's helpful. But I can't help you on how you would quantify that.
END BUSH TEXT _ 7 TAKES

DOC.HEAD: Bushes to Spend Weekend at Kennebunkport
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, will spend the weekend at their seaside home in Kennebunkport, Maine, the White House said Monday. They will travel to Kennebunkport on Friday afternoon and return to the White House on Monday, which is President's Day and a federal holiday. Bush is making the vacation trip the day after returning from his one-day drug summit with leaders of the Andean nations in Cartagena, Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Short-term Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level since last month. The Treasury Department sold $7.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.65 percent, down from 7.83 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.65 percent, down from 7.72 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.57 percent on Jan. 8, and six-month bills averaged 7.58 percent on Jan. 22. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.91 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,806.60 and 8.07 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,613.30. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.13 percent last week, up from 8.09 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Fair Festivities Begin as Industry Forecasts Moderate Growth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Toy sales should grow moderately this year, industry officials forecast Monday, as the business builds on 1989's momentum and traditional American toymakers learn to cope with the video game craze. Industry officials provided the outlook on the opening day of annual American International Toy Fair, which started its 10-day run amid a bevy of colorful characters aimed at catching the attention of an estimated 20,000 buyers from stores around the country and abroad. A pair of jumbo, ruby-red lips, perched atop a woman's body, sashayed on the Fifth Avenue sidewalk plugging a new game called Read My Lips. Nearby, a model in a scanty mermaid costume shivered as she hawked a new line of children's clothing to visitors entering the show, many of whom were chomping pizza courtesy of a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle. Activists protesting war toys got some good news: The industry reported sales of make-believe guns, weapons and accessories fell last year by 12.5 percent. Models Christie Brinkley, Beverly Johnson and Cheryl Tiegs posed for photographers at the Matchbox Toys (USA) Ltd. showroom. The company's Real Model Collection has three dolls modeled after the glamorous trio, with some of the sales proceeds earmarked for charity. At the Tyco Toys showroom, 7-year-old quintuplets Ben, Julie, Kristi, Kari and Jami Chikaraishi helped the company introduce a new Quints line of small dolls, five to a set. Police were called in to control a crowd of young fans outside the Hasbro Inc. building where the New Kids on the Block appeared to pitch dolls based on the singing group. Such promotions are commonplace at Toy Fair, where each year thousands of toys make their debut. Many, many will never make it to store shelves. Amid the publicity stunts, the industry reported business improved moderately in 1989. Similar results are expected this year, depending on whether video games lose some of their following. Jack Stoneman, chairman of the Toy Manufacturers of America Inc., sponsors of the trade show, said retail toy sales totaled about $13.4 billion in 1989, up from $12.75 billion in 1988. The association's figures don't include the $3 billion or so pulled in by video games last year. This year's retail toy sales will rise by 4 percent to 6 percent, Stoneman told a news conference. Competing with video games has been one of the biggest challenges for toymakers. Some of them have taken an if-you-can't-beat-them-join-them approach by offering software and accessories for use with the Nintendo Entertainment System and other machines. Companies also are emphasizing lower-priced toys to attract dollars left over after video game purchases. Association officials and company executives were reluctant to speculate on whether the video game boom would end soon. Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive officer of Hasbro, the country's largest toy company, said the industry has adapted. ``All of us are learning to co-exist with video games,'' he said in an interview. ``The cold war is over with video.'' Meanwhile, the toy industry is looking to Europe as a possibly lucrative market. But prospects for business in Eastern Europe are unclear. Stoneman, speaking at the news conference, said: ``Eastern Europe ... now presents all of us with a unique set of opportunities. The potential for growth there is simply staggering.'' Hassenfeld of Hasbro, however, said cultivating the East European market would take time and the first step will be the establishment of factories in countries there to support economic development and raise incomes. While Europe overall ``has fabulous growth potential,'' Hassenfeld said, ``the Eastern European market I think is a different story. I think there is honestly too much being written on the Eastern European market and its potential.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Discuss Effect of Bush Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: A congressional international affairs expert on Monday described President Bush's Andean drug initiative as a ``major turning point'' in U.S. drug policy, but a specialist in the region said the policy is doomed to failure unless attention is paid to the needs of coca-growing peasants. Raphael Francis Perl, a specialist in international affairs with the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress, said the Bush initiative, calling for $2.2 billion in aid to countries in the region over five years, ``represents an increased awareness of the economic and trade component'' of drug policy. Kevin Healy, Inter-American Foundation representative for Bolivia and Ecuador, on the other hand, said, ``We have had economic aid and crop-substitution programs going on in Bolivia since 1976. If they are implemented with the same ... kind of understanding of the peasant economy and the national agricultural problems, I think they are doomed to fail.'' ``I think we have got to go in and get serious about, not economic development, but peasant economic development, putting the emphasis there. We have had economic development before, but it seldom gets through to the peasantry. I'm sort of a disbeliever until I can see that it's not just business as usual in foreign aid.'' Perl and Healy spoke at a briefing called by the Panos Institute in connection with this week's drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia. The organization, founded in 1986, primarily by environmental journalists, describes itself as ``an independent, international institute working for sustainable development.'' Its sources of funds include the governments of Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Britain, as well as international organizations and the Ford and Rockefeller foundations. A study distributed at the briefing said no approach to the drug crisis is likely to succeed unless it deals with the problems of farmers who grow the coca leaves from which cocaine is made. The study by Patricia Ardila, a Colombian magazine journalist who is director of the institute's Narcotics and Development Information program, said, ``Cocaine money plays a vital role in helping to cushion the economic crisis facing Bolivia and Peru, due to debt and structural adjustment, and in contributing to Colombia's healthier economic performance.'' At the same time, the study, said, ``traditional or new elites are amassing immense fortunes through cocaine trafficking'' and ``helping to reinforce the inequalities that have prevailed in these countries for centuries.'' ``The illegal nature of these economic activities, which makes violence the chief means used by traffickers to regulate the cocaine business, combined with the international response to the drug trade, which has overlooked the issues of poverty and underdevelopment facing coca producers, is occurring at enormous cost to the Andean countries,'' Ms. Ardila said. ``Whatever solutions are proposed, chances are that none are likely to succeed unless coca producers can participate in all stages of the process, to ensure that their economic and social needs are met,'' she wrote. Perl, whose duties include advising members of Congress on international drug control, said, ``There is no question that the U.S. invasion of Panama has placed significant obstacles to drug policy in the short term.'' He said that on a recent trip to Peru he expected people to ask him about drugs, but most of the questions he got were about the U.S. invasion that resulted in the arrest of Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. In the long run, however, Perl said he is more hopeful about prospects for U.S. drug policy in the region. ``I believe that the Bush initiative represents a major turning point in U.S. international narcotics control policy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chirac Re-Elected Leader of France's Neo-Gaullist Party
DOC.TEXT: Former Premier Jacques Chirac has been re-elected to head France's main conservative party, the neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic, but political analysts expect challenges to his leadership will persist. A motion by Chirac supporters obtained two-thirds of the vote at a party convention Sunday against an insurrectionist motion advanced by two men who served as Cabinet ministers under Chirac, Philippe Seguin and Charles Pasqua. Chirac, 57, who is also mayor of Paris, then was re-elected by a unanimous vote for a three-year term. He had threatened to resign if his motion lost. Seguin leads a reform movement within the party's left wing and Pasqua heads the right wing. Pasqua has urged the party to compete with the extreme-right National Front for votes. Seguin wants the party to lure centrist supporters. Chirac said after his victory that the party, which he created in 1976 and has dominated ever since, would emerge from weeks of conflict ``strengthened and enlarged'' and ready to fight the next legislative elections in 1993. But newspaper commentators said Monday that by capturing almost a third of the vote with their motion, Seguin and Pasqua showed strong opposition to Chirac existed in the party. They said the initiative now may pass to a more serious challenger to Chirac's authority, Michel Noir, mayor of Lyon, who is expected to launch an initiative to try to form a single opposition party with the other main right-wing group, the Union of French Democracy. Le Courier de l'Ouest, a provincial daily, said Chirac had scored a Pyrrhic victory. The paper said, ``It is unlikely that Pasqua and Seguin will give up ... and Chirac risks another battle with Michel Noir. (His) problems are only just beginning.'' Chirac served as premier from 1974-76 and from 1986-88 and failed in two runs at the presidency. He has been notably quiet since his May 1988 defeat at the hands of incumbent Socialist President Francois Mitterrand. In issuing their challenge Jan. 10, Seguin and Pasqua said the party ``has not recovered confidence in itself, and as a result has never seemed so far away from regaining the confidence of the French people.'' They did not mention Chirac by name but no one was fooled. ``It's a struggle for power, it involves destablizing Jacques Chirac and myself,'' said party Secretary-General Alain Juppe, who also was re-elected Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Says It May Pull Out of Ruling Council
DOC.TEXT: An opposition leader said Monday that it will pull out of Romania's new power-sharing government if the previous interim government continues to ``sabotage free discussion.'' ``This would throw the country into political crisis,'' said Radu Campeanu, president of the National Liberal Party. His warning came one day before the ruling Council of National Unity, which will run the country until elections May 20, meets for the second time. The council last week replaced the National Salvation Front, which took power during the bloody revolution in December that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Front was forced to share power with the opposition after announcing it would, in essence, become a political party and participate in the elections, reversing an earlier pledge to stay out of the first free balloting since World War II. But opposition leaders say the Front is trying to maintain power by controlling the new government. In a related development Monday, Razvan Teodorescu, a reputed Front supporter, was appointed to head Romanian national TV and radio, the national news agency Rompres reported. He replaces Aurel Dragos Munteanu, who resigned last week following almost daily demonstrations by protesters who said he was too close to the Front and the media was being used as a political weapon against the opposition. Campeanu said in an interview that he was certain his party would form an alliance with the National Peasants Party _ the largest of Romania's revived political parties _ to challenge the Front in the elections. A unified opposition would ``crystalize the fact that the Front is in reality the Communists, and the opposition is the anti-Communists,'' he said. He said he also asked the Social Democratic Party, the third party in Romania with historic roots, to join the alliance, and that he had been approached by several smaller, interested parties as well. Campeanu said he expected the parties to reach agreement by the end of the month. Valentin Gabrielescu, spokesman for the Peasants' Party, also said an alliance was ``very desirable and almost a certainty.'' Social Democrat Secretary Mira Moscovici said her party, which is ideologically further left than most of the others, is undecided on whether it will join. ``Cooperation may be imperative as we are faced by a totalitarian threat from the Front,'' she added. Several opposition leaders have accused the Front of manipulating the National Unity Council's inaugural meeting Friday to assure itself of a majority of the 250 seats to vote down the opposition demand that elections be postponed. The opposition wants the election delayed until September to allow it more time to prepare and to educate Romanians about multiparty democracy. Campeanu said the hall in which Friday's meeting was held also was packed with boisterous Front supporters invited ``to create intimidation and sabotage free discussion.'' He said that ``if this recurs Tuesday, we will quit the Unity Council and I think we will be joined by all the other political parties as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Sudan, Central African Republic Resume Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: Sudan and the Central African Republic announced Monday the resumption of diplomatic ties broken last May. The official Sudan News Agency said the announcement came during an unexpected visit to the Central African Republic capital Bangui by Lt. Gen. Omar el-Bashir, Sudan's military strongman. He met with Andre Kolingba, president of Central African Republic, and they later issued a joint communique saying the two neighbors were restoring diplomatic relations, reopening their borders and resuming air service. The two countries severed links May 30 after Sudan, then under civilian Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi, refused to allow a Central African plane to cross Sudanese airspace en route to Israel. Kolingba was aboard the plane, but Sudan said it had not known it at the time. It said it was merely following a general Arab ban on flights heading for Israel. A junta led by el-Bashir overthrew el-Mahdi's civilian administration June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Alaskan Air Heading South
DOC.TEXT: Cold air began forcing its way into the Northwest and the northern Plains on Monday, threatening snow and sharply lower temperatures, but it was good news for cold-weary Alaska. Alaska has been experiencing severe cold the past couple of weeks, and a change in the weather pattern across the northern hemisphere made Alaska's cold air shift toward the Lower 48 states. Parts of Alaska experienced rapid warming as the cold air began leaving, with Nome reporting a temperature rise of 19 degrees in 21 minutes during the morning, from 25 below zero to 6 below zero. On the opposite side of the moving air mass, temperatures dropped during the day in the northern Plains and the northern Rockies. At midday, Cut Bank, Mont., reported a temperature of just 3 degrees above zero, and strong northerly wind produced a wind chill reading of 39 below. Readings were only in the 20s during the afternoon across parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan. In the Northwest, the cold meant snow. A heavy snow warning was issued for elevations above 500 feet in the coastal mountains of western Oregon, with snow advisories in effect elsewhere at higher elevations in Oregon and Washington. Advisories for snow and blowing snow were posted for the mountain passes of Montana west of the Continental Divide. A winter storm watch was posted for Tuesday for the Nebraska Panhandle. The advancing arctic air was expected to generate windy weather in Southern California, and a frost advisory was posted for Wednesday night for agricultural areas around San Diego. In the East, a storm early Monday dumped up to 8 inches on parts of mountainous eastern West Virginia. ``It was a pretty impressive show. It had lightning with it. It was coming down like gangbusters,'' said Jeff Johnson, a spokesman at the WinterPlace ski resort south of Beckley, which had to close over the weekend because its snow melted. The new snow was short-lived _ temperatures climbed into the 40s Monday. Elsewhere, gusty southerly wind prevailed from the southern Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley. Temperatures were in the 70s across the southern Plains and the lower Mississippi Valley, and in the 60s as far north as Iowa. Temperatures also were in the 60s in the Southeast, with 70s across the Florida Peninsula, and reached the 60s and 70s in Southern California and southern Arizona. Monday's overnight low for the Lower 48 states was 5 below zero at Caribou, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Seek Cause of Theater Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire gutted the historic Savoy Theater before dawn Monday, and the adjacent Savoy Hotel was evacuated as a precaution. There were no injuries, officials said. Scotland Yard investigators examined the wreckage to determine the cause, but police said they did not believe the fire at the empty theater was suspicious. ``There's no evidence at this stage of arson,'' said a Scotland Yard spokesman, who was not identified, in accordance with British custom. The theater had not been staging a production at the time. The Scotland Yard spokesman said the elegant Savoy Hotel suffered little damage. About 130 guests, including actor Richard Harris, and 61 employees were evacuated. The London fire brigade said 60 percent of the 109-year-old theater in The Strand in central London was ablaze when firefighters arrived shortly after 1:30 a.m. Flames fanned by strong winds burst through the roof of the theater and lighted the night sky. Thick smoke brought traffic to a halt. Harris, wearing a white Savoy Hotel dressing gown and sipping tea as he watched firefighters tackle the blaze, told reporters he was lying in bed learning lines when he heard the hotel fire alarm. The 58-year-old actor said he walked downstairs because he had been told that in a fire people should not use elevators. ``There was no panic. It was perfectly organized by the Savoy staff,'' he said. The Savoy Theater, which can seat 1,123 people, was built by Gilbert and Sullivan impresario Richard D'Oyly Carte in 1881. The Savoy Hotel opened in 1889 and swiftly gained a reputation as one of the world's grandest hotels, often frequented by the rich and famous. The best suites currently cost about $850 a night.

DOC.HEAD: Friday Morning, LA Federal Courthouse Set For Reagan Deposition
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with judge setting time and place for Reagan's videotaped testimony. Informatively, deposition scheduled 10 a.m. PST Friday, Courtroom No. 8 of the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, Los Angeles.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Monday delayed the start of John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial by two weeks and said former President Reagan's videotaped testimony would be taken Friday morning at the federal courthouse in Los Angeles. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said disagreement over the use of about 150 classified documents, the need to edit Reagan's taped testimony and other matters would require delaying Poindexter's trial from Feb. 20 to March 5. Richard Beckler, a lawyer for the former national security adviser, urged that Reagan not be questioned until Iran-Contra prosecutors completed presenting their case. ``I'm not going to buy that,'' Greene said. ``We are going to proceed.'' Greene accepted Reagan's proposal to have the deposition on Friday in Los Angeles, but the judge rejected the suggestion by Theodore Olson, one of Reagan's lawyers, that the questioning take place in Reagan's offices. Greene said the U.S. courthouse has the necessary amount of space plus security for classified documents. At a hearing, Greene said it was doubtful he would allow the news media attend the deposition. Seven news organizations have filed an application seeking to have the questioning open to the media and the public. The organizations _ Cable News Network, Capital Cities-ABC Inc., CBS Inc., National Broadcasting Co., The New York Times Co., Times Mirror Co. of Los Angeles and The Washington Post _ argued that the First Amendment right of access has been held to apply to pre-trial proceedings in addition to all aspects of a criminal trial. One reason for having the questioning on videotape is so that if Reagan inadvertently discloses classified information, that portion can be edited before being shown at the trial. The news organizations said Greene could close portions of the deposition if he believed the questioning would elicit sensitive information at certain points. At a minimum, the media argued they should have an opportunity to inspect and copy the videotape and any written transcript ``as soon as possible after the proceeding.'' Meanwhile, Greene must rule on whether the approximately 150 classified documents in dispute are necessary for Poindexter to get a fair trial. If he rules that they are necessary and if U.S. intelligence agencies refuse to allow their declassification, the Poindexter case could be in jeopardy. As past Iran-Contra cases have shown, it is not unusual to have unresolved last-minute disputes over the use of classified material. There were repeated disputes over the use of such material before and during the trial of former National Security Council staff member Oliver North. Problems over the use of classified material led to dismissal of criminal charges in the Iran-Contra case against former CIA station chief Joseph Fernandez. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh filed an affidavit barring disclosure of classified material dealing with CIA facilities in Central America and certain CIA programs in Costa Rica. Iran-Contra prosecutors are appealing that case to the U.S. Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va. The prosecution argues that a lower court judge erred in ruling that information pertaining to the programs and facilities was material to Fernandez's defense. The prosecutors said the lower court erred by not allowing substitutions for the classified material proposed by the government.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Rebels Say Fighting Continues for Mavinga
DOC.TEXT: Angolan rebels said Monday that fighting raged for control of Mavinga airstrip, with government forces using hundreds of Soviet-built tanks and dozens of aircraft to ``massacre UNITA soldiers and civilians.'' The statement from the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola was released in Lisbon and signed by UNITA chief Jonas Savimbi and other senior rebels. A separate UNITA miltary statement signed by Zacarias Mundombe, vice-chief of army administration, said rebels pushed back Marxist government forces to three miles outside Mavinga. The airstrip and a UNITA base near Mavinga's bombed-out old town, 680 miles southeast of the capital city of Luanda, block the way to the rebels' Jamba headquarters more than 120 miles farther south. Fighting, said to be the heaviest in the 15-year-old civil war, has raged there since late December. The government said it captured Mavinga a week ago. UNITA people in Lisbon have said Savimbi was in Mavinga organizing defense against the attacks after he cut short a five-nation European tour in the Portuguese capital on Jan. 30. Neither statement on Monday revealed Savimbi's whereabouts. The military statement said government columns lost vehicles but counter-attacked UNITA positions with MiG-23 jets. It gave no casualty figures. It claimed 51 soldiers and four rebels died in a rebel attack Saturday on a barracks at Quitexe, northern Uige province. The statement singed by Savimbi said UNITA was still open to dialogue, based on a cease-fire and national reconciliation that would open the way for a multiparty political system in Angola. It called ``pure illusion'' any attempt ``to subjugate UNITA and force us to accept negotiations with a knife at our throat.'' The government offensive has been seen as a last-ditch attempt to pressure UNITA into accepting government terms at possible peace talks. Officials in Luanda introduced water rationing after UNITA bombed the city's main water supply pipes, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported. UNITA has been fighting to force the government to share power since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Alternate-Fuel Cars Idea Running Out of Gas
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is easing away from a proposal that would have required automakers to produce up to a million alternate fuel cars as part of tougher air pollution controls, officials acknowledged Monday. When President Bush proposed a broad-ranging program last summer to clean up the nation's air, the centerpiece of plans to combat urban smog was a call for legislation requiring automakers to provide up to 1 million new cars annually by 1997 that could run on fuels other than gasoline. The cars would be sold in nine cities where smog is worst and were calculated eventually to reach 30 percent of the motor vehicle fleets in those areas. But William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, confirmed Monday that the administration no longer considers requiring the production of such cars, which would use fuels such as methanol or natural gas, as essential to curbing urban smog. Instead, the administration is proposing in negotiations with Senate leaders that a form of ``reformulated'' gasoline, which would also reduce smog-causing pollution, might be an alternative to automobiles using non-gasoline fuels. Vehicles using reformulated, low-polluting gasoline do not require any additional equipment or modifications. Atlantic Richfield Co. already is selling reformulated gasoline in California. Reilly rejected sugestions that the change was a weakening of the administration proposal to reduce automobile pollution. ``There is no change in the goals or the performance objectives that we want to achieve, but we have tried to indicate more flexibility about methods of getting there,'' he told reporters. Legislation before the Senate to tighten federal air pollution controls does not include a requirement for alternative fuel vehicles and, instead, would impose new automobile tailpipe emission controls that the auto industry has vigorously opposed. But the White House has opposed the additional tailpipe emission requirements, arguing that an alternative fuels vehicle program focused on the areas with the dirtiest air is more economical and achieves nearly as much pollution reduction. Some Senate Democrats have voiced frustration in recent days over the changes in the administration's proposal, maintaining that while the White House opposes tougher exhaust controls it is also weakening the approach it is trying to sell as a substitute. Reilly acknowledged that the administration's original proposal requiring automakers to produce and sell a specific number of alternative fuel vehicles ``has caused us considerable opposition'' and kept some senators from joining in support. ``We have been willing for some months to redraft some language on the alternative fuels (proposal) to try to reassure people that ... we do not prefer one fuel over another'' as long as the overall pollution reduction is the same, said Reilly. Reilly suggested, for example, legislation that would require all new cars in a polluted urban area to use the ``reformulated'' gasoline may accomplish the same pollution reductions as requiring 30 percent of cars in the area to run on something other than gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: Ritual Slayings Gang Member Dies in Mexico of AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Omar Francisco Orea Ochoa, a member of a cult accused of committing ritual slayings along the U.S.-Mexico border, has died of a heart attack brought on by AIDS, the Mexico City attorney general's office said Monday. The government said he died of a heart attack Sunday afternoon in the hospital at Mexico City's Santa Marta Acatitla federal penitentiary. Dr. Francisco Guerra Izquierdo at the hospital said the cardiac arrest was caused by AIDS. Orea Ochoa, 24, was diagnosed as having the deadly disease in June, the attorney general's office said. Before joining the cult, he was a journalism student at Mexico's National University. Orea Ochoa reportedly was the lover of Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, the Cuban-born leader of the cult. Orea Ochoa was one of five cult members arrested May 6, when Constanzo ordered his own killing and that of another man when police began closing in on them in Mexico City. Authorities believe the gang was responsible for the deaths of at least 13 people in and around Matamoros, across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Texas, and several others in Mexico City. The April killing of Mark Kilroy, a Texas pre-medical student on a border town visit, was the most widely publicized of those murders. Cult member Sara Aldrete said after her arrest that Constanzo had invited her to join the Santeria cult and asked her to practice voodoo rituals. They were designed in part to ``protect'' the gang's drug smuggling from Mexico into Texas. Cult members originally were called ``narco-satanics'' under the assumption their unusual rituals were connected to Satanism. After further investigation, it was determined that Santeria is a blend of Catholicism and old African beliefs that includes animal sacrifices. Gang members were charged with homicide, criminal association, wounding a police agent and damage to property. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a virus that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of fighting illnesses. It is most often transmitted by sexual contact or exchange of blood products and there is no known cure.

DOC.HEAD: African National Congress Minister Says Economic Sanctions Should Remain
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The exiled chaplain of the African National Congress said Monday that the release of Nelson Mandela should not be the sole basis for lifting economic sanctions against South Africa. The Rev. Fumanekile Gqiba of Zambia said he feared that ending sanctions against South Africa would undermine the ANC's push for democracy. Mandela, founder of the ANC, was freed Sunday after 27 years in prison. ``The release of Mandela is the first step. It is not the end,'' said Gqiba at a news conference Monday. He is a guest at the international meeting of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). After his release, Mandela also reaffirmed his support for continued economic sanctions until the government dismantles apartheid, the legal separation of the races in South Africa. Gqiba fled South Africa in 1985 and has not returned. He has since traveled the world speaking against apartheid. ``Our struggle has become an international war,'' he said. South Africa President F.W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC on Feb. 2. The ANC seeks a one-person, one-vote system, which would be dominated by South Africa's 28 million blacks. Gqiba said he won't return to his homeland ``until the pillars of racism'' are brought down.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Communists, Opposition Clash Over Parties in Workplace
DOC.TEXT: The opposition clashed with the ruling Communists at negotiations Monday on the future of Bulgaria, demanding the party withdraw from the workplace and that talks be suspended until a consensus is reached. The state BTA news agency said the opposition, represented by the loosely grouped Union of Democratic Forces, renewed its demand that Communist Party organizations in factories and other work places be dissolved. Last month the Communists announced plans to remove party control of the armed forces and police. On Monday, the Communists agreed that party organizations should also be banned from state offices, the judiciary, education and health care, but not from the factory floor, BTA reported. The opposition wants a constitutional amendment placed before Parliament to dissolve party organizations at factories before the elections set for May. BTA said the opposition also wants action postponed on a measure dealing with political parties, but the Communists also rejected this proposal. On Tuesday, a working group will meet to try to reach a compromise, it said. BTA reported that a spokesman for the opposition, not identified, accused the Communists of stalling at the talks to impede the opposition's election campaign. The Union of Democratic Forces has been negotiating for more power-sharing with the Communists, who have so far rejected demands for opposition access to radio and televison that would take their platforms nationwide. According to BTA, however, reform Communists who split from the party to form an Alternative Socialist Party last Sunday backed opposition demands, as did the once-docile Agrarian Party. The opposition rejected an offer by the Agrarian Party to seek an intermediary role and take part in the talks as a third negotiating partner. Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the Union of Democratic Forces, observed that the Agrarians had not gone into opposition. According to BTA, Zhelev invited the Agrarians to join his group. Premier Andrei Lukanov was forced to form the country's first all-Communist government last week after the Agrarian Party announced it would no longer knuckle under to the Communists and the opposition refused to heed Communist calls to join the government.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Opens Sluice Gates, Euphrates Water Flows Downstream
DOC.TEXT: Turkey opened sluice gates of the huge Ataturk Dam on Monday, allowing Euphrates River water to flow south to Syria and Iraq. Turkey diverted the river's main flow Jan. 13 to increase the water level in the Ataturk reservoir and finish some construction work on diversion channels. Iraq and Syria protested that their agricultural land might be damaged and their electricity production reduced. Cengiz Altinkaya, the public works minister, said at the dam site 60 miles from the Syrian border near Sanliurfa that the diversion channel opened Monday was closed in July 1988, and work also was done on a second channel closed in May. His remarks were carried by the semiofficial Anatolia News Agency. Ataturk Dam's reservoir has three main diversion channels. The third was blocked last month and will not be opened for some time, the agency report said. During the cutoff period, Syria and Iraq got water from downstream tributaries of the Euphrates, but the flow was reduced to about one-fifth the usual 500 cubic meters per second. Altinkaya said average flow was being resumed Monday. The Euphrates originates in the mountains of eastern Turkey and flows 1,460 miles through Syria and Iraq to confluence with the Tigris River and Persian Gulf. Anatolia quoted officials at the dam as saying about 2.5 billion cubic meters of water had accumulated in the Ataturk reservoir, whose full capacity is nearly 20 times that. Tobacco farmers in Western Turkey rioted for higher support prices Monday, breaking shop windows, blocking highways and fighting police, news agencies reported. Anatolia said several thousand farmers blocked traffic for about four hours by sitting on the railway line that connects Akhisar in the Aegean region to Istanbul, and on the three major highways that run through the town. Hurriyet, an independent agency, said the farmers later moved into the center of Akhisar, 320 miles southwest of Ankara, and broke the windows of the tobacco shops and the State Cigarette Monopoly building. The farmers threw stones at police trying to disperse the crowd and police arrested an undetermined number, Hurriyet reported. Support prices are what state-owned cigarette factories will pay for the next tobacco crop. Because cigarette production is a virtual government monopoly, they also determine the free-market price. This year's support price was set 54 percent higher than for the last crop, but farmers complain that it falls short of the 65 percent annual inflation rate. Resit Kursun, head of Turkish Chambers of Agriculture, told state radio the price would not enable the farmers to repay their production loans.

DOC.HEAD: East Berlin Mayor to Quit, Had Historic Meeting after Borders Opened
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Erhard Krack, whose handshake with his Western counterpart last November symbolized the historic crumbling of the Berlin Wall, said Monday he plans to quit. The official East German news agency ADN said Krack decided to resign following a furor over allegations of election fraud during municipal balloting last May.
