East German opposition leaders used the fraud issue to rally support for the peaceful revolution that ousted hard-line Communist leaders and has brought the country to the threshold of its first free elections. Krack will turn in his resignation at the next city council meeting, but ADN did not say when it would be held. Krack and West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper shook hands on Nov. 12 minutes after a new opening had been cut in the Berlin Wall at Potsdamer Platz, one of Europe's liveliest crossroads before World War II. The historic meeting symbolized the crumbling of the Cold War barrier that divided the city since 1961. Only three days before that, the East German government opened its borders, allowing the Communist nation's people free access to the West for the first time in 28 years.

DOC.HEAD: Protest Police Killings, University and Schools Closed
DOC.TEXT: Several unions went on strike Monday, including teachers and miners, and students marched into downtown Niamey to protest the killing of three students by police last week. President Ali Saibou's military Cabinet, continuing an emergency meeting begun over the weekend, praised ``the valor of the forces of law and order'' who opened fire Friday to disperse a rally of about 3,000 high school and university students. The government says police killed three people and wounded 33. Students put the death toll at 12. A government statement said the Cabinet ordered all secondary schools and Niamey University closed. Police did not interfere with Monday's march. The students also denounced the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and government for an unpopular austerity program that was a causes of Friday's demonstration. Saibou's government said in its statement the Cabinet ordered an investigation ``to unmask agitators and trouble-makers.'' It claimed students were being manipulated by ``traitors to the national cause pursuing personal ambitions.'' Striking teachers said they also were protesting the arrests of two colleagues detained on suspicion of encouraging student unrest. Leading politicians invited to the Cabinet meeting said the government had agreed to meet with student representatives. No date was given. In the past, the government has accused students of being greedy in demands for larger grants, better-equipped libraries and laboratories and guarantees of government jobs. The government has put a freeze on public jobs. Government officials say the demands are excessive in one of the world's poorest nations. The unrest is the worst in Niger since Saibou won a new seven-year term Dec. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Likud Meeting Breaks Down in Argument, Sharon to Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to move higher Sharon's resignation, ADD Bush comments, UPDATE with Labor Party meeting; pickup 9th pvs, `The meeting...'
DOC.TEXT: A leadership meeting of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc broke down in chaos and shouts of anger Monday after Shamir called for a vote of confidence in his plan for Palestinian elections. Shamir stormed out of the session of the Likud Central Committee after getting into a shouting match with his hard-line party rival, Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, who said he would resign to protest Shamir's policies. Shamir later claimed in a radio interview that he had received a large show of support. The chaotic results left the already stalled Middle East peace process in even worse shape and raised doubts about the future of Shamir's fragile coalition Cabinet. Leaders of Likud's coalition partner, the center-left Labor party, met Monday night and decided not to make any moves that would likely break up the government as long as there is a chance for peace. But a senior Labor official said the party would demand a new Cabinet vote on the peace initiative and could leave the government unless it got backing. Some Labor members demanded that the party quit the coalition immediately because Israel's peace initiative has been compromised. ``I don't think we can continue to live in this marriage,'' Yossi Beilin, a top aide to Labor leader Shimon Peres, told The Associated Press. In Washington, President Bush said Sharon's resignation could suit U.S. policy if it led to progress in the stalled peace process. ``Mr. Shamir was a proponent of these talks, and if this clears the way for the talks to go forward, that would (be) in keeping with U.S. policy,'' Bush said at a White House news conference. Monday's meeting of Likud's Central Committee contained two surprises. The first was Sharon announcing his resignation. The second was the chaotic ending, which came after polls predicted a victory for the prime minister over his hard-line rivals. The meeting broke down when Shamir called for a vote of confidence at the end of a speech in which he essentially bent to the political demands of Sharon and his supporters. ``Do you accept my proposal? Let us vote,'' Shamir shouted. But Sharon, who later claimed Shamir had broken an agreement to delay the vote until the end of the debate, began shouting into a microphone for a vote on his own stands. Hundreds of delegates raised their hands amid the chaos, and both sides claimed they won. ``I received a decisive, massive majority,'' Shamir said moments after leaving the meeting of Likud's 3,085-member Central Committee in a circle of security guards. ``It was very clear that our proposals were accepted,'' Sharon argued later in a radio interview. Sharon convened the meeting as a challenge to Shamir's leadership and his peace plan, which envisages a limited Palestinian autonomy in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Likud hawks say the plan gives the Palestinians too many concessions. Opening the session, Sharon surprised even his close supporters with his offer to resign from the Cabinet. ``My decision to resign from the government is in order to continue the difficult struggle for our national goals ... endangered as a result of policies of the present government,'' he said. As he spoke, most delegates rose to their feet, and several hundred began chanting ``Arik, Arik'' _ Sharon's nickname. Shamir tried to seize the initiative with an emotional speech that embraced most of his rivals' stands: refusing to allow Arab residents of annexed east Jerusalem to vote in the proposed elections, and demanding an end to the 26-month Palestinian uprising before peace could be negotiated. ``We cannot imagine real political negotiations and autonomy as long as attacks and violence continue,'' Shamir said. Speaking later on army radio, Shamir indicated he would accept the trade minister's resignation, saying: ``It seems natural that Sharon resigns from a government whose policies he opposes in all its aspects.'' However, the prime minister and his chief supporters said the chaotic meeting would not lead to a split in the party. ``This is not the end of Likud but the end of those who wanted to break Likud down,'' said Environment Minister Ronnie Milo. But Moshe Zorenstein, a delegate, described the meeting as ``being at our own funeral.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Blames Children's Deaths on Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `Twenty people' to CORRECT province spelling. Pickup 3rd, `A statement...'
DOC.TEXT: The armed forces on Monday blamed leftist rebels for the death of at least six civilians in a camp for recently returned refugees in northeastern El Salvador, but witnesses said the five children and one adult died in an air force attack. Twenty people also were reported wounded in the camp at Corral de Piedra village, 53 miles northeast of San Salvador in Chalatenango province. A statement from the armed forces press office said guerrillas took refuge in the settlement Sunday and from catapults launched bombs that landed among homes in the village. The statement gave no details. On Monday, an army patrol at a roadblock barred seven foreign journalists from entering the attack site. The camp was set up in Corral de Piedra last October for about 300 refugees who returned to El Salvador after spending eight years in a refugee camp in neighboring Honduras. Army officers have recently accused the refugees of secretly collaborating with the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the guerrilla organization that has fought for power since 1979. Monsignor Eduardo Alas, Roman Catholic bishop of Chalatenango, said the casualties were caused by air force helicopters and planes rocketing the settlement. Alas told a local radio station one house where six people died was hit by a rocket fired from a helicopter, and many roofs in shanty homes were riddled by machine-gun fire. ``There were no guerrillas in the settlement,'' Noemy Lopez, whose husband and infant daughter were killed, told The Associated Press. She spoke in an interview at Rosales Hospital in San Salvador, where she was recovering from shrapnel wounds. Emoteria Orellana, another victim at the hospital, also said the village contained no guerrillas. Both women blamed the casualties on an air raid, which included helicopters and an A-37 fighter-bomber jet, according to reports. An American nun, who works in the region and was in the village on Sunday, also blamed the air force. She spoke on condition her name not be used for fear of possible reprisals. The witnesses said guerrillas and soldiers engaged in a firefight with automatic rifles outside the village around dawn, but the rebels retreated long before the air raid began.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Forces Head into Hills Against Rival Christian Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with State Department comment, SUB last graf with 4 grafs; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Slopes packed with skiers two weeks ago were dotted with tanks on Monday as the forces of maverick Christian Gen. Michel Aoun moved against the militia of a rival Christian leader. Aoun's troops and Lebanese Forces militiamen under Samir Geagea also fought with automatic weapons and hand grenades in the rain-soaked streets of east Beirut, police reported. The general is under growing pressure to deliver a knockout blow and seize Geagea's strongholds in east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh, Ein Rummaneh and Karantina districts. But Aoun's troops were unable to break through the Lebanese Forces defenses in the battle for control of the Christian enclave north and northeast of Beirut that erupted Jan. 30. Police said the only casualty reports they had were one man killed and a girl wounded by sniper fire late Monday in the low-income district of Ein Rummaneh. Aoun's command, however, reported the death of four officers and nine soldiers in the last two days of combat. That raised the overall toll to 471 killed and 1,702 wounded in two weeks of fighting. Aoun moved against Geagea's right-wing militia to eliminate the main challenge to his authority as ruler of the 310-square-mile enclave, home to 1 million Christians. But Geagea's 6,000-strong militia, which has 30,000 reservists, is proving a tough opponent to Aoun's 19,000 troops in the bloodiest intra-Christian fighting in the 15-year-old civil war. Police said Aoun's army was concentrating on a new front in the mountain province of Kesrouan, a Maronite region 15 miles northeast of Beirut. His tanks stabbed into a militia-held triangle formed by the resort towns of Daraya, Kleiat and Ajaltoun below the ski slopes in the Kesrouan mountains, police reported. A spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the hit-and-run mountain attacks appeared to be softening up Lebanese Forces defenses before a large-scale assault to break a militia siege of the army's main helicopter base at Adma and take the whole of Kesrouan. The International Committee for the Red Cross, the Lebanese Red Cross and Christian religious leaders issued fresh appeals Monday for a mercy cease-fire to allow civil defense teams to recover at least two dozen decomposing bodies from the sniper-infested streets. There was no formal break in the fighting, but civilians took advantage of occasional lulls to dash across Beirut's dividing Green Line into the Moslem sector, which has been outside the combat zone. ``The snipers shot a woman running ahead of me,'' said Therese Yakoub after she sprinted 500 yards across the Museum crossing, the only gateway open along the 3-mile demarcation line. ``Poor thing, she has five children and she was planning to buy bread and powdered milk for them,'' Ms. Yakoub said. Police said at least 75,000 Christians in the enclave have fled to west Beirut and Syrian-controlled north and east Lebanon since the fighting broke out. President Elias Hrawi appealed again to the superpowers, France and the Vatican to support possible intervention by his Syrian-backed troops to halt the fighting. Hrawi made a similar appeal last week. Beirut newspapers said Pope John Paul II and France, traditional protector of Lebanon's Christians, warned against Syrian military intervention. In Washington, the State Department said Monday night it was clear that Aoun had pursued a ``violent course'' and ``bears responsibility for the current round of senseless fighting among Christians.'' The department also expressed concern that Aoun's actions had heightened the risk of greater Syrian involvement in Lebanon and said only Hrawi could decide whether the Lebanese government should intervene. ``We strongly support President Hrawi,'' it said in a statement. Aoun does not recognize Hrawi's Christian-Moslem government, which is backed by Syria. He also has vowed to drive the Syrians, who support the Moslem militias of west Beirut, from Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Airliner Crash Kills Two
DOC.TEXT: A domestic airliner hit a station wagon and crashed while trying to land in southeastern Brazil Monday, killing a woman and her son, an airline spokesman said. All 39 people aboard the plane survived. Luiz Carlos Franco, spokesman for TAM Regional Airlines, said the 48-seat, twin-engine Fokker turboprop crashed at Bauru, 220 miles from Sao Paulo. The plane was flying from Sao Paulo to Cuiaba, with a stop at Bauru. Franco said details still were lacking, ``but we can confirm that all 36 passengers, the pilot, co-pilot and the flight steward are alive. It was a real miracle.'' Dr. Cesar Carvalho, director of Bauru Municipal Hospital, said the pilot was in the intensive care unit and the co-pilot suffered a fractured spine. The flight attendant and most of the 36 passengers were unhurt. Some passengers were treated for minor scrapes and bruises and released, Carvalho added. Carvalho said the plane hit and damaged two unoccupied houses in trying to land, then hit a station wagon near the airport, killing a 29-year-old woman and her 4-year-old-son. Maria Dalva, head of the news department of Bauru's Auri Verde radio station, said, ``The plane crashed after it failed to gain altitude following an unsuccessful landing attempt.'' She said the wings and engines burst into flames but the fuselage remained intact. ``Most of the passengers and crew members walked away from the accident and only a few had to be carried on stretchers,'' Ms. Dalva added. She and the others in Bauru spoke by telephone.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Drop $64 Million in Fines Against United Mine Workers
DOC.TEXT: A state judge refused Monday to drop $64 million in fines against the United Mine Workers, raising new doubt about the future of a tentative settlement by 1,700 miners in three states. The strike against Pittston Coal Group spread far beyond that one company last summer, when thousands of miners staged wildcat sympathy strikes. The UMW and Pittston reached a tentative agreement Jan. 1, but union leaders said they wouldn't put the contract to a vote of the rank and file until all legal action connected with the strike is settled. Both the union and the company had asked Circuit Court Judge Donald McGlothlin to drop the fines, but on Monday he refused. The judge gave the union an additional 10 days to come up with new arguments in favor of dropping the fines, imposed for a variety of illegal strike activities. UWM General Counsel Robert Stropp said union leaders would reassess their decision to withhold a vote on the tentative contract. Asked if there may be a vote even if McGlothlin upholds the fines, Stropp said, ``I think that is going to have to be part of the assessment.'' The union has said it would appeal a decision to impose the fines. The union offered to have its 1,700 striking miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky perform 10,000 hours of community service over 30 days if the fines are waived. McGlothlin rejected the offer Monday, calling it, ``an affront to this court.'' The judge said dropping the fines would send the wrong message to the community and to future strikers. McGlothlin said it would ``convince people ... that mass violations of the law are a valid means of conducting a strike.'' He said he knew dropping the fines would make all parties in the dispute happy. Miners would be able to get back to work, state and local governments would be free of the law enforcement burden associated with the often violent strike and Pittston would be able to return to full production. Pittston attorney Carl Kindig told the judge Monday a decision to drop the fines would ``help bring an end to this dispute in a fashion that will lead to labor peace in this area and ultimately be in the public interest.'' McGlothlin criticized Pittston for asking him to drop the fines after coming to him repeatedly during the strike asking for harsh penalties against the union. ``Now the same plaintiff says everything is fine and we want you to drop everything and wipe the slate clean,'' he said. ``It's an incredible irony in this court's opinion.'' ``The courts are not pieces of a gameboard to be manipulated,'' McGlothlin said later. McGlothlin said there were 263 violent violations of his court order restricting strike activities and 137 non-violent violations. The fines are the largest obstacle to a final settlement in the strike, union officials said. Friday, the miners who have been on strike since April 5 moved a step closer to a vote on returning to work as the National Labor Relations Board settled complaints filed by both the company and the union. U.S. District Judge Glen Williams will decide Tuesday or Wednesday whether to waive nearly $1 million in strike-related fines he assessed against the union. Both judges issued the fines for violations of court orders limiting picket line activity and prohibiting the disruption of Pittston's operations. About half of the fines were for violence aimed at company personnel and property. McGlothlin also fined the union $5 million for taking over Pittston's main coal processing plant in September for four days and several million for the use of massive sit-down demonstrations and enormous bumper-to-bumper convoys of cars and trucks to block coal truck traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Told Their Work No Quick Fix to Acid Rain Problem
DOC.TEXT: Scientists gathered to review a 10-year study on the causes and effects of acid rain were warned Monday that their work won't provide a quick fix for policy-makers. ``The full story is seldom, if ever, known about the complex issues of environmental science,'' said William Rosenberg, an assistant administrator for the federal Environmental Protection Agency. ``Scientific investigation must continue, including an evaluation of the control program put in place,'' Rosenberg said. ``In the meantime, we must take prudent actions to protect our health and our environment.'' About 700 scientists from across the United States and 35 foreign countries have gathered to review 28 draft reports on acid rain compiled by the National Acidic Rain Assessment Program. The program was established 10 years ago by Congress and has spent $500 million investigating acid rain, which is caused by air pollution and is said to pose the greatest threat to lakes in the Northeast and upper Midwest. Acid rain is a blanket term for a combination of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide which mixes in the atmosphere and can fall as rain, snow, fog or dust particles. It can make lakes and streams acidic and can kill trees. Along with smog, acid rain is a target of clean air legislation being considered in Congress that would would reduce pollution from factories, power plants and automobiles. About 1,000 researchers have been at work during the past decade compiling the reports being considered at the conference. The documents don't take policy stands. ``You have changed the way the world thinks about acid rain and you've helped policy-makers decide which steps need to be taken,'' said Michael Deland, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality. But, he added, ``it is highly unlikely we'll reach scientific certainty on issues like acid rain.'' That thought was echoed by James Mahoney, director of the assessment program. `We must critically analyze all our hypotheses. But there is no way the scientific community can provide a single answer that this is the level'' for reducing industrial emmissions. Most of the reports which are the focus of the meeting have been released over the past two months. This week's meeting gives scientists from aboard a chance to review the material. Discussions Monday centered on acidity in the nation's streams and lakes based on sampling completed in the mid-1980s. The survey found that 4.2 percent of the 1,181 lakes sampled were considered acidic with the most acidic lakes in the Northeast, the upper Midwest and Florida. The study also found that 2.7 percent of the 5,506 kilometers of streams sampled are acidic _ most of those streams in the Appalachian Mountains and the mid-Atlantic coastal plain.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Heads Home, Defends Violence Against Apartheid
LaserPhotos JOH2, CPN5, CPN10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for 10th graf, Andries Treurnicht ... UPDATING with Bush reaction. Picks up 11th, `Mandela said ...
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Monday he seeks a South Africa that is fair to both whites and blacks, and he insisted that violence against apartheid is justified. The 71-year-old black leader, enjoying his first full day of freedom after 27 years in prison, defended the policies of his African National Congress but said talks with the government could be held soon. In the tribal homeland of Ciskei, 10 blacks celebrating Mandela's release Sunday night were shot and killed by police, and 20 were injured, according to the Daily Dispatch newspaper in nearby East London. Homeland authorities refused to comment, and civil rights groups demanded a judicial inquiry. In Mandela's hometown of Soweto, schools were deserted as thousands of students marched and danced in the streets, anticipating his return home. Believing Mandela was due back for an afternoon rally, tens of thousands of Sowetans crammed into a soccer stadium, and dozens were injured in the crush. Hundreds of youths heading home from the stadium surrounded a police van and freed 13 prisoners inside, according to Gen. Herman Stadler, a police spokesman. He said the officers in the vehicle decided not to use their firearms, and no injuries were reported. The activists making arrangements for Mandela decided he should not re-enter Soweto until Tuesday, when a massive welcoming rally was planned. They refused to disclose where he would spend the night, although television networks deployed helicopters to pursue him. ``I am absolutely excited to be out,'' Mandela told reporters in Cape Town before taking an evening flight to Johannesburg. He was released unconditionally on Sunday. Mandela said negotiations between the ANC and the government could begin ``very soon'' if President F.W. de Klerk continues his peace initiative and makes further reforms. ``The state of emergency has to be lifted in its entirety and political prisoners have to be released,'' Mandela told more than 200 journalists assembled on the lawn outside the official residence of Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu in Cape Town. At a news conference in Washington on Monday, President Bush expressed optimism Monday that Mandela's release was a sign the Pretoria government was ``at last'' on the way to ending apartheid, but Bush showed no inclination to move quickly to lift U.S. economic sanctions. He noted that he had invited both Mandela and de Klerk to the White House _separately, with no times yet fixed _ and wanted to discuss sanction provisions with them. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, accused the de Klerk government of falling victim to ``Mandela hysteria'' and moving toward white surrender. Eugene TerreBlanche, leader of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, said de Klerk is now powerless to control Mandela, and he warned that his movement ``will protect itself and its property when the government can no longer do so.'' Mandela said whites should not fear the prospect of an ANC-led government. ``Whites are fellow South Africans. We want them to feel safe,'' he said at his news conference. ``The ANC ... will find a solution that will suit both blacks and whites.'' The ANC seeks a one-person, one-vote system, which would be dominated by South Africa's 28 million blacks. De Klerk seeks to negotiate a new constitution that would establish some political rights for blacks, but provide the 5 million whites with some sort of veto over major decisions. Police have reported about 40 deaths in unrest around the country since daybreak Sunday, including a clash between police and looters in Cape Town that left one black dead and more than 100 people injured. Tutu, in an unusual move, issued a statement deploring the looting and refraining from criticism of the police. Other activists appealed to blacks to welcome Mandela in a dignified, non-violent manner. At midday Monday, a white security guard in Johannesburg killed a man who was among a group of blacks that chased and cornered him, carrying bricks and clubs, police said. The group had been chanting slogans welcoming Mandela's release, the police said. In Cape Town, a bomb blast damaged a ticket office at a stadium where an English cricket team is due to play this week in defiance of an international sports boycott. Mandela said the white government's intention when it jailed him and other ANC leaders ``was that we should be forgotten.'' Instead, his release from prison was covered by journalists from around the world as an epic event that could lead to sweeping political change in South Africa. Mandela said he had been conferring with government officials for the past three years on the prospect of negotiations with the ANC, as well as on the issue of freeing political prisoners. He denied there was conflict between his commitment to peaceful solutions and his endorsement of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. ``I have committed myself to the promotion of peace in the country. But I have done so as part and parcel of the decisions and campaign that have been taken by the ANC ... The armed struggle is a defensive act against apartheid.'' The ANC's bombing and sabotage campaign, launched by Mandela and his colleagues in 1961, has been nearly dormant in the past year, although the movement has refused to confirm it is scaling back its military actions. Mandela reaffirmed his support for continued economic sanctions until the government dismantles the institutionalized racism of apartheid. He also endorsed the ANC's commitment to nationalization of South Africa's mines. He told reporters his years in prison were hard. ``I have lost a great deal over these 27 years and my wife has been under all sorts of pressure,'' he said. ``It's not a nice feeling for a man to see his family struggling without dignity, without a man around.'' Mandela described de Klerk, who on Feb. 2 lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC, as ``flexible'' and ``a man of integrity.'' ``If Mr. de Klerk is able to carry the National Party with him in the new line he has taken ... then I think very soon we will be able to begin negotiations,'' he said. He said he wanted to travel soon to Lusaka, Zambia, to consult with the ANC's exiled leadership. He said he had no right to decide unilaterally what role he would play. The decision to free Mandela, after a long international campaign on his behalf, was announced de Klerk on Saturday. Eight days earlier, de Klerk lifted bans on the ANC and other opposition groups, suspended executions, and announced other reforms aimed at clearing the way for black-white negotiations. In the mid-1980s, Mandela rejected offers to go free in exchange for a renunciation of violence.

DOC.HEAD: Britain: Ease Sanctions to Save De Klerk from White Backlash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf on Syrian reaction
DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain called on Monday for a swift relaxation of sanctions against South Africa to save President F.W. de Klerk from being toppled by a white backlash. But most other countries said the release Sunday of black leader Nelson Mandela was not enough to warrant easing sanctions. The 12-nation European Community appeared likely to isolate Britain on the issue, and President Bush said it was too early to talk about lifting sanctions. The Soviet Union, which armed Mandela's African National Congress guerrilla movement, and China joined in international expressions of delight at Mandela's freedom. The Iranian Foreign Ministry said Mandela's release was ``a token of good omen'' because it came on the 11th anniversary of Iran's Islamic revolution. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyrpus, said the Foreign Ministry also reffirmed its support for the struggle against apartheid and warned South Africa's blacks to watch out for ``the tricks of racist agents and weathered supporters of the world arrogance.'' World arrogance is Iran's term for the United States. Most African nations, including powerful Nigeria, said the continent's last white government had taken a significant step but should still be isolated. However, two West African conservatives, the Ivory Coast and Gabon, urged immediate closer ties with South Africa. In London, Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said it was ``vital to send a signal to the white community that President de Klerk's steps will find a response from the international community.'' ``If we don't provide any response at all ... (you) will surely blame us when the white backlash sweeps de Klerk away,'' Waldegrave retorted in acrimonious exchanges wth opposition Labor Party legislators in the House of Commons. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wrote to fellow European Community leaders Sunday seeking an end to a 1986 ban on new investment in South Africa and to a ban on promoting tourism there. European Community foreign ministers will consider the proposal at a Feb. 20 meeting. Mandela, who walked free Sunday after more than 27 years in jail, said that sanctions and the armed struggle should continue. In a radio interview, Waldegrave brushed aside the international chorus for continued sanctions. He said the only countries whose positions mattered were the United States, Japan, West Germany and Britain _ all major South African trading partners. ``It doesn't actually matter very much what the distant chorus says,'' said Waldegrave. ``What really matters is that those who have influence show to de Klerk that his line ... is going to get a response. If it doesn't get a response he will be swept away.'' Ireland, current president of the European Community, said it believed the trade bloc should maintain its embargoes. The relatively mild sanctions include bans on imports of coal, iron and gold coins. ``President de Klerk displays great moral courage ... but (it is) only a start,'' said Irish Deputy Prime Minister Brian Lenihan said in Dublin. Other big trading partners confined themselves to welcoming Mandela's release. In Bonn, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher called it a ``decisive step'' and said his government would insist on a ``national dialogue in South Africa.'' Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said it was a ``clear turning point'' that would allow South Africa to move toward democracy. In Beijing, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said China welcomed the release of a man ``respected by all the justice-upholding people the world over, including the Chinese people,'' the Xinhua news agency reported. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov told reporters, ``We hail the release of Nelson Mandela ... a step that should have been taken long ago.'' At its exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, the ANC renewed its commitment to armed struggle. ``Our glorious people's army must be given all the necessary and possible assistance to enable it to enhance its combat capacity,'' ANC Secretary-General Alfred Nzo declared. Nzo made no reference to a call Sunday by Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda for the ANC to suspend bombings and other guerrilla actions in South Africa, but to maintain its military capability in case of violence by right-wing extremists. Zambian officials said Mandela telephoned Kaunda Sunday night and in emotional exchanges thanked him for ``his steadfast support for the ANC.'' In Damascus, Syrian President Hafez Assad welcomed Mandela's release and compared the fight against apartheid to Arab efforts to regain land claimed by Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Challenge U.S. on Surveillance at `Open Skies' Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADD 8 grafs with Baker, Shevardnadze weigh German unification
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OTT1
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union challenged the United States on Monday to extend superpower cooperation in arms control surveillance to the high seas and to space. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, addressing the opening of a 23-nation ``Open Skies'' conference, also accused the United States of bolstering its naval strength even while agreeing to cut ground forces and land-based missiles. ``Let us face the truth,'' Shevardnadze said. ``Today, the easiest way to launch a surprise attack, a military invasion or an aggression is from the seas.'' U.S. officials dismissed the idea, telling reporters in a separate briefing that Washington was not interested in a naval arms control agreement and that surveillance flights already are allowed over oceans and in space. However, President Bush told a White House news conference that he expected a ``major success'' on arms control at June's superpower summit in the United States. Shevardnadze's tough speech, and one by Secretary of State James A. Baker III leveling criticism at Soviet positions, broke from a recent trend of soft-spoken reconciliation between the superpowers. The exchange also strayed from he main topic at hand, an agreement between the 16 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven members of the Warsaw Pact on allowing the alliances to survey member nations by air. Bush originally made the proposal in May. It includes aerial inspection on 24 hours' notice to allay fears of surprise attack. The plan has been promoted as a confidence-building measure and both alliances have agreed to it in principle. Shevardnadze endorsed the proposal, which is likely to get final approval at a second conference in Budapest, Hungary, this year. He also announced that an agreement was reached during Baker's talks last week in Moscow to provide for inspections of radar sites. A Soviet team will be permitted to go to Thule, Greenland, and to U.S. installations in Britain, while an American group inspects the Siberian radar station at Krasnoyarsk and other sites. The two sides have exchanged accusations that the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty's limitations on a defense against missiles are being violated. Shevardnadze acknowledged last year that some activities at Krasnoyarsk were illegal and promised to dismantle the station. On Monday he criticized the United States at length for excluding naval forces from disarmament talks and for the ``Star Wars'' program of seeking ways to use nuclear weapons in space to block a ballistic missile attack. ``Again and again, at various negotiations, the issue of naval arms and confidence-building measures affecting the activity of states on the seas and oceans is being left out of consideration,'' the Soviet foreign minister said. ``No fair argument is cited to justify this,'' he said. Sarcastically, Shevardnadze said of the U.S. space program: ``They do not just grow chickens.'' He urged the Bush administration and all nations to join in developing a system to verify activities in space. On the open seas, Shevardnadze said, there should be exchanges of information about fleet positions and movements of large naval formations. ``Strong rays of light should focus on the darkest corners of military activity,'' he said. Baker, meanwhile, said positions taken by Moscow on troops and aircraft still stand in the way of completing a treaty this year to limit non-nuclear forces. He criticized Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for rejecting a proposal by Bush that would permit the United States to keep 30,000 troops in Britain, Italy and Spain, while both sides were held to 195,000 in Central Europe. Gorbachev countered with ceilings of 225,000 Soviet troops to 195,000 U.S. soldiers on foreign soil throughout Europe. That would, in effect, prevent a U.S. numerical edge because the Soviets could offset in Central Europe any Americans stationed eslewhere on the continent. Bush Monday said he stood by his plan. Baker said Gorbachev's proposal for equal ceilings had not taken into account that the Soviets could quickly expand their forces in a crisis while American troops would be an ocean away. Baker also criticized the Soviets' resistance to imposing ceilings on aircraft that Moscow claims have a defensive role. This was ``hardly a step toward arms reduction,'' Baker said. Raising the prospect of an impasse, Baker said ``disagreements over aircraft limits must not prevent us from signing a CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) agreement this year.'' A senior U.S. official suggested, however, that the issue might be finessed by leaving airplanes out of the treaty. Baker's tough approach seemed in contrast with his description in Moscow last Friday of Gorbachev's proposal on troop levels as ``very, very interesting,'' and close to Bush's approach. He said he would consult the NATO allies before giving a U.S. reply. A response _ and an early agreement _ now appears to be unlikely before Baker flies home Tuesday night. Baker and Shevardnadze met outside the conference to discuss German reunification. They set another meeting for Tuesday. Baker suggested this scenario, according to State Department officials: After East Germany holds elections March 18, officials of the new government would meet with West German leaders to begin planning unification. They would make decisions on the new Germany's legal and political arrangements and the size of its army. Afterward, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France would discuss ``security arrangements'' to allay the concerns of Germany's neighbors. As sovereign states, however, the two Germanys would have control of the nation's destiny. The Soviets have stressed those concerns, and Shevardnadze proposed two weeks ago an international plebisicite. But the State Department officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviets were ``quite interested'' in the U.S. proposal and that it had the endorsement of Britain and France.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to CORRECT splling to Copland, sted Copeland
DOC.TEXT: Walter Cronkite gave voice to Abraham Lincoln's words to the accompaniment of the 44-piece U.S. Coast Guard Academy band. The former CBS news anchorman also narrated Aaron Copland's ``Lincoln Portrait,'' as well as reciting speeches and writings of the 16th president, whose birthday was Monday. Cronkite read extensively from Lincoln's Gettysburg address at the ceremony Sunday at the academy's Leamy Hall.

DOC.HEAD: 1989 National Book Critics Circle Awards Announced
DOC.TEXT: E.L. Doctorow's ``Billy Bathgate'' won the fiction category in the 1989 National Book Critics Circle awards announced Monday. The awards are given annually for new books by American authors published in the United States. The board called ``Billy Bathgate'' a ``wondrous achievement by a writer who has written other fine novels in his distinguished career.'' The winner in the general non-fiction category was ``The Broken Cord'' by Michael Dorris, a first-person account of how fetal alcohol syndrome affected the author's son. ``A First-Class Temperament: The Emergence of Franklin Roosevelt,'' by Geoffrey C. Ward, was the winner in the biography-autobiography category; ``Transparent Gestures,'' by Rodney Jones, won for poetry; and ``Not by Fact Alone: Essays on the Writing and Reading of History,'' by James Clive, won for criticism. The National Book Critics Circle, founded in 1974, is a non-profit organization of 580 book critics and book review editors. The award ceremony is scheduled for March 8 at New York University.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Premier Ryzhkov Says His Country on Right Track
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Ryzhkov arriving in Australia, SUB 3rd graf pvs with 2 grafs and pickup 4th pvs, `He said...' and SUB 15th graf pvs to CONFORM; pickup 16th pvs, `Thailand, Australia...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov said Monday the Soviet Union is on the right track at the start of a radical, far-reaching process of change, despite world talk about a crisis in his country. He spoke at a news conference in Bangkok at the end of a two-day visit to Thailand, days after the Soviet Communist Party announced it was willing to give up its constitutional right to the leading role in government. Ryzhkov then flew to Melbourne, Australia, for a three-day visit and was greeted by Prime Minister Bob Hawke. He said in Bangkok that Moscow had laid the basis of revitalization and that economic changes had brought some positive results, although he admitted ``in some respects we have found that things are not moving in the direction that we planned.'' He said rival political parties would be allowed to form ``some time in the future,'' although the government believed the party should remain the driving force in the country. But the Communists would take part in politics as an equal and their leading role would be gained through political struggle, not by right, he said. ``Of course it is a new thing for us and we are just starting on our way (but) first experience has shown us that we are on the right track,'' he said. He said new political parties would need a legal basis as the process of change under way also had some negative implications. ``If the parties ... are for drawing two nationalities against each other, then these organizations should not be established and we shall fight against such organizations,'' he said. Ryzhkov's 50-member delegation included Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev. He was the first Soviet prime minister to visit Thailand. Ryzhkov said earlier that peace in Cambodia would benefit the entire region. A Soviet-backed government there has been fighting Western- and Chinese-backed guerrillas in an 11-year-old conflict. He said the Khmer Rouge guerrilla faction should take part in a meeting of warring Cambodian factions scheduled in Jakarta from Feb. 26-28. The group has indicated it will not attend. Ryzhkov held talks Monday with Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan and had an audience with King Bhumipol Adulyadej. In a luncheon speech, Chatichai, whose government backs the guerrillas, praised Moscow's ``constructive efforts in helping to find a political solution to the Cambodia problem.'' Ryzhkov said the Soviets were eager to improve trade ties and felt they could offer Thailand's developing economy expertise and modern technology to strengthen its basic industries. While in Australia, he is to visit three cities and sign several agreements ranging from port access for Soviet fishing trawlers to commodities deals. Ryzhkov then is to travel on to Singapore. Thailand, Australia and Singapore are major players in the Cambodian issue. On Monday, the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ the Soviet Union, the United Styates, China, Britain and France _ arranged to meet U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to brief him on efforts to enhance the U.N. role in the peace process, including plans for the world body to administer Cambodia and supervise elections.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Greets Congo President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs from state dinner; picks up 7th graf pvs: ``Bush recalled. FYI, the Congo republic has no connection with Zaire, formerly the Belgian Congo
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged Congolese President Denis Sassou-Nguesso to keep promoting peace in Angola and saluted ``the growing health of free markets and free ideas'' in the Congo. At a state dinner Monday night honoring the president of the People's Republic of the Congo, Bush said Sassou had helped make Southern Africa ``a more peaceful and stable place. ``Namibia will soon be independent. The new beginnings in South Africa may help end an old evil, apartheid,'' said Bush. ``And in Angola, as Cuban troops are leaving, our search for national reconciliation has intensified.'' He urged Sassou to use his ``respected voice'' to pursue peace and self-determination for the people in Angola. Bush said the Congo, once closely aligned with Moscow, ``has taken some welcome steps, encouraging private enterprise, placing some limits on the power of single-party rule and opening the legislature to non-party groups.'' Bush raised a glass to toast Sassou's health, success and ``the growing health of free markets and free ideas in your homeland.'' Sassou applauded Bush's role in leading the world to a more peaceful era, saying, ``History will note that the U.S.-USSR dialogue of the 90s helped sketch out the 21st century.'' Speaking in French, the Congolese president said: ``May all benefit from these trends, big people as well as small. May democracy and freedom be combined with peace and development.'' He called life in Africa today ``tragic'' and said international support, especially from the seven major Western democracies, is needed more than ever before ``to ensure our survival and our recovery.'' Earlier, in welcoming Sassou to the White House, Bush assured his visitor that the dramatic events in Europe will not diminish U.S. interest in African affairs. ``Africa's our friend. And friends don't forget one another,'' Bush said at a full-dress military welcome. Bush said that despite ``undiminished'' U.S. support for the UNITA rebels, ``we continue to hope for a negotiated settlement to that tragic war'' in Angola. Bush recalled he had visited Africa three times as vice president and said he hoped to do so again as president. ``Some have suggested that events in the rest of the world, including Central Europe, mean that the United States will no longer pay attention to AFrica. I can assure you and everyone in Africa that this is not the case,'' said Bush. ``I hereby renew the commitment of the American people and government to ... (work closely) in partnership with Africa,'' Bush said. Sassou paid tribute to the 200-year history of freedom in the United States that ``has inspired so many ideals and dreams for mankind.'' He called Bush ``one of the great figures who have inherited this rich legacy.'' Noting that this is African-American History Month and Monday was the birthday of Abraham Lincoln, Sassou also invoked the memories of Lincoln and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ``Their lives, their struggle, represent for us Africans a never-ending source of admiration, pride and hope,'' he said. Both leaders hailed the release from a South African prison of Nelson Mandela. Bush called it ``another important sign that South Africa may soon begin negotiating a democratic, nonracial society and at last be on the way to ending apartheid once and for all.'' Sassou said Mandela was ``a great symbol of dignity for African men'' whose ``release ushers in great prospects for the negotiations on the future of South African society. From this day on, the Congo can look forward with optimism to the future of its own relations with South Africa.'' This was the first official visit of a Congolese president, although Sassou came here in 1986 as chairman of the Organization of African Unity. The United States is its largest trading partner, importing $400 million worth of Congolese petroleum annually.

DOC.HEAD: Three Guerrillas Killed by Israeli-Backed Militiamen
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-backed militiamen shot and killed three suspected guerrillas Monday in south Lebanon, Israeli military sources said. One soldier from the South Lebanon Army militia was slightly wounded in the incident, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said a force from the Israeli-backed militia opened fire after spotting the guerrilla squad near Taibe, a village 2{ miles from the Israeli border. Three were killed, they said. The sources were unable to identify the guerrillas, but Israel's Itim national news agency said documents on the bodies indicated they were members of the Lebanese Communist Party. The clash occurred in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone, a six- to 10-mile-wide strip of land patrolled by Israeli troops and the SLA militia. Israel carved out zone in 1985 when it removed the most of its troops from Lebanon following the 1982 invasion of that country.

DOC.HEAD: Priest, 15 Others Guilty of Obstruction in Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with verdict, quotes, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Daniel Berrigan and 15 others who blocked the elevator doors in the federal building in this city to protest U.S. aid to El Salvador were convicted by a federal judge Monday of obstruction. U.S. Magistrate Ronald Fonseca sentenced Berrigan and each of 14 other defendants to 20 hours of community service. Another defendant was ordered to spend seven days in a halfway house because she was on probation for trespassing in an anti-nuclear protest. ``This court does not doubt you're sincere,'' Fonseca told the defendants. ``But you cannot force your actions (on others) merely to prove your case.'' Berrigan and 22 others were arrested Dec. 1 in the Hale Boggs Federal Building after they blocked the eight elevators in the lobby for more than an hour. As many as 100 demonstrators went to the federal building that day to protest U.S. aid to El Salvador, where six Jesuit priests were slain in November. Berrigan is a Jesuit priest. Of the 23 arrested, seven pleaded guilty earlier and also were sentenced to perform community service. Bill Quigley, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, said he didn't plan to appeal Fonseca's decision. ``The trial today showed there is justice and there is law,'' Quigley said. ``I think it was a technically correct decision. I think the defendants were correct as well.'' Berrigan, a veteran of anti-war and other protests who says he's lost count of the number of times he's been arrested, was less conciliatory. ``I feel the whole thing was a cover-up for the illegal murders of the Jesuit priests,'' Berrigan said. Quigley argued the protesters should be acquitted because federal law requires that rules governing prohibited behavior in federal buildings must be posted in a conspicuous place. They weren't when the demonstration occurred, he said. Several of the defendants testified they weren't told blocking the elevators was a federal crime. Prosecutor Patrice Harris argued that they should have known. The one protester sentenced to seven days in a halfway house was Janet LeBoeuf. She has lost nearly 20 pounds since she began a water-only fast Jan. 22 at St. Louis Cathedral to protest continued Salvadoran aid after the six priests were killed. She said she would continue the fast in jail if she is sentenced in connection with the demonstration. ``The question for me is not when will the fast end, but when will the military aid to El Salvador end,'' she said. Berrigan lives in New York City, where he works with AIDS patients. He was arrested last week in New York for blocking the doors of the office of U.S. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Member of Congress to Seek a Seventh Term
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Strom Thurmond, who at 87 is the oldest member of Congress, announced Monday he would seek a seventh term. ``I am just your humble servant,'' the Republican told a small group of supporters gathered in his western South Carolina hometown. ``I'm proud of South Carolina and we will continue to work together to make it the greatest state in the nation,'' Thurmond said. ``In all my years of public service I have never felt a stronger obligation to continue my work for the future of our state and our nation.'' Thurmond became the oldest member of Congress when Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla., died last year at age 88. The South Carolina legislator, who has served in the Senate since 1955, was president pro tem from 1981 through 1987. A former governor, state senator and judge who ran unsuccessfully for president as a Dixiecrat in 1948, he switched from the Democratic Party to the GOP in 1964. Thurmond has a campaign war chest of about $700,000, according to the Federal Elections Commission, and no formal opposition. ``I've had opponents every time,'' he said. ``The office belongs to the people. I'm a temporary occupant of the office.'' Wearing a red, white and blue tie and an American flag pin in his lapel, Thurmond said that if re-elected, he would work to improve education and the quality of life and to protect the environment. Thurmond celebrated his 87th birthday in December and said at the time his secret for a long life is a good diet, exercise and an optimistic outlook.

DOC.HEAD: Journalists Group Protests Attack on TV Crews, Beating
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute on Monday protested an attack on Turkish, Dutch and German television crews covering the trial of two politicians in Greece. In a letter to Prime Minister Xenofon Zolotas of Greece, Peter Galliner, director of the institute, said the television crews were attacked and beaten by a group of people waiting near the court building in Komotini. ``The institute is very concerned about this violent attack. We defend our colleagues' right to cover and distribute news without fear of violence or other interference,'' Galliner said in the letter. ``We urge your authorities to ensure the media can operate freely without harassment and threats to their safety,'' he said. The IPI on Monday also condemned the beating of a news photographer by Pakistani police. The institute said Zafar Ahmed, who was working for Agence France-Presse, was beaten by police in Karachi on Sunday. The institute represents more than 2,000 journalists, including editors and publishers.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Rebels Claim Downing of Troop Transport Plane
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese rebels said Monday they had shot down a transport plane ferrying troops to the southern Sudan town of Maridi. In a clandestine radio broadcast, the Sudan People's Liberation Army said the C-130 Hercules was brought down last Thursday by ``a heat-seeking missile.'' ``The plane fell inside Maridi and all aboard perished,'' said the broadcast monitored in Kenya's capital of Nairobi. It gave no estimate on the casualty toll. The broadcast said the plane was one of two being used by the government to return an estimated 1,000 soldiers who fled into northwest Zaire following the fall of a border garrison last month. The rebels also claimed to have halted a relief convoy bound from Malakal to Juba, the besieged capital of eastern Equatoria province, killing 72 government soldiers and destroying 10 trucks and two tanks. There was no independent confirmation of the claims.

DOC.HEAD: Gray Whales Behind Schedule, Mexican Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: Mexican officials said a weekend aerial survey showed low numbers of gray whales arriving in bays along the Pacific coast of Baja California though U.S.-based whalewatchers reported were seeing normal numbers. ``Only about 20 percent of the normal population has arrived, and we're still concerned,'' said Ulises Cesena Montano, coordinator of the Vizcaino Biosphere Reserve, a favored gray whale calving area. But he said bad weather limited the survey. The San Diego Sportfishing Council, whose members run commercial whale-watching expeditions to the Baja California lagoons, said its members were reporting normal numbers of whales. Flyovers of the San Ignacio and Ojo de Liebre lagoons on Saturday and Sunday revealed 90 grays, Cesena said by telephone Monday. Jorge Hernandez, a biologist at Vizcaina, said he spotted 30 more of the marine mammals off the coast south of the reserve between Todos Santos and San Jose del Cabo. ``That probably means that along the length of the coast there are many more,'' Hernandez said. But he said the number of gray whales normally in the lagoons at this time of year ranges from 900 to 1,150. ``The reality right now is that the population has been held up, and we still don't know why,'' Cesena said. Patricia Warhol, director of the American Cetacean Society in Los Angeles, which also runs whalewatchers' expeditions, said her organization received reports that the whales arrived in Baja California in the same numbers as usual. She said her association calculates that the same number of whales as usual passed the southern California coast on their migration, but they showed up late and followed a new migration route. ``The migration was two weeks late here, and they're now going outside the Channel Islands instead of through the (Santa Barbara) channel. Possibly that makes the trip a little longer and they may not have shown up yet,'' Ms. Warhol said, adding that weather and food supplies can influence migration timing. Cesena said Baja California experts speculate that a previously unknown cold current, called the Corriente de la Nina, might be holding up the whales. The species was once hunted almost to extinction, but estimates of the total population now run from 17,000 to 21,000.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Monitor Says He Never Saw Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Cole asked...,' with 10 grafs to UPDATE with testimony of crewmen describing chaos on bridge; picks up 10th graf, ``I did...
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard vessel monitor who was on duty when the Exxon Valdez ran aground testified Monday that he never looked for the tanker on his radar screen before the nation's biggest oil spill. Bruce Blandford, testifying in the trial of former tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood on felony criminal mischief and other charges, said he came on duty 40 minutes before the disaster. He said he was told by Gordon Taylor, the monitor who preceeded him, that the ship had gone out of radar range. Blandford said he heard nothing from Hazelwood and added, ``I wasn't looking for him because he had been lost (from radar) and I had no reason to believe anything was happening other than what Mr. Taylor had told me.'' He said he went about straightening up papers, had coffee and did his chores without looking at the radar before he got a radio message. He said Hazelwood called to report the Exxon Valdez was ``hard aground and leaking oil.'' ``Did you respond immediately?'' asked Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole. ``It seemed like forever,'' said the witness. ``It took about a minute for me to figure out what was going on.'' Blandford said he glanced at his radar screen and could see the marker indicating the troubled ship. I asked him, ``Are you about a mile north of Bligh Reef? And he said yes.'' In other testimony, two seamen who took turns at the helm on the Exxon Valdez painted a chaotic picture of the minutes before the tanker went aground. Harry Claar told of being at the helm about 11:20 p.m. when Hazelwood ordered him to put the ship on automatic pilot. He said he followed the order and yielded the helm to Robert Kagan just before midnight. Kagan said he knew the tanker was on automatic pilot when he took over and can't remember when the order came to go back to hand steering. He said he and the third mate, Gregory Cousins, were near the autopilot control and, ``We both reached for it at the same time.'' Then, he said, he heard three separate commands to go right, left and then right again. In the final seconds before grounding, he said, there was a command to turn hard left and Cousins grabbed the wheel with him. ``I started making the turn and he grabbed the wheel and helped make it,'' Kagan said. ``I think he was kind of panicking then. ... He was kind of excited.'' At last, Kagan said, he heard ``a little rattle, bumping'' and the ship was aground. Asked about Hazelwood's orders after the grounding, Kagan said he can't be sure whether the captain was trying to move the ship off the rocks or stabilize it on the rocks. ``I really wasn't sure what he was doing,'' the witness said. Cousins took the stand briefly before court recessed, and was to tell his version of the grounding Tuesday. During questioning of Blanford, Cole asked the civilian Coast Guard employee what went through his mind at the time of the grounding, but Blandford said he didn't remember. ``I did a pretty hard swallow ... the adrenalin started pumping.'' He said he called the commanding officer of the Coast Guard station and told him ``this was the big one _ the Exxon Valdez was on the rocks leaking oil.'' Within an hour, he said, phones were ringing off the walls and the Coast Guard had begun search and rescue operations. The Exxon Valdez was gashed open when it hit part of the long, jagged Bligh Reef, and spewed more than 10 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound. The spill blackened hundreds of miles of rocky coastline, killing hundreds of thousand of birds and wildlife. Exxon says the cleanup has cost $2 billion. Hazewlood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is the only person charged criminally in the case. His lawyers are trying to show that the Coast Guard's inattention may have caused the disaster, not Hazelwood's alleged recklessness. Hazewlood is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Both Blandford and Gordon Taylor, who concluded his testimony Monday, said that even if they had thought Hazelwood was off course, they lacked authority to order him to change position. They said they would have had to defer to a commanding officer in such a situation. ``Who is in the best position to navigate a tanker?'' asked Cole. ``Certainly the master,'' Blandford said, referring to the captain. Asked to explain, he said, ``With reference to a vessel traffic controller with radar contact, I can only see where he is in relation to other vessels. I can't see what he can see. I know approximaely where he is. But he is much closer to the locale and I can't see what he sees.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Born Politician Wins Seat in Canadian Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD winner's quotes, polling percentages, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: ST-BASILE-LE-GRAND, Quebec (AP) _ U.S.-born Phil Edmonston easily won a special parliamentary election in the Chambly district Monday to become the first politician from the New Democratic Party to be elected in Quebec. Edmonston defeated Liberal Party candidate Clifford Lincoln by about a 70 percent to 15 percent margin, according to results late Monday from nearly all of the 194 polling stations. Lincoln needed a victory to boost his campaign for the national Liberal leadership; four other candidates polled marginal returns. Known as a consumer advocate, Edmonston overcame allegations in the final days of the campaign that he had accepted kickbacks in the 1970s. His triumph was considered all the more remarkable because Edmonston, born in Washington, D.C., 45 years ago and a U.S. armed forces veteran who served 2{ years in Panama, speaks French with a strong American accent. The Chambly constituency is overwhelmingly Francophone and traditionally nationalist. ``Quebec is a province where people are very tolerent,'' said Edmonston, who was greeted by a rousing version of the Quebec nationalist anthem Gens du pays. Residents of Quebec accept people of ethnic and cultural backgrounds, ``but French must be first,'' Edmonston added. He failed in earlier attempts to get a seat in the federal Parliament in a special election in 1977 and in 1988 general elections. Said Lincoln, ``I accept my defeat, but life continues.''

DOC.HEAD: Schools to Reopen; Judge Refuses to End City Hall Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES redundant 14th graf, ```I anticipate ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: Angry black students carrying the banner ``Keep The Dream Alive'' marched out of Selma High School on Monday, ending a five-day sit-in, but decided they wouldn't return to class when the school reopens. In another development, a federal judge turned down the city's request to halt a sit-in at City Hall in this landmark city of the civil rights era. Mayor Joe Smitherman announced that all schools would reopen Tuesday, but the racial protest that brought public education to a halt last week seemed far from resolved. Some white parents said they were transferring children to other school systems. Superintendent Norward Roussell, whose dismissal at the end the school year sparked the protests, ordered teachers to report at 7:15 a.m. Tuesday and predicted that about 70 percent of the school system's 6,000 students would be in class. ``I anticipate some of our students will not show up tomorrow, but we will have students tomorrow and we will have regular classes for those students,'' Roussell said Monday. More than 100 black students who took part in the sit-in voted Monday night to march to the high school when it reopened Tuesday, but said they wouldn't attend classes. The students met in the basement of First Baptist Church while more than 300 adults sat upstairs singing hymns. After the vote, Roussell told the parents and students it was their decision how to react to schools reopening, but added, ``I didn't come here to be superintendent over empty classrooms and closed schools.'' U.S. District Judge Charles Butler of Mobile, after hearing arguments partly through a telephone hookup, refused earlier in the day to grant a temporary restraining order against the black protesters in Selma. However, he said he would reconsider the order if continued protests interfered with school and City Hall activities. On the steps of City Hall, Smitherman said Monday afternoon that officials felt public schools could safely reopen Tuesday. ``I will have adequate law enforcement at each school to ensure the safety of the children,'' he said. His statement was greeted by ``boos'' from a few dozen black protesters in the crowd. Roussell predicted about 70 percent of the students would show up Tuesday. About 150 students paraded Monday morning from the high school to City Hall, where they briefly packed corridors, then most departed. About 25 adults and students continued a City Hall sit-in that began six days ago. Roussell was reinstated a week ago as rising racial tensions forced the school closings, but the board has declined to extend his contract beyond its June expiration. Roussell and his supporters say the board opposes him because of his race, not his alleged lack of managerial skills cited in an evaluation. The five black members of the 11-member Selma Board of Education announced their resignations after the initial vote not to extend Roussell's contract. Protesters also want the school board to be elective rather than appointed by the City Council, which has five whites and four blacks. Roussell spoke with student leaders of the high school sit-in Monday, shortly before their parade. ``He felt it was in our best interest to leave. Plus, the school board would fire him if we didn't leave,'' said student protester Latima Salaam. Roussell confirmed that the white members of the school board threatened to fire him if he did not expel students continuing the sit-in. He said he would not expel them, but he did not rule out lesser disciplinary action. Joe Pickard, a white member of the school board and a former superintendent, said he was not aware of any threat to fire Roussell if he did not expel the protesting students. ``I know nothing about such a statement to him whatsoever,'' Pickard said. The racial tensions and shutdown of the school system has prompted some white parents to transfer their children. Sandra Knapp Sewell was among them, transferring her daughter, Melissa, to Prattville. ``I'm leaving a place I've lived in 45 years to make sure she has a safe place to go to school,'' said Mrs. Sewell. Black student protesters did not immediately say what their next step would be. Most returned to the high school, picked up their sleeping bags and went home. Ms. Salaam said the students would meet Monday night. City Attorney Henry Pitts urged Butler to issue an order prohibiting the protesters from ``totally paralyzing city government.'' He said the dispute does not involve the human rights that were at stake in 1965, when the Selma-to-Montgomery march helped blacks gain voting rights. J.L. Chestnut, a black attorney in Selma, said, ``We don't think some blanket injunction barring our people from the seat of government should be granted.'' He said fundamental rights to peaceful assembly would be violated. By noon, after about 150 students marched from Selma High School, all but about 25 adult and student protesters were gone from City Hall, which reopened its offices. When the student marchers first jammed inside, all the offices closed, except for Smitherman's. Several police officers guarded his door.

DOC.HEAD: ANC, South African Government Leaders Join in TV Debate
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seated in a Johannesburg television studio a few feet from an African National Congress leader, South Africa's Foreign Minister Pik Botha on Monday night described followers of the black guerrilla movement as ``my friends.'' The ANC's Ahmed Kathrada, released a year ago after 26 years in jail, said nothing really had changed, but he didn't doubt the sincerity or integrity of the white government leaders. His face lined and somber, Jeff Masomola of the smaller, militant black nationalist Pan African Congress dismissed negotiations as futile. Only immediate universal suffrage for the 5-1 black majority, he said, ``will result in the taking over of this country by the people who own it.'' And veteran white liberal politician Helen Suzman chided Botha for ``making the sort of speeches I made 30 years ago.'' All were guests on the British Broadcasting Corp.'s ``Panorama'' current affairs program beamed live from Johannesburg in what the network said was the first such appearance by South African leaders from across almost the entire political spectrum. It came a day after ANC head Nelson Mandela, considered by many of South Africa's blacks to be their leader, was released after 27 years in prison. Only the far-right white opposition Conservative Party refused to come to the studio because its followers object to sitting in a room with members of the ANC. Conservative Party spokesman Koos van der Merwe made his contribution in a separate recording. ``He (Nelson Mandela) came out of that jail without having given in one inch of his demands,'' said van der Merwe. ``They are not interested in peace or democracy. They want complete capitulation of the white people.'' No one raised their voices or interrupted throughout the near one-hour program. In the studio audience, several whites expressed unease or resentment about the insistence by Mandela that the armed struggle should continue. Some of the blacks wondered why, after decades of apartheid, blacks were now supposed to help allay white fears.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says Soviet Moslems Fete Revolution Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Monday that Soviet Moslems in troubled Azerbaijan province celebrated the 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution that brought the Shiite Moslem clergy to power in Tehran. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, said Soviet Moslems gathered along the border Sunday, the culmination of the 10-day celebrations marking the anniversary, and shouted Islamic slogans. It said did not say how many people assembled across the Aras River near the border city of Poldasht in Iran's East Azarbaijan province. The area is in Nakhichevan, an Azerbaijani enclave bordered by Armenia, Iran and Turkey. Soviet Azerbaijanis share a common culture, language and religion with their Iranian cousins. Azerbaijan was once completely ruled by Iran, but was divided in 1828. Border violence flared last month during protests in Soviet Azerbaijan for closer links with Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Prime Minister Meets Britain's Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher said Monday after meeting with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland that Britain will help the Warsaw government try to solve its economic problems. The two also discussed German unification and the consequences for Europe at a meeting that lasted more than two hours, a spokesman for the British prime minister said. Next week in Paris, Poland will ask Western governments to reschedule and ease its $39 billion foreign debt burden. Mrs. Thatcher congratulated Mazowiecki on his handling of Poland's transition from a communist to a free-market economy since he became prime minister last August, and he thanked Britain for its help. Mrs. Thatcher later told reporters Britain wanted to see German unification accomplished with security and stability in Poland. Poland's borders should be guaranteed by treaty, she said. Part of Poland's territory once belonged to Germany. Polish officials have expressed concern that moves toward German unity could threaten boundaries. Mrs. Thatcher said Britain would consider giving more help to Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Raspberry Awards Select Worst Films, Performances of Year and Decade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Angelyne is complete name in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Saluting the very worst in motion pictures, the Golden Raspberry Foundation on Monday announced the nominees for the 10th Razzie Awards, with Sylvester Stallone, John Travolta, Jane Fonda and Bo Derek heading the list of film flops. Nominated for the most inept film of 1989 were ``Karate Kid III,'' ``Lock-Up,'' ``Road House,'' ``Speed Zone'' and ``Star Trek V.'' The latter film received a top six Razzie nominations, followed by ``Karate Kid III'' with five selections, ``Road House'' with four, and ``Lock-Up,'' ``The Lonely Lady'' and ``Mommie Dearest'' receiving three nominations apiece. In addition to recognizing the low lights of 1989, the Raspberry Foundation also will dishonor the decade's most dreadful films and performances. Nominated for worst actor of the year were Tony Danza (for ``She's Out of Control''), Ralph Macchio (``Karate Kid III''), William Shatner (``Star Trek V''), Stallone (``Lock-Up'' and ``Tango & Cash'') and Patrick Swayze (``Next of Kin'' and ``Road House''). Miss Fonda (the star of ``Old Gringo'') was nominated as worst actress of the year, joining Heather Locklear (``The Return of Swamp Thing''), Brigitte Nielsen (``Bye Bye, Baby''), Paulina Porizkova (``Her Alibi'') and Ally Sheedy (``Heart of Dixie''). The nominees for worst supporting actor of 1989 were Christopher Atkins (``Listen to Me''), Ben Gazzara (``Road House''), DeForest Kelley (``Star Trek V''), Noriyuki ``Pat'' Morita (``Karate Kid III'') and Donald Sutherland (``Lock-Up''). The nominees for worst supporting actress of 1989 were Angelyne (``Earth Girls Are Easy''), Anne Bancroft (``Bert Rigby, You're a Fool''), Madonna (``Bloodhounds of Broadway''), Kurt Russell (dressed in drag in ``Tango & Cash'') and Brooke Shields (``Speed Zone''). Nominated as the worst films of the 1980s were ``Bolero,'' ``Howard the Duck,'' ``The Lonely Lady,'' ``Mommie Dearest'' and ``Star Trek V.'' Atkins, Ryan O'Neal, Prince, Stallone and Travolta were nominated as worst actor of the decade. The worst actress of the decade nominees were Miss Derek, Faye Dunaway, Madonna, Miss Shields and Pia Zadora, the organization said. Worst new star of the decade nominees were Atkins, Madonna, Prince, Miss Zadora and Diane Scarwid. The nominations are determined by ballots from more than 275 Raspberry Foundation members throughout California and 21 other states, with additional members in Canada and Switzerland, said a news release from the foundation made up of film fans who enjoy celebrating the worst in cinema. The awards will be presented at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, where the Oscars were first held, on March 25, the night before the Academy Awards.

Perrier says it plans to destroy its entire U.S. inventory of bottled mineral water _ about 72 million bottles _ because a small amount of poisonous benzene was found in some samples. The company has also shut down its France-based bottling operation and directed its distributors to pull the water from stores' shelves, said Ronald V. Davis, president of the Greenwich-based Perrier Group of America Inc., which distributes the bottled water in the United States. The head of the Food and Drug Administration said the levels detected pose a ``negligible'' health risk. ``If I had a bottle in the refrigerator, I would drink it,'' said acting FDA Commissioner James Benson.

President Bush says it is a time for ``rejoicing'' over Nelson Mandela's freedom after 27 years in South African prisons, but not for deciding whether to keep up stiff U.S. sanctions on the country's white minority-ruled regime. Bush telephoned the newly liberated black leader on Sunday and invited him to visit the White House. Afterwards, Bush had only words of praise for both Mandela and the man who freed him, South African President F.W. de Klerk. ``I'm not prepared to express my views on sanctions at this time,'' Bush told reporters in the Rose Garden. Asked if he believed it was the sanctions that prompted de Klerk's decision to release Mandela, Bush replied, ``Maybe so. I don't know.''

Capping a week of high-profile and apparently successful European diplomacy, Secretary of State James A. Baker III is sounding out NATO allies on how to shape an accord with Moscow to withdraw a half-million U.S. and Soviet troops from the continent. Baker's sessions at a NATO-Warsaw Pact ``Open Skies'' conference in the Canadian capital could extend a skein of arms control breakthroughs that marked his four days of talks in Moscow last week. The United States and Soviet Union now stand on the brink of treaties to slash their chemical weapons and long-range nuclear missiles. And if the talks with allies and a session today with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze pan out, the differences between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on troop cuts can be worked out.

Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is sidestepping a striking snub from President Corazon Aquino and moving ahead with plans to meet top Philippine military officials on the future of U.S. forces in the unsettled country. Cheney, here on the opening leg of a two-week tour of Asian allied nations, did not respond to Mrs. Aquino's refusal to meet with him on his first visit to her country as defense secretary. ``He doesn't take it personally.
