For release Thursday Feb. 22
DOC.HEAD: Fifth in a Series
Japan Lukewarm to Expanding Business in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: When Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu toured Europe last month he demonstrated Japan's economic might by announcing almost $2 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary, dwarfing what the United States has committed. In contrast, private Japanese industries, known for their aggressive expansion elsewhere, are reluctant to plunge into a part of the world they see as inexperienced, ill-equipped and still emerging from 40 years of communism. A few prominent deals have been done. Suzuki Motor Co., for example, recently agreed to establish an automobile plant in Hungary, the first Japanese company to enter a joint venture with Eastern Europe since the tumultuous political changes there. But Eastern Europe remains virtually untouched by Japanese business. In 1988, Japan trade with the region totaled about $1.47 billion, excluding the Soviet Union. That's less than 1 percent of Japanese trade worldwide. Though many Japanese firms have offices in Eastern European nations, only about a dozen joint ventures have been established. No Japanese company has yet invested in Poland, East Germany or Czechoslovakia. Japanese businessmen have a range of reasons for holding back. High inflation rates, a heavy debt burden and inconvertible currencies make it difficult to profit in Eastern Europe, in their view. Restrictions on exports of high technology to the East bloc, a vestige of the Cold War that remains entrenched, also have reduced the spectrum of trade opportunities for the Japanese, leading exporters of high-tech items. Nonetheless, the changing political and economic landscape of Eastern Europe has evoked Japan's interest. The government has allocated $750 million for export insurance to encourage Japanese firms to trade there. To Daihatsu Motor Co., economic reform and Japanese government aid cannot alleviate the tremendous risks it sees. One of Japan's smallest automobile manufacturers, Daihatsu has tried for more than five years to set up an assembly plant in Poland. Though it developed an ambitious plan to build a 12,000-vehicle-a-year plant with Polish automaker FSO, Daihatsu failed to acquire enough financing and the plan collapsed. Last fall, FSO approached Daihatsu again. This time, said spokesman Wataru Shindo, the company has considerably scaled down plans _ it will export about 6,000 unassembled Charade models to Poland. ``We don't know whether we'll be able to meet our costs. At a scale of 5,000 to 6,000 cars, even if we fail there will be little damage done,'' Shindo said. Japan's largest glass manufacturer expressed the same caution. Asahi Glass Co. has been negotiating with Poland to establish a plate glass factory in the southern city of Sandomierz. The risks remain high, said Asahi official Shigehiko Tomita, and no commitment has been made. Tomita said trade insurance and other Japanese government support was necessary but stability in Eastern Europe was more important. ``The political and economic situation in Poland is still fluid, and the risks great. The country has high inflation, and even though we think that democratization will proceed, we need to have some protection,'' he said. Shigeki Ura, a senior officer with merchant trader C. Itoh and Co. in Eastern Europe, doubted Japanese firms will attempt any large-scale investments. Nevertheless, he added, ``As businessmen specializing in the Eastern European market, we should not be so optimistic, but not so pessimistic. Economic reform and democracy will give us chances.'' Ura said Japanese firms differ fundamentally from European firms in their attitude toward developing the Eastern European market. The Japanese want clear-cut laws in place specifying what is permissible for foreigners, but some European investors are willing to overlook legal vaguenesses, Ura said. Despite Japan's reluctance, its neighbor South Korea seems eager to exploit opportunity in Eastern Europe. Yoo Chang-soon, chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, South Korea's largest business organization, said recently that ``prospects are bright'' for direct investment there. ``Some big entrepreneurs have already studied plans for direct investment in communist countries,'' he said. South Korea established diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia only last year, and has a $91 million dollar trade surplus with those countries.

DOC.HEAD: GDANSK: no quality.''
DOC.TEXT: For 40 years, Eastern Europe has produced goods only the Soviet Union would buy. They got back oil, raw materials and finished products. Artificial rates were fixed in ``transferable rubles.'' This closed circuit within strictly patrolled borders reduced former industrial powers to Third World levels, with 40 percent of the European Economic Community's productivity rate at twice the energy consumption. Reform-minded countries must now wean themselves from the Soviet Union and its socialist trading bloc, Comecon. The Soviet Union and Comecon partners agreed in January to work toward trade in hard, convertible currency. But there was sharp disagreement on how. ``I don't think these countries know what they're in for,'' said Jan Vanous, a specialist on Eastern Europe at PlanEcon Inc., a Washington consulting firm. ``They'll see inflation, unemployment, debt, the works.'' Because East bloc currencies are useless in the West, no one knows precisely what they're worth. Many economists say these currencies will have to find their true value in a free market of foreign exchange, but most agree they are worth a fraction of their officially set rates. This means, for example, that it could take huge sums of Polish zlotys, Czech korunas, or Hungarian forints to buy the same things that smaller amounts of those currencies bought previously. ``They will have to break out of the old cycle of `you pretend to work and we pretend to pay you,''' Vanous said. ``It will be very difficult.'' Some Eastern European leaders who espouse free enterprise and open markets still recoil from the term capitalism. Romania's revolutionary government, for example, cannot remove the social safety net as it picks up the pieces of a potentially rich agricultural economy plundered by executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. When the revolution began, Petre Roman said Romania would open its economy to the world. Later as prime minister he remarked, ``It would be irresponsible to speak of this in detail now.'' Czechoslovakia is slowly opening without abandoning socialist safeguards, guided by economists who pushed for reform under the communists. Not only are top managers reluctant to relinquish power but many workers fear the adventure of free competition. ``We will have a tremendous job breaking up the mafia that runs the big state companies,'' said one government adviser, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``I am not sure we can do it.'' East Germany is trying to intertwine with West Germany while keeping its socialist character. But as people move west, from cab drivers to physicists, plans are in turmoil. Pressure from Bonn is accelerating economic integration. Hungarians have experimented with a private sector since the early 1980s and have long been open to outside influence. Today Budapest looks like a prosperous Western capital. Vaci Street, nearly as swank as Paris' rue de la Paix, glitters with wealth. Its McDonald's is Europe's busiest. General Motors Corp. recently committed $150 million to a joint venture, one of 400 deals struck in the last six months between Hungarian and foreign companies. Hungarian officials toured U.S. stock exchanges last month in preparation for plans to expand their own, launched a year ago. In a desperate image-building move, Hungary decided to co-host the 1995 World's Fair with Austria, which will cost its strapped economy an estimated $2.5 billion. Laszlo Lengyel, an influential economic consultant in Budapest, said little has changed for Hungary's or Eastern Europe's three main classes despite giant political strides. In Hungary, wages average $150 a month. Waiting lists for tiny subsidized apartments approach 20 years. Private homes are prohibitively expensive. While the elites retain power, Lengyel said, a broad class of workers sees no prospect for new income beyond controlled wages. Worse, many fear layoffs in a new free-for-all atmosphere. A third class of people with second jobs or small businesses on the side might take new risks, he said. But few have contacts, access to capital or reliable suppliers. Lengyel said a breakthrough may come from European and Japanese investors who join local entrepreneurs in businesses that control their own supply and distribution. But, he said, the American approach offering minimal official aid and encouraging joint ventures will have limited impact. Even some American diplomats in the region say privately that a country which spent trillions to combat communism militarily should risk a few billion to defeat it peacefully. The Gdansk Shipyard, birthplace of the Solidarity movement that incited the East bloc's sweeping changes, embodies the challenge. Operations director Hans Szyc explained he could sell all the ships he could make, but not without capital. Foreign investors remain cautious and local banks charge 58 percent interest per month. ``True, I am proud of the role this shipyard played in changing the whole world,'' Szyc said. ``But the problem is not the past, not today, but the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Number of Models For Eastern Europeans to Emulate in Transformation
With BC-EUR--Economic Challenge
DOC.TEXT: Eastern European nations face a range of alternatives in the search for prototypes to reform their stagnating economies. All involve dismantling state-run subsidy systems that keep prices artificially low, unleashing market forces of supply and demand, and moving toward integration with the rest of the world. The unprecedented undertaking is fraught with risks. Moreover, none of the models advanced so far has been put to an extended test. Below are some of the approaches under discussion:

State-owned companies would be converted to worker-owned businesses through the issuance of stock to employees. Under this arrangement, the government would give preferential low-interest loans to these businesses, repayable over long periods, while workers would control production, expansion, research, marketing, hiring and firing. Employee ownership would preserve the socialist ideal of workers controlling their own destinies. But in the West, where variations of this model also have been tried, they often have resulted in inefficiency and a reluctance by employees to make tough decisions needed for their businesses to compete and survive.

State-owned companies would be sold to existing management, foreign companies or a combination of both. In essentially one bold stroke, the government would end its role as a giant business monopoly, theoretically encouraging competition and productivity. Sales of state-owned assets would be financed by low-interest government loans. If the buyers are overseas investors, the government would benefit by an infusion of foreign currency and expertise. The risks lie in entrenching old managers, mostly unqualified Communist Party functionaries. The process could create enormous resentment by workers who feel little has changed.

State-owned companies would be restructured into interlocking networks of suppliers and lenders that own stakes in each other, creating an incentive for them to cooperate. An automaker, for example, would form a partnership with a steel factory, which would be partly owned by a bank, which in turn would be partly owned by the automaker. Workers would assume a role in helping direct these networks and would be protected by labor unions. Variations of this model helped revive the shattered economies of postwar Japan and West Germany. But in Eastern Europe's case, they raise the possibility of entrenching unqualified managers, similar to the risk presented by the management ownership model.

State-owned companies would be turned over to the population at large, either in the form of stock given to all or via an auction in which groups of citizens would compete to buy them. This strategy in many respects is the fairest, by giving people an equal economic opportunity. But it also presents the threat of instability and confusion. If companies are simply restructured into stock portfolios for each citizen, no new capital is created for the economy to grow.

The government would encourage the creation of small-scale private businesses by managers and employees of existing state-owned firms. This strategy would preserve the state's dominant economic role indefinitely but would create new sources of employment and production. The risk lies in the advantages that some state enterprises have in access to supplies, creating the possibility of profiteering and a polarization of classes into rich and poor. Variations of this strategy have been tried on a limited basis in China, but often have led to official corruption and a popular backlash against entrepreneurs who become relatively wealthy.

DOC.HEAD: Air France Pilots to Strike Feb. 17-18
DOC.TEXT: Air France's pilots union called on its members Monday to strike for 48 hours this weekend to protest deteriorating working conditions and a continuing loss in purchasing power, a union statement said. The statement came as a two-day strike by flight navigators and mechanics at France's three main airlines, Air France, Air Inter and UTA, was drawing to a close. Air France officials said they expect the pilots' strike Saturday and Sunday to disrupt service on the 300 long- and medium-haul flights the state-owned airline normally operates in that period.

DOC.HEAD: US-Soviet Trade Talks Open Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 new graf after 7th graf pvs, `Bush has ...,' to ADD sanctions imposed in 1947. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Top American and Soviet trade officials today launched wide-ranging negotiations aimed at normalizing trade between the two superpowers for the first time in nearly a half-century. Asked if the talks could be accomplished in time for President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to sign a new trade treaty at their summit in June, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said, ``We are a very efficient team.'' She and Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz led the American negotiating team, while the Soviet delegation was headed by Yuriy N. Chumakov, deputy minister of foreign economic relations. The agenda for just the first day of consultations listed 15 areas of discussions. The complexity of the negotiations was demonstrated by the fact that the U.S. delegation included 19 officials from six separate government agencies. Officials said the first round of discussions were scheduled to last through Tuesday, with more talks expected at the end of February, possibly in Moscow. U.S. officials are hoping to wrap up the negotiations in April, giving plenty of time for drafting the final document that will be signed by Bush and Gorbachev at the Washington summit in June. Bush has said he hopes that normalizing trade relations between the two nations will boost the Soviet economy and lend support to the political reforms being undertaken by Gorbachev. Then-President Truman imposed trade restrictions on the Soviet Union in 1947 after relations between the World War II allies deteriorated. Under a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement, U.S. consumers would see lower prices for such popular items as Soviet vodka, which by one estimate could drop in price by $1.25 a bottle, and for luxury items such as Russian furs. As part of a trade agreement, the United States would grant the Soviet Union ``most favored nation'' status, qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to other countries. Currently, the Soviets are blocked from that status because of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment, which penalized the Soviets for their ban against emigration by Soviet Jews and other dissidents. The Soviets have liberalized that policy since Gorbachev came to power, and Bush has said he will propose to Congress a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik tariffs once the Soviet parliament passes legislation that would put the liberalized policies into law. The lower tariffs cannot take effect, however, until there is a trade treaty between the two countries. One primary area of dispute in the trade talks is expected to be how the Jackson-Vanik tariffs will be lifted. The Bush administration would like a three-year trade agreement with annual presidential review and waiver of the high tariffs. The Soviets, however, would like to see the tariffs removed permanently to build confidence among business leaders that trade relations will remain stable in coming years. But such a position is not likely to find political favor in Congress. Micah Naftalin, national director of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said his organization supports the more limited one-year waivers. ``We should be giving them what they have earned, but we shouldn't go overboard,'' he said. ``The country is still extraordinarily unstable and we should take it step by step.'' The administration seeks to guarantee the protection of American-patented products from piracy, an arbitration method to settle business disputes and provisions allowing either country to impose temporary trade restrictions if a domestic industry suffers injury because of an unexpected surge of imports. Under a trade agreement between the two nations, the administration predicts that two-way trade, which last year totaled under $5 billion, could double or even triple within the next two or three years. But many experts said the administration was being over-optimistic in its projections of increased trade, given the troubles plaguing the Soviet economy. ``The reforms that have captured world attention so far have all been on the political and social level,'' said Richard Kaufman, an expert on Soviet affairs with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ``I am not all that optimistic about significant increases in trade flows until the Soviet economy is reformed.'' Robert Cullen, editor of Soviet-American Trade, a newsletter on the subject, said that even with a trade agreement, ``the fundamental barriers between the Soviet Union and America, such as not having a convertible ruble, are not going to be alleviated.'' American farm groups are watching the trade negotiations with keen interest. Three-fourths of U.S. export sales to the Soviet Union involve American farm products and the Soviets reportedly have stated that they will not approve a new grain sales agreement with the United States until they are granted lower tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Earnings Up 14 Percent in Quarter, 27 Percent for 1989
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro Inc. on Monday reported profit gains of 14 percent for the fourth quarter and 27 percent for the full year. The company also said it discontinued its Maxie line of fashion dolls, Hasbro's primary competition against Mattel Inc.'s Barbie, because the doll did not meet sales expectations. The toy manufacturer earned $24 million, or 40 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $21 million, or 36 cents a share a year earlier. Sales rose 5.6 percent to $417 million from $395 million. Income for the year ended Dec. 25 totaled $92.2 million, or $1.56 a share, compared with $72.4 million, or $1.24 a share, in 1988. Revenue for 1989 was up about 4 percent at $1.4 billion from 1988's $1.35 billion. A Hasbro executive said the the toymaker's annual results were not as good if a 1988 video game write-off were considered. ``But it's not as dramatic as it seems'' when tempered by 1988's charge for the Nemo video system that never came to market, said John T. O'Neill, executive vice president and chief financial officer. Deducting that from 1988 research and development costs would have improved earnings to about $80 million, in the range of $1.40 a share, he said. Hasbro, however, maintained its margins by holding costs down _ advertising increases, for instance, rose less than 1 percent. ``We managed very tightly in terms of operating costs and ... we succeeded in getting a lot more leverage on our fixed costs,'' O'Neill said. Alan G. Hassenfeld. chairman and chief executive, said there was balanced growth domestically and overseas, despite the strong dollar. Domestic growth came from the Milton Bradley and Playskool lines, Hassenfeld said. He said the addition of Cabbage Patch Kids from Coleco brought more balance to Hasbro's product lines. Spokesman Wayne Charness confirmed that Hasbro had discontinued Maxie. He said the decision was made about a month ago and that Hasbro was keying on its recently announced New Kids on the Block line as its latest fashion doll entry. ``Maxie was doing OK, but it really wasn't living up to the expectations we had for it,'' Charness said. He refused to provide figures. The Wall Street Journal said an analyst estimated Maxie sales last year were $20 million to $25 million, about the same as a year earlier, while Barbie sales were approximately $375 million.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Decides Monsanto Not Liable in Toxic Waste Suit
DOC.TEXT: Jurors unanimously agreed Monday that Monsanto Co. was not liable for alleged damages to residents whose homes were built near a toxic waste dump. The 222 homeowners were asking for $335 million from the chemical company, the chief user of the dump. Past and present residents of the subdivision in southeast Houston sued Monsanto after learning much of the toxic waste in the dump came from the chemical company. The plaintiffs claimed the Brio waste site has been the cause of medical problems ranging from upset stomachs to headaches. Some residents testified they fear they will contract cancer because they live so close to the dump. In addition, plaintiffs claimed their property values have dropped significantly. Monsanto denies responsibility for any injuries, saying it is one of many companies that have used the Brio site through the years. Monsanto has sued the developers and builders who constructed homes in the area, saying they should be responsible for any damages awarded by the jury. During closing arguments, Monsanto attorneys charged the suit is a ``conspiracy'' against the company on the part of builders and developers of the subdivision, who settled a lawsuit filed by the homeowners, then joined forces with them against Monsanto. The trial began in state District Judge Alice Trevathan's court in October. The Harris County jurors began deliberations Feb. 6.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Plummet
DOC.TEXT: Share prices plunged Monday on London's Stock Exchange as news circulated that the large Wall Street investment house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was looking for a major investor or a merger partner. Drexel said that unsettled markets, particularly the junk bond market, have adversely affected the liquidity of its parent company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group. Wall Street has been abuzz for months with rumors that the firm needed financial support to keep afloat amid lagging markets. ``We're very concerned about the Drexel statement,'' said one head of market making at a London firm. ``We're waiting for a clarification to see what it means and how bad it is.'' At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 26.7 points, or 1.15 percent, at 2,286.9. It was down from a session high of 2,313.3 points and slightly above a low for the day of 2,282.4. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 20.1 points at 1,810.6 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 11.92 points to close at 1,248.64. Volume came to a modest 337.4 million shares, compared with 521.7 million shares Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Delegation Meeting With U.S. Business People
DOC.TEXT: A delegation led by the head of the Soviet economic reform program is meeting with business executives and government officials this week to study U.S. business methods. The two-week, coast-to-coast study is the result of an agreement between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev at their recent Malta summit. The seven-member delegation is headed by Valentin Vologzhin, chairman of the Supreme Soviet's Committee on Economic Reform. It is responsible for development an economic reform package for the Soviet Union. Its schedule here includes meetings with officials of the Commerce Department and the Small Business Administration and with members of Congress. The delegation will be in Chicago Feb. 14-17, San Francisco Feb. 17-20, Los Angeles Feb. 20-21, and New York Feb. 22-23.

The stock market turned downward today, backing off after last week's advance. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 45.50 points last week, dropped 16.89 to 2,631.31 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 465 up, 1,018 down and 450 unchanged. Activity was curtailed, as expected, by a national holiday in Japan and the absence of some U.S. investors observing the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. Analysts said traders had been encouraged by the results of the Treasury's auction of notes and bonds last week, which generally went off better than had been expected. That provided some relief from recent worries over rising interest rates. But many market participants remained edgy over the outlook for rates in other leading industrialized countries. For several weeks now Wall Streeters have been worrying that rising rates overseas would push U.S. rates higher as well, increasing the chances of a recession. ASA Ltd. dropped 4{ to 64]. DOC.HEAD: First Trial Begins in Guinness Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The first trial began Monday in the ``Guinness Affair'' stock manipulation case, the unprecedented white-collar scandal that rocked British business after the multibillion-dollar takeover of Distillers Co. by brewing giant Guinness PLC. Eight men, including Guinness' former chairman Ernest Saunders, have been accused of involvement in a scheme to purchase Guinness shares during the 1986 takeover fight for Distillers, a Scotch whisky and gin maker, in an attempt to boost Guinness' stock price. The defendants allegedly aimed to make Guinness' $4.3 billion cash and stock bid more attractive than a rival offer from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC. Guinness succeeded in April 1986 in what was Britain's largest takeover ever. But in December of that year, the Department of Trade and Industry announced it was investigating the deal and the alleged financial wrongdoing started coming to light. The defendants in the first trial, which is expected to last up to six months, are Saunders, 54; Gerald Ronson, the 50-year-old chairman of the diversified conglomerate Heron International PLC; former stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44; and millionaire financier and arts patron Sir Jack Lyons, 74. They face a total of 35 charges on such counts as stock manipulation, theft, false accounting and destruction of documents. The four men briefly exchanged words as they took their places on swivel chairs behind moveable desks in Southwark Crown Court. A jury of seven men and five women is to hear the case. The trial judge, Sir Denis Henry, adjourned the case until Tuesday to give the jurors time to put their affairs in order. The judge ruled last September that because of its complexity, the case should be split into two consecutive trials. In the second trial, not scheduled to begin before October, Saunders will be joined by Roger Seelig, 44, former Morgan Grenfell and Co. Ltd. corporate finance director; Lord Patrick Spens, 47, former director of corporate finance at the merchant bank Henry Ansbacher and Co. Ltd.; and David Mayhew, 48, who continues as senior corporate finance partner of the investment firm Cazenove and Co. The seven men have pleaded innocent to the charges and each is free on $850,000 bail. The eighth man charged is Thomas Ward, an American attorney who also has denied wrongdoing. British police are seeking Ward's extradition from the United States. Saunders _ who maintains that he is a scapegoat _ appears as a broken public figure, openly bitter about trial delays, the extensive legal fees which have forced him to obtain legal aid, and the scandal's devastating effect on his family. He spent a night in jail when he was arrested in May 1987. In an unusual step, the judge decided the defendants in the first trial would not be required to appear in court every day. He told them to apply to him for permission to be absent on days when there was no likelihood of evidence concerning them being called.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Comments Send Tremors Through Business World
By BARRY RENFREW
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's declaration of support Monday for nationalization of gold mines and other key assets sent shockwaves through South Africa's business world. Mandela's statement on his first full day of freedom sent gold shares down 4 percent on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. The financial rand, a special currency used to encourage foreign investment, plummeted 10 percent. The reaction apparently did not extend overseas. Gold prices rose in Europe and the United States. Mandela told a news conference he fully supports the economic plan of his African National Congress for a state-run economy, including nationalization of mines and other major pillars of the economy. ``The nationalization of mines is a fundamental policy of the ANC,'' Mandela said. ``I believe the ANC is quite correct in this attitude.'' Businesses also were unnerved by Mandela's statements that he supports armed struggle to end white-minority rule and destroy the apartheid system. Mandela also stressed his desire for peace and said whites had nothing to fear from blacks under a true democratic system. The remarks punctured optimism in the business community that had been generated by President F.W. de Klerk's announcement Feb. 2 of reforms to pave the way for talks with blacks on peacefully ending white minority rule. The stock market and other economic indicators rose after de Klerk's speech. Mandela's pronouncements were causing ``jitters and uncertainty,'' said an economist at a major bank, who requested anonymity. The black leader's stance will ``definitely have a negative effect on foreign perceptions of investment in South Africa, on local business confidence and on private fixed investment,'' the economist said. Whites control the economy and white business and political leaders say any future power-sharing deal with blacks must rest on a free enterprise system. The white business community fears nationalization will cripple the economy. Business leaders still hope de Klerk's reforms and concessions will convince Western countries to abandon or ease the sanctions imposed on South Africa in recent years as a protest against apartheid. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a longtime opponent of sanctions, dropped academic and cultural embargoes when de Klerk legalized the ANC earlier this month, and she now wants to end a ban on new investment. U.S. President George Bush has said his government will review existing sanctions against South Africa, but a final decision would require congressional approval.
Stock prices slumped today, giving up some of last week's gains. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 20.95 at 2,627.25.

The stock market posted a broad loss today, backing off after last week's advance. Activity was curtailed, as expected, by a national holiday in Japan and the absence of some U.S. investors observing the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. Analysts said traders had been encouraged by the results of the Treasury's auction of notes and bonds last week, which generally went off better than had been expected. That provided some relief from recent worries over rising interest rates. But many market participants remained edgy over the outlook for rates in other leading industrialized countries. For several weeks now Wall Streeters have been worrying that rising rates overseas would push U.S. rates higher as well, increasing the chances of a recession.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain On USDA Report, Soviet Trade Prospects
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, bolstered by perceptions of shrinking supplies and prospects for new grain sales to the Soviet Union. In a monthly report released after the close of trading Friday, the USDA projected the nation's corn stockpile at 1.48 billion bushels by Aug. 31, the end of the 1989-90 marketing year. That compares with the January estimate of 1.61 billion bushels and last year's ending stocks of 1.93 billion. The USDA pegged U.S. wheat stocks at 443 million bushels by May 31, the end of the wheat marketing year, compared with a January estimate of 468 million bushels and last year's ending stocks of 698 million. Both estimates were below trade expectations. The Aug. 31 soybean projection of 335 million bushels, unchanged from January, was near expectations. Traders also were attuned to the opening Monday in Washington of U.S.-Soviet trade talks, which could lead to the United States granting the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trade status, allowing freer trade between the superpowers. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.88} a bushel; corn futures were 2\ cents to 3{ cents higher with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were } cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $1.38} a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 5{ cents higher with March at $5.67{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Report: UAL Unions Eye Chief Executive Candidate
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines' labor unions, who are seeking employee ownership of parent UAL Corp., have approached at least one candidate to replace UAL Chairman Stephen M. Wolf, according to a report published Monday. The Chicago Sun-Times reported that Richard Ravitch, former chairman of Bowery Savings Bank of New York and onetime head of New York's transit authority, said he had held ``very preliminary discussions'' with union representatives. Ravitch also said he had the impression the union group was talking with others about taking Wolf's job, according to the newspaper$. Attempts by The Associated Press to contact Ravitch were not immediately successful. A receptionist at his New York office said Ravitch was out of town, but would not reveal his whereabouts. There has been no indication that Wolf would resign from Chicago-based UAL, which he has headed since December 1987, as part of any employee buyout deal between the unions and the company's board of directors. But the union group, representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants, is believed to be hoping to dump Wolf and Chief Financial Officer Jack Pope and recruit a new management team before approaching banks for loans to finance a buyout. Union and UAL board representatives have been negotiating the terms of a formal buyout bid and are expected to report on their progress at a Feb. 22 board meeting. Neither a UAL spokesman nor spokesmen for the three unions would comment on the Sun-Times report. A source within the union group, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the management issue has not been decided. But, he said, ``I think it's probably fair to say that everyone wouldn't mind looking elsewhere.'' Wolf's role in an employee-owned UAL was not covered in a buyout proposal outlined by the unions last month, nor was the price of the 75 percent stake that the workers want to buy. Some airline analysts believe dumping Wolf would be a mistake, despite his history of fractious relations with the unions. They say Wolf's experience in turning around the financial fortunes of the former Republic Airlines and Flying Tiger air-freight carrier before coming to UAL make him a good leader for United, which has fallen behind American Airlines in ridership in recent years after long leading the industry. Analyst Louis Marckesano of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia said the subject of dumping Wolf came up at a recent meeting of airline analysts, most of whom ``thought it would be big dumb thing the unions may be trying to do.'' UAL's stock lost $4 to close at $132.50 Monday in New York Stock Exchange Trading.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher; Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended narrowly higher Monday against most key currencies in quiet, uneventful trading. Gold prices rose here after a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $419.20 a troy ounce, up $3.10 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $418.70 an ounce, up $2.95. Currency dealers said the dollar continued to gain ground at the expense of the West German mark. Gold rose in London to $419.50 an ounce from $415.75 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $419 an ounce from $416 Friday. But earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 92 cents to close at $414.41 an ounce. DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Announces $317 Million Loss Due to Warner Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. announced Monday it lost $317 million in the fourth quarter and $987 million for all of 1989 because of costs related to its $14 billion acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. Despite the loss, which was expected, securities analysts said they were satisfied with the results because Time Warner's cash flow _ which is crucial for paying off its $10.6 billion in debt _ was strong. Time Warner, formerly Time Inc., completed its acquisition of Warner Communications on Jan. 10 after having acquired more than half of Warner's shares in a tender offer last July. The results announced Monday were reported as though Time had acquired Warner on Jan. 1, 1988, and therefore included results from all of Warner's divisions. Time Warner's fourth-quarter loss amounted to $5.52 per share and compared with a loss of $320 million, or $5.61 a share, in the same period of 1988. However, Time Warner's operating income, which does not reflect interest, taxes, costs associated with the Warner acquisition and other expenses, totaled $412 million, up from $351 million a year earlier. The company's fourth-quarter combined revenue rose to $3.09 billion from $2.5 billion a year earlier. Time Warner said its quarterly results reflected a $175 million loss before taxes on the sale of its Scott, Foresman and Co. book publisher. They also included a $63 million gain before taxes on the sale of Time Warner's stock in Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. The company said all its divisions performed well during the quarter. Time-Warner's magazine division, which includes Time, Sports Illustrated and People magazines, had operating income of $108 million in the fourth quarter, up 13 percent from 1988. Advertising revenue was up 8.7 percent while circulation revenue increased 4.7 percent. Time Warner said its magazine revenue more than offset start-up costs for its Entertainment Weekly, which it launched Monday. The company's filmed entertainment division, which includes Warner Brothers Studios, had operating income of $80 million, compared with a loss of $20 million in fourth quarter 1988. Time Warner said it continued to profit from the success of the motion picture ``Batman,'' which was in videocassette release domestically and theatrical distribution overseas during the quarter. The company's recorded music and publishing division, which includes Warner Records, had operating income of $141 million, up 11 percent from a year earlier. Operating income at the company's cable television division was up 58 percent to $180 million. Time Warner said the results partly reflected the addition of a Florida cable system acquired from Centel Corp. Time Warner's programming division, which includes Home Box Office and Cinemax, had operating income of $37 million, compared with a loss of $1 million a year earlier. The company's book division had a loss of $134 million, reflecting the Scott Foresman sale, compared with operating income of $35 million in fourth-quarter 1988. John Reidy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said Time Warner had a ``solid quarter.'' Judging by the performance of the company's various divisions, cash flow for 1989 was in line with expectations, he said. Analysts are more concerned with Time Warner's ability to pay its debts and shrugged off the company's losses. ``They're meaningless,'' said Pavlos Alexandrakis at Argus Research Corp. Alexandrakis also said Time Warner's cash flow would be enough to service its debt load. For the year, Time Warner said it lost $987 million, or $17.29 per share, compared with a loss of $1.14 billion, or $19.84 a share, in 1988. Full-year revenue totaled $10.78 billion, up from $9.1 billion. The results for all of 1989 also include the costs of the Warner acquisition. Operating income for the year totaled $1.92 billion, up from $1.33 billion in 1988.
