DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Reported to Say United Germany Cannot be Part of NATO
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told East German leaders a reunited Germany cannot belong to the NATO alliance, the state news agency ADN said Monday. The Soviet leader's stand disagrees with the United States and Western European nations, who oppose a neutral Germany with no ties to the Western military alliance. East Germany rejected a West German proposal Wednesday for quick adoption of a common currency, but approved the principle of a monetary union. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, trying to hasten reunification, has said a single currency should be adopted soon to help resolve East Germany's severe economic problems. East German leaders asked West Germany on Monday for financial aid of up to $9 billion, but the West Germans said no. Finance Minister Theo Waigel said there was ``no sense'' in financing a ``system that has still not decided to make fundamental changes and has not shown it is capable of doing so.'' About 70,000 East Germans turned out Monday evening for the weekly pro-democracy rally in Leipzig. Dozens carried West German flags and one banner read: ``If the West German mark comes, we'll stay. If the West German mark doesn't show up, we'll go to join it.'' ADN, the official East German news agency, said two young people were slightly injured in scuffles with about 75 to 100 right-wing radicals who showed up in Leipzig. About 80,000 people held a rally in Karl-Marx-Stadt and chants of ``Germany, one fatherland!'' rang through the city. Last year, 340,000 East Germans moved to prosperous, capitalist West Germany. They now stream West at the rate of 1,800 a day, making the economic chaos in East Germany even worse. The exodus helped bring down the old hard-line Communist government, beginning in October, and now encourages a growing reunification movement. What remains of the Communist Party in East Germany has tried to slow the process. On Tuesday, Kohl and Hans Modrow, East Germany's Communist premier, are to meet in Bonn. Foreign ministers of the European Community said in Brussels that Kohl would make Modrow an official offer of monetary union. They said Waigel mentioned the plan at a meeting of EC ministers Monday. No details were released. Kohl said he got the ``green light'' for unification from Gorbachev during a weekend visit to Moscow, but the official East German agency ADN reported Monday the Soviet leader insisted a united Germany stay out of NATO. The chancellor has said repeatedly that West Germany is firmly in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and has rejected neutrality for a single Germany. ADN said Gorbachev told Modrow by telephone he had ``clearly told'' Kohl a ``united Germany staying within the structure of NATO cannot be accepted.'' Gorbachev said the ``question of military structures and questions of political status can only be solved in a gradual transition,'' the agency reported. Its dispatch gave no details on Gorbachev's position about the Western military alliance, but said he acknowledged German unity could come ``more quickly than previously thought.'' ADN indicated Gorbachev initiated the conversation with Modrow. In Washington, President Bush said: ``We support Chancellor Kohl's position that a unified Germany should remain a member of NATO. Let me also express my appreciation of Chairman Gorbachev's statesmanlike view that decisions regarding German unity should be left to the people of Germany.'' Kohl has denied West Germany wants to ``annex'' the East, but comments from East Berlin indicate growing resentment to pressure from Bonn. At the weekly talks Monday between the government and other organizations, a set of guidelines was approved for Modrow's meeting with Kohl. Most important was rejection of speedy action toward the single currency Kohl says is necessary to bolster the East German economy. The panel added, however, that monetary union eventually could be an ``important measure for the creation of a German economic system.'' Sixteen political parties and other groups are represented in the weekly ``round table'' discussions, which are part of the interim administration guiding East Germany to free elections March 18. On Monday, panel members warned against ``artificial overheating of the German process.'' The guidelines said reunification ``cannot endanger European integration.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Gives Eastern Eight-Day Extension on Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Monday gave Eastern Airlines another eight days to file its proposed plan of reorganization, after several parties in the proceeding said progress has been made toward agreement on a plan. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland granted Eastern's request for the extension, to Feb. 20, of the deadline for filing its bankruptcy reorganization plan. During that time, other parties such as creditors cannot submit competing proposals. Miami-based Eastern has been restructuring under bankruptcy court supervision since a grueling strike began last March 4. The airline asked the court last week for a 30-day extension but reduced its request before Monday's hearing, indicating that Eastern and its major creditors may have moved toward compromise on a plan. David I. Shapiro, the court-appointed examiner overseeing Eastern's Chapter 11 proceeding, supported the request and told Lifland that ``substantial progress'' is being made in negotiations between the airline and its creditors. Shapiro said last week he would fight liquidation of Eastern, as rumors circulated that Texas Air Corp., Eastern's owner, would opt for a Chapter 7 liquidation. The committee representing unsecured creditors also supported Eastern's petition. Representatives of preferred shareholders, who recently advocated liquidation or outright sale, supported the airline's request for more time, however. In papers filed earlier in bankruptcy court, a committee representing tthe preferred holders said it had lost faith in Eastern's management because it was ``cannibalizing'' the airline by selling vital assets. The preferred shareholders criticized Eastern's latest reorganization proposal, recently diclosed publicly, which proposes to pay them no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new stock. ``We are examining all of our various options; we're hopeful we can come up with a solution,'' Robert Miller, an attorney for the preferred shareholders' committee, said after the hearing. The new plan also calls for paying unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and 70 percent more over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Texas Air would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Eastern's equity. Lawyers representing the Air Line Pilots Association and the Machinists union opposed Eastern's request. The pilots and flight attendants abandoned their sympathy strikes just before Thanksgiving, but Eastern had since rebuilt as a smaller carrier and hired mostly non-union workers to replace the strikers. The Machinists union remains on strike against the carrier. Monday's extension was the fourth granted by Lifland to Eastern since the bankruptcy proceeding began last March 9.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ambassador Says Political Changes Helping Economic Recovery
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Ambassador Yuriy V. Dubinin said Monday that the recent historic meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee has given ``a powerful political impetus'' to the Soviet Union's plans for economic restructuring. Dubinin, speaking to a business audience about joint ventures in the USSR, said the committee's agreement last week to accept a multiparty system and adopt a new platform of reforms would help accelerate the country's economic recovery and expand trade with the West. The Soviet Union's economic agenda includes taking emergency steps to rebuild the economy and laying a foundation for economic development, Dubinin said. It also includes creating a legal system with laws on property, employment and taxes; decentralizing the economies of republics within the country; making the currency convertible; and reducing foreign debt, he said. However, Dubinin said, the ``natural mutual attraction'' between the U.S. and Soviet business communities could be destroyed by ``the cold war or severe restrictions.'' ``Shall we postpone our business interaction until better times?'' Dubinin asked. ``I believe the answer lies in the fact that...we are already experiencing an explosion of interest on the part of American businesses toward establishing ties with Soviet business.'' Dubinin underscored the need for a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement that would relax trade barriers between the two countries and help remove obstacles to granting the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trade status, a move that could ease the economic troubles under which the Soviets are living. Top U.S. and Soviet trade officials on Monday began negotiations in Washington aimed at reaching a new trade treaty by the time of the June summit between Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and President George Bush. Dubinin said more than 1,000 joint ventures have been registered between Soviet and Western companies in the last year. And more than a dozen more joint venture agreements will be signed with major American companies in the next few months. However, only about a fifth of those registered have become reality due to the structural and economic problems in the Soviet Union. ``We are trying to solve those problems,'' Dubinin said. The ambassador said the so-called ``economic conversion,'' or the converting of Soviet military plants into facilities for manufacturing consumer goods, is helping lessen the political tension between the Soviet Union and the West while helping in the recovery. ``Conversion serves to accelerate economic development and...opens new horizons,'' Dubinin said. Dubinin said he returned on Sunday from Moscow, where he attended meetings of the Communist Party Central Committee and meetings with Secretary of State James A. Baker III that wound up Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Thrifts Falling Short of Financial Standards, Regulators Say
DOC.TEXT: Fewer savings and loans are falling short of tough new financial standards than originally feared, thrift regulators said Monday. Of 861 S&Ls originally thought to be short of capital, 147 have demonstrated they meet new standards that took effect Dec. 7, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. The claims of an additional 43 are being evaluated. Thrift office Director M. Danny Wall said the 18 percent improvement over earlier expectations ``doesn't come as a big surprise'' because industry data showed that thrifts were shrinking their operations in order to compy with the capital standards, imposed as part of the S&L bailout bill last August. S&Ls that fell short of the standards were required to submit recovery plans by Jan. 8. Regulators have from 50 to 80 days, depending on the circumstance, to approve or reject the plans. So far, they have rejected 53 and approved two.

DOC.HEAD: Ties Galore on Display at Annual Trade Show
With AM-Toy Fair, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The annual American International Toy Fair that opened Monday provides an opportunity for manufacturers to showcase their latest creations and classics. Here are brief sketches of some of the dolls, toys and games being introduced this year: _Dolls: My Pretty Ballerina is a battery-powered doll that dances. The doll, from Tyco Toys, performs on her toes and executes moves on one leg with the help of someone guiding her arm. New Kids on the Block dolls based on the five-member singing group from Hasbro Inc. are expected to be a rage with teeny-boppers. _Plush Toys: Peeper Pals is a line of stuffed animals that also function as night lights. When pressed on their bellies, the battery-powered pals from Lewis Galoob Toys Inc. open their eyes, which light up. Zoo Tunes are high-tech hand puppets made by Worlds of Wonder Inc. Three animals _ a lion, hippo and alligator _ sing children's songs. The pupeteer controls the tempo by opening and closing the puppet's mouth. Guard dogs from Nasta Industries are electronically activated dogs that bark but look like soft, cuddly stuffed animals. They have special pouches to stash valuables. If someone tries to unlock the combination or pick up the dog, it barks. _Games:

Gorbachev, named for the Soviet leader, is a family game in which players must acquire Western-style consumer and luxury goods. Special Gorbachev cards help players cut through red tape in their buying binge as they advance around a board. The player with the most goods at the end wins. It is made by the Milton Bradley division of Hasbro Inc. Taboo is another family game from Milton Bradley. Players must guess words via one-word clues from their teammates but five obvious clues cannot be used. For instance, the clues ``space,'' ``shuttle,'' ``moon,'' ``John Glenn'' or ``NASA'' can't be given for the word ``astronaut.'' Motor Mouth, from Tiger Electronics Inc., is a family game co-designed by John Moschitta, known for his fast-talking deliveries in radio and television commercials. The object of the game is to successfully move around a board by correctly reading a series of tongue twisters. Two samples: In Huron, a hewer, Hugh Hughs, hewed yews of unusual hues; Classy Karla clumsily crammed clunky clams into cluttered clothes closets clammering clearly and clicking castenets.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices rose in moderate trading Monday, helped mainly by technical factors and protective buying by investors. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 29 cents to $22.03 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract posted a net loss of $1.28 last week. The April crude contract climbed 28 cents to $21.84 and May added 26 cents to $21.66 a barrel. Among refined products, March wholesale unleaded gasoline, which fell 1.61 cents on Friday, rose 0.84 cent to 60.40 cents a gallon. April gained 1.16 cents to 61.41 cents and May ended up 0.59 at 64.84 cents a gallon. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery, which had lost ground in recent sessions pressured by warm weather in the Northeast, finished at 55.95 cents a gallon, up 0.87 cent. The April contract rose 0.65 cent to 55.27 cents and May added 0.55 cent to 54.61 cents. Analysts said there was little news to move the petroleum markets. ``There was more movement than news,'' said Peter Beutel, energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc. ``It seemed to have been short covering that boosted prices.'' Prices had been under pressure recently from industry and government reports that showed an increase in crude and product supplies in the nation's storage tanks. Analysts also attributed the recent weakness in crude prices to an announcement by a few big refiners last week that they would be doing annual maintenance turnarounds in March and April. The maintenance requires refiners to slow operations, which suggests they would be using less crude oil.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Posts Quarterly Loss Due to Charge
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. said Monday that it lost $25.7 million in 1989's fourth quarter due to a $97.8 million charge to cover the cost of discontinuing two health care divisions. But the beauty products company said it had a profit of $54.6 million, or 34 cents a share, for all of last year. That was an improvement from 1988's deficit of $404.5 million, or $6.79 a share, which had been caused by $545.6 million in losses from discontinued operations. The loss for the three months ended Dec. 31, which came to 61 cents a share, compared with a profit of $56.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in the final 1988 quarter. Sales in the latest quarter amounted to $1.03 billion, up 2 percent from $1.01 billion in the corresponding 1988 quarter. For all of last year, sales rose 8 percent to $3.3 billion from 1988's $3.1 billion. The non-cash charge taken in the fourth quarter was for two Mediplex health care divisions and reflects the divisions' realizable value, the company said in a news release. Avon, which has been divesting its holdings in the health care field to focus on its core direct selling business, said it has reached an agreement to sell all the shares of Mediplex Group Inc. for $100 million in cash and notes convertible to cash. The buyer, Diamond Healthcare Acquisition Corp., will assume Mediplex's leases, mortgages and liabilities. With the sale, Avon will have divested all of its health care operations. Proceeds will be used to reduce debt. Avon said earnings from continuing operations were up 27 percent in the fourth quarter and 26 percent in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: GM Unit Agrees to Buy RFC for $62 Million
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s home mortgage subsidiary has agreed to buy Residential Funding Corp., a Minneapolis-based mortgage services company, for $62 million, the companies said Monday. RFC has a portfolio of nearly $8 billion, said Thomas Hernly, spokesman for RFC's parent company, Anchor Savings Bank in New York. RFC purchases residential loans from the institutions that originate them and resells them in the form of securities to investors such as banks and insurance companies. The purchase by GMAC Mortgage Corp., a subsidiary of General Motors Acceptance Corp., the automaker's financing arm, is expected to be completed by the end of March. GMAC Mortgage Corp., based in the Philadelphia suburb of Elkins Park, Pa., has more than 70 home mortgage offices and a portfolio of nearly $30 billion in loans, representing nearly 400,000 customers.

DOC.HEAD: Inglis Shareholders Approve Purchase by Whirlpool
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders of Canadian appliance-maker Inglis Ltd. approved the company's purchase by Whirlpool Corp. for $28.38 a share, or about $42 million, Whirlpool said Monday. Inglis, affiliated with Whirlpool for more than 40 years, becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of the U.S. appliance manufacturer. ``The amalgamation will strengthen the operations of both companies by integration into a North American Appliance Group,'' said William Marohn, Whirlpool executive vice president. Inglis Chairman Arthur Mingay said the Canadian company would benefit from Whirlpool's technological and administrative resources and buying power. Inglis, headquartered in Mississauga, Ontario, will continue making Inglis, Whirlpool, Admiral, Speed Queen and KitchenAid brand appliances at its plants in Port Credit, Cambridge and Montmagny, serving the Canadian marketplace. Inglis reported 1989 earnings of $9.3 million on sales of $349 million. Whirlpool reported that its profits for the first nine months of 1989 rose 14.5 percent to $137.8 million on sales of $4.72 billion.

DOC.HEAD: High Priced Stock Loses $730 A Share
DOC.TEXT: The bigger they are, the harder they fall. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Wall Street's priciest stock, tumbled $730 a share Monday in a sell-off that brokers blamed on negative publicity in a Barron's magazine story. The stock's preeminence remained untouched, however. Even with the drop, Berkshire Hathaway was still trading at $7,220 a share, keeping it in a class by itself on the New York Stock Exchange. Barron's said the company, a hodgepodge of insurance and investment concerns controlled by legendary multibillionaire Warren Buffett, has become extremely overvalued since Buffett switched trading in the stock from the over-the-counter market to the NYSE in 1988. J. Verne McKenzie, Berkshire Hathaway's chief financial officer and spokesman for Omaha-based company, said ``no comment'' when asked about the Barron's report and the stock slide. A total of 1,450 shares traded hands in the sell-off. The shares have been on the decline since peaking at $8,900 late last year. Barron's suggested that Buffett's investment miscalculations were largely responsible. The magazine said some of Buffet's recent investments have not been made based on his celebrated adherence to buying into companies with sound balance sheets and strong management. Berkshire Hathaway's genesis was a struggling textile mill that Buffett acquired 25 years ago, then trading at $12 a share. Over the years, Buffett expanded and strengthened the company into a conglomerate with stakes in enterprises ranging from insurance giant Geico Corp. to the Washington Post Co.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Has Problems in Washington Area
DOC.TEXT: MCI, a long-distance telephone carrier, had dialing problems Monday afternoon but said the trouble was confined to callers in the Washington area. ``Customers were experiencing a slow dial tone,'' said MCI spokesman David Thompson. ``Based on the information we have, it looks like a hardware problem.'' A slow dial tone, he said, meant the customer experienced a lag between the time the number was dialed and the time the destination telephone began ringing. The nation's major long-distance carrier, AT&T, suffered a major failure Jan. 15 when it was unable to connect long-distance calls because of a computer problem in New York. Thompson characterized MCI's problem as ``very localized, minor ... nothing major at all.'' There also was some trouble with calls coming into the Washington area, he said. The company's electronic mail and toll-free 800 service were not affected, Thompson said. The problem occurred about 4 p.m. EST when the volume of business calls was tapering off, Thompson said, adding that most service had been restored by 5:30 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Infiniti Ads: The Cars are Showing In Some Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Auto Dealers Bjt listed on AM-Business News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Corp. said Monday it would begin airing regional television ads for its Infiniti luxury cars featuring the vehicles in their entirety, instead of simply showing scenes of rocks, birds and pussy willows. The ads, the second stage of the company's unusual advertising campaign for the cars, will air in less than 45 television markets, where Infiniti has dealerships, company officials said. Nissan drew some automotive ad industry barbs when its Infiniti ad campaign began last year with ads that featured such scenes as countrysides or fields, but did not show the car. The new ads will be broadcast on network affiliates in Infiniti markets during local news and prime time shows for the next 3{ months. Nissan is broadcasting the new ads regionally because each of the spots will carry the area dealer's name, said Nissan spokesman Bob Thomas. The original ads, carried on television, newspaper and in magazines, were intended to create name recognition for the new auto line. ``If you had to do advertising to get a name established, we did that in spades,'' said Thomas Mignanelli, executive vice president of the company's U.S. sales arm. Mignanelli also said Monday the company was offering too many cars in the United States, and indicated it may cut the size of its sports car lineup. ``We probably ought to have one or two (car lines) less,'' he said. ``We've got all the bases covered. You have to say how many sports cars do you need?'' Within the last year, Nissan has introduced its 240SX and 300ZX and the new Pulsar NX sports cars. Nissan is setting up a new organization in southern California designed to streamline its product development process in North America, he said. The organization, called Nissan North America, will coordinate operations of the eight other companies Nissan runs in the United States. ``It's a transfer of the planning and review process to the United States,'' Mignanelli said. During the last year, Nissan broke ground for a huge research and development center northwest of Detroit to bring research for future U.S. products closer to the company's plant in Smyrna, Tenn., and to the market where the cars will be sold. ``It provides us with a lot more say in our company,'' said Mignanelli. ``We can do a project from the seed to the tree in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Platinum Futures Soar On Mandela Remarks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `West Texas ...,' to CORRECT decimal points in crude oil prices.
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices jumped Monday after Nelson Mandela endorsed anti-apartheid violence and nationalization of South Africa's mining industry, sending a shudder of supply fear through the precious metals markets. On other commodity markets, oil futures fell; coffee futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Platinum futures settled $9.80 to $10.10 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the contract for delivery in April up $9.80 at $523.90 a troy ounce. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold finished $3 to $3.20 higher with February at $419.20 a troy ounce; silver was 2.8 cents to 3.2 cents higher with March at $5.305 a troy ounce. South Africa is the world's largest producer of both platinum and gold. It dominates in platinum, accounting for an estimated 2.6 million, or nearly 80 percent, of the estimated 3.3 million ounces produced last year, according to British refiner Johnson Matthey PLC. Mandela, the African National Congress leader who was freed Sunday after 27 years in South African prison, said in a speech that ANC bombings and sabotage were defensive acts against apartheid and that the party's call for nationalization of mineral and diamond minds was ``quite correct.'' Those statements, along with reports of 30 deaths in scattered South African violence since Sunday morning, smashed perceptions that Mandela's release signified easing racial and political tensions. ``Anything that causes uncertainty, anything that even hints at the possibility of less reliability as far as source of supply is concerned, is bullish for the platinum market,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst at PaineWebber Inc. Mine sabotage poses obvious production problems while the ANC's call for mine nationalization ``leaves open the possibility that the flow of supply will diminish because of the inefficiencies of government-owned mining operations as opposed to those controlled by free enterprise,'' Savaiko said. Oil futures rallied late in an otherwise lackluster session on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Ray Mazzeo, energy futures specialist with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the rally was inspired by technical market factors and did not appear to have much staying power. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 12 cents to 29 cents higher with March at $22.03 a barrel; heating oil was .51 cent to .87 cent higher with March at 55.95 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .84 cent to 1.5 cents higher with March at 60.4 cents a gallon. The threat of a Brazilian port strike pushed coffee futures to new five-month highs on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange. Leaders of the dockworkers union voted Saturday to recommend that their members strike, beginning this Saturday, if their wage demands are not met by Thursday. Coffee futures settled 1.21 cents to 2 cents higher with March at 86.27 cents a pound. Most grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade, bolstered by perceptions of shrinking supplies and hopes for new grain sales to the Soviet Union. Wheat futures settled \ cent lower to 3\ cents higher with March at $3.90 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 3{ cents higher with March at $2.42 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2} cents higher with March at $1.39{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with March at $5.65\ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures for near-term delivery were supported by forecasts for cold, snowy weather in the Great Plains, which could delay marketings. Similar concerns prompted buying of pork futures amid predictions the same storm is headed for the Midwest. Live cattle ended .05 cent lower to .47 cent higher with February at 79.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 81.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .22 cent lower to .58 cent higher with February at 49.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 49.55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: British Telecom Sells 25 Percent Stake in MTV Europe
DOC.TEXT: British Telecommunications PLC said Monday it sold its 25 percent stake in MTV Europe to MTV Networks, a division of the U.S. entertainment company Viacom International Inc. MTV Europe is a 24-hour music and entertainment channel which is headquartered in London. It now reaches more than 1.1 million subscribers in 17 European countries. The sale price was not disclosed. British Telecom, Britain's major telephone company, said it decided to sell its MTV holding as part of its strategy to concentrate on worldwide telecommunications. The purchase raises MTV Networks' stake in MTV Europe to 50 percent, with the other half held by British media magnate Robert Maxwell's Maxwell Entertainment Group.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Calls Georgia-Pacific, Three Executives Liars
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. asked a federal judge Monday to block Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s $3.8 billion hostile bid for the rival paper company, charging that Georgia-Pacific lied about plans to sell Great Northern assets. Meanwhile, Georgia-Pacific announced the sales of its own assets in three states to avoid antitrust problems that could develop if it succeeds with its $63 a share offer. In federal court in Portland, Great Northern attorney Bernard Nussbaum asked U.S. District Judge Gene Carter for a preliminary injunction halting the takeover attempt as well as Georgia-Pacific's efforts to oust Great Northern's board at a special shareholders meeting March 2. Great Northern accused Georgia-Pacific of violating federal securities laws by trying to cover up plans to sell Great Northern assets, including two mills and 2.1 million acres of woodlands in Maine, if its completes its planned takeover. ``G.P. is lying. They're not telling you their true plans,'' Nussbaum told Carter. Nussbaum said handwritten notes and typed memos from consultants, bankers and Georgia-Pacific itself demonstrated that the Atlanta-based paper giant has planned since at least 1984 to sell the assets. Georgia-Pacific attorney Stuart J. Baskin in turn accused Great Northern of ``pandering to the poor people in Maine'' through an unfair motion that has no basis in law. Baskin said Georgia-Pacific has produced depositions and affidavits from 14 people, including Georgia-Pacific executives, consultants and bankers, who dispute Great Northern's contentions about a planned asset sale. The judge said he would rule on Great Northern's request as quickly as possible. After Monday's hearing, lawyers for both sides met with Carter and agreed to unseal a motion for a preliminary injunction filed last month by Georgia-Pacific, which alleged Great Northern's directors breached their fiduciary duty by resisting the offer. Great Northern has rejected Georgia-Pacific's bid as inadequate. However, Georgia-Pacific contends, Great Northern's investment banker, Goldman Sachs & Co., conducted a study last spring that put the value of Great Northern's stock at somewhere between $46.39 per share and $68.75 per share. The motion asked the judge to force Great Northern to forgo its ``poison pill'' takeover defense and to strike down ``golden parachute'' payments to Great Northern's executives if they lose their jobs in the battle. Georgia-Pacific also asked the judge to force Great Northern's directors to refrain from using Maine's anti-takeover law to block the merger. Great Northern issued a statement saying the Goldman Sachs study was ``stale'' and ``originally prepared for a different purpose than evaluating a bid for the company.'' Also Monday, Great Northern filed papers saying it wanted to pursue a speedy appeal of an order last week from Carter, who ruled it would take a two-thirds vote by Great Northern's shareholders to oust the Great Northern board. Great Northern's bylaws called for a three-fourths vote, but the judge agreed with Georgia-Pacific that two-thirds was the most allowed under Maine corporate law. Georgia-Pacific said Monday it had agreed to sell safety-paper operations in Vermont, Iowa and New York to remove an antitrust question in the takeover attempt. The company said it was selling facilities in Gilman, Vt., and Burlington, Iowa, to Seattle-based Simpson Paper Co. The deal also calls for the sale of two wet process machines and a precision sheeter in Warwick, N.Y. The Gilman plant employs about 200 people making safety paper, which is used in personal checks, securities certificates and other documents that need to be protected against forgery. The Burlington plant employs about 20 workers.

DOC.HEAD: Neiman Marcus Sues Federated for Taking Chairman
With AM-Federated-Allied
Ed: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `Neiman Marcus ...,' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY who defendants are; DELETES 6th graf pvs, `Also named ...,' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The new chairman of the Federated and Allied retail chains became the subject of a lawsuit Monday when his former employer, Neiman Marcus Group, claimed he was lured away in violation of his contract. Neiman Marcus, part of General Cinema Corp. in suburban Newton, said it filed the suit in state court in Dallas, Texas, where the group's Neiman Marcus Division is based. Named as defendants are Federated Department Stores Inc., Allied Stores Corp. and Canadian property company Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which provided a $250 million cash infusion last year to Campeau Corp., the Toronto-based owner of Allied and Federated. Neiman Marcus Group accused the defendants of ``tortious interference'' in enticing Allen Questrom to become the chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied, which filed for bankruptcy protection Jan. 15. Questrom was hired this month to oversee the troubled retail chains. But in a statement, Neiman Marcus said the defendants pursued him for the new position ``although they knew or should have known that Mr. Questrom had a valid employment contract which obligated him to serve as head of the Neiman Marcus Division until September 1991.'' The retailers, based in Cincinnati, declined to comment on the suit. The Neiman Marcus Group consists of three operating units: Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Contempo Casuals.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Industry Criticizes Proposed Supercomputer Definition
DOC.TEXT: Suggested government regulations defining supercomputers are too broad and would handcuff U.S. manufacturers, industry officials said Monday as the Department of Commerce began public hearings on its proposals. Although conceding there is a national interest in strict controls over the biggest and fastest computers, experts said the suggested definition of a ``supercomputer'' is so broad it could include some personal computers within a few months. ``We have to make sure that we're controlling supercomputers and not everything else in the world,'' said Terry Rock, a vice president of Convex Computer Corp., a Richardson-based manufacturer of so-called ``mini-supercomputers.'' The Commerce Department has proposed defining a supercomputer as a machine with a total peak performance of 100 million floating-point operations per second, a measure of the speed with which machines add, subtract, multiply or divide very large numbers. The rules would require an export permit for machines with a performance of 100 Mflops or greater. Machines with a capacity of 150 Mflops and 300 Mflops could only be sold to 22 U.S. allies and even then under strict guidelines, including certification of security and access limitations. The industry is concerned that the proposed regulation, written in consultation with the Department of Defense, will hamper its ability to compete with computer makers internationally. ``It's obviously of great importance that we balance the requirements of security with a minimum negative impact on competition,'' said Stanley Sienkiewicz, the Commerce Department associate deputy undersecretary who conducted Monday's hearing in Dallas. ``Setting a 100 Mflops threshold for supercomputers today will soon make it very difficult for both U.S. computer and semiconductor manufacturers to effectively compete in the world market,'' said Murray Goldman, head of the microprocessor group at Motorola Inc., the No. 1 U.S. computer chip manufacturer. D.J. Thompson, a Dallas-based industry consultant, said a better definition would be a machine with a 500 Mflop to 600 Mflop rating. ``This sort of system would have particular usefulness in the known `strategic' applications, for instance, code-breaking, fluid flow calculations, (anti-submarine warfare) signal processing and the like,'' Thompson said. ``If one is truly speaking of `supercomputers' as understood by the industry, the security controls are not at all onerous,'' he said. ``A supercomputer is an expensive and delicate piece of capital equipment and physical access to it and its use would certainly be controlled and in a very strict way.'' Industry officials also complained Monday about the pace of the regulation-making, noting that rapid technology advances could make the rules unrealistic almost before they take effect. ``Given the current performance trend for microprocessors, you will soon need a 1,000 Mflops definition for a supercomputer, not the 100 to 300 range you are currently evaluating,'' said Motorola's Goldman. ``By the late 90s, we will see such systems common on engineers' desks.'' Commerce officials indicated they were sympathetic to the industry's concerns, and hoped the public hearings will provide evidence to help overcome Defense Department concerns about the low-range computers. Other hearings are scheduled for Wednesday in Santa Clara, Calif., the heart of the Silicon Valley; Boston, another high-tech center, on Friday; and Feb. 19 in Minneapolis, home of Cray Research Inc., the U.S. leader in supercomputers. The information gathered at the hearings will be reviewed by the Commerce and Defense departments, and it will be several months before a final regulation is prepared.

DOC.HEAD: Fruit and Vegetable Industry Pushing Food Safety Theme
DOC.TEXT:
Reacting to last year's apple chemical fear and the Chilean fruit cyanide scare, the nation's fruit and vegetable suppliers and buyers opened their convention Monday with a predictable theme: produce safety. ``If it is an area of concern by the consumer, we have to reassure them,'' said Jim Halloran, spokesman for the Chilean Winter Fruit Association. His organization's members are among more than 7,500 attending the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association's annual convention, where the food safety question seeped into almost every presentation. Association spokesman John McClung said produce safety is the biggest issue at the group's 86th convention, but food safety has been a concern for years. ``I am always amazed about the resiliency of the food safety issue in the public mind,'' said McClung, emphasizing that though specific food safety concerns wane, the overall question remains. ``The next issue to come along always attracts attention.'' Roger Blobaum, director of Americans for Safe Food, a project of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said he believes the fruit and vegetable industry is moving away from use of chemicals and pesticides. ``There's a considerable amount of consumer interest and pressure to reduce pesticide residue,'' Blobaum said Monday in a telephone interview. ``We're encouraged by a lot of things that we see.'' He said his Washington-based organization has worked with the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association and similar groups to promote food safety. The fruit and vegetable association has helped form the non-profit Center for Produce Quality to spread its message that produce is safe, McClung said. The entire produce industry in the United States represents about $60 billion a year, although that includes retail and several levels of wholesale sales, McClung said. About 30 percent of produce is imported. In a speech to the produce association, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said he said he was concerned that food safety laws may be affected by emotion rather than science. Last winter, a widely publicized consumer report linked the chemical Alar to a long-term health threat. Alar is the trade name for a spray that keeps apples red and fresh longer. On the heels of that controversy, traces of cyanide were found in two grapes from Chile. The Food and Drug Administration ordered Chilean fruit held at ports where it was entering the United States, and FDA officials urged stores to remove the fruit from their shelves. No other tainted fruit was found. However, millions of dollars worth of produce went bad while it was held for the federal inspections. Produce industry officials say they'll bounce back despite last year's setbacks. Chilean fruit, which also includes nectarines, peaches and plums, undergoes the same type of inspections domestically grown fruit does, Halloran said. ``It's kept under rather rigid quality control from the time it's picked to the time it makes it to the supermarkets,'' he said. ``They (Chilean growers) are very concerned, and they're not going to do anything ... to jeopardize the quality.'' Grapes constitute about 70 percent of the fruit Chile exports, and virtually all of the fresh grapes sold in the United States during the winter months are from Chile.
Another glitch in 1989 came during the U.S. military invasion in Panama in December. Closing of the Panama Canal forced some ships to wait several days before getting through. But Halloran said while there was a slight delay in getting produce to market, fruit on the refrigerated ships wasn't damaged. The convention ends Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Investor to Buy 9.6 Percent of Blue Arrow
DOC.TEXT: A large U.S. investor reportedly has agreed to buy 9.2 percent of Blue Arrow PLC for $96.7 million to become the biggest shareholder in the British company, whose chief asset is the temporary employment agency Manpower Inc. Blue Arrow Chairman Mitchell Fromstein said he was delighted by the investor's decision to purchase the shares from NatWest Investment Bank, the British bank that has owned them since 1987. The investor was not identified, but The Milwaukee Journal described it in its Monday editions as a major insurance company, pension fund or private investment group. Manpower is based in suburban Milwaukee. ``It's a marvelous late chapter in the story,'' Fromstein said, adding the purchase would increase U.S. ownership of Blue Arrow to more than 75 percent. ``It removes an overhang from the market that's been there for two years.'' Fromstein has proposed reincorporating Blue Arrow in the United States. He said the identity of the U.S. buyer would be announced when the transaction was completed on Wednesday. NatWest will take an $88.7 million loss on the stock sale, the Journal reported. The disclosure in 1988 that NatWest had owned the shares for a year jolted Britain's financial community because British regulations require public disclosure when anyone owns 5 percent or more of a public company. As a result, the bank's top executives were dismissed, and criminal charges eventually were filed against 10 executives of the bank and a brokerage firm. The cases have yet to go to trial. NatWest acquired the shares through its investment banking subsidiary, County NatWest, which underwrote an offering of new stock to finance Blue Arrow's $1.3 billion acquisition of Manpower. County NatWest wasn't able to sell all the shares, however, and was forced to keep 66.7 million shares itself, or a 9.2 stake. The disclosure of the NatWest stake not only rocked the bank but also helped erode confidence in former Blue Arrow Chairman Tony Berry, who was ousted last year by Fromstein, the former president of Manpower.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Told Eastern Europe Should Give Priority to Changes in Finance
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe governments attempting to move away from communism should seek to stabilize their budgets, inflation and exchange rates before dealing with problems of trade, industry and labor, a banking group advised Monday. Nevertheless, the other problems also have to be tackled soon, said a report of the Institute of International Finance, an association of major banks throughout the world. ``The problem of successfully liberalizing a distorted economy can be likened to the problem of teaching a baby elephant to stand up,'' it said. ``The order in which it straightens its legs is important only to the extent that it influences the elephant's ability to straighten them at all.'' Titled ``Financial Sector Reform: Its Role in Growth and Development,'' the study is based on the experience of Chile, Greece, Malaysia, New Zealand and Tunisia. It said detailed priorities should vary from place to place. In some Third World countries, such as Malaysia, the study found the main task was to build institutions where few or none existed, to develop skilled people and to build the basis for a modern economy. Most heavily indebted Latin American countries had followed misguided policies for many years, the study said, adding that at various times countries such as New Zealand, Tunisia, Greece and Chile have made similar mistakes. The priorities listed by the study included: _ getting control and stabilizing taxation, government borrowing and spending, credit and prices; _ decentralizing decisions, to get them out of the hands of bureaucrasts and politicians and giving more authority to people with information and incentives; _ developing a situation for healthy markets so that prices reflect cost and scarcity, giving people the incentive to put their money into useful investments; _ adopting an exchange rate that reflects actual value on the market, getting rid of taxes on exports, high duties on imports and preference for state-owned business; _ reorganizing state-owned business. The report warned that delay in financial changes may lead to high inflation and instability in other parts of the economy. ``These issues are particularly important to the design of programs in Central and Eastern Europe,'' said Horst Schulmann, managing director of the institute. Pushing financial changes, including control of the government budget and convertibility of local currencies into hard money, also is the priority for Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard University professor who is advising Poland and Yugoslavia. Sachs said last week that Poland is already beginning to see results in lower food prices. ``The Yugoslavs have also introduced full convertibility of the dinar as of Jan. 1, backed by billions of dollars of foreign exchange reserves,'' he told a business conference last week. ``The currency is perfectly stable, fixed against the Deutschemark (the West German currency). I think it's a safer bet than the dollar in the next few months because they are committed and will be able to achieve stability.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Statement Embraces Principle of Private Property
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thrughout to UPDATE with further details of platform, quotes; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party embraced the principle of private property Monday in a radical rejection of some of the fundamentals of Marxism and Soviet socialism. ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union believes the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development,'' the party's new platform says. The platform was approved Wednesday by the party's policy-making Central Committee but not published in final form until Monday. It represents Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's boldest break with communist orthodoxy and contradicts public statements he made just months ago. The platform says the party took into account the new hunger of Soviet citizens for democracy and reform, as expressed by mass rallies and local political organizing all over the country. The document also says the Communist Party supports: _ ``Protection of a citizen's personality and honor, the immunity of his home and property, the secrecy of correspondence.'' _ Citizen ``participation in running the affairs of society and the state, freedom of speech, the press, meetings and demonstrations and the formation of public organizations.'' _ ``Man's free self-determination in the spiritual sphere, the freedom of conscience and religion.'' _ A stronger presidency that would further erode the power of the party in favor of the government. Party officials said last week they would would give up their constitutional monopoly on power. Soviet laws long have promised wide political freedoms, but the Communist Party has dominated every aspect of life and has been intolerant of any challenge. It was in economics, the foundation of Marxist theory, that the party made its strongest break with both its ideological heritage and decades of Soviet practice. Marxist theory holds that factories and other means of producing goods must be owned by the state rather than individuals because private ownership inevitably results in one person exploiting the labor of another. The platform bowed to Marxism by also proclaiming that any form of property must prevent man's alienation from production or exploitation, but it did not define either term. Communists intend to reform the top-heavy Soviet system, in serious economic straits, into a ``planned-market economy based on a diversity of property forms, competition between independent manufacturers, a developed financial system and on the powerful stimuli of personal and collective interest,'' said the platform, published by the Tass news agency. It said state-owned property should be turned over to worker control through leasing, contracts, joint-stock holdings and other methods.

DOC.HEAD: Vestron Receives Merger Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Vestron Inc., a film and video company whose credits include ``Dirty Dancing'' and ``Hamburger Hill,'' announced Monday it has received a merger proposal from a party it didn't identify. In a short statement, the Stamford-based company said it was evaluating the proposal. The company said it has been meeting with several parties regarding the merger or sale of the company or its businesses. J. Garrett Blowers, a company spokesman, did not immediately return a telephone call Monday night to his office in New York seeking comment. Vestron announced June 29 that it was undergoing restructuring that involved the layoffs of 140 employess. The restructuring included eliminating its theatrical distribution activities and substantially reducing its feature film productions. The restructuring followed Security Pacific National Bank's termination of a six-year, $100 million credit line in October 1988, the company said. Vestron officials, who said the reasons for the termination were never made clear, filed suit Aug. 16 charging Security Pacific with breach of contract. Vestron Pictures was launched in January 1986 as an offshoot of Vestron Video, at the time the country's largest independent video cassette distributor. Among the 8-year-old company's completed or near-finished films are ``Little Monsters,'' starring Fred Savage; ``Fear'' with Ally Sheedy; and ``Blue Steel'' with Jamie Lee Curtis. Vestron's recent releases include ``Earth Girls Are Easy,'' ``The Rainbow,'' ``Wonderland,'' and ``Far From Home.''

DOC.HEAD: Billionaire Developer And Former Czech Olympic Skier Separated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to RECAST lead, CORRECT that Trumps married 13 years, sted 12, UPDATE with statements from both lawyers, edit to conform; picks up 12th graf, `In a restaurant ...'
DOC.TEXT: The juiciest gossip Monday in the Big Apple was the separation of Ivana and Donald Trump, the billionaire developer who had the foresight to perfect the art of the prenuptial deal. If the split sticks after 13 years of marriage, the prenuptial agreement decrees that Ivana gets $25 million, plus the couple's Greenwich, Conn., mansion and custody of the three children, according to columnist Liz Smith, who broke the story in Sunday's Daily News. The gossip mill was kept spinning by battling tabloids and TV stations that can't get enough of the tuxedoed Trump and the bejeweled, begowned, blond Ivana, fixtures on the social circuit. Statements from the Trumps did nothing to slow the mill. Her attorney, Michael Kennedy, issued a release Monday saying: ``We do not consider the so-called prenuptial agreement to be serious. It will have no relevance to a court because it is unconscionable and fraudulent.'' Kennedy also called Ivana ``a family woman. Her marriage and her family have always been the most important things in her life. Mr. Trump has now left her and the children. While one hopes for a reconciliation, my mandate, at this time, is to document the 13 years of marriage and partnership in the Trump holdings.'' In response, a spokesman for Trump released this statement: ``The prenuptial agreement signed by Donald and Ivana Trump is a long and detailed document which covers all aspects and is 100 percent enforceable in courts of law. The agreement they have was updated approximately two years ago. Prior to that, this agreement has been updated on numerous other occasions throughout the years. In virtually every instance marital agreements have been upheld by the courts.'' ``The Donald,'' as Ivana affectionately called him in happier times, keeps everything else _ a business and real estate empire worth somewhere from $1.7 billion to $4 billion, depending on who's counting. Trump was back in town Monday after witnessing another shocker _ James ``Buster'' Douglas' knockout of boxing champ Mike Tyson in Tokyo. According to Smith, Trump's comment on that debacle was: ``He fought a bad fight and the other guy fought a brilliant fight.'' But the author of the best-selling ``The Art of the Deal'' wasn't making himself available for comment, spokesmen said, leaving Smith's reports of jet- and car-phone conversations as the latest word. ``It is better for Ivana and me to separate at this time,'' Trump told the columnist. ``But I am leaving because I want to leave. ``Ivana is a wonderful woman and a very good woman and I like her. We might even get back together. I can't say we won't. Who knows what could happen? ``And as for those other women I have been linked with, well, I want to say that we are all just friends and that's as far as it goes.'' Other women? The New York Post plastered the faces of actresses Catherine Oxenberg and Marla Maples and skater Peggy Fleming across the top of a page. Not that anyone is on the record claiming a romance, but the ``Aspen Argument'' was trotted out as evidence by all three tabloids _ the News, Post and New York Newsday. The New York Times devoted three paragraphs to the story Monday. In a restaurant in that Colorado ski spa over the holidays, Ivana reportedly warned Maples, star of a movie called ``Maximum Overdrive,'' to stay away from ``the Donald.'' The Trumps were then seen arguing on the slopes. Trump, 43, has been seen all over town in past weeks with a half-naked woman _ on the cover of Playboy magazine, that is. Inside, he says he enjoys flirting, but when asked if marriage is monogamous to him, he replies: ``I don't have to answer that. I never speak about my wife. ... My marriage is and should be a personal thing.'' Not anymore it isn't. The Post, citing an unidentified confidante, quoted Trump as saying: ``I like Ivana, but we've grown apart. ``Her level of arrogance has grown steadily worse in recent years. The bottom line is I don't want to create another Leona Helmsley.'' Leona is the self-described hotel queen recently convicted of tax evasion; at her trial, former employees described her as ill-tempered and demanding. Trump gave his wife the job of renovating the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan after running Trump Castle in Atlantic City, N.J. ``I have told Ivana, `Whatever Leona would do, do the opposite. Be nice to everybody.' And she is nice, anyway,'' Trump told Playboy. Ivana, a former Czechoslovakian ski racer and sometime model who turns 41 next week, ducked photographers Sunday night outside the Trump Tower, where the couple has a three-floor penthouse. Trump moved out Sunday night, the Post reported. Despite the headlines and the hiding out, The Trump Organization's publicity machine kept grinding away. Monday's release was about how Trump saved a struggling East Harlem candy maker by ordering 75,000 pieces of chocolate to place on pillows at the Trump Plaza Hotel in Atlantic City. The press release headline: ``Trump Creates a Sweet Valentine Dream.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Statement Embraces Principle of Private Property
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UDPATE with further details of platform, background on party's traditional policies; no pickup. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party embraced the principle of private property Monday in a radical rejection of some of the fundamentals of Marxism and Soviet socialism. ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union believes the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development,'' the party's new platform says. The platform was approved Wednesday by the party's policy-making Central Committee but not published in final form until Monday. It represents Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's boldest break with communist orthodoxy and contradicts public statements he made just months ago. The platform did not make clear in what sense the party still considers itself to be Communist, but pays homage to the creative spirit of Marxism and the philosphy's humanistic outlook of opposing religion and emphasizing man's daily existence. It also points with pride to the concepts of pensions, free education and medical care and other social benefits that it says the Soviet system pioneered. In deciding on sweeping changes, however, the platform says the party took into account the new hunger of Soviet citizens for democracy and reform, as expressed by mass rallies and local political organizing all over the country. The document also says the Communist Party supports: _ ``Protection of a citizen's personality and honor, the immunity of his home and property, the secrecy of correspondence.'' _ Citizen ``participation in running the affairs of society and the state, freedom of speech, the press, meetings and demonstrations and the formation of public organizations.'' _ ``Man's free self-determination in the spiritual sphere, the freedom of conscience and religion.'' _ A stronger presidency that would further erode the power of the party in favor of the government. Party officials said last week they would would give up their constitutional monopoly on power. Soviet laws long have promised wide political freedoms, but the Communist Party has dominated every aspect of life and has been intolerant of any challenge. In a departure from one of the Marxist slogans once used to justify rule by terror and liquidation of the middle class, the party dismissed the concept of a dictatorship of the proletariat, saying: ``The rule-of-law state of the whole people has no room for dictatorship by any class.'' It was in economics, the foundation of Marxist theory, that the party made its strongest break with both its ideological heritage and decades of Soviet practice. Marxist theory holds that factories and other means of producing goods must be owned by the state rather than individuals because private ownership inevitably results in one person exploiting the labor of another. The platform bowed to Marxism by also proclaiming that any form of property must prevent man's alienation from production or exploitation. Communists intend to reform the top-heavy Soviet system, in serious economic straits, into a ``planned-market economy based on a diversity of property forms, competition between independent manufacturers, a developed financial system and on the powerful stimuli of personal and collective interest,'' the platform said. Central planning has left the Soviet Union chronically unable to provide its people with adequate food, housing or consumer goods, and the platform said the system had been ``characterized by monopoly, lack of initiative, wastefulness, mismanagement and disregard for consumers interests.'' The platform also said state-owned property should be turned over to worker control through leasing, contracts, joint-stock holdings and other methods. Private property could face stiff resistance in many parts of the country, where state schools have preached its evils for generations. Sociologist Tatyana Zaslavskaya told Tass last week that while 80 percent of the population of Latvia, a small Baltic republic, approve of private property, the attitude was exactly the opposite in many other areas. The young Soviet state under Lenin's leadership confiscated most private property after the 1917 revolution, and Stalin's drive to strip peasants of their land through collectivization in the 1930s took millions of lives through famine, deportation and summary execution. The platform also called for restructuring heavily subsidized state prices as an indispensable prerequisite to the market's regulation of the economy. Subsidies have kept many prices artificially low. A pound of sugar costs 70 cents, a loaf of bread 33 cents and a bus ride and most daily newspapers a few pennies apiece. The system has kept many inefficient industries afloat and has meant there is rarely any direct relationship between the cost of manufacture and retail prices. The platform introduces the concept of competition _ once taboo among Communist ideologists _ as a necessary tool for regulating prices and ensuring availability of goods and services. It calls for legislation to break up state monopolies, trade, credit services and insurance businesses to permit competitive consumer services. As recently as last November, Gorbachev stated firm opposition to permitting Soviet citizens to hold private property. Tass said at the time he told a student assembly he remained committed to the Communist Manifesto, which calls for state ownership of all means of production to ensure that workers get full value for their effort without factory owners taking a share as profit. The Manifesto is the blueprint for communism written in 1848 by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. At that time he also rejected calls for allowing political parties other than the ruling Communist Party, although he left open the possibility the constitution might eventually be changed to permit a multiparty system. Tass quoted him as saying there was ``no other political force capable of both renewing the bodies of Soviet power that were gaining strength and consolidating society.''

DOC.HEAD: Traders Association Predicts Worst Trade Deficit in Nine Years
DOC.TEXT: South Korea will run a trade deficit of $3.3 billion this year, the worst in nine years, the Korea Foreign Trade Association predicted Tuesday. The figure compared with a government projected deficit of $2 billion. Both figures were on a customs clearance basis. The national traders group expected $66.3 billion in exports this year, up 6.4 percent from $62.3 billion in 1989, while predicting $69.6 billion in imports, up 13.5 percent from $61.3 billion in 1989. The government projected $66 billion in exports and $68 billion in imports for 1990. Association officials said exports are expected to recover somewhat in the second quarter of this year but the growth is likely to be far outpaced by surging imports. After years of substantial trade deficits, Korea scored its first annual trade surplus in 1986, amounting to $3.1 billion. The country's trade surplus rose to a record $8.8 billion in 1988 but plunged to $1 billion in 1989 because of the loss of export competitiveness, affected by the Korean currency's appreciation, steep wage hikes and labor unrest in the past three years. The association said its projection was based on assumption that the Korean currency will be devalued by 5.6 percent during this year to 720 won to the dollar, accompanied by moderate wage hikes and few labor disputes. The group called on the government to take substantial steps to reinvigorate exports. The government so far has refused to take any drastic measures on exchange rates and bank loan interest rates for fear of high inflation and instead has called for structural reform of Korean industries.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Will Make Offer on Monetary Union to East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The West German government will make an official offer Tuesday to East Germany to form a monetary union of the two countries, diplomats of the European Community said Monday. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel revealed the move at a meeting of finance ministers of the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, according to officials. No details of the plan were released. East German Premier Hans Modrow was scheduled to travel to Bonn to meet with West German officials on Tuesday and Wednesday. Community officials had anxiously awaited Waigel's remarks because of concern about the effect of a monetary union of the two Germanys on the rest of Western Europe, which is planning its own monetary reform as part of its plans to remove trade barriers by 1992. A German monetary union no doubt would involve circulation of West Germany's strong mark currency in the East. Communist East Germany has seen its centrally planned economy deteriorate rapidly since the border between the two countries opened late last year. Thousands of East Germans have poured into their western neighbor. ``I fully understand Bonn's position ... to accelerate its economic and monetary (union) with East Germany,'' said Dutch Finance Minister Wim Kok. ``But Brussels must be the place where we help determine Germany's position on that.'' ``I have full confidence in the fact that German-German economic and monetary integration will be firmly anchored in wider European consultations,'' he told reporters. ``I find that crucial.'' West Germany's economy, based on a free-market system, is the most powerful in the European Community. Many of the West European currencies are closely tied to the West German mark, and the EC countries have been working on plans to form a common currency for their members. Irish Finance Minister Albert Reynolds said Waigel ``indicated the German government will make an offer to (East Germany) tomorrow on closer integration for monetary union.'' Ireland currently holds the community's rotating six-month presidency. He said Waigel promised to keep the community ``fully informed of developments.'' A diplomatic source, demanding anonymity, said Jacques Delors, president of the community's executive body, raised questions about how the German monetary union would affect the trading bloc's monetary system. An internal report by the European Commission, the executive body, said that immediate monetary union would create a strong confidence factor. But it also cautioned that a quick marriage would ``irrevocably'' link West Germany to East Germany. ``Any turbulences and setbacks in (East Germany) would be transmitted to the (West German) economy and thereby also to the community,'' said the study. ``These turbulences and frictions seem, however, almost unavoidable,'' it said. ``It should not be forgotten that almost the whole (East German) population has had no direct experience with democracy and a market economy.'' Waigel told German reporters that he delivered a message to the finance ministers from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who said his country remains committed to the community's campaign to form an economic and monetary union. Kohl also said the Bonn government would discuss its unity plans with all community institutions. Waigel said no date was mentioned for a German monetary union because it depended on discussions this week with Modrow and the outcome of the March 18 elections in East Germany. He also noted the East German economy is one-tenth the size of West Germany's. ``The dimension of the integration issue should not be exaggerated,'' he said. ``I tried to convince my colleagues that the challenge can be met by West Germany if one takes a mid-term view, that is, from five to 10 years,'' he told reporters.
